5 reviews 5 reviews
'A Real Gem'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012 NEW

We arrived late on Friday evening for a quick getaway. The lobby was lovely and the staff friendly and professional. Our room was nicely appointed and comfy. We were delighted with the amenities.

Morning coffee and early evening wine are complimentary. Many guests gathered at the end of the day to socialize and enjoy a glass of wine.

This hotel is pet friendly and the dogs that we encountered were really well behaved.

Located right off of Times Square, the location was perfect for dining and the theater. We parked our car and walked all weekend.

We are planning to make this an annual event.
Less

'Midtown Oasis'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW

We loved this hotel! It has a nice "small hotel" feel in a large city. The location is great - right off Times Square, close to Rockefeller Center. Problem with this review?
Tom R
Tyngsboro, Massachusetts
1 review
'The Muse & Kimpton'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW

The Muse is our second Kimpton Hotel, the other being the Nine Zero in Boston. I hear so many people say that once they've had the Kimpton experience, they'll seek out Kimptons wherever they go. We're certain to do that ourselves.

Today's online NYTimes has an article about innovations. Here's one they call "The Kindness Hack."

"Researchers at Wharton, Yale and Harvard have figured out how to make employees feel less pressed for time: force them to help others. According to a recent study, giving workers menial tasks or, surprisingly, longer breaks actually leads them to believe that they have less time, while having them write to a sick child, for instance, makes them feel more in control and 'willing to commit to future engagements despite their busy schedules.' The idea is that completing an altruistic task increases your sense of productivity, which in turn boosts your confidence about finishing everything else you need to do."

While 'force' seems antithetic to 'altruistic', it seems to us that The Muse selects for its staff people for whom menial tasks and long breaks aren't what they came for. Everyone we met, from curbside to 9th floor housekeeping, seemed to have that urge to care, eager to go out of their way to make our day a little better, even if just by sharing a smile. More than just hiring for that quality, they're given license to let it show. It does. It can't be faked, of course, nor even taught. It's all natural, in delightfully unpretentious, low-key ways. Good people being themselves. It's very real.

Hotels can't screen guests for altruism. Doubtless The Muse staff serve some difficult or impossible people. It's then more to the staff's credit that they approach all of us as if sure we will be worthwhile. Maybe that ever-fresh optimism makes us try hard not to disappoint them. We enjoyed the lobby wine & social hour with at least five groups in two nights, from near and far, tourists and business people, from teens to senior citizens like ourselves. I'm certain they'd all agree that being at Kimpton brings out the best in us, too.

Who wouldn't go back for more of that?
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Tom R about The Muse Hotel New York - a Kimpton Hotel

49 reviews 49 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
8 helpful votes 8 helpful votes
'Kimpton classic'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012 NEW

This hotel is a typical Kimpton classic, and by typical, I only mean good things. I have always been happy with Kimpton hotels. I like their funky decor and good service.

As is very typical of New York hotels, the rooms are small. The hotel should have gone with furniture that fit the room a bit better, but that is the fun of New York hotels. The bed was superior - to the point of I am seriously considering buying their exclusive Sealy mattress.

Service was excellent. The hotel gives a nice happy hour of very average wine. If the wine was a bit better, I would have given this hotel a 'Excellent' rating rather than just 'Very Good'.

As a 'MUST' - check out their lobby bathrooms. Never seen anything like it.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

36 helpful votes 36 helpful votes
'Beautiful hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

We saw a great deal through SniqueAway and decided to take advantage of it. We went with a King Premier room. This is a beautiful boutique hotel, very close to Times Square. The bell staff and front desk staff were extremely friendly and accommodating. This is a pet-friendly hotel, and there were a couple of nice doggies asleep behind the front desk. In addition, there was a "welcome" bowl of dog food in the front entryway, awaiting some canine guests who were due to arrive. Our room was gorgeous - exactly as pictured on their website, and quite large for a hotel room in New York City. The furnishings are modern, everything very clean, the king bed nice and comfy. The shower was powerful! Really powerful! They had free WiFi in the room, which was a nice plus. There was also the all-important safe for storing valuables that we didn't want to take with us. The only thing missing was a coffee maker, but we requested one, and had one brought to our room within minutes. The hotel location was excellent - just a minute's walk to Times Square. And 2 blocks down W. 46th Street is "Restaurant Row," a wonderful area with a vast variety of restaurants. All in all, a lovely hotel in a great area. Highly recommended.
Less

'Girls Weekend'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

I had booked this hotel for a girlfriend's weekend getaway and it was perfect. From being greeted at the door by name when we arrived and whenever we left and came back to the hotel (impressive!) to the friendly check in at the front desk and the room/hotel staff being accommodating with bringing us ice to chill wine, wine glasses, extra anything we needed to make our stay more comfortable - they were on top of it all. The room was more than comfortable, the beds were great, and the hotel was so quiet. This is one of my favorite hotels in NYC and I will try to stay here anytime I am back in the city.

'Ideal spot for visiting NY'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW

Our family of two moms and two young daughters stayed here for 4 nights in April. The room was small, even though it is advertised as a studio, and we did not use the kitchen. When the sofa bed was pulled out, there was no room to walk around. Still, it was what we expected and we had no intention of staying in the room. It was easy to get around. The best part is the proximity to Bryant Park (one of the loveliest in the city).

Breakfast was standard Residence Inn fare. The coffee could have been better.

Our room had a nice view of the Empire State Building. The room was quiet.

The housecleaning staff was nice. One woman found out our girls liked smart food and she brought extras.
Less

Salman_QLD
Queensland
Senior Contributor
30 reviews 30 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
19 helpful votes 19 helpful votes
'2nd & 3rd Visit'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

We stayed at the Residence Inn twice over the space of two weeks. Once was during the week and once included the weekend.

The main drawcard for us in staying at Resi Inns is the free wifi and the free breakfast. During the week both worked well on the weekend it all went pear shaped.

We went down to breakfast on the Saturday about 30 mins before closing time and there was no food left. Staff members were actually taking away the empty bins. Staff members stationed at the elevators were less than apologetic when we notified them that there was no food available. It wasn't even closing time!

The elevators are also extremely slow on the weekends. We waited about 20 minutes on the Saturday to get back to our rooms following the horrible breakfast experience.

Surely the hotel has by now noticed the many reviews saying the same thing about the breakfasts. Couldn't you open up a conference room or something with a second buffet on the weekends?

Will we be back? Yes, but only if we are staying during the week.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'Awesome Location'

person found this review helpful

Loved the location of the hotel. Walking distance to all the popular attractions in NYC. The full breakfast was delicious, (not continental) full breakfast. The employees has great customer service as well. This hotel has a really nice bar on the third floor, which we loved. We watched the NBA playoff games each night at the bar. But, I wouldn't stay here again, due to the fact, the rooms are outdated, small flat screen T.V. The bathroom was horrible, you couldn't closed the door to the bathroom properly, you have to go in and turn around to close the door, not very functional. The hotel should add a modern touch to the rooms, new bedding, carpet, larger television, and maybe brighter paint on the wall.

See 8 more reviews by OntarioJellybean for New York City
OntarioJellybean
Ontario
Contributor
18 reviews 18 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
14 helpful votes 14 helpful votes
'better than I expected'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The Residence Inn located at 6 and 38 is staffed by a very pleasant and help group of employees.
We were there during Memorial Day weekend and they had opened up meeting rooms for the high volume of breakfast crowd. Breakfast was standard sausage rounds, scrambled eggs, pancakes and waffles with all the fixings. Soy milk available on request. Everything kept clean and tables cleared regularly.
Nightly room messages warned us of the elevator traffic between 9-10. We noticed that people on the low teens and down were often faced with full elevators with no ability to board.
The room truly has a weird design. It was big and roomy, but bathroom felt like a closet with a huge door that opened into the cramped space. While there was a mirror outside - it was very dark and not of any real use to alleviate sink traffic. Certainly this is a design flaw and not the fault of the current employees. However, I'm surprised at the recent renovations that didn't consider the needs of two bed visitors.
The rooms were cleaned well. The street sounds were not noticable (we were on floor 28). The fully stocked kitchen was a useful bonus.
The location is within walking distance of Time Square and close to a subway station at Bryant Park. Took us only 12 minutes for a private car to take us to LGA airport on Monday aft. - but I guess traffic was good.
Overall a positive experience.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

bmorechris
Ellicott City, Maryland
Senior Contributor
27 reviews 27 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
20 helpful votes 20 helpful votes
'Good Stay Again at the Residence Inn'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

This is the second time we have stayed at this hotel, first was winter a few years ago and we had another good experience this time as we did then. The location is excellent for tourists, just 5 min from Times square (but far enough away from the crush of people there), 15 min walk from Central Park, one street over from 5th Ave, it certainly puts you close to everything in Midtown. Subways are convenient and we always saw a cab out front. The queen room was a good size and included a couch and coffee table, kitchenette with refrigerator w/ freezer and ice maker, microwave, kitchen sink and plates/glasses/pots/etc, and a counter with 2 stools. Bathroom was small but but nice. Always had hot water on demand, showerhead was not the strongest but got the job done. The bed was comfy, and quite soft (we like a soft bed).

All the staff were very friendly and accommodating. We arrived well before check-in and they held our bags for us and did the same as we checked out before it was time to catch our train. Check-in and check-out was efficient and done with a smile.

As mentioned in other reviews, breakfast was busy, but we had a message left on our phone alerting us that it was a holiday weekend and to expect the breakfast room to be very busy, especially around 9 am. We heeded this advice and got down for breakfast at 8 am both days of our stay and had no line and no problem finding a place to sit. The breakfast selection was very good and the food quality was good too (not gourmet, but not advertised as such). They had a selection of cereals, oatmeal, dried fruits, milk, pastries and other sweet goods, hot foods including sausage patties, scrambled eggs, hash browns, french toast, waffles; whole fruit, cut fruits and yogurts in a salad bar and also bagels, breads, etc. We did hear from others that when they left the breakfast room around 9 am it was completely packed and had a long line. Since it was a holiday, there were a lot of families in the hotel, and my guess is that they were handling many more people than they usually do when they would typically have more business travelers. Someone in another review mentioned the trash was located right next to the plates for the buffet line, just wanted to say that it is on the other side of a wall and doubt it is an issue for most people.

Only real issue was the elevators. One morning after breakfast, we returned to the room and prepared to leave for the day, and we waited 5-10 min for an elevator down from the 8th floor. We ended up just taking the stairs, but if you were higher up this would be a less desirable option. One night we returned around 1030pm and there were about 20 people in line for the elevators. It looked as though only 1 elevator was coming to pick people up. One stayed at the 34th floor (top floor), another at the 18th floor, the third at the 3rd floor. We had to wait for two trips before we could get on the only one running people up from the lobby. I understand the logic of having elevators stationed on the higher floors so people trying to come down don't have to wait for one to come up from the lowest floor, but it still didn't seem to quite work that well. We did hear another guest say one of the elevators may have had an issue, but cannot confirm that to be true.

We felt we got a very good value as we were able to book the room with Marriott points only 3 days before our stay. We would likely stay here again if we come back to New York and the price is right.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 2 more reviews by bmorechris for New York City
Ask bmorechris about Residence Inn by Marriott Times Square New York

'Good value, nice hotel'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Stayed at this hotel over Memorial Day weekend. Used Marriott points. Room was nice, very good kitchen facilities in the room. Bathroom was small and water pressure in shower wasn't great. Great view from room of Empire State Building and skyline. Neighborhood ok, about four blocks from Times Square.
Pros: location, value, view, size of room, friendliness of staff;
Cons: small bathroom, free breakfast VERY crowded to the point is wasn't worth going to; elevators completely jammed up at breakfast time.
SUMMARY- good hotel experience. Will stay there again.

Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 2 more reviews by Michaelnwhite for New York City
Ask Michaelnwhite about Residence Inn by Marriott Times Square New York
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Ryan Cortese, Guest Relations Manager at Residence Inn by Marriott Times Square New York, responded to this review
May 29, 2012
Dear Michaelnwhite:

Thank you for reviewing my hotel on TripAdvisor. I'm glad you enjoyed your stay and found our staff friendly, location convenient, and rooms accommodating.

Our breakfast can become crowded on the weekends. Elevator delays are common on the weekends as well. I'm sorry for any inconvenience this may have caused. It seems most guests sit for breakfast around the same time and leave for the day shortly after. We try our best to educate guests on potential crowding so that they can plan accordingly. Its sounds like you saw the worst of it being a holiday weekend.

Overall, it sounds like you enjoyed your stay. I look forward to your future visit.

My best,

Ryan Cortese
Guest Relations Manager

Wolfgang_Frankfurt
Seoul, South Korea
Senior Contributor
41 reviews 41 reviews
Reviews in 18 cities Reviews in 18 cities
29 helpful votes 29 helpful votes
'Best location in Manhattan'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I visited New York after 13 years again and wanted to stay in a hotel close to all attractions. This hotel is going to be definitely my choice for my next visit to NYC. Here some details.

Room:
As usual in Residence Inn the room comes with a small kitchenette and a huge fridge to keep all your drinks. The room was quite big for a hotel in Manhattan. I liked the bathroom ameneties - usually you find these ones only in saloons. Free wireless internet was very fast!

Breakfast:
BF had a good variety of offer from pancake to croissants. But it was as the hotel was fully booked always crowded.

Location:
Located between the 6th Avenue and 39th street it is the best location. Very close to Times Square and the subway stations it is central to all your destinations in Manhattan.

Car parking:
I mad a mistake and came with a car, the valet parking costs 56$ a day! But I heard that this is usual in New York.

Price:
As I searched for price comparisons in Manhattan and found out that there is no room cheaper than 350$. Therefore the price was ok for Manhattan. If you want to stay cheaper than I recommend to stay in New Jersey that has good bus connections to the city.
Less

TravelTexan1
Nacogdoches, TX
Senior Contributor
31 reviews 31 reviews
Reviews in 18 cities Reviews in 18 cities
12 helpful votes 12 helpful votes
'Good location. Great for a long term stay.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 23, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

I was here for ten days, mostly on business that was spread out around the city. This is one of the smallest Residence Inn rooms I have been in, but it is large for a NY hotel room. My room on the 11th floor had a great view of the Empire State Building, but not all rooms would have that. The positives: 2 minute walk to Bryant Park/42nd street station, about five minutes to Times Square station, Good breakfast, Full sized frig, safe big enough for your laptop, comfy bed. Negatives: the curved rod on the shower made the bathroom even more crowded when the door was opened, during busy tmes you could wait up to 10-15 minutes for elevator, and the night snacks were minimal (had much more of a spread at other Residence Inns), and would have loved a small desk for my laptop instead of the kitchen bar. I stayed on a discounted promo, so I am not sure that I would pay full price for the room; however, I would stay here again if I could have that same rate. The concierge (Judy) was helpful with directions and arranging car pickups. There is a Pret a Manger on the corner across from the hotel for sandwiches and a small market next to the hotel on that side as well. Bryant Park is a great place for a little sunshine (when it is not raining) and it is about a half of a mile to Penn Station and to Grand Central as well.

    *

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask TravelTexan1 about Residence Inn by Marriott Times Square New York
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

May 29, 2012
Dear TravelTexan1:

Thank you for posting your review of my hotel on TripAdvisor. I'm glad to hear that we were able to meet your travel needs and you enjoyed our full complimentary breakfast and convenience location. I'll be sure to pass your kind words on to Judy as well.

For future reference, some of our rooms do have a lower desk, rather than the counter height table. You can always request one on your next visit. Thank you for posting a photo of the view from your window!

My best,

Ryan Cortese
Guest Relations Manager

nezzie
New York City
Senior Contributor
32 reviews 32 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
16 helpful votes 16 helpful votes
'A lovely B&B in Lenox - it deserves its' high ratings!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I spent Mother's Day weekend at this lovely B&B. We've been to Lenox 50 times at least over the years, and never stayed here. But we've stayed at many other Lenox B&B's so I think we have a good sense of comparison. We stayed in Room #1 in the main house. For those not used to old B&B's, this is an OLD house (think 18th c.) so don't expect the W Hotel. Rooms can be funky and ceilings low and bathrooms small. If you understand antique houses, you'll be happier. That being said, the bed was COMFORTABLE - something we never take forgranted anymore and have, in fact, stopped going to several B&B's because they don't understand that charm isn't everything - sleeping is important also! Both the terrific breakfast and the gorgeous grounds make this place heavenly. Walking into town is a delight. The innkeepers are helpful as can be and the chocolate chip cookies are lethal! Try it. You'll like it!

    Stayed May 2012, traveled as a couple
        3 of 5 stars Value
        5 of 5 stars Location
        5 of 5 stars Sleep Quality
        4 of 5 stars Rooms
        5 of 5 stars Cleanliness
        5 of 5 stars Service

ClarissaM
New York City, New York
Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews
Reviews in 12 cities Reviews in 12 cities
21 helpful votes 21 helpful votes
'Sweet Stay at the Garden Gables Inn'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 12, 2012
5
people found this review helpful

My husband and I stayed here in February. It's a wonderful inn, and Denise is the best innkeeper. She's friendly and welcoming and at the same time, gives you your space - and to top it off, she's an excellent chef! Because it was a long drive for us, I booked us the 'chef's table' at the Inn for our first night's dinner and I'm so happy I did, dinner was delicious! My husband had to refrain from licking his plate - and the dessert was a perfect sweet ending: homemade lemon pound cake with fresh whipped cream, lemon curd and berries.

I would absolutely stay here again. The only negatives during our stay were:

We stayed in a large room (#15) but the bathroom could use a little sprucing up. I assumed the 'whirlpool' tub would be a large tub but it's just a regular tub with whirlpool jets and the bathroom is so dark, I really didn't feel like soaking. It could use a little renovating.

Also my husband and I booked massages, and (unfortunately I can not remember the name of the man who was our massage therapist) but hands-down the WORST massage either of us has ever had! I get massages often, I was surprised that I wasn't told or asked upon booking if a male masseuse would be okay with me (kinda not) and when I was chatting with him, I asked "how long have you been doing massage" and he said 7 years. There's just no way this guy has been a professional massage therapist for 7 years. He used almost no pressure, even though I kept saying "you can use more pressure"; there was no skill or technique or type of style (swedish, shiatsu, etc) and I kept waiting for him to get started but in the end it was just a really annoying, disappointing experience - waste of time and money. My husband was equally underwhelmed with his massage. So just a head's up.

    Stayed January 2012, traveled as a couple
        3 of 5 stars Value
        4 of 5 stars Location
        4 of 5 stars Sleep Quality
        4 of 5 stars Rooms
        4 of 5 stars Cleanliness
        4 of 5 stars Service

rjmcs
New York City, New York
1 review
'Awesome New England Vibe'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 3, 2012

It doesn't get more classic New England than this spectacular B&B - a renovated nineteenth century farm with all the modern amenities you could want, on a country road nestled on the side of Lenox mountain and just a 15-minute walk to Tanglewood. The farmhouse is filled with an incredible collection of art, pottery, books and DVDs. While we stayed there this past weekend, a young couple were planning their wedding reception for the fall foliage season. Yes, there's plenty of room to do that in the huge converted barn that also serves as an exhibition space for a variety of talented artists represented by the innkeepers. Our room, the farmhouse and the entire property were perfectly maintained; the bed and pillows were the ultimate in comfort; and the innkeepers Tom and Suky Werman were ideal, low-key yet attentive, hosts. With a comprehensive breakfast selection that includes Tom's special-recipe 'tomlettes', this was flat-out the best B&B we've been to in the region. - Bob & Jane
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Bobsiej1
Bucks, UK
Contributor
20 reviews 20 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
22 helpful votes 22 helpful votes
'Wonderfully different'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 1, 2010

We stayed for 2 nights with our 2 children aged 10 and 12. Stonover is utterly wonderful - great location, if you are looking for peace & quiet yet a few minutes' drive from the town, with delightful walks on your doortstep. Traditional on the outside, contemporary/electic on the inside, impeccably clean and delightfully comfortable, with the atmosphere of a home and the style of a boutique hotel. We had Rock Cottage to ourselves - an ideal setup for a family - set slightly above the main house, overlooking the pond with ducks & chickens. The kids loved these and the wild turkeys wandering around - but not as much as they adored Tom & Suky's two Siamese cats! Breakfast was extensive & delicious, with lots of whole grains, granola, fresh fruit and Tom's goat's cheese omelettes, which are truly historic. The early evening tradition of wine & cheese made us feel very welcome, even though we were the only people staying at the time. We were rained in one afternoon and availed ourselves of Tom's huge range of DVDs. We were given plenty of recommendations for walks and nearby restaurants, too. We can highly recommend Stonover Farm to anyone looking for something out of the Berkshires ordinary and, even though it isn't cheap, it is definitely worth it.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Bobsiej1 about Stonover Farm Bed and Breakfast
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
FrequentFliers77
Hoboken, NJ
1 review
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Elegant Historic, Yet Modern B&B With Picturesque Grounds'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 9, 2009
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I were searching for a relaxing and luxurious place to spend the weekend in the Berkshires near a bit of hiking/walking and found it at Stonover Farm. Unlike other B&Bs, their website is an accurate representation of the grounds and the real thing is even better in person. We stayed at The Cottage and enjoyed every minute of it. Both the Cottage and the main house were very beautifully decorated, clean and well-maintained. The host couple is very pleasant to be around and the wine and cheese and breakfast were nicely done. It may be helpful to note that this review is from the perspective of a 32 year old (as opposed to an antiqueing B&B-goer) and we found that other young professional couples were also enjoying Stonover while we were there, which is a bit unusual in the general world of B&Bs and makes this place all the more wonderful.
Less

'Awesome New England Vibe'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 3, 2012

It doesn't get more classic New England than this spectacular B&B - a renovated nineteenth century farm with all the modern amenities you could want, on a country road nestled on the side of Lenox mountain and just a 15-minute walk to Tanglewood. The farmhouse is filled with an incredible collection of art, pottery, books and DVDs. While we stayed there this past weekend, a young couple were planning their wedding reception for the fall foliage season. Yes, there's plenty of room to do that in the huge converted barn that also serves as an exhibition space for a variety of talented artists represented by the innkeepers. Our room, the farmhouse and the entire property were perfectly maintained; the bed and pillows were the ultimate in comfort; and the innkeepers Tom and Suky Werman were ideal, low-key yet attentive, hosts. With a comprehensive breakfast selection that includes Tom's special-recipe 'tomlettes', this was flat-out the best B&B we've been to in the region. - Bob & Jane
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask rjmcs about Stonover Farm Bed and Breakfast

Bobsiej1
Bucks, UK
Contributor
20 reviews 20 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
22 helpful votes 22 helpful votes
'Wonderfully different'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 1, 2010

We stayed for 2 nights with our 2 children aged 10 and 12. Stonover is utterly wonderful - great location, if you are looking for peace & quiet yet a few minutes' drive from the town, with delightful walks on your doortstep. Traditional on the outside, contemporary/electic on the inside, impeccably clean and delightfully comfortable, with the atmosphere of a home and the style of a boutique hotel. We had Rock Cottage to ourselves - an ideal setup for a family - set slightly above the main house, overlooking the pond with ducks & chickens. The kids loved these and the wild turkeys wandering around - but not as much as they adored Tom & Suky's two Siamese cats! Breakfast was extensive & delicious, with lots of whole grains, granola, fresh fruit and Tom's goat's cheese omelettes, which are truly historic. The early evening tradition of wine & cheese made us feel very welcome, even though we were the only people staying at the time. We were rained in one afternoon and availed ourselves of Tom's huge range of DVDs. We were given plenty of recommendations for walks and nearby restaurants, too. We can highly recommend Stonover Farm to anyone looking for something out of the Berkshires ordinary and, even though it isn't cheap, it is definitely worth it.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Hoboken, NJ

1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Elegant Historic, Yet Modern B&B With Picturesque Grounds'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 9, 2009
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I were searching for a relaxing and luxurious place to spend the weekend in the Berkshires near a bit of hiking/walking and found it at Stonover Farm. Unlike other B&Bs, their website is an accurate representation of the grounds and the real thing is even better in person. We stayed at The Cottage and enjoyed every minute of it. Both the Cottage and the main house were very beautifully decorated, clean and well-maintained. The host couple is very pleasant to be around and the wine and cheese and breakfast were nicely done. It may be helpful to note that this review is from the perspective of a 32 year old (as opposed to an antiqueing B&B-goer) and we found that other young professional couples were also enjoying Stonover while we were there, which is a bit unusual in the general world of B&Bs and makes this place all the more wonderful.
Less

DoubleTree Suites by Hilton - Boston

jgoto
Toronto, Canada
Top Contributor
55 reviews 55 reviews
Reviews in 26 cities Reviews in 26 cities
18 helpful votes 18 helpful votes
'Great choice for a family'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I stayed at the DoubleTree Suites in Boston with our 9-month-old and were very happy with our decision and impressed with our room. The location of the hotel is a bit isolated, so I would only stay here if you have a car. We chose this hotel because it was located a quick drive away from downtown, Harvard Square and Tufts University and because it offered rooms with a separate bedroom and sitting area. The room was large, clean and comfortable with a fridge and microwave - all of which made traveling with our infant very easy. The only complaint we had was that there was usually only one person working at the front desk at a time, otherwise staff were very prompt and helpful. We would definitely recommend this hotel and would stay here again.

Nice central location if you have a car. Otherwise, it's more than half a mile to Central Square or Harvard Square. Nice short walk to Harvard Business School, but that's about it. Much more activity near the Back Bay Hilton.

Great rooms, large and functional.

harvardmom2
rockaway, nj
Senior Reviewer
8 reviews 8 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Treated like royalty!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012

At first, we were bummed out about staying here. Our son and daughter in law live in the Back Bay and we have stayed at the Hilton near Prudential Center now for nearly 4 years. We always brought our beloved dog, whose last visit was in the fall of '11 before she succumbed to cancer on November 1. The Hilton was literally across the street from their apt.

This past weekend was our first time traveling anywhere with our new dog, a 6 year old beagle whom we rescued in April. I was all set to book the same hotel when I noticed they were no longer dog friendly, apparently due to a new owner. Hence, the not so near Double Tree. ( which we had stayed in many times since 2000 when our sons were enrolled in college nearby)

I called the hotel to request an upgrade based upon our HH diamond status and also because the day we were checking in was going to be our 37th wedding anniversary. I spoke with Wendy who assured me that she would try her best to upgrade our room.

We arrived Friday afternoon and were warmly greeted at the front desk with anniversary wishes and the signature Choco chip cookie. We went to our room and what a treat to find a 2 story dwelling with floor to ceiling windows! There was a half bath downstairs, with a huge wall mounted flat screen tv, of course couches, chairs and table... Microwave, sink and fridge. The sink in the half bath was awesome! See picture.

Upstairs was the bedroom with full bath and a fabulous shower! The best surprise was the tv that was built into the mirror!!

The bedding was plush and there was a great mattress.. There was a railing overlooking the downstairs and views of the Charles River from the multistory windows.

Kudos to Wendy and her warm and sincere staff. All personnel were genuinely cheerful and friendly.

We look forward to staying here again!
Less

MaestroNewJersey
New Jersey
Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'Great for families'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012 via mobile
1
person found this review helpful

The best part of the Doubletree Suites are the large rooms. Spacious and comfortable, especially for families. We have five in our family and are often cramped in hotel rooms. Layout of these suites is a bedroom with two beds and a living room with pull-out couch, kitchen tale, fridge and microwave. The beds were a little small, but still great to have the privacy of a separate bedroom at a regular hotel room price. The pull out couch was surprisingly comfortable, which was usual and nice. Parking was overpriced, but the in-out self-park was convenient, especially since the hotel is not really walking distance to a lot. Convenient to Harvard Business School and parts of Cambridge, but a bit of a hike to Harvard Square or downtown. Convenient to major roadways so easy to get to what you need by car or cab. Not close to the subway though.

All told, I was very happy with the rooms, service and general feel of the hotel. I will be back.
Less

MJRTZ
New Jersey
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
10 helpful votes 10 helpful votes
'Good with a few flaws:'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 21, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The hotel is very nice and convenient. They have a shuttle that offers round trip service to many different attractions around Boston and the view to the river is very pleasant, from the rooms that offer it.

My only issue with this hotel was the cleanliness of the room, especially the bathroom. There was hair all over the shower walls and tub. Also, mold was clearly visible. I took pictures and I showed the front desk and they promptly sent housekeeping and they did a thorough job of cleaning the room. The mold was still there but I assume that it would take more than cleaning to get rid of it and we were only there for one night so we just accepted it for lack of a better term.

I gave the rating as "Very Good" because the staff was extremely responsive and pleasant. Also, the hotel really is nice. While it was a bit of a downer that the room was not cleaned properly and that mold was visible in the bathroom the staff responded in a fast and friendly manner.

If you are in Boston, consider this hotel. Sometimes the difference between a good and bad review is how the staff handle "stumbles" in a guest's experience at a hotel. This hotel did its job.

Safe Travels!
Less

I travel quite a bit and most hotels no longer even charge, let alone by device. So if you are working on your laptop during the day, then jump on your iPad to read or game in the evenings....$25. Cha Ching. Oh, and it's $40 to park.

So, if traffic's OK, you can easily access anything in the city, but be out of the center of it.

Sara C
Derby CT
2 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'An Amazing B&B Experience'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 14, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Where to begin? The Cornell in Lenox is quite possibly one of the most unique and amazing experiences. When I travel I prefer to stay in B&B's and the Cornell far suprasses all. Let's start with the food. Lance (their head chef) is utterly incredible. His culinary pairings are of the utmost quality. Lance has an understanding of food that is just beyond my comprehension; his scalloped potatoes make the Iron Chef look bad. Lance has a passion for food and it is absolutely reflected in his servings. If you have the opportunity to stay for brunch, you would be missing out if you didn't experience it. Then there is Judith. Judith is the primary innkeeper at this point in time, and she is incredible. She's kind, she's caring and most importantly, she just wants you to have a good time. Any good inkeeper is one who cares about the quality of your stay, and Judith wants to make sure your stay is fabulous. I haven't even mentioned the rooms (that's probably because I think they speak for themselves), so quanit, so clean, so outstandingly beautiful. Colleen and her crew absolutely enhance the rustic ambiance of this mangical Inn. The Cornell has an amazingly antique charm. Upon walking in you just feel welcomed. Time seems to just slow down and you're suddenly able to stop and smell the roses. Personally, I fell inlove with The Cornell from the moment I walked in. Its an experience I would recommend for anyone.
Less

R W
Hadley, Massachusetts
1 review
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Wonderful Stay at the Cornell'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed October 21, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

My wife and I stayed at the Cornell this past weekend and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves. We were celebrating our 5th anniversary and our visit was relaxing and memorable. I'll say right off that my wife and I are not finicky/fussy. On the other hand, we are not indiscriminating in our expectatiions. I was more impressed by the hospitality at the Cornell than some $300+ hotels I've stayed at. My wife's mother ran a B+B for more than 10 years and recognizes good service. In part, I am writing this review to offset a poor review that I read with disbelief. I honestly feel that 4 stars is a fair appraisal.

I like Victorian style homes and found the rooms beautiful and clean. The inn was not fully occupied so Lance offered us a choice of several rooms. We upgraded to a room called "Dolly" at no extra cost. The decore was spendid with period furniture and tasteful floral wallpaper. We loved the antique touches in the room such as lamps in the style of the early 20th century and depression era glassware. The complementary coffee mugs we received were a pleasant surprise. After dinner we took advantage of the cozy bar which had a variety of tablegames. The fourposter bed was comfortable and we slept well.

The next morning the breakfast included a delicious egg/potato/herb casserole, homebaked cinnamon rolls, fresh fruit, coffee and juice. We had a lively conversation with the staff and then walked about the property. The Cornell has a lovely Koi pond, a patio with umbrellas, and a wooden swing on the lawn. The main house has an inviting porch with rocking chairs. Afterwards, we had a great hike in Kennedy Park which was within walking distance from the B+B.

I will mention some things which could use a little attention. The house could use painting. Some yard items could be spruced up. My wife and I have renovated our house which dates back to the 1840's and believe that things don't need to be perfect to be appreciated. Overall, I felt the friendly staff attended to our needs and gave us a wonderful stay. We'd gladly stay at the Cornell again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask R W about Cornell in Lenox
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Charm and Fun'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 7, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The Village Inn was highly recommended to me by friends at work, and I was not disappointed. It was a wonderful weekend get-away to meet friends and get out of the city. It started with the scenic drive up the Taconic Parkway. Driving through Lenox was like walking in the past, such history but yet they still kept up with the times. When I arrived at the Inn I felt like I was family, the warm welcome was matched by the excellent service and many answered questions about the area. The Inn is in walking distance to the many shops in town. The room had a lovely historic charm to it, very clean and I loved the antiques. Once I settled into my room, I went to Rumpy's Tavern, which is within the Inn, to see if the rest of our group arrived. We had pre-dinner drinks and found the bartender most friendly, he serves an excellent martini. We then went upstairs to Rumplestiltzkin's for dinner. The dinner was superb and the service excellent. We were told this was one of the best restaurants in the Lenox area, if not the best. We were not disappointed. After dinner we all went back to Rumpy's Tavern to have after dinner drinks and to our delight it was karaoke night! A good mixture of tourist and local patrons, it was a perfect ending to a perfect day. The next morning we were served a wonderful breakfast. If you are in the Lenox area this Inn is a must!

This lovely colonial style Inn provided good nold New England atmosphere and excellent service. The rooms are very comfortable and clean, and decorated with a lovely mix of antique furniture. What a treat to find the bathroom had a whirlpool tub, a great way to unwind and/or start the day.
The Inn has a great Restaurant, we had dinner and I must say that the Pork Osso Bucco was fabulous, as was the rest of the meal. Breakfast is included with the stay and I was impressed by the lovely buffet.
We had a great time in the Tavern - Rumpys, definite rustic charm and a fun group of patrons (guests at the Inn as well as some local regulars).
The Inn is walking distance to downtown and a variety of stores. There is parking available on sire for guests - this is a definite plus for a B&B.
I would definite recommend the Inn as a great get away - I am looking forward to returning in the Fall to enjoy the change of season in this charming and welcoming B&B

WB2260763
New York City, New York
Contributor
14 reviews 14 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
17 helpful votes 17 helpful votes
'Beautiful colonial inn which is remarkable value for a weekend getaway'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed March 10, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

We have to say we were outright delighted with this place, where we spent a weekend three hours north of New York City for a second time. It is small and intimate, located in the oldest building in the village, dating back to the late 1700s. It has comfortable and atmospheric rooms with some antique furniture. It is more rustic than lavish - the room still has a VCR! - but that is the charm. But our room still had 4mb/s wifi (although not all rooms do). It is located within walking distance of dozens of other shops and cafes on the main street. And one of its main advantages is its in-house restaurant, Rumpelstiltzkins, which produces extremely good food, New England Traditional with a French/italian spin, at very attractive prices. So you don't even have to go out, but if you do, there are dozens of interesting museums and restaurants and other attractions in the surrounding area (try the nearby bookstore which serves wine in the evenings). At some times of year they offer a $50 voucher for the restaurant with the room, which we got. And it all meant we felt we got extremely good value for an atmospheric and comfortable stay.
Less

'We go back again... and again...'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed December 6, 2011

This is the only place we stay at in the Berkshires, even if it is further than others! We've gone here since 2006, and have visited at least half a dozen times. We've even gone back with our toddler, for whom they set up a port-a-crib, gave her her own breakfast, had a high chair for her use, and just treated her like a princess. They are always very understanding of my vegetarian diet, and always make sure that I get something delectable to eat! And they always make sure the coffee is fresh! My husband went to change a diaper, and by the time he came back, they'd decided his coffee was too cold, so promptly served him a new one. The staff are incredibly kind and generous and approachable, the innkeeper Amy knows EVERYTHING about ANYTHING in the area and is an amazing resource for planning any type of vacation in the area, be it romantic, family or otherwise! We are definitely going back in the Spring. See you there ;)

'A Luxurious and Welcoming B&B'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 9, 2011

After a stay in a rustic B&B in Vermont, the Rookwood Inn appeared to us both luxurious and entirely welcoming. Amy, the innkeeper, greeted us as if we were her most valuable guests and was a font of wisdom regarding local and area places in which to eat, swim, and hike. Our room was beautifully coordinated and entirely comfortable with Eastlake antiques predominating. Breakfast was well-prepared, but the secret delight of the place lies in the screened-in side porch where morning coffee and evening drinks can be taken along with the cool Berkshire air. Lennox and its many attraction is just a block away, but the ambience of Rookwoord is rural peacefulness. We would stay here again in a heartbeat.

AlizaFromOttawa
Ottawa, Canada
Contributor
13 reviews 13 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
8 helpful votes 8 helpful votes
'Our first experience with a B&B and it could not have been better'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 23, 2011

The location can't be beat; Lenox is in the middle of the Berkshires, and this inn is steps away from the shopping, restaurants, and Shakespeare & Company is walkable. I learned the hard way last year that the decent accommodations in or near Lenox are relatively pricey, but the Rookwood looks after its guests. I have new health issues, and felt completely taken care of, from the inn's very generously portioned, balanced breakfasts to the helpful binder of menus from area restaurants (I could check if there were things I could eat-- and we could plan costs). If you're gluten free or dairy free, or have other health issues, the Rookwood will look after you: they'll serve you completely safe versions of the foods everyone else is eating (e.g. very tasty waffles, french toast, parfaits and omelettes). PS the sausages are also delicious.

We had a chance to peek in all the guest rooms over the course of our stay (when empty, they are left open), and can say that they look exactly like the online photos and descriptions. My favourites online were my favourites in-person. We needed a room that was quiet, and while you could hear voices in the hall a bit, once people were in their rooms you could not hear a thing-- it was like you were the only people in the inn. The air conditioning was effective, and it was great having our own a/c (and heat) controls. We stayed in the "Tavern" room; it was small, but there was ample room for both our suitcases and also new purchases, and to sit & check email-- and there's so much to do in the area, we were barely there. As for the common rooms, we particularly enjoyed spending some late (and rainy) afternoons on the screened porch off the salon, sipping tea, enjoying the snack, staring at the trees and talking.

The only quibbles were minor, and with the quality of the accommodations and food would not matter to most people. The water pressure in the shower was weak (third floor of an old building) but even with my long hair it wasn't a problem at all. We weren't used to springy type beds, but slept well after we quickly adjusted to it. I'm only mentioning these two things in case someone's picky-- and to show this is a real review. No place is perfect-- even home has its quirks!

Lastly, the innkeeper Amy was just lovely, as was her cook. We really enjoyed spending time talking with them. That wasn't only our impression-- while we were in town, in store after store, when they heard where we were staying, they commented on how nice Amy is. We agree! And while sitting in the inn's salon, we found that even several of the other guests were nice, too.

It's not just good food, nice rooms and wonderful innkeepers that tempt people to come back-- the Rookwood is very professionally run, with an efficient registration system online, prompt replies to email queries, a good system for late arrivals, that menu binder, free wifi, parking right near the entrance to the inn, two luggage racks in the room, the well-gravelled (and thus minimal puddles and mud) parking lot, and other details. It's a small facility but I know a few big-name hotels that could learn some lessons from them.

Bottom line: if you're looking for commercial accommodations in the Berkshires, I highly recommend staying at the Rookwood. We definitely hope to return!

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Apple Tree Inn

M M T

1 review
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Customer service not great'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

I booked a last minute 2 night stay at the Apple Tree Inn in order to attend a seminar at Kripalu. There was no lodging space available at Kripalu and the proximity of this inn made it a good second choice. Unfortunately the speaker I wanted to see cancelled the seminar 2 days before the scheduled start date. Kripalu refunded my fee entirely. The owner of Apple Tree was not as gracious. Even though my reservation at her Inn had been booked for less than 36 hours, she kept $25 of my deposit as a cancellation fee and will keep the remainder ($55) to be used only as a credit towards a future stay. So this will essentially be a waste of $80 as I am unlikely to stay there for any reason other than a Kripalu seminar and would normally try to stay on-site at Kripalu. This reservation was unusual due to the last minute booking.
As a CPA I can understand that the owner's business was negatively impacted by this cancellation, however, I believe the negative goodwill associated with this charge far outweighs the short term business loss. I feel as if I was charged $80 to have a reservation for 36 hr plus the disappointment of my seminar cancellation. The Inn owner is the only one that benefited from the cancellation and she didnt even have the courtesy to contact me directly. Instead I could only talk to a manager or via email. I consider this poor customer service and will stay at Kripalu or Ironwood Inn for my next seminar.
Less

Gina C
New York City, New York
Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Egg-eaters pay for their own.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed February 24, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed here for one night prior to a stay at Kripalu, extending our retreat while adding only moderate expense. The inn is a bit slapdash and the service haphazard, but in all it's much more atmospheric and spacious than Kripalu's dorm-like rooms. The cold buffet breakfast was tasty, and while one might resent paying extra for hot food, I appreciated that this was a way to keep room charges down by not subsidizing egg-eaters. We were in the main house (at the suggestion of another reviewer, who warned against the mildewy lodge), Room #15, which is on the 3rd floor. How wise it was to add a skylight to the slanted eaves, which might otherwise have felt claustrophobic! Charming floral decor without becoming cloying.

Here's why I don't give it an excellent rating: First, there was no porch light on, making for a precarious entry to the place (although allowing us to enjoy the velvet darkness and glittering stars of the Berkshire winter). Second, there was no recommendation for a dinner spot in Lenox. Third, we got up for the 8 am breakfast we were told would await us, only to be told that it would start at 9, and then later this was retracted but it started at 9 anyway. Fourth, when we asked for green tea bags we were told that there weren't any, but after we drank our distant second favorite, green tea was produced. So you see why I say slapdash and haphazard.

Nonetheless, it might be nice to try the place for a day or two in the summer to use the pool and walk over to Tanglewood. The location can't be beat.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

chins01
Brooklyn, NY
Contributor
20 reviews 20 reviews
Reviews in 19 cities Reviews in 19 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Good lodging option if you're visiting Kripalu'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed January 6, 2012

I stayed here while visiting the nearby Kripalu Yoga Center. This is a great option if you're getting a daypass and don't qualify for lodging at Kripalu or if you're coming with friends/a partner and want a cheaper and MUCH nicer housing option than Kripalu offers.

It is definitely less convenient than staying at Kripalu itself since it's a good 10 minute walk so you can't just run back to your room to get something. On the other hand, during off-peak times you're paying much less for the accommodations by staying at the Apple Tree Inn and you're getting a way better place to stay. Kripalu doesn't have air conditioning, a pool, or super comfy beds, but the Apple Tree Inn has all of the above. The walking path is not that well lit so if you're staying here in the winter when it gets dark early I'd recommend driving the short distance between the two locations instead of walking back in the dark.
Less

'A heavenly location'

I stayed at the Apple Tree Inn in 11/2011 while attending a seminar at Kripalu. The best part was the landscape, fruit ladde trees, and overall cleanliness of the inn. The host and other attendants were very professional, sweet and kind. I got a room at the lodge that I did not care for and was relocated to the main building which has lovely rooms with very victorian style and comfortable beds. The inn serves breakfast which is in its dining room. Beautiful settings and very sunny rooms. In the morning the lobby and dining areas are bathed with warm sunlight. A definite place to revisit. The rates were decent. I will definitey stay here on my future trips to Kripalu and would highly recommend other nature enthusiasts as well as vacationers to pick this spot.

There are some nice restaurants in the vicinity and lovely walking landscape if you are into exercising.

Fresh air and lovely landscape.

'Views, Ambiance, Great Owners - What's Not to Like!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 14, 2011

This was our second stay at the Apple Tree Inn and it was as great this time as last year! The owners went out of their way for us, giving helpful advice and directions on places to visit. The inn is beautifully furnished - there is always coffee, tea, hot chocolate, etc. waiting for those who want it, lending to the relaxed atmosphere. The breakfast was ample and leisurely with no one rushing us out. The views from the inn are incredible overlooking a lake and nearby Tanglewood. Our room was spotless and quiet and the shower worked very well. While there is no television, we can honestly say it was never missed. We heartily recommend this inn.
Less

Adams
Durham, NH
Senior Contributor
41 reviews 41 reviews
Reviews in 32 cities Reviews in 32 cities
63 helpful votes 63 helpful votes
'Nice inn but a few glitches'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed November 9, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

The rooms in the main Inn are comfortable and the Inn is very clean. The wood fire in the living room is wonderful on a cold day. The antiques are lovely. The inn was close to Kripalu so you can do a day rate there. It snowed when we were there and staff were kind enough to help us clean the car. The inn appealed to women over 40.

Now for the glitches. There is no one at the Inn after 11:00 pm, so if something goes wrong you are on your own. We had a smoke alarm going off in our room at night because of a low battery. There was no one around to help us. We called the owners but the alarm did not go off until 6 am when the maintainence staff arrived. We did not sleep all night and were not compensated in any way. Not great for business. For this reason we would not be back.
Less

jim s
Edinburgh, United Kingdom
1 review
'Peace and quiet'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 27, 2011

Imagine waking up in the morning and hear birds singing instead of coughing, green fields in all directions instead of smog and traffic jams, no tv (except in the suites), no telephones and cell./mobile phones are not allowed in the Lounge..plus FRESH AIR for FREE!!!. Then imagine The Apple Tree Inn near Lenox in Mass. USA

The Bar is very atmospheric - typical late 1800's New England 'Pub' atmosphere (very good selection of Scotch Whiskies - blended and Malt) and a building with history going back to that time period.

A 20 minute walk (leave the car) from a music festival area - Tanglewood which is - among other things home to many world famous Boston Orchestras and Jazz Festivals - (but no sound at the Inn from the area)

My son and I flew from Scotland on vacation and we stayed at Apple Tree Inn to go to - among other things - the Tangelwood Jazz Festival (excellent)...The Inn is owned by Sharon and Joel and they have kept many late 19th century character fixtures and fittings and also created a very warm and friendly atmosphere from all the staff..Is like visiting friends rather than vacation...Breakfast is light - but cooked breakfast is available - and Dinner is excellent value..There is a pool but the scenery and peace and quiet is priceless..Far from the Madding Crowd is definitely the words to use

Jim and Neil
Less

Walker House

gindras
Charlotte, North Carolina
1 review
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Musty and shabby'
1 of 5 stars Reviewed July 16, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

Maybe the people who have written glowing reviews of Walker House had the only decent rooms in the place. There is a vast difference between eclectic decor and cluttered mess, between worn and downright dirty, between charming and decrepit, between basic and spartan, and between aged and ramshackle. The Walker House misses on all counts. We only saw our hostess Peggy, a few fellow guests, and several cats. Never saw Richard. Our rooms were musty, dark and decorated with a mix of (interesting) opera memorabilia and worn-out junk. The lamps were too dim to see anything at all and the wallpaper had come almost completely away from the wall. The smell of mildew was overwhelming. The bath shared by our two rooms had a dirty fiberglass shower and tub insert with a showerhead meant for a munchkin. The linens looked as though they had come from a yard sale; they were mismatched and tattered. Admittedly, there was a large and attractive veranda across the back of the house, onto which our rooms opened. However, the floor was dangerously weak at points, the furniture was literally falling apart, and the garage off the back leaned to one side and had a huge hole in the roof. A strong wind might have knocked it down by now. We are early risers, but no one even started a pot of coffee before 8:30. Breakfast, never ready before 9, was cold cereal and maybe some fruit or a few pastries. It was very disapponting, not at all like the descriptions we had read, and grossly overpriced. Location was the only positive for this place. It is within walking distance of Lenox shops and restaurants, and a short, easy and uncongested drive to the secondary parking lot at Tanglewood.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask gindras about Walker House
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
K-Anne10
Boston, Massachusetts
2 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Feel instantly at home'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 3, 2011

I've been coming to Walker House for the past 12 years, and every time I step through the door, I instantly feel at home. Large fireplaces, wide porches, piles of books and friendly cats all contribute to a truly relaxing atmosphere. The rooms are spacious and decorated with antiques, in keeping with the history of the house. The inn is also walking distance to the shops and restaurants in downtown Lenox. Owners Peggy and Dick are warm, friendly hosts, and have their fingers on the pulse of the local arts scene. All in all, a great place to stay for the perfect Berkshire experience!
Less

pookabun
new york
1 review
'We make special trips just to stay at Walker House!!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed December 14, 2010

My husband & I head over to Lenox to attend the excellent concerts at Tanglewood in addition to local museums and just to wander the villages and take in historic Lenox.

Walker House is the perfect Inn to come home to after our days forays. Each of the rooms is named after a different composer and designed in period (the innkeepers obviously know their stuff). One finds lovely canopy beds, working fireplaces and huge bathtubs in the rooms.

The public areas are fun to relax in and explore, full of books and charming nick nacks. In addition, the innkeepers offer a huge video screen on which to watch a variety of dvds.

We love that Walker House is pet friendly - with several cuddly cats wandering through. We don't travel with pets, but have our own at home, so we appreciate the furry friends!

The Innkeepers, Peggy and Dick, are very helpful and pleasant, whether they are providing a lovely breakfast in their dining room or talking about the area that they so obviously love.

Overall, Walker House is wonderful all year round - an enhancement to a stay in the Berkshires or perhaps even a reason to plan a trip there!
Less

'a stay in a mid 19th century , traditional inn at the heart of the berkshires'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed September 30, 2010

my stay was made all the more enjoyable by the warmth of my welcome from Peggy the owner , room was spacious , overlooking the private woodland at the rear .Ideally situated for all the facilities of this charming town ,nothing was too much trouble breakfast most enjoyable providing a real chance to talk to other guests .
Peggy is a cat lover , there are numerous antiques & collectables accumulated over a period of time - several featuring cats her cats add personality , leading their own relaxed , languid lifestyle in what must be ideal surroundings .
There are several , shaded terraces , verandahs etc where you can spend a couple of hours reading or watching the abundant wildlife in the grounds .
All told , my stay was very enjoyable & relaxing - exactly what I wanted .
I will definately return in the not too distant future .

TravelingMatt66
Elmwood Park, New Jersey
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
13 helpful votes 13 helpful votes
'Very Satisfied'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012 via mobile

I spent three nights at this hotel on business and was very satisfied with the overall product, particularly the staff. Miriam in the Bistro always had a smile in the morning (a rare commodity these days) and Jimmy at the valet station was eager to please. The room was super clean, the valet was completely efficient and it was located adequately close to the 10 and the 405.

The room was on the small side, but being alone it did not bother me in the least. Had I been with my family, it would have been cramped. There were no signs of renovations and my room felt up-to-date, so perhaps it was done already.

The only negatives are the cost of parking, which was $54 for three days and somewhat limited options at the Bistro.

I will use this hotel again on future trips to LA
Less

'Wonderful stay! Most welcoming staff ever!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 21, 2012

As a Marriott Vacation Club owner I stay almost exclusively at Marriott properties and have high expectations. This stay surpassed expectations in every way. Wonderful property, great updated lobby and bistro area. Clean, comfortable room with good amenities. But the real star here is the staff -- just fantastic! Everyone knew my name and seemed genuinely interested in whether our stay was going well. None of this felt fake or forced -- it seemed sincere in every case. Little touches like fruit water in the lobby added to the experience. Good location, close to a lot but not so close as to be noisy. We were in a stressful situation -- a two-day job tryout for my son -- a bad hotel stay would have increased the stress but instead it minimized it. Thanks so much!

1 review
'An Oasis in the city'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 21, 2012

We had a lovely stay at the Courtyard Los Angeles Century City/Beverly Hills, recently. The rooms and the entire hotel were clean and very pleasant. The staff was without exception courteous and helpful. We needed adjoining rooms, which can be hard to find, but the night manager did his best and found them for us, despite our very late arrival. The "Bistro" on the second level, which boasts a very European flair, is a great place to get a quick coffee,excellent breakfast, or a light meal. This hotel is truly a delightful "oasis" in the heart of the city, and we would definitely stay there again.

Each night I intended to work or read while laying in bed. However, the bed was so comfortable and relaxing that I fell asleep each night before being able to get anything done.
The room was large and very spacious. Not sure if this was a normal size room or not, but I was not about to complain.
Although I have been to LA many times, this was my first time driving in LA. The hotel was easy to find and fairly easy access to the highway. I would stay here again.
Less

'This is my first review'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 9, 2012

I am writing my first review for this particular establishment because this Courtyard facility does stand out amongst ALL of the Courtyards I have stayed out throughout California. The hotel staff is incredible and they really create a somewhat more upscale feel (more of a Renaissance level feel)...although it's still just a Courtyard level. Even with the relative high price per night, service is up to par for it. James is a fantastic manager there who will remember you, as does Joy, who works the front desk. Valet parking always bothers me, but that's pretty much the norm around here.

Whistler's Inn

SueWrites
Rochester NY
1 review
'Charming, Comfortable, Close to Tanglewood'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 30, 2012

Located in the Berkshire mountains just a mile from Tanglewood, Whistlers Inn is a special treat for travelers looking for charming, historic ambiance and warm, welcoming service. The public rooms are stunning and decorated in period antiques. Porches surround the first floor on two sides and overlook the garden. A Steinway piano graces the parlor, and a wine decanter and glasses awaited guests when I arrived on a Friday evening. Lisa Mears, the inn manager and daughter of author Richard Mears and his artist wife Joan, greeted me at the door and gave me a quick tour of the house. My room was cozy with a private bath and a comfortable bed. The full breakfast was served in the spacious dining room; it was more than ample and guests were offered a choice of hot, freshly cooked breakfast entrees as well as fruit and juice, a large selection of pastries, and coffee and tea. Guests lingered after the meal to hear Richard's stories about the house and to watch a brief screening of the Travel Channel episode that was shot at the inn. Lisa directed me to the many literary and artistic sights in the area and made suggestions based on my interests. This trip I was traveling on business; I'll be back, next time with my husband and more free time to sightsee!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask SueWrites about Whistler's Inn
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Jules G
Washington, District of Columbia, United States
1 review
'Home Sweet Home'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 18, 2012

Well, it was a dark and snowy night, in the middle of a winter storm, in the middle of winter and we landed, all according to plan at the hidden entrance gothic, gingerbread storybook world of Whistler's Inn. After ringing, ringing, ringing and no one coming, we simply pushed the door easily open and let ourselves in. Deep caramels, crimson and indigo lights of treasured objects everywhere, crystal chandeliers, marble, dark wooden beams and book lined walls, scent of cedar, balsam and sage, wafting around us in the warmth, fusing shapes, colors and old world dimensions altogether embracing our senses. Still no one else but us to meet. We were so happy already and grateful to be there.

We readily unfurled the layers of winter coats off us, put our bags aside and proceded to peer through the collection of mysteries around us. We ventured unescorted, our imagination captured, through the secret victorian rooms and recesses with abandon. What pure delight we felt and so welcomed with the discovery of the hot herbal tea, digestifs and fresh baked pastries we noticed awaiting us in the dining room. Naturally, we just poured our tea, grabbed some sweets and plunked down into one or another of the overstuffed chairs to sit and gaze around us. That was happiness.

Moments later, a beautiful, young blond woman appeared soundlessly through the swinging kitchen door. With a wry and welcoming smile, she said softly, "Hi, do you have your room yet?" Well, she then produced a heavy key for some room upstairs, as I recall.

After thawing out from the cold and being sweetly entertained with music and her mellow, enquiring conversation, we retreated for the night. Our room was a darling,cozy, wallpapered refuge `

That was Lisa.That was twenty years ago.

She and her parents, Richard and Joan, all artists, have since become life long friends and their magical world, a yearly necessity.
Less

'A bit right of center'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed October 13, 2011

The owner went a bit overboard with what I'll politely call his "right of center social views." If that's not your thing, you might have a hard time at the Whistler's Inn. The breakfast was warm and generous in a lovely room, the bedroom however was on the cold side. The interior is old, when was the last time money was spent on maintenance or renovations? I suppose it's charming to have a toilet seat as old as the house - the large square footage and coffee maker in the hallway were nice. Sorry to say, but I'll look for a different B&B next time I'm in the area.

bygeorgew
Dartmouth, Canada
Senior Contributor
24 reviews 24 reviews
Reviews in 17 cities Reviews in 17 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Wonderful Stay in Berkshire Inn'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed September 24, 2011

We wanted to stay in an Inn in the Berkshires and we are certainly glad we found Whistler's Inn in one of our searches. It is in a good location in the historic town of Lenox, Mass; well situated for exploring the Berkshires. Our hostess was wonderful during our stay. She was friendly and helpful about good restaurants in the area and helped out when we had difficulty with the WIFI. You could tell she truly enjoyed meeting and talking with her guests. Our room (The Hunt Room) was comfortable and large. Everything was clean, although some signs of age are showing (not a bad thing in an Inn with character). There was a library, sitting room and sun room  I will attach pictures. We certainly had the feeling that we were welcome to use any of these rooms. We walked down the hill to the business section of Lenox and had supper outside. It is not far and a comfortable walk (evening walking back up the hill). Breakfast in the dining room was delightful  french toast made fresh with lots of other goodies to enjoy. The grounds are beautiful and I wish I had taken more time to spend in the garden.

Less

person found this review helpful

We stayed in the "Africa Room". The buffet breakfast included hostess donuts, store bought mini muffins, bagels and croissants and a few other items. The pitcher of milk at our table was so far gone that it had a thick ,chunky consistency. Felt like inn keeping was an afterthought. Worst place I have ever stayed.

Kevin N
Newmarket, Canada
1 review
'Absolutely wonderful!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 25, 2011

My two traveling buddies and I were on a ghost tour of New England and decided to stay at the Whistler's Inn due to its history and location. It couldn't have been a more enjoyable time. We stayed in the Santa Fe room which was spacious and comfortable. Sitting for hours in the library reading (the sherry was a nice touch) and the music room was so relaxing. The host, Lisa, is simply enchanting with so many fascinating experiences around the world. Her company alone is worth the visit. The owner, Richard is a author of note and a fascinating guy to talk to over breakfast (which was so much better than previous reviews prepared me for).

As for haunted, I expected to only go to a place that OTHERS claimed was haunted, but ending up having a bit of an experience myself. Don't worry if this is not what you are looking for, however. In my experience, you really only see things if you are looking for them (other families were there, and none of their kids look petrified).

All in all, I can't imagine having picked a better place.
Less

'We had a very relaxing vacation and we felt right at home.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed July 13, 2011

It was so nice to wake up in the early morning to hear nature calling and taking an early
morning walk. Enjoyed all the delicious meals and visiting with people from all over the
world. There is so much history in Lenox and many sites to visit. It is nice to be able to
walk to these near by sites and find the town itself very enchanting. The atmosphere is
very relaxing and one can imagine what it was like in the 1800's. The music room is
beautiful and the flowers and grounds surrounding the Inn is lovely. Whistler's Inn takes
you a step back in time and you can only wonder what it was like many years ago. Enjoyed the library and having a sip of sherry while visiting with guests. Loved every moment of our visit. I am ready to return soon.

rimlet
Kingston, New Hampshire
1 review
'disappointing'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed July 9, 2011

We knew that we had booked a small room in this b&b and were happy to have a private bath since I am pregnant, but the overall condition of the room and the entire interior was somewhat shabby. And small did not even cover it- the room was about 8 feet by 12 feet. The bathroom was also so small, you had to sit diagonally on the toilet. The decor was last updated at least 30+ years ago, and that with the peeling paint from ceilings and walls left us feeling like the prices were much too high for what we were getting. ($130 per night) The included breakfast was terrible; an array of store bought muffins and toast, with only a small sample of fresh watermelon and 2 egg dishes, one of which I couldn't eat anyway as I am gluten-free and pregnant. This was not a sufficient start to my day and we had to go out and spend more money for breakfast anyway. The service was less than wonderful, although they were nice enough. We had to wait 45 mins for our room to be cleaned when we arrived, even though we arrived after check in time, then whenever I had a question, I had to interrupt conversations to get noticed. Finally, we actually left a day early, and after having to interrupt a conversation to turn in our key, they did not even ask why we were leaving early. I don't think they cared because they had their money. It is a nice location within walking distance to downtown Lenox and the common rooms are well decorated with antiques, however it seems to me that they've spent too much time and effort on their antiques, and not enough updating the rooms and taking care of the general condition of the house itself. I would not stay here again because there are so many other places to choose from in the area. And be sure to book months in advance, as the summer time fills up quick and early. Each thing in and of itself wasn't so bad, but all of them together left us feeling like we had spent too much money for not enough amenities. If you want to spend the money to stay in a bigger room, you might be happier. And also, they seem to only give attention to those who appear to have more money, so maybe you'd do well here if you look affluent.
Less
