Canyon Ranch in Lenox: Traveler Reviews

DonaAFS
New York City, New York
Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
20 helpful votes 20 helpful votes
'So disappointed'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW
2
people found this review helpful

My daughter and I went to Canyon Ranch, Lenox for four nights of spa time before her wedding next month. We have both been to quite a few spas before and were truly looking forward to a great, relaxing, revitalizing few days. Instead, we ended up leaving after 1 1/2 days because we found the experience to be so unpleasant.
The entire place seemed more corporate/institutional than spa like. The rooms and grounds were tired and felt like a 3 star hotel. Even the soaps and shampoos were of low quality .
We love fresh healthy spa-like food. The food here was awful tasting and unappealing to the eye. It is really not too difficult to take fresh healthy ingredients and create simple and delicious healthy food. The foods all tasted as if they were created from inferior ingredients and prepared ahead of time. The flavors were muddled and created with dried stale tasting herbs. Nothing had a fresh or vibrant taste. It was more like hospital or airplane food than what one would expect to find at a spa. The only snacks around were institutional fruits, oranges, delicious apples, bananas and pears. Not a carrot stick or a spa cookie or smoothie to be had. WE asked four people where we could get a snack and finally someone took us to a hidden mini fridge behind an unmanned counter where they offered us string cheese and finally a trail bar (which was the only delicious thing we ate while there).
The spa services were truly sub-par and the spa itself was not quiet, tranquil, pretty or nice smelling.
The bright spot were the few exercise classes we attended which were lots of fun and a good workout. Women's stretch, morning run, morning walk, aqua fit and cardio circuit were all great.
I am really perplexed by all of the positive reviews on Tripadvisor. My only guess is that people have not been to other spas and therefore did not have a basis for comparison. Maybe people truly believe that low-calorie food has to be punitive to the tastebuds. I don't know, but all I can suggest is that if you are a sophisticated traveler/spa goer, you will not like the general vibe or the food or the spa services or the accommodations at Canyon Ranch, Lenox.
I will close by saying that the staff was cooperative about letting us out of our commitment to stay for four nights.

    Stayed June 2012, traveled with family
        1 of 5 stars Value
        3 of 5 stars Location
        3 of 5 stars Sleep Quality
        2 of 5 stars Rooms
        3 of 5 stars Cleanliness
        2 of 5 stars Service

Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask DonaAFS about Canyon Ranch in Lenox
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
JYGfromNYC
New York City, New York
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
13 helpful votes 13 helpful votes
'Save up your $$ and go!! Well worth it!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012

I had always felt a trip like this would do me good but that it was out of my reach financially. I took advantage of a promotion they were running, and although still an extravagance, I have to say I am so glad I went. From the moment I stepped off the Amtrak train at Albany, I was engulfed by a feeling of restfulness. A wonderful driver was there waiting to take me on the 45 minute drive to Canyon Ranch and I just knew the instant he said hello to me that I was going to have a great time. I went alone, which is what I needed to do for myself, but since my return, everyone I know insists they are joining me the next time - even my husband. We'll see if that happens...I loved being alone and focusing only on my health and well-being for a change! Arrival and check-in were very smooth; my room was not ready when I got there (way before 3 pm as I wanted to take advantage of as much as possible), so I went to Easter brunch which was delicious. In general I found all the food to be very yummy and I was never hungry throughout my four days there! My room was all the way at the end of the West wing, which meant I had a good seven or so minute walk to the spa, the dining hall, the locker rooms, etc. I liked the room location because it was very quiet. I didn't mind, though, since I was so energized the whole time I was there, and if you plan your day well, you rarely have to go back to your room at all during the day. The room itself was lovely, clean, comfortable. I wouldn't say it was five-star luxurious, considering the amount you are paying, but it is very lovely and cozy. There are some cute touches in the room, like a CD alarm clock and CD's with restful music on them for you to listen to; there's also filtered water, a small fridge, a safe, a robe, and great reading lights over the bed, all things I appreciated.
Shortly after arriving I met with a "program advisor." For me this was not so useful as I had already pretty much decided everything I wanted to do while I was there and had spoken to an advisor before I arrived. I had no interest in having medical treatments or examinations. However, the advisor was very friendly and supportive and I was impressed that two days later when I ran in to her in the hallway, she remembered me.
A great thing about CR in Lenox is that in bad weather, you never have to go outside. Everything is cleverly connected via a lovely heated and attractive walkway. On the other hand, the grounds are very pretty and it was nice, when the weather was good, to sit outside reading a book or just take a stroll.
On two days, I was dropped off and picked up for shopping, once in the town of Lenox (where there was one particular shop, a yarn store, that I wanted to see), and the second day I went to the local outlets. If I return to CR I will skip the outlets next time. They are underwhelming and I would have rather spent the time in another terrific class or at the gym. But I note this here because I was so impressed by the staff's determination to assist me and support me in my desire to shop! They went out of their way to make sure I could do both of these things and provided me with reliable transportation, which I really appreciated.
Now to the stuff I actually came for...I wanted to try new things, do some moving, and refocus myself on health and wellness. I loved the fitness and exercise classes that I took. In one class, myself and one other woman were the only participants and it was like having a personal trainer. I also took other classes, such as a circuit weights class that was so much fun, and a stretch class that was excellent. On two days, I had the entire swimming pool to myself for about two hours each day; that was an unbelievable treat. I found the pool to be underutilized and I am not sure why, it is a beautiful pool. The steam rooms and whirlpool were also great. I love the nonjudgmental atmosphere of the place, the supportive environment, and the incredible diversity of women in all kinds of shape who were there for the same reasons I was there. And it was not just women; there were quite a few couples, and yes, some men were there solo as well. This is a great place to go in any configuration, because they make it very "homey" for you.
I did a lot of treatments while I was there as I decided this was going to be a self-indulgent few days for me, something I don't often do. The deep tissue massage was excellent, as were the facial and the sea salt scrub. The one treatment I would not do again is the 'Lavender Relax.' This is just my personal preference; it was a lovely treatment but now that I've done it, I don't think I'd feel the need to try it again. In general I would do fewer treatments next time (and thus, save a bunch of money), and focus more on the classes and opportunities for movement. This is not a commentary about the treatments, only on my personal preferences. By the way, the official policy is "no tipping" and its impressive that despite this policy, CR has managed to attract and retain some excellent service providers, but I know from speaking to several of them that the tipping policy is a bone of contention and I wonder how much better the services would be if tipping were encouraged. (They are supposed to refuse tips. I'd rather pay less for my overall stay and then tip for service myself).
My one disappointment with the experience were the two lectures I attended. On my first day there I attended a lecture on wellness and intention. On the second day I attended one on weight management. Unfortunately, both lectures were given by the same person and they were virtually identical. I wish she had told those of us at the first one that she would be facilitating again the second day and that the sessions were going to be similar; there were other things I could have gone to instead. That being said, when she finally got to substantive matters in both lectures, the classes were almost over. 45 minutes is not really enough time if you want to have a substantive conversation. I would say that out of 45 minutes in each lecture, 30 minutes were basics - very basics, especially if you've done any work on nutrition or weight management at all. They were not too dissimilar from a Weight Watchers gathering. However, these were minor disappointments when put in the context of my entire experience, which was truly a wonderful one overall.
If you are looking for pure relaxation and a chance to be good to yourself, sleep well, be active and recharge yourself, this is the place to be. I've already told my husband I'll be saving up to go again. While three nights did not change my life, it did help me reprioritize myself and I did come home feeling very recharged, something I cannot say about every vacation I have. I wish it were not so expensive - but this time, at least, it was worth the money to have four days that were all about me! Unfortunately it has taken me too many weeks more than I hoped to sit down and write this review, but my experience there was so strong, I am still feeling the impact two months later. All I can say is, GO!
Room Tip: Rooms on the "west" wing are further from the spa, but honestly, who cares? You're the...

The grounds are peaceful to the point of being surreal, beautiful in all four seasons. From the moment we arrive for our visit, we feel that we have returned to our very special sanctuary for body, mind, and spirit.

Hampton Inn & Suites Berkshires

Marci B
New York City, New York
Senior Contributor
34 reviews 34 reviews
Reviews in 14 cities Reviews in 14 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'A little clinical but a friendly and comfortable home base in the Berkshires'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

In an area full of lovely, personality filled (and often overpriced) accomodations, the Hampton Inn doesn't offer a lot of character. It is located on a particularly uncharming stretch of highway. However, the hotel does go above and beyond in other departments. First of all, their rates are excellent considering it is summer in the Berkshires. Second, the hotel is very conveniently located (about a 5 minute drive) from the wonderful town center of Lenox as well as hiking, biking, historical properties like The Mount, Edith Wharton's former home. The property has some expected amenities like a small but pretty indoor pool, a clean fitness center, a great breakfast spread plus all day coffee and tea and a little candy shop. The staff is not only welcoming but very knowledgable (they easily directed us to a difficult to find hiking spot). The rooms are spacious and the beds are comfortable. It isn't the most memorable place but it is a solid choice of lodging.
Less

'pleasant stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 8, 2012 NEW

This Hampton Inn is a fairly new one and well appointed. The staff is extremely helpful and friendly. It is a couple of miles from Lenox itself but is well situated to explore the general Berkshire area. Since it's on "motel row" you have to really look for the little sign. The Hampton Inn is set back from the main road....which makes it quiet but hard to find. We drove by it twice before seeing the sign. Not their fault..it seems the city fathers control the signage.

'Best Free Breakfast!!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 14, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

We stayed here over the weekend because I was taking a cheese class in Ashfield, Mass and all of the hotels in that area were booked thanks to UMass' graduation. Boy did we luck out! The room was on the first floor and VERY spacious. The bed was surprisingly comfortable and the room was very clean. We loved the 24 hour a day cookies/coffee/hot chocolate. It was a great snack after a long drive up.

Our stay was even more delightful when we got up the next morning for breakfast. Even though we were only a couple of doors down from the lobby, we didn't hear any of the noise from guests eating breakfast from our room. The breakfast was delicious. Steak and eggs and tortillas to turn them into breakfast burritos, cheese omelets, pancakes, waffles, hot oatmeal, breakfast pastries, yogurt, the whole nine yards. This was one of the best breakfasts we have had and we travel a lot!

After finishing up our breakfast, the front desk manager made his way around the tables. He was very personable and we really enjoyed the conversation with him. It was great to have such a friendly and welcoming staff during our stay.

I would absolutely recommend this hotel to others who are staying in the Berkshires.

'Comfortable, Accomodating and Clean!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 14, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

This was our first visit to the Hampton Suites in Lenox. We were pleasantly surprised with our experience. The hotel staff greeted us warmly and provided us with local information about sites and restaurants to choose from me. Our room was on the second floor, although the view was disappointing, the room was quite large, very clean and included a whirlpool. The breakfast was robust and plentiful. The hotel location was perfect, right in between Lenox. Lee and Stockbridge. We were most impressed with a member of the hotel staff who asked how we were enjoying our stay (while at breakfast). During our discussion, she offered us discount tickets to the Norman Rockwell Museum ($12 instead of $16) and a certificate for a free print at the Museum Shop. She also gave us some handy tips on additional restaurants and coffee shops to try. Very friendly and accommodating. We plan to go back in early December and plan to stay at the Hampton Suites. Excellent!

contheroad
usa
Top Contributor
52 reviews 52 reviews
Reviews in 22 cities Reviews in 22 cities
24 helpful votes 24 helpful votes
'Very good, very comfortable in the Berkshires ...'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 4, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Our first time ever at a Hampton property and we were very satisfied. We wanted a centrally located hotel because we would be driving around - Lenox, Stockbridge, Williamstown, etc. This Hampton is perfect for that - off a major road but set back and quiet. If you want to walk around in town, this location is definitely not it. It's very close to Pittsfield and Pittsfield is not a classic pretty New England town - lots of auto repair shops, liquor stores, etc. For walking around in a scenic environment go stay right in town in Lenox.

Our room was clean and spacious - comfortable bed, good water pressure, nice kitchenette (sink, fridge and microwave), sofa, desk, good lighting and air. I noticed the room, the lobby and the hallways were maintained very well - no obvious scrapes, stains, nicks. Everything in the place worked which is great. We missed breakfast every morning except once when I managed to get there exactly at 10am - surprisingly, everything was still there, neat and still welcoming. There's coffee and tea in the lobby all the time. We noticed cookies and fruit too.

Housekeeping was very good. We leave a tip & thank you note for the housekeeper every morning even on check out morning and one housekeeper did leave a return thank you note. The front desk was very competent. They were friendly enough by saying good morning and hello but no one cracked a smile especially at check in and check out. I thought that was strange since everything else about the property was very good.
Less

OK, maybe not EVERY way. The elevator was jumpy. That's the only negative. Other than that, this hotel was marvelous. It's only a few years old so everything feels brand-smacking new. It's behind another building on Route 7, so you don't get the road noise. We faced the back so all we saw were woods. I heard no noise from the hallways or other rooms. The beds were comfortable. The business center was very nice. The breakfast was really good. And thank you, Hampton Inn, for being environmentally conscious with your plates and utensils. I liked the little grocery market, where you could purchase ice cream and other goodies.

The staff was very nice. They let us check in early, which was very helpful. I highly recommend this hotel and it would be my first choice for staying in the Berkshires.

Dreamer320
Richmond VA
Senior Reviewer
10 reviews 10 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
28 helpful votes 28 helpful votes
'Nice property in okay location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed March 9, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed at the Hampton Berkshires in October, 2011 for three nights. When I started researching the trip, I was rather surprised at the lack of mid-priced lodgings in the Berkshires - a Comfort Inn at $200 a night?? The Hampton was a good choice, and worth the relatively high price. We had a king suite, and the space in the room was amazing. There was a mini-fridge and coffee area, and the toilet and shower were in separated from the sink, which was in the main part of the room in an alcove.

The staff were all pleasant, and gave us flashlights when the area was hit with a power outage. The breakfast seating area was the largest I've seen in this type of hotel, and much appreciated. Unbeknown to us, we left our camera charger in the room, and they called us and mailed it back.

The only negatives about the property was a lack of a place to hang towels by the sink. The only towel rack was in the toilet/shower room, so the hand towels just had to be left on the sink countertop. Also, the cleaning person left a dirty cleaning rag on the kitchenette countertop by the entrance door on our first morning, and it remained there until we checked out.

This hotel is near but not close to any of the places you're likely to want to visit. It seemed like we did a lot of driving to and from our sightseeing. Also, the choices for dinner close by were fairly limited.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

meagan1223
Boston, Massachusetts
Contributor
11 reviews 11 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
12 helpful votes 12 helpful votes
'Most incredible hotel I have ever stayed in!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 28, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I have stayed in many world class hotels but this one has them all beat. Some hotels are spectacular because of the scenery, some the accommodations, some the service, or even the food; but this hotel has them all. We went for a long weekend in January and have wanted to return ever since. I was supposed to go with my husband but since he had to work I took a close friend. We stayed in the two bedroom Ice house and it was truly magical. I felt like we had our own cabin in the woods. Everything that you could possibly want or need was available at our fingertips. I wish I had the words to be able to truly express how magical this place is. When we arrived, even though we had both driven they took our bags and put them into the resorts car and guided us to our cottage. They built us a fire, put our bags in our rooms and gave us a tour of the cottage. It had a wonderful window seat in a bay window in the living room, a sun room built entirely of windows with a sofa, chairs and a table, there was a hidden flat screen tv in the living room with a variety of movies (more available upon request) and a dining room with an antique table for 6. There was brand new stainless steel kitchen with luxury dishes and cook wear, complimentary drinks in the refrigerator as well as a welcome basket with fruits, teas, cookies and chocolates. The master bedroom located on the main level was large, bright and spacious with a changing area/walk in closet and an enormous bathroom with a separate shower and bathtub, dual sinks and the toilet was behind its own door (water pressure was excellent). In the morning, they send in several people at once to clean, to cut down the amount of time that they are there. At turn down, we were given a box of chocolates as well as the blantyre cookbook, which is beautifully done, my friend, who was staying in the bedroom downstairs, received the same thing. Although the other bedroom is downstairs with its own bathroom, it is still above ground and both bedrooms have decks that you can walk out on or have a meal. While we were there we went ice skating, (they even have a hot chocolate menu you can order from while on the rink. We took a carriage ride, went snow shoeing, had massages and just generally explored. The food was exceptional, especially dinner, their sommelier was incredible, we had no desire to go anywhere else. Before dinner, they bring you drinks and canaps. I could go on forever about this place but I think this one experience will sum it up, my friend was starting to get sick so we called the front desk to see where the closest grocery store to buy cough drops was, they said they would call right back and about 10 minutes later the grounds keeper knocked on our door with a bag of cough drops, he said "I didn't know what flavor or brand you wanted so I got them all" furthermore, he refused to allow us to pay them or accept a tip. Blantyre really goes beyond every expectation. I can't wait to return

See all photos

Harking back to a bygone era of style, wonderful service and amazing attention to detail our all too brief four night stay at Blantyre will definitely reside in my memory as one of the most enchanting trips I've ever taken. The Laurel Suite was a beautifully appointed combination of antique packed rooms that overlooked the magnificent MA landscape of rolling hills and forest. The bathroom was large, warm and comfortable with an amazing shower and claw foot tub. We had delicious breakfasts and dinners, they also have an amazing wine-cellar with thousands of incredible varieties and vintages to choose from, from around the globe. We also enjoyed some wonderful spa treatments - and even got to ice skate on their private rink. Each evening a pianist discretely entertains in the main drawing room for the cocktail hour. The staff are charming and totally invested in the well-being of the guest. If you can appreciate being taken perfect care of, then I insist you visit Blantyre.

Contributor
20 reviews 20 reviews
Reviews in 18 cities Reviews in 18 cities
19 helpful votes 19 helpful votes
'Very Nice But Not Incredibly Exceptional'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed February 28, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

With all the wonderful, glowing reviews of this property, I had to really question our own experience to see if there was something at fault with my opinion of the weekend before writing this review. . . but here it is. I thinki this is a very beautiful property. It is a wonderful spot for a romantic weekend or a gathering of friends. I do think the 20 percent service charge added to everything is very high, and we really didn't find the food (dinner and breakfast) to be exceptional. Perhaps it was because we were there in the off season? I'm not sure.

I will say that probably a lot of the allure of Blantyre is the experience of it all. We chose to eat in our accommodations rather than experiencing the dinner service in the dining room. I do regret that. The poor weather also prevented us from experiencing all the resort had to offer (i.e. the snowshoeing and ice skating ). . . which I had been so looking forward to.

The dangerous thing about TripAdvisor is other reviewers set the bar so high with some properties that it is very hard for the experience of other guests to live up to theirs every single time. For example, I was really looking forward to the bottle of champagne upon arrival that others noted (we were celebrating my 40th birthday) but received a half bottle of red instead. Our particular accommodations, while nice, were also not up to the standard of a $1000-a-night accommodation though I couldn't find any past reviewers that had stayed where we were located.

All that said, I think back to a weekend spent at the White Barn Inn in Kennebunkport, the only other Relais and Chateaux property in which I have stayed. The weather that weekend was terrible too but I had an absolutely unforgettable time thanks to an extremely attentive staff, sumptuous food, and a very cozy room. If I compare the two properties, I don't think they are of the same caliber . . . at least that was our experience.
Less

AlbanyNYIslandlover
Albany NY
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'The Finest Hotel (small or otherwise) in America'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed January 7, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I stay at the Blantyre once or twice a year, most recently in October 2011 when we had the pleasure of also attending their Roderer Estate Champagne Dinner. I agree with other commenters that this property is nothing short of amazing. Ms. Fitzpatrick Brown has truly done something exceptional in not only the decor and ambiance of the property but in her training of the staff, as well. You'll feel whisked away to a long-lost time and place. Each room has a curated collection of fine antiques and books and high-quality dvd's and cd's. You feel as if you are staying in the fine country home of someone with exquisite taste, and really, you are. We have stayed in the Patterson Suite, which is absolutely enormous (with two separate bathrooms!) and also some of the smaller rooms, like The Orchard Suite in the Carriage House. Staying in the rooms in the Carriage House is nice if you are going to be using the beautiful pool or the super-relaxing spa. In the winter time, it's nice to stay in the rooms in the main house, as most of them have fireplaces. The food is exceptional and keep in mind a full (and I mean enormous) breakfast is included in your room rate.

Ms. Fitzpatrick Brown spares no expense nor any effort in making your stay something you will never forget. Do not let the price put you off in booking a stay here. It is worth every penny.
Less

lanaeps
Lexington, Massachusetts
1 review
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Extraordinary Elegance and Kindness'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 6, 2011
5
people found this review helpful

I recently spent an unforgettable overnight at Blantyre. As numerous reviews attest, the place is extraordinary. No detail goes unnoticed. I have stayed in many hotels and this one truly distinguishes itself from the rest. It's difficult to even think of it as a hotel! You do feel more as if you've been invited to a friend's country manor.

I was traveling to Lenox to have dinner with the high school guidance counselor who had turned my life around, and who I had not seen in 45 years. After reading reviews of restaurants in Lenox, I chose Blantyre for what promised to be a very special dinner.
An unseasonal snowstorm arrived soon after I did, and by 5:00 p.m., the roads were blanketed. The restaurant stayed open, and, not wanting to brave the roads twice, I reserved a second room for my guests, who--though both in their eighties--were ready for the adventure. When we arrived back at Blantyre, we were greeted outside by 4 or 5 people, including Ann Brown, the owner. Ann was so excited that we'd made it and so happy for us that she offered a free room for my guests that night. With a guest who was more than willing to pay for the room, I found Ann's generosity remarkable. And it's that remarkable generosity of spirit that makes Blantyre so special. It begins with Ann, and was evident in every single staff person I met there. Although I'm sure the staff is held to a high standard, I felt the staff members I met were genuinely good-natured and enjoyed providing a memorable experience to guests.

So we dined at leisure, in our own beautifully appointed small dining room, with wait staff that were nothing less than courtly, without being pretentious. When we wanted a photograph, someone appeared with a camera. The next day a disposable camera materialized. The dinner was extraordinary-- perfectly prepared and delicious. The creme brulee was the best I've ever tasted. We lingered over dinner for hours, and then were driven to our rooms in the carriage house. My room was as lovely and as comfortable as has been reported in other reviews.

In the morning, we were driven to the main house again for a sumptuous breakfast and, while we ate and talked, the amazing staff were busily digging out and cleaning off my car.
All in all, the Blantyre was much more than I'd hoped and I am looking forward to my next visit there. Try it. You won't be disappointed!
LE Lexington, MA
Less

'Lovely and Magical'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 25, 2011

The people are warm and go out of their way to make your stay exceptional. We stayed in one of the rooms in the carriage house called Brookside. We loved it. The room is beautiful and elegant but also comfortable and homey. As we entered our room right behind us they came in with champagne accompanied by a cheese and fruit plate. A nice way to start our adventure. We had dinner at their restaurant the first night and the experience was wonderful. You enter the main room with the scent of the fireplace and the sound of the piano in the air. You are given tasty canapes to start in the main room before dinner. We made our dinner and wine selections and then after a nice relaxing time were brought into the dining room. I must stop here and just say that the service and the people that work here are all amazing, friendly and go out of their way to add to your experience at Blantyre.The meal was wonderful from beginning to end. Fine dining indeed!

In addition to the property it is the local area that adds to this experience. We went for a nice hike up Monument Mountain one day and then to Ice Glen the next. Amazing hikes and great views.

We had dinner in Lenox at a great restaurant called Nudel. Great food bursting with flavors.

Blantyre is one for the memory books and we will be returning over and over. We loved it and highly, highly recommend it.

AKR1
northern NJ
Senior Contributor
32 reviews 32 reviews
Reviews in 25 cities Reviews in 25 cities
62 helpful votes 62 helpful votes
'Truly extraordinary- a peek into life in the gilded ages'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 10, 2011

A stay at Blantyre allows you to experience what life must have been like during the gilded age, prior to nuisances like the income tax, and working to earn a living, got in the way, and the Berkshire "cottages" like Blantyre were basically abandoned.
We had a truly extraordinary and might I say magical, stay at Blantyre. While my wife and I are widely traveled and love to stay at fine places, a stay at the Ice House, a two bedroom cottage that Ann Brown, the owner, kindly offered us, at 2k a night for just the room, would probably be out of our league.
Before I proceed, in terms of full disclosure, we did not have to pay for our stay at Blantyre as I had won an event where the prize was a two day stay with all meals and wine included. But as a frequent traveler and TA contributor, I will attempt to be completely objective in this review.
Blantyre is just as my title says, truly extraordinary. At any of the world's great hotels, however perfect their location, the mark of distinction is mostly carried by the quality of the service and the staff. Here Blantyre shines- the service was without any doubt exceptional throughout. From the moment we reached, we were whisked into this magical world, where there was nothing required except savoring the champagne and the world of Blantyre that Mrs Brown has so lovingly created.
The property is beautifully maintained and the absolutely gorgeous weather the weekend we were there added to the Berkshires beauty in the fall, but Blantyre shines by itself, creating an ambiance regardless of the weather. There is a very nice hiking trail right on the property, if you do not want to go outside. The Potting Shed, Blantyre's spa is perfectly situated on the property and the staff, like all of Blantyre's shine. I am not much of a spa person, but my wife, who has indulged across the globe said the treatment was comparable to the best.
I will comment on the food and wine. The food was excellent, the chef's creativity was challenged by my wife having the vegetarian tasting menu and I the regular one, and he delivered in spades. The vegetarian menu was amazing and I kept asking for a taste (which after the first one) was firmly denied.
And then the wine. We are both very wine centric with a cellar at home, but I have to say, this was one of the "wine weekends" of our lives, comparable to our trips to Bordeaux, the Rhone valley and Brunello (Montepulcino). I owe a debt of gratitude to Luc Chevalier, the amazing sommelier for making our stay so memorable. His knowledge, sensitivity to the guests palate, and ability to match just the right wine with whatever one is eating, is sheer perfection.
In summary, I am determined to go back, this time on our own dime.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

'Very pleasant spot'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

My husband and I stayed here overnight on a Saturday at the beginning of June. The staff members at check-in were pleasant and helpful. We had a king room in the Founders Cottage, which I gather is one of the newer buildings at the facility. Our room was huge. It was clean and very comfortable, and included two upholstered chairs, a desk, and a very large entry area with a sink, coffee maker and mini-frig. The bathroom was also quite big, with double sinks. We were in town to attend a wedding at a different site, so we didn't have occasion to eat at this hotel. We did have a drink in the tavern, which was nice but rather small. We didn't spend much time at the Cranwell and we didn't try out the main features of the resort (golf and spa), so that's why I only gave it 4 stars, but our overnight stay at the Founders Cottage was very pleasant.

Douglas S
Ridgefield, Connecticut, United States
1 review
'A very mixed bag... the price is high though.'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

We just go back from a family get together (4 rooms) at the Cranwell over Memorial Day weekend 2012. 2nd stay. Key points:
Th good:
Beautiful grounds and lovely location
GREAT massages and Spa facility. Very, very nice.
Nice staff - clearly overwhelmed.
Very nice chipping area for practice golf.
The pool was nice- and they turned on the heater for the second day.
One room had to be changed because of mouse droppings in the bathroom, sofa, etc.
One room had to be changed because the air conditioner didn't work.
The golf course was not up to muni course standards - let alone resort. Overgrown and not maintained except for the greens - nice looking but slow as mud.
The food was medicore - the breakfast buffet was a small step above a Hilton Garden Inn. Rangy bacon, french toast that had been there for hours (and hardened) overcooked omelettes were Bill's specialty - really? THAT brown? Yikes. Strawberries were not even clipped of their green leaves. Hopefully they were washed.
Dinner was basically banquet food- overcooked filet, killed salmon, etc. The salad was good though.
The tavern restaurant was better since last time I was there. Food and service improved from two stars to three on them.
Truthfully, if it wasn't for the great massage - would really have hated it.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

We're very sorry for the need to change rooms. Each concern was addressed immediately and we do hope you appreciated the consideration extended due to the inconvenience of having to move. We also hope the alternate rooms were comfortable for your visit. We will of course review your concerns relating to our food with our Executive Chef; we are always looking to satisfy all of our guests' individual preferences.

26 helpful votes 26 helpful votes
'Wonderful family getaway'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

Spent Memorial Day Weekend here as a surprise for my wife. We have two small children so we got a suite which was fantastic. Some notes:

Pros:

Suite was spacious, comfortable and clean. Sliding door between rooms makes it great for families. Loved the jacuzzi tub.

Grounds are beautiful (despite construction). Great place just to walk around for an hour or two.

Staff was very friendly.

Location! A lot of attractions for families, art lovers, antiquers, hikers etc. Great little restaurants in the area (we enjoyed a brunch at The Haven in Lenox)

Excellent food in Sloane's Tavern and the breakfast buffet.

Cons:

Housekeeping did not show up until 1:30pm, smack dab in the middle of my children's nap time.

The reservation person with whom I spoke was very rude and clueless.

Tips:

Search for rates on internet, can get a much better deal than calling.

We loved the Berkshire Museum and Hancock Shaker Village. Did not get to the Rockwell Museum, the wildlife land or Tanglewood, but they are on our list!
Less

ShazamBoston
Boston
Contributor
13 reviews 13 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
23 helpful votes 23 helpful votes
'Fantastic Experience in the Berkshires'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 21, 2012

My wife and I stayed at the Cranwell Resort to celebrate our anniversary and we had an amazing experience from beginning to end. Our room was in the Founders Cottage and was perfect, in between the spa, gym and indoor pool and the main restaurants. Big, clean and quiet, and had its own Keurig coffee brewer as well which we enjoyed. The grounds of the resort were immaculate and the customer service we experienced from everyone we encountered was top notch. When we checked in, we were given a voucher for a complimentary bottle of wine to enjoy at the restaurant which we appreciated! The spa was outstanding, and we both enjoyed the indoor pool, steam room, sauna and whirlpool. I tried the "head in the clouds" massage from Katie which was unbelievable, and my wife really enjoyed her swedish massage. The sandals, bathrobes and towels provided at the spa were a nice touch, and it was nice to be able to walk to and from your room with them.

We ate at all three restaurants and the food was excellent. We had lunch outside at Sloane's Tavern overlooking the golf course, and the burgers were fantastic. Dinner at Wyndhurst Restaurant in the historic mansion was perfect. There were only 14 or so tables in a very elegant room overlooking the Berkshire mountains, with quiet classical music playing in the background. I had quail stuffed with wild boar stuffing which was the best, and my wife had a crazy delicious salmon meal. We had a banana fosters bread chocolate bread pudding for desert which was also incredible. The host of the restaurant stopped by our table to talk about the history of the place which was very interesting. Finally the breakfast buffet in the Music Room the next day was also outstanding. Fresh fruit, cottage cheese, scrambled eggs, french toast, muffins, pastries, corn beef hash, hash browns and an omelet station.

This resort exceeded are high expectations, and we are looking forward to coming back in the future.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'Fabulous Service with passionate hosts'

2
people found this review helpful

We are a young couple from New York. We went up to the Berkshires for a short weekend getaway and were also attending the BSO performance at Tanglewood. We decided to stay at Wheatleigh for the first time. We were surprised to see the staff waiting at the driveway with a warm, welcome smile and who couldn't wait to welcome us inside. We had some welcome champagne at the back Terrace before heading to our room. The view was magnificent overlooking to the mountains and lake. This place is exactly what my husband and I wanted. It was so peaceful. The service was extremely personalized. The Front office agent offered us a tour of the property and also gave us a short orientation about the history of the Wheatleigh. Even though it was built in 1893 the interior and architectural design is modernistic. Especially for us, we love staying at a modern and up to fashion hotel which seems hard to find in the Berkshires. We also saw the fitness room and a wonderful wine cellar. There was a great collection of wines from around the world. We were even offered a wine tasting at the end of our tour. We were extremely happy and already enjoying our time here. The last thing we saw was the outdoor heated pool; again I could not believe there is such thing like Wheatleigh up here in the Berkshires. It was such a lovely setting. We requested for an Aromatherapy massage on Saturday by the pool and the hotel was kind enough to arrange for us at the last minute. Our room was a Junior suite on the 2nd floor overlooking the mountain sand the lake with a private covered balcony. We couldn't ask for more with the price we've paid. The room was equipped with a Bang& Olufsen entertainment system and a powermat for my Ipad and Black Berry. At first I couldn't understand how to use it but the agent noticed and immediately explained it to me. For dinner that evening we went down to the AAA 5 diamond awarded Dining room. We were greeted by the host from the stairway down to the great hall. We were laughing to each other and still can't believe these young people are so detail oriented and passionate about what they are doing. I noticed the entire staff was young but provided such an exceptional service. We had the seven course chef's tasting menu and were completely filled, but it was a delicious dinner. Throughout our stay we were completely spoiled; it was a memorable experience with prompt service. We will definitely return, let us hope our work gives us more days like this. Thank you to all for such a wonderful weekend.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Niramol G about Wheatleigh
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
mand0line
NYC, New York
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Peace and Rest'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 4, 2011
1
person found this review helpful

I have a soft spot for Wheatleigh. My husband and I make an annual pilgrimage to dine there, and recently stayed for the second time at the hotel. One certainly can be at peace here, a transformation that is sometimes instantaneous for me, sitting on deck chairs in one of the most enchantingly peaceful spots in the Berkshires, overlooking the Berks hills (not mountains, but pleasing nonetheless), and the massive trees found throughout the property. This is a quiet place that exudes elegance and historical substance and doesn't feel overly opulent despite the Italianate mansion aspect of the place, because of the spare, modern furnishings. (As an aside, if you haven't been and are comparing to Blantyre, the interiors are vastly different, so check out the photos carefully-- I think of Blantyre as a 'winter, cozy by fireside' spot, and a bit too gloomy for me for the summertime). I was grateful that we were upgraded when we arrived, given that it was our 20th anniversary, never take that sort of thing for granted, and found ourselves in a lovely room overlooking the courtyard fountain, and given some bubbly to celebrate. I can understand why some reviewers here would balk at the price. It is expensive, but that's why we just like to 'hang out' on the property and it feels worth it if that's how you like to spend your time away, without too many other people, if any, to contend with. There is also a lovely staff to welcome you and assist, and though some are 'newbies' they are earnest and sincere. You can literally walk to Tanglewood, for more lawns and massive trees, with music as an accompaniment. One word of advice-- I found that the main restaurant was closed midweek, and although we were able to eat in the library, the food was just not of the standard as the main restaurant, or perhaps I just felt the lack of choices on the prix fixe menu. The experience is decidedly different, and was not my idea of our grand 20th anniversary meal-- however, we have built up sufficient wonderful gastronomic memories there and nostalgia to have tossed off that particular dining experience. So if you are going for the 'total' experience, do make sure you can make a reservation in the main dining room, and that it is open.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask mand0line about Wheatleigh

'Be warned: Nasty to visitors.'
1 of 5 stars Reviewed August 1, 2011
5
people found this review helpful

We wanted to bring house guests to visit Wheatleigh for drinks on our way to Tanglewood. After calling the prior day, specifying the time of our visit and being assured of welcoming hospitality, we were coldly informed by a uniformed doorman that we should wait while he checked with the restaurant manager. A few minutes later, he returned to tell us that, "No one is available to serve us" and, "Sorry, but you must leave." You can imagine how embarrassed we were to be rudely turned away in front of friends -- especially when a couple seated nearby was enjoying drinks served by a waitress. Avoid this snooty place at all costs. Go to Blantyre or Cranwell.
Less

Yankee Inn

Scoots93
New Jersey
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'A Clean, Pleasant, Hotel for a Family Weekend Getaway'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We chose this hotel based on it's proximity to the Lenox area in the Berkshires; an area we hade never been to, but wanted to visit. The reviews were good and it was priced affordably, so we took a chance. The reason the place is affordable is that it sits a couple of miles outside Lenox, the more desired swanky little sister town with the cutesy shops. The hotel itself sits on Route 7, so you are not too isolated. But it turns out the place was perfect for a family of 4 with 2 five-year olds. The place was very clean, the staff was very pleasant, and the rooms were well insulated against hallway noise. There were 2 pools, so you can swim inside or out, and neither were crowded. The outdoor pool was colder, but the indoor pool features an skylighted roof, so it feels like you are outside. A nice bonus was the free continental breakfast. They offered everything from homemade waffles to fresh pastries. They even had made-to-order omelets on the weekends. Trust me, for some places, "free continental breakfast" equates to apples and some prepackaged Entemann's danishes. This was a fair deal. There isn't a ton of things to do for kids under 7, so you need to be a little creative, like picnicking at a nearby lake or going for ice cream. It should be noted we weren't looking for amusement parks and just wanted a clean place with a pool to chill out for a few days. If that is your bag, then the Yankee Inn is great choice.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

If you're looking for something more relaxing and upscale, there are numerous luxurious hotels/B&Bs that we've stayed at in the area but get pricey quickly...

'Nice Place to Stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 23, 2012

My husband and I stayed at the Yankee Inn for a weekend getaway in April 2012. The place is not fancy, but it is very pleasant and clean, and the price is reasonable. The hotel staff was very nice and helpful. Our room had a gas fireplace, which we didn't use since it was warm during our visit, and a balcony. We really enjoyed the indoor heated pool, and used it both nights of our visit. The hotel is very well located on Pittsfield Rd (Route 7), so you are on a major road in the Berkshires and close to pretty much everything in the area. We would definitely recommend the Yankee Inn, especially if you are looking to save some money.

'Great stay!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 17, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We chose the Yankee Inn based on other TripAdvisor reviews, and were very pleased with our two night stay. Located in Lenox, it was central to our needs. Just a short drive to Pittsfield or Lee for shopping, and, of course, the Norman Rockwell Museum. We stayed in a King bed room with a fireplace and balcony on the third floor of the main building, overlooking the pond and mountains. The room was very clean and the bed was one of the most comfortable we have encountered in our travels. Front desk staff were very courteous and most helpful in providing information about the local and surrounding area's dining and sightseeing locations. Given their reasonable rates, and great customer service, the Yankee Inn is clearly the place to stay.

'Happy surprise'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 12, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

On par with a Hampton Inn but as the Hampton Inn's seem to be aging, this hotel is staying crisply clean. We stayed in the HOTEL portion and not the motel which I cannot comment upon. Decor: typical, although the furnishings are a darker wood and not modern, it all looks as if it was purchased recently. (that is how impressed I am with the maintenance.) The room has a traditional tv cabinet and not a flat screen. The breakfast area, unlike a Hampton Inn, is not on the main floor but on the room floors in a large room set up exclusively as the eating room.

Positives: Friendly staff, clean, omelets made while you wait.
Negatives: pool smell when you enter the building, no enlargement mirror in bathroom, Poor water pressure (hand held shower helps make up for it so you can actually rinse the shampoo out of your hair.)

I was told that the rooms are about to be updated.
Less

'Berkshire Deal'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed March 4, 2012

We booked a last-minute overnight the beginning of March. Rooms were very clean and updated. Had a very comfortable King with a fireplace, spacious bathroom and small deck. Add the pool, hot tub and other amenities and you couldn't ask for anything more for $119/nt. The free continental breakfast was quite elaborate with a made to order omlette station, belgium waffle machine, plus the normal bagels, muffins, cereals, etc. The night was topped-off in the lounge with $8 top-shelf martinis served up by a wonderful bartender named Lucille.
The Inn is located just 15 minutes from several towns offering fine dinning, shopping, cultural events, skiing, etc.

Contributor

Reviews in 14 cities Reviews in 14 cities
11 helpful votes 11 helpful votes
'You get what you pay for'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

We took a motorcycle trip from Florida to Boston this was one of our stops along the way. We initially were placed in room 114. Since it was a warm day we turned on the A/C when we entered the room. It sounded like a diesel truck running. It was an old unit so we tried to see if it was just the casing or cover but neither seemed to be the cause. When the compressor shut off the sound would stop. There were also flies in the room and it had a musty smell to it. We gave the A/C a half hour or so to see if it would quiet down but it didn't. I asked the hotel clerk if we could get another room explaining about the A/C noise. He told me he has had no complaints and we need to adjust the front cover of the A/C and it would quiet down. I explained to him that we tried that and it did not improve. So after much pushing he acquiesced and gave us another room. We ended up in room 104. The A/C unit was newer and much quieter. There were no flies or bad smells. Good size room with an ok bed. There were not enough pillows or blankets. The bathroom was small but clean. The TV was old but large and functioning. The pool was closed and we could see the liner was all torn up so it didn't look like it had been open in a long time yet the billboard out front still advertised a pool. It also advertised HBO but the HBO was not working.
Less

'Great place to stay in the Berkshires'

We stayed here for a week and liked it so much that we bought a week. Excellent location, quiet yet close to Lenox, Stockbridge and Pittsfield. Layout is very good, particularly the two bedroom units. Second bedrooms have isolation and private bath. Couches mentioned in other reviews have been replaced. Staff was energetic and responsive. Plenty of hot water and strong water pressure insure a delightful shower. Nice indoor pool, tennis courts, bicycles, paddle boat. Comfortable and relaxing!

3
people found this review helpful

We stayed here last weekend in a 2-bedroom unit to use it as home base for a weekend trip to Butternut. While the unit is technically a sleep-6, we actually had a dozen people (6 adults and 6 children). The unit has 1 bedroom on the first floor, along with a sleeper sofa in the living room; upstairs is another sleeper sofa and a second bedroom. There was plenty of room for everyone since most of the children slept in sleeping bags. Other reviews are correct that the units are dated. However, we found it to be clean, which is most important. The place is a 15 minute drive to Butternut, which is very convenient. The clubhouse has an indoor pool, which the children enjoyed. Wi-fi in the units (unsecured). A few recommendations if you are going to stay here...First, the units have a fireplace in which you are allowed to burn only artificial logs - they sell small 2-hour logs at the front desk for $3 apiece, but you could probably bring better ones to save a little money. Secondly, while the clubhouse provides pool towels, they are small so you may want to bring your own. Lastly, my wife found the sheets to be of low quality - if you want to improve your experience, you may want to bring your own sheets. Overall, we enjoyed our stay and would certainly return for another ski weekend.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask howdog14 about The Ponds at Foxhollow

Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Beautiful Grounds, Decent Unit'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed August 23, 2011
3
people found this review helpful

The historic site with its beautiful grounds makes for a wonderful environment. The outdoor pool was lovely, there was a majestic heron sitting on the pond at one point, and we took a walk along Laurel Lake (you have to exit the property to access a laneway down). The units themselves have excellent layout and a clean, well-stocked kitchen (but bring your own supplies, including aluminum foil, etc.) and rooms. Furniture and carpet are dated but clean, bathroom needs a reno but is clean. This place could use a lesson in customer service -- tiny frustrations detract from the pleasure of the stay. E.g., no shampoo in the rooms, and the nearest store requires a trip in the car. Newspaper is not free. We would stay here again as a couple, and would recommend it for young children as there's lots to do. However, older teens may find it dull -- the amenities close at 9:00PM.
Less

svetich
New Jersey
1 review
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Wonderful trip to the Berkshires'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 18, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

In planning our trip to the Berkshires, we were looking for a family-oriented place to stay that would be close to major attractions, yet secluded enough to give us some alone time with our new baby (who, heading into the Memorial Day weekend, was only 4 months old). The Ponds at Foxhollow perfectly fit our needs  it was only 5 minutes away from one of the major attractions in the area  the Edith Wharton estate  as well as only 10 minutes away from both Tanglewood and the town of Lenox, which we had always heard was one of the best towns in the Berkshires. (Hint: the Canyon Ranch Spa  typically ranked among the best spas in the nation - is in Lenox)

Foxhollow  which was apparently a former retreat for scions of the great New York City families back in the day (i.e. folks like Edith Wharton)  did not disappoint. We had a two-room condo with a private backyard patio that had a view of a private lake. Within the Foxhollow complex, there was also a pool, a health club and tennis courts, not to mention trails for walking. Foxhollow is itself set far back from the road, and bordered by hedges, trees, and a long, winding path accessible by both car and bike. We loved this privacy and seclusion  but if you're planning on walking to a restaurant  or even to a grocery  late at night you'll be out of luck. You'll need to hop in your car and hit one of the nearby towns  the drive isn't bad at all, but we definitely stocked up on our arrival night with food and beverages.

For a relaxing, scenic stay in the Berkshires, I would readily recommend Foxhollow. The booking system is not Web-enabled, and that gave us cause for concern before arriving, but the staff was extremely helpful (even offering to help us assemble our borrowed baby travel crib). All the amenities were modern, but the charm and feeling of the place hearkened back to an Age of Innocence.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask svetich about The Ponds at Foxhollow

I would NEVER stay there again, nor would I recommend it to anyone. I think you would get better service at the Quaiity Inn down the street. Maybe the Gen Manager Ed, should watch the movie 'Give them the Pickle' . Its all about customer service!!!!!!

Fredonian
Fredonia, New York
Top Contributor
50 reviews 50 reviews
Reviews in 22 cities Reviews in 22 cities
36 helpful votes 36 helpful votes
'A fine choice in an excellent location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 13, 2011
3
people found this review helpful

We very much like the Ponds and stay there at least once a year--and we're looking forward to spending more weeks there in the future.

The Ponds consists of two types of units--the Westinghouse units are on the ground floor and sleep up to four. The Vanderbilt units are on the second and third floors and sleep up to six (two bedrooms sleeping two each and the sleeper couch in the living room). Those names fit because the property was once the vacation home of those famous families.

The rooms are spacious and although the counter space in the kitchen area is limited, these are the most fully equipped kitchens we've ever experienced in a timeshare.

The grounds are attractive, especially the "ponds" themselves on which it is possible to row or use a paddleboat. The clubhouse is strikingly beautiful.

The resort did have problems with high speed internet access, but that's been completely resolved and the service is now excellent.

The units are attractive, well appointed and clean, but some aspects of maintenance could be better. For example, the threshold to outside doors may be a bit worn and in the unit we were in the "fit and finish" on a Jacuzzi tub would have been better if finished off with some molding between the tub and the wall.

Lenox is a great location for a wide range of activities throughout the entire year. There are any number of historic properties to visit and during the summer there are a full range of cultural attractions in Lenox (Tanglewood and a Shakespeare program). Edith Wharton's "The Mount" adjoins the Ponds. The Normal Rockwell Museum and Chesterwood (where the model for the Lincoln Memorial in Washington, D.C. was crafted) is in nearby West Stockbridge. The Hancock Shaker Village is just a few miles away in Pittsfield along with the home in which Herman Melville wrote "Moby Dick."

Lots of stunning scenery and, of course, during the fall, this is a prime jumping off place to view the foliage and during the winter there is easy access to a number of ski resorts.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

'Not bad'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 20, 2012

I was recently at a conference and the conference hotel was sold out for the last night. I called Marriott reservations to make a reservation at another property, which was within walking distance from the conference hotel. Other conference attendees were staying at this property. The agent advised me that this property was booked, but the Residence Inn was right across the street. He went on to say that the hotels shared the same parking lot. After checking out of the first hotel, I told the cab driver that he must have taken me to the wrong hotel because this hotel was not walking distance. Well, I was at the right hotel and the reservation agent lied. The front desk person confirmed that I was not given accurate information. I was pressed for time so I checked in to the hotel anyway. My experience at the property was pretty good. The members of the staff were very friendly. My room was clean and spacious. The hotel decor was somewhat dated. However, the breakfast was excellent. Although my bill was credited for one cab ride, I am still very unhappy with Marriott reservations. I skipped the last day of the conference because I did not want to spend additional money on cab fare. I would rather that they not provide any information, if it is going to be inaccurate. However, I am basing my rating on the hotel property, not reservations.

ResortMeg
NJ
Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'Great location, great staff--we will be back!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 17, 2012

Family and I stayed here for a graduation celebration for 6 nights and very much enjoyed our stay. The rooms were a little smaller than expected but beds were excellent and it was nice to have our own kitchen area. One room was a 1 bedroom suite, the other was a standard room...if you are looking to save a little on cost the standard and 1 bedroom are not all that different except that you can shut the door to the bedroom in the suite for watching tv/sleeping on the couch. Also, a tip, though we did not encounter a problem, if you need quiet to sleep ask for a room that faces the courtyard rather than the street. Location is great--you can walk to great restaurants and Rodeo Drive and the hotel offers a free shuttle within 3 miles. Restaurant Row is also a short cab ride away. Staff was SO pleasant, helpful, and kind--there was no LA attitude here! From check-in to breakfast to check-out to cab service we could not have asked for more attentive staff to assist in making our trip enjoyable and it was so nice to hear "have a nice day!" or "welcome back" after a long day! The small gym was also great with nice, new equipment for vacation workouts. We were thrilled by the great breakfast offered daily with many choices--eggs, breakfast burritos, french toast/pancakes, a waffle maker, coffee, juice, omelette station, yogurt, fruit, etc. It was really excellent and a great cost saver not having to spend $ on breakfast each day. There is also a lobby bar that serves CA wines in the evening which was a nice surprise and Mon-Wed there are appetizers offered in the lobby area. The only thing that would have made the stay perfect is if there was an outdoor pool to enjoy the CA sunshine! We had an excellent stay and would definitely stay at this property again on our next trip to LA--highly recommend!
Less

FeliciaPhiladelphia
Philadelphia
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
'Replacement Hotel for Us'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

When our original hotel cancelled two nights ahead of our scheduled trip, Days Inn was our replacement hotel. The staff was nice enough, but there were several disappointing issues: We booked two rooms for our large family and they initially tried to put us on opposite sides of the hotel. Easily fixed, but when they gave us rooms right next to one another, one was smaller and smelled very musty, and yet it had a huge tv whereas the cleaner smelling room had a small tv.

The decor was modest and old fashioned, but the room was attended to every day and cleaned by excellent staff. The AC made a lot of noise and kept shutting off. There was no internet in the room, and going to the lobby was not a solid option as it is is very hot there and limited outlets to plug in a laptop; if you needed to work in the am, which I did, the eating/lobby area is too congested and not conducive to getting on internet. The waffle, muffin, bagel breakfast was okay--waffles were the best, but the staff did not keep the area clean enough and if you put your styrofoam plate down, it might come up sticky. Syrup was generic, muffins cold and kind of stale, toaster completely broken, juice machine pumped hot liquid, tea bags were stale and the layout was not conducive for even 12 people to be able to eat; unless they were comfortable sharing tables or knew one another, very few people remained after grabbing a breaded something to eat. Whilst there were apples, which we very good, they were also warm and that was a little disappointing.

The worst part was the shower head that was not positioned above my head and hit my face or neck intsead, and not being able to utilize the pool, which was why I agreed to take this replacement location. We had limited money due to an unexpected emergency before leaving home, so we had to plan our days carefully. We anticipated being able to get on internet in the evening or am and also to swim whilst not seeing a local site--no such luck, which was very frustrating as the temperatures grew quite warm at times, and my young daughter became unquestionably uncomfortable and bored.

Being in the room was okay, but not comfortable for sleeping or extended periods of time, and when we tried to have dinner in the room, we had to bring in two chairs from the adjacent room and it was just ridiculously crowded.

No conditioner or monetary aids were offered other than a mini shampoo and mini soap--not enough for one person for the amount of days we stayed, but luckily we always bring our own and there was a sign stating that if you needed something the hotel would help you get it--this meant giving directions to the local market.

Overall, for the price and location, safety was okay and it was clean enough for us to make our own fun and feel safe leaving our things whilst we toured--would prefer a better place on next travel venture though.

If you only need a quick place that is safe, quiet, and no frills for a cheap price--this is the place.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 2 more reviews by FeliciaPhiladelphia for Lenox

Cyndy265
Ossining
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
8 helpful votes 8 helpful votes
'Beautiful & Comfortable-A Great Value'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 25, 2011
7
people found this review helpful

I stayed at this motel for 2 nights over Labor Day. It is located between the towns of Lenox and Pittsfield MA, but close to the tourist towns of Lee and Stockbridge. The setting is lovely, off the road on a hill, spacious grounds with a pool and a picnic area. There is a mountain view from the parking lot. The room was large, clean and comfortable, very quiet sleeping. The hotel is an easy drive to the many attractions in the area, but the country setting provides a peaceful retreat from the busyness of the tourist towns. One must drive for meals, but the on-site breakfast is good and several restaurants will deliver meals. I was tired on my arrival and the desk clerk suggested I try one. I did and the meal was delicious.
The room had microwave, refridgerator and coffee maker so it is possible to do light meals on your own. All in all very comfortable and a very good value. I will be visiting this area in the future and will choose this motel again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
PSKZ
New York City, New York
Senior Reviewer
10 reviews 10 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Basic, no frills, good for a stop over'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed April 8, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I stopped here for a night when passing through. What you get is exactly what they say. A bed, a fridge, TV, WiFi, a bathroom, and that's about it.

There's no microwave nor is there in-room coffee - and that's as advertised. There is coffee in the office but it's that slightly dark-brown warm water that comes out of a pot marked coffee but doesn't actually taste much of coffee, or anything. Someone else mentioned the paper-thin walls. Oh yes, you most certainly can hear the conversations of your neighbors.

On the downside, the extractor fan in the bathroom rattled so much that it sounded like a jumbo jet so I was thankful for the ability to turn on the light by the bathroom mirror. The sheets on my bed were somewhat rough to; perhaps over-bleached, perhaps just cheap. Again, this is a budget motel and if you're expecting more then you'd be in the wrong market segment.

If you are simply looking for a bed for the night, then this is a viable option. If you prefer your comforts and a little more style, then you might want to pay a little extra and move up-market instead.

Would I come back? Maybe.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

pm_luluus
Boston, Massachusetts
Reviewer
5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
'"You Get What You Pay For" Comes to Mind'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed February 22, 2012

I rated the Lenox Inn three stars solely based on its affordable rates and the bang-for-buck factor. The "you get what you pay for" expression comes to mind.

Don't come to this motel if you're a germaphobe because the place wouldn't pass your standards. The room's odor alone will knock you off your feet.

Also, don't stay here if you care at all that others can hear your in-room conversations and activities--yes, all of them! The walls are so paper thin that my niece, staying in the adjoining room, was able to recite word-for-word what I'd been talking about.
Less

university1traveler
State College, Pennsylvania
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
'wouldn't stay again'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed December 16, 2011

I'm submitting this review because in my experience this week the motel is highly overrated on all of the sites I checked. The stay wasn't a disaster, but I wouldn't want to repeat it. The place isn't very clean--during my usual bedbug check, I discovered lots of uncleaned corners, including lots of hair and dirt between the mattress and bedspring on the bedspring cover, which looked like it hadn't been washed in ages. There was also hair on the back of the toilet. The room smelled like chemical air fresheners. The motel rooms are very near a busy road and the sound of passing cars was constant throughout the night (as were sounds from people in the room next door). The proprietor kept talking on the phone while checking me in, and couldn't be bothered to recommend a local restaurant. Also, there was no latch on the inside of the door to the room, which generally makes me feel less safe. I really don't understand the good reviews that have been written!
Less

'Good Value...good stay..'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed October 30, 2011

For $50 and the name "wagon wheel, with a white cement horse out front, we were sceptical ... I have never stayed in a motel this "cheap"... but after reading trip advisor reviews we decided to give it a try.

It was fine...room was clean, king size bed was very comfortable. TV was old..but had cable, -- nothing fancy. Staff was friendly ... I went to the small office for coffee a little late, the manager said he would brew me some...called my room it 5 minutes for coffee. Next door is a very good Irish pub and some shopping across street and a wine store within a block.

We would stay again... a great stop-over on a trip.

Amanda W
Worcester, Massachusetts
1 review
'Not as Bad as you might think...'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed October 5, 2011

When I was looking for a room in the area, I was astonished at the expensive rates at similar hotels in the vicinity. The Wagon Wheel was 60 dollars, and was incredibly worth the cost. The room we got (king size) was well cleaned, nicely furnished and exactly what we were looking for. The hotel is very close to several restaurants within walking distance, close to attractions like Arrowhead, The Mount, et cetera as well as Pittsfield and southern Berkshire County. If you looking for pomp and frills you probably won't like this hotel - but it's a terrific place for a good deal.

'Well, it IS CHEAP! But, that is about all I can say'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed August 16, 2011

OK, maybe the location is wonderful, for all the Berkshire sights and sounds. But, it is a really down and out motel from the old days. Complete with a replica of Roy Roger's horse in the front.... well, maybe it wasn't Trigger, but it could have been. There is fresh paint around the place. The clientele seem to working stiffs and cheap vacationers. This is the sort of motel that often houses "homeless" people... but, I saw little evidence of that sort of thing. The rooms were clean and tacky decor abounds. Even though it is on a major thoroughfare... the room we had at the back wasn't noisy. I would be cautious with security issues. Use your common sense.

SMH3
Toronto
1 review
'Absolutely Fabulous!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed July 30, 2009

This is a charming, quaint motel -- clean, attractive. An extremely kind family runs the place, so you get a very at-home feeling here. I stayed for three nights, and was happy here the entire time. The bed was comfy and I slept really well. I'm happy to say the windows are like windows in a real house -- they open! There are lots of restaurants nearby, all within walking distance, as well as one of the nicest grocery stores I have ever been in called Guido's (a five-minute walk). A Chinese restaurant and a Friendly's, a CVS and a Price Chopper are just across the road. I could easily have stayed here longer. Also: I spent almost the entire two days in my room (was finishing some work) and I didn't feel claustrophobic at all. The rooms smell nice, too. (Microwave, TV, small fridge included.)

Less

Winterstime
Annapolis, Maryland
Senior Contributor
45 reviews 45 reviews
Reviews in 21 cities Reviews in 21 cities
14 helpful votes 14 helpful votes
'Comfortable, well located, inexpensive'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed January 18, 2012
4
people found this review helpful

Visited the Berkshires during January 2012. Off season, it was a delight to see the mountains, during a beautiful snow event, with the luxury of NO CROWDS! The Econo Lodge is well located and only 10 minutes from almost anything you want to do in this area, including the Norman Rockwell museum, Kirpalu, and lots of hiking. The rates were dirt cheap.

The room had a micro wave and little fridge. The wifi signal was to weak in our room, #137, so NO INTERNET access. The room was clean and no frills. While it had everything we needed it was badly out of date. The beds were passably comfortable, but very old. There was junk in the hallways by the ice machine.

The hotel staff was nice enough.

While I was comfortable enough in the hotel and very much enjoyed the trip to Berkshires, I would have to say this hotel is a clean dive. The no wifi is a concern.
Less

Jacquelyn C
Boston, Massachusetts, United States
1 review
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Great hospitality'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 4, 2011
1
person found this review helpful

My experience was I was stranded in Lenox in a horrible snowstorm and could not find a place to stay because I was traveling with 2 cats.

I finally saw a bright Econo Lodge sign and stopped the car at the foot of the driveway - I wasn't sure I could drive the car up the hill, and the snow was falling so fast I couldn't see anything. I finally reached the lobby, shaking from the cold and fear of driving on glare ice for hours. I confessed to having cats, but the man at the desk just said "I will help you." I almost cried. He offered to drive my car up the hill, gave me a room on a courtyard away from the wind, and actually unloaded my bags from the car, cats and all.

There were other stranded travelers there that night, and the next morning there was a nice breakfast (free) in a diningroom with waffles, juice, pastries and hot coffee. It was wonderful.

I can't thank Econo Lodge enough. The room was very clean, with a great TV.

I would definitely stay there again -- on a vacation next time I hope.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Jacquelyn C about Econo Lodge Lenox
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

'Amazing Grace at Liberty Hill Inn'

The loss of my 89 year old mother brought my entire family of 12, plus many more friends and extended family, to Yarmouthport in January 2012. We were most fortunate to be able to have the graciousness of the entire Liberty Hill Inn plus the Guest House for a long week-end. John was alone as Kris was in the East visiting family. His generosity, consideration, flexibility and kindness were shining examples of "Grace under pressure." He provided for us, he tended to us, he overextended himself and he made us feel as though we were home basking in the warmth of our own homes. Words cannot express my and my families heartfelt appreciation for all of his understanding and support. We have been frequent visitors to this charming Inn and I can heartily endorse every aspect of hospitality extended by the Inn Keepers...Impeccably clean, outstanding food, and especially the cookie jar by the front door! Super Service!! We look forward to our next visit.

nezzie
