Senior Contributor
32 reviews 32 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
16 helpful votes 16 helpful votes
'A lovely B&B in Lenox - it deserves its' high ratings!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I spent Mother's Day weekend at this lovely B&B. We've been to Lenox 50 times at least over the years, and never stayed here. But we've stayed at many other Lenox B&B's so I think we have a good sense of comparison. We stayed in Room #1 in the main house. For those not used to old B&B's, this is an OLD house (think 18th c.) so don't expect the W Hotel. Rooms can be funky and ceilings low and bathrooms small. If you understand antique houses, you'll be happier. That being said, the bed was COMFORTABLE - something we never take forgranted anymore and have, in fact, stopped going to several B&B's because they don't understand that charm isn't everything - sleeping is important also! Both the terrific breakfast and the gorgeous grounds make this place heavenly. Walking into town is a delight. The innkeepers are helpful as can be and the chocolate chip cookies are lethal! Try it. You'll like it!
Less

ClarissaM
New York City, New York
Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews
Reviews in 12 cities Reviews in 12 cities
21 helpful votes 21 helpful votes
'Sweet Stay at the Garden Gables Inn'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 12, 2012
5
people found this review helpful

My husband and I stayed here in February. It's a wonderful inn, and Denise is the best innkeeper. She's friendly and welcoming and at the same time, gives you your space - and to top it off, she's an excellent chef! Because it was a long drive for us, I booked us the 'chef's table' at the Inn for our first night's dinner and I'm so happy I did, dinner was delicious! My husband had to refrain from licking his plate - and the dessert was a perfect sweet ending: homemade lemon pound cake with fresh whipped cream, lemon curd and berries.

I would absolutely stay here again. The only negatives during our stay were:

We stayed in a large room (#15) but the bathroom could use a little sprucing up. I assumed the 'whirlpool' tub would be a large tub but it's just a regular tub with whirlpool jets and the bathroom is so dark, I really didn't feel like soaking. It could use a little renovating.

Also my husband and I booked massages, and (unfortunately I can not remember the name of the man who was our massage therapist) but hands-down the WORST massage either of us has ever had! I get massages often, I was surprised that I wasn't told or asked upon booking if a male masseuse would be okay with me (kinda not) and when I was chatting with him, I asked "how long have you been doing massage" and he said 7 years. There's just no way this guy has been a professional massage therapist for 7 years. He used almost no pressure, even though I kept saying "you can use more pressure"; there was no skill or technique or type of style (swedish, shiatsu, etc) and I kept waiting for him to get started but in the end it was just a really annoying, disappointing experience - waste of time and money. My husband was equally underwhelmed with his massage. So just a head's up.
Less

My husband and I's recent vacation in Lenox will always be memorable due to our stay at the Garden Gables Inn. The owner, John greeted us with a warm welcome and a helping hand with our bags. Denise, the innkeeper provided for a comfortable stay with pampering as if we were staying in a family member's home. Being a french trained chef, Denise served us amazing breakfasts and the BEST EVER chocolate chip cookies! The inn itself is beautiful and we very much enjoyed our fireplace room while laying in bed looking out at falling snow. We looked forward to coming home in the evenings and sipping the Harney and Sons teas offered. Lenox is a charming town and the local dining was excellent! Denise's recommendation for a special dinner at the Old Inn on the Green was wonderful. It was a step back in time, a former stagecoach relay, and unique experience to dine by fireside and cande light with no electricity in the dining rooms. We will never forget our memorable week in the Berkshires and will definitely return to the Garden Gables!

1 review
'A+ B&B! Great Hosts and Accommodations!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 13, 2012 NEW

We could not have been happier with our stay at The King's Inne! We had never stayed at a B&B and were not sure what to expect. Paul and Carina were wonderful hosts. They were warm, friendly, and informative.

The description 'Old English' on the website fits this place perfectly. Very cute. The landscaping on the grounds is so lovely, it looks like a post card. The Kensington Suite was very up to date, while keeping the cozy old fashioned feel you look for in a B&B. The layout was very roomy. Perfect room for women to get ready ingreat lighting, multiple outlets, awesome vanity.

We were a bit nervous about the cat, being an allergic couple, but we had absolutely no issues. We would definitely go back.

1 review
'Truly the best B & B'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

I have stayed in B and B's in Europe and in the US, and the King's Inne is one of the nicest, if not the nicest I have ever stayed in. Carina and Paul are wonderful hosts and more than accommodating. The rooms were all tastefully appointed, and the bedding in the room we stayed in was unbelievable. It was hard to get out of bed in the morning! The breakfasts that Paul prepared were gourmet, very filling with a presentation so wonderful you hesitated before diving in. The setting surrounding the King's Inn is beautiful with walks immediately outside the door that are the ultimate Cape Cod experience- the ocean with salt marshes, beautiful trees and flowers, wonderful old style Cape Cod homes, a quaint thatched roof barn, not to mention the beautiful gardens that Paul has created on the grounds of the King's Inne. I can't say enough about how fantastic our stay was, and we so look forward to returning to the King's Inne.

opuntus
New York City, New York
Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
14 helpful votes 14 helpful votes
'A MUST STAY B&B on Cape Cod - Simply THE BEST!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 9, 2012 NEW

After a long and painful research on TA, I ended up calling the owners of King's Inne (thanks to all wonderful reviews!). Once I have heard Paul's kind and full of British accent voice answering all my questions with confidence and patience (I asked some silly ones, I am sure) -> I was charmed and assured that my special weekend (it was my hubby's birthday) will be spent at exactly this B&B on Cape Cod.

And how RIGHT I WAS!! We arrived on Friday, when the weather was as perfect as it gets, and Paul was waiting for us in front of the house, as if we were old friends and he was excitedly waiting for our arrival. The garden was shining in its perfect shape welcoming us too. Then a beautiful smiling lady, Carina, with the same charming British accent came downstairs to greet us and show us around. We all were chatting as if we knew each other for at least 10 years!

The house is a historical property on the historical route 6A - that is already a jewel by itself, but once we walked in, our breath was taken away: every solid detail of old school British culture mixed with New England charms was present in this house and we felt welcomed fully.

It was supposed to be raining on Saturday and Paul kindly advised us on our plans adjustments for Friday and Saturday- and we were grateful as the rain came down on Saturday indeed. Carina was advising on where to go to feel "local" sense of Cape Cod, what not to miss and where to dine... Simply unbelievable hospitality and welcome! I do not recall such personal attention and participation anywhere - and we travel a lot!

The room was spacious and spotless, the bed was as comfortable as it gets, the decor was rich, solid and to our taste. We stayed in Kensington room upstairs and enjoyed every single detail of it. The colors were so pleasant that we were waking up smiling every morning. My favorite part of the room was the old school beautiful bath-tab - one can never get enough relaxation while taking it ! Highly recommended room indeed and those little details are to die for !

Breakfasts - yam - so tasty and so big that we could not resist those homemade blueberry muffins and absolutely melting in mouth egg benedicts. We were looking forward to our breakfasts every morning! And the 'sun-rise' drink  simply great!

We will be back - surely! And we keep on recommending to our friends to go too! In fact we did not want to leave on Sunday, when we felt three days were too short and we need at least a week to enjoy the King's and the Cape.

We cannot have enough words to thank Paul and Carina - the best innkeepers we have ever met! Thank you and all the very best to you and the greatest success to the Inne!

Olga and Joseph

Less

BullyLover2
Darnestown, MD
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Great B&B on Cape Cod'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

Via a strange route I found the King's Inne. At 6'5" tall my husband requires a king size bed. I had no idea how difficult it would be to find one on Cape Cod. But with a lot of research and help from Trip Advisor I was able to find the King's Inne and oh what a find! Paul and Carina are hosting the most wonderful B&B on the Cape. Paul calls himself a cook but he really is a chef in disguise. He makes the most amazing breakfasts ever. His morning fruit plate is so beautiful that you don't really want to eat it but are forced to because it looks so tasty. He makes a blueberry muffin to die for; if I were a blueberry this is the way I would want to go. He really knows how to cook bacon and his egg dishes are just wonderful. We stayed there for 6 nights and each breakfast was a treat. Carina is a wonderful hostess and is just full of information about the area. She was a big help as we tried to pack in as much sight seeing as possible while we were on the Cape. When she suggests a town or restaurant you need to listen to her. The room we had was just lovely and certainly a place where you can relax and wind down after a busy day. They have a lovely little closet in the dining room where water and drinks can be found (we're big H2O fans) around the clock. They also have umbrellas on the ready should the weather not be as accommodating as it was for us. Paul and Carina maintain a beautiful garden and I learned a lot from Paul on the care and feeding of plants and flowers. The B&B is small (only 3 rooms) which means a lot of individual attention (if you want it). We met some very interesting people while we were there. The Inne is centrally located so we had no problem getting to either the upper or lower Cape; Nantucket or Martha's Vineyard. They are a 5-10 minute drive to Hyannis where you can catch ferries to the islands. If you are on the Cape, please do not hesitate to stay with Paul and Carina, it will be a stay you won't forget!
Less

Joshua K
New York, New York, United States
1 review
'Beautiful B&B, Great Location in Cape Cod'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

We stayed at the Blushing Oyster B&B during Memorial Day weekend, 2012. It was our first trip to Cape Cod and we picked a perfect central location. It was very easy to get around and explore the nearby towns and beaches. Our host, Jim, was warm and welcoming. He gave us great local advice and let us borrow beach chairs, which were put to good use!

The Inn was clean and well cared for. We stayed in the Blue Point room which was private and beautifully decorated. Breakfast was served outdoors on the patio overlooking the garden blooming with fresh flowers. We enjoyed Greek yogurt with fresh fruit and home made granola, and a delicious egg souffle with tomato and goat cheese. A great start to the day!

After spending a day on the beach in nearby Wellfleet, we returned to our room and were delighted to find a bottle of chardonnay on ice waiting for us -- that was a perfect touch!

I highly recommend the Blushing Oyster Inn and would definitely stay there again.

ldyplantagenet
Atlanta, Georgia
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Gorgeous place to stay: highly recommend'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 19, 2011

Even though we own a cottage and a house on the Cape and we have lots of family here we could stay with, I wanted a B&B experience for my birthday. My husband made a very good choice in the Blushing Oyster. I was thrilled! I am very picky and already know a lot about the Cape. Some places on the Cape (especially cottages and hotels) have terrible beds and furniture and smell like mold and mildew. A B&B is the way to go and this one is especially nice. The home is beautifully restored/decorated and they have kept some very authentic Cape Cod touches. While having some modern luxuries (comfy bed, fluffy towels, modern bath, etc.) and beautiful decor, you still have the feel of a period house. We had a suite on the main floor which was spacious and had an electric fireplace and also a huge tub (Wellfleet). We stayed during the week and people who live on the Cape need to go to work so 6A can be a busy road even in November. It did not keep us from sleeping--just something to note if you are a very light sleeper and want to sleep in during the week- you may wish to choose a room on the back of the house. We are early risers, so not an issue for us. All of their rooms are lovely so whichever one you pick, you just can't go wrong. We had a sitting area where we could work on our computer and watch TV. I borrowed a book from their library and read it, which was fun. They also have movies you can watch. I read a review of his B&B here that said the staircase is a bit steep. Steep staircases are authentic to Cape houses. This staircase is not as steep as most houses I've visited on the Cape--so disregard that person's comment unless you have some kind of physical disability, in which case just stay on the main floor at any Cape house. You really want to have the real, authentic Cape Cod experience as part of your trip to the Cape so enjoy the stairs as part of that. Breakfast was delicious each day (we really loved the sweet potato pancakes and also the baked pear!) and the coffee was very good. Jim was a lot of fun to visit with. Sue is a sweetheart. The stay at the B&B was a surprise for me so I did not book and had not read the policies. My husband worked in the hotel industry for years and didn't realize we needed to be timely for check in or else call. Even though we disregarded a policy (whoops!), Sue was very sweet when we checked in. We felt badly about it, but they were very nice and accomodating. We stayed in November during very misty, chilly weather and the inn was warm, charming and a wonderful place to come to at night. Each room has its own temperature control, which is not the norm on the Cape and you will enjoy being in control of your room temp. when staying here. By the way, the Cape is a great getaway in November. It's quiet, there is no traffic and you can see a lot more in less time. Many places are closed, but some great shops and places to eat are still open. People who don't come to the Cape in the fall and at Christmas time are missing out. It's not just for summer anymore. Even though we live where it is warm and lovely in November, we come every year in November for my birthday getaway and are now thinking about adding December to our yearly pilgrimages. My best friend and I are coming back to the Cape for a girl's weekend in April, as well. We would definitely stay at this property again. Enjoy!

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

1 review
'Cape Cod Treasure'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 4, 2012

This is just the most perfect Bed and Breakfast ever, full of charm and warmth. Brian is a wonderful and helpful host, upon checking in he takes time to sit down with you and after asking what you want to do goes over a map showing you where things are located and providing useful information on "must does" that you might not have been aware of. His breakfasts are delicious and huge, he is a 5 starl cook. The lemon zest pancakes are to die for.You feel you are visiting an old friend. There are several common areas and a library full of wonderful books and Cape Cod resources. The rooms each have their own personality, and coziness. My favorite the Yarmouth with a 4 poster, huge bathroom and a jacuzzi . The Crook jaw is perfectly located easy to all Cap Cod attaractions and as a bonus in walking distance from the Yarmouth Inn , an excellent restaurant. You can't go wrong choosing to stay here. I was with friends from the UK and they loved it too.

'Breakfast was fantastic'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 20, 2011

This was our first visit to Cape Cod and we spent 3 nights at Crook Jaw Inn with close friends. Our room (Sea Breeze) was extremely comfortable, bathroom small but very good shower. Brian is the perfect host. My partner is a fussy eater and Brian couldn't have been more helpful in providing him the breakfast he wanted. We were too full to eat the daily home baked muffins, but Brian packaged them up and we ate them during the days exploring Cape Cod. Brian was full of great advice about restaurants and places to visit and as the previous reviewer has already said a born B & B owner. Crook Jaw is a lovely home, where we felt extremely comfortable coming back from a long day, watching one of many DVDs in the spacious lounge area or sitting in the garden reading our books. Perfectly located in Yarmouth for visiting all areas nearby. If we ever get back to the Cape would have no hesitation in staying with Brian at Crook Jaw Inn again. Thank you Brian for making our first visit to Cape Cod so enjoyable.

KMaven
2 reviews
'Great breakfast, service, and central location.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 21, 2011 via mobile

We stayed here for 3 nights as a little getaway from the daily grind. Upon arrival, we were greeted warmly and offered lots of great tips for our stay (where to eat, beach, etc.). Daily breakfasts were enormous and absolutely delicious. There is a large common area, as well as a tv room/library, and we relaxed in the common space on the first night over a bottle of wine. The place is adorable and has all of the charm you could hope for in a New England B&B.

We had the room with the jacuzzi-wouldn't recommend the extra expense, as the tub is tiny and for one person only. The bed in that particular room also has very creaky posts and is right next to the common area...you see where I am going.

The Crook Jaw is right across from a great restaurant called the Old Yarmouth Inn. Delicious seafood, and you can get a little toasted and walk back to the Inn.

We would for sure stay again.
Less

pjsharad
Mankato, Minnesota
Contributor
14 reviews 14 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
12 helpful votes 12 helpful votes
'A quaint Cape Cod experience'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 7, 2011

Just got back from our 5 night stay at this B&B run by Brian. The moment we checked in Brian was a most hospitable host, recommending sites to see and places to eat. Never having been to the Cape we found his suggestions to be most helpful. I was glad I decided to choose the location of Yarmouth Port as our home base for the 5 day tour. The Main St. location is also known as the Old King's Highway and the homes have all been preserved and no lit signs are permitted so the area is very residential and relatively quiet. It is centrally located to visit the other towns on the cape. Brian will give you beach chairs and towels to take along to the myriad of beaches in the area.
Brian prepares mouth=watering breakfasts each morning and serves them in the small dining area right off his kitchen. This is a small inn with only 5 rooms. We stayed in the Captain Crocker room, the only room with a king bed. My suggestion - if you must have a king bed then by all means this room will be fine. The drawback,however, is the very small bathroom. It is literally the size of a small closet; just room enough for a sink and toilet opposite and a very small shower. Being up in a dormer-type room the in-room air conditioner and fan really had to work to keep the room cool. If you don't mind a queen bed, try to get the Yarmouth room on the main floor - big bathroom and very nicely appointed. The other rooms upstairs are also very nicely decorated and all had bigger bathrooms than ours.
The location, cleanliness, hospitality, and the value all made this location an excellent choice. I would definitely stay here again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask pjsharad about Crook Jaw Inn
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

The Inn at Cape Cod

'Wonderful Inn'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012

I am not always a big fan of B&B's but my partner found this Inn when I wanted to get away for a couple of days after having to cancel a weeklong vacation due to a death in the family. The Inn was lovely! The owners have done a wonderful job of renovating and updating this property and their British & European touches make it even more special. You can tell that they love the Inn and I suspect some bad experiences with past guests have led them to request a level of respect from current guests, do not take offense as I see some other reviewers have (negative reviews from 2008).
Everything here is 1st class, including the breakfasts and I recommend the Inn to all. I also recommend the Old Yarmouth Inn next door for dinner.

anne w

1 review
'Wonderful getaway'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 8, 2012

We enjoyed a perfect spring weekend at this lovely and impeccably maintained inn. The rooms are tastefully renovated and beautifully furnished. I am very picky about bedding and the linens and pillows were also high quality. The bathrooms are also very nice and spacious.
The real charm of the inn are the gracious hosts who really want you to feel like you are a guest in their home. You have the run of several of the downstairs rooms with fireplaces and current magazines and a gorgeous veranda. Homemade cookies and tea are laid out in the late afternoon.
Don't miss Helene's breakfast! I am not much of a breakfast eater but her breakfast, which changes daily was creative, freshly prepared and beyond good. If you have no room for her scone at the end, take it with you for later. I was glad I did because it was the best scone I have ever tasted.
I will definitely be back to this inn. I live in the Boston area and have stayed in many NE inns and this one was really special.
Less

John C
Harrogate, United Kingdom
1 review
'New England's gem'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 16, 2011

We can thoroughly recommend The Inn at Cape Cod for those wanting a truly unique and personal service. This was our ninth and last hotel in a three week tour of New England. The other hotels were of a high standard but often lacked the personal touch desired by the discerning guest. On arrival at the Inn at Cape Cod we were greeted by a charming miniature White House'. The interior was finished to a very high standard, each room different in style. Indeed the whole atmosphere is most welcoming and relaxing. Housekeeping was of the highest standard. A charming library also provided excellent facilities for guests to prepare beverages. Breakfast can be enjoyed on the terrace and consists of carefully prepared and beautifully presented dishes which are different each day. Everything is homemade and freshly made from high quality ingredients. Mike and Helen, the proprietors, and the staff are happy to help guests with advice on sightseeing, trips or venues for evening meals. We would certainly make The Inn at Cape Cod our first choice on another visit to the Cape.
Less

LondonLinx

4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Best hospitality ever'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 7, 2011

What a beautiful Inn. We staying in the Plantation Suite and had lots of room and a lovely balcony. We were greeted by Mike on arrival and shown around the Inn. There is a lovely sitting room and a kitchenette area next to the breakfast room, which has lovely fresh coffee and home made cookies available during the day and evening. Although there is not the option of an evening meal there are plenty of choices nearby. We chose to eat at the Inn opposite which has a tavern and a separate dining room both with a very good menu. It was 2 minutes walk so no trouble at all if you did not want to drive out in the evening. Breakfast was delicious. Helen and Mike served you - no self service. There was the option of fresh fruit juices, tea and coffee, fresh fruit, different types of cereal (Helen's home made granola was really tasty), following by a cooked dish (always something different) and then a homemade cake to finish. Breakfast was so filling we ended up taking the cakes with us for a snack later in the day ... and very nice and welcome they were too.

Mike takes a lot of time and trouble to explain the area, if you want, and he gave us lots of different options of what we could do. Nothing seemed too much trouble. He booked tickets for us over to Nantucket island, provided us with maps and directed us to the best parking. Mike is a wealth of knowledge and enthusiasm.

We have stayed in numerous hotels around the world and I can honestly say that we have never received such excellent hospitality and friendliness as we received here. Highly recommended.
Less

'Really loved this place, like a home from home'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 5, 2011
1
person found this review helpful

We stayed here for 3 nights on the 2nd part of our trip around New England and thought it was great! The Inn itself is really lovely and grand but not over the top. The decoration and furnishings are spot on and give the place a very nice comfortable and homely feeling.

We didn't specifically choose our room as it was booked through a travel agency but I believe we had 'Bronte' and it was perfectly comfortable. The bed and pillows were lovely and soft and we had perfect nights sleep when we were there. Traffic noise and distrubances were practically non-existant. The room had a small flat screen TV, a couple of chairs and chests of drawers. The bathroom was small but perfectly adequate. The Inn does have free Wifi but it was very weak and quite slow.

We had never really stayed in a B&B before and I loved all the little extra things like small library and DVD collection you could make use of, and the cookies laid out every evening. I really looked forward to coming back from a day out and resting up in my room with a complimentary hot chocolate and cookies from downstairs.

The breakfast in the morning was also great and changed each day, with 4 courses you can never leave with an empty stomach!

Mike and Helen and really great and friendly hosts and knows loads about the area. We were given great suggestions about the best beaches to go and visit. I'm sure anything you would want to do they would know about it and there is lots of info, maps, books, in the Inn to help you. I fell in love with Cape Cod while we were there and didn't get to do half the things I wanted to. A good excuse to come back!

I think for the first time ever when leaving a holiday accomodation I was sad to go and would have loved to have stayed longer. I look forward to coming back again.
Less

'Lovely place to stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed October 3, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

Having just returned from a stay at The Inn at Cape Cod, I was very interested to read the other reviews - good and bad. I therefore hope this review provides a balanced viewpoint.

Like one of the other guests, we did arrive 20 minutes early and having called the number on the door, we were told we had to wait for 20 minutes until check in opened at 3. After a two and a half hour drive, this was slighty frustrating, so we had to wait on the doorstep.

However, having now met Helen and Mike and experienced their hospitality, they really do want their guests to have a superb time. Their local knowledge is unsurpassed and they were very willing to help in any way.

The inn is beautiful and spotless throughout. While a couple of reviews have moaned about the ''rules and reguations", they rather unfairly forget to mention that the building is listed and therefore additional care and attention is needed. They also happen to be very proud of their inn and I'd rather rather stay somewhere that is looked after. I'm always the one that spots the scuffed paper and mildew on the shower curtain, so I'm quite fussy.

If i'm honest, this is the sort of place which is cosy and intimate. If you like to just be left alone and come and go as you please with no interaction with people, then you'd be better off with a larger hotel as this won't be for you. Other than perhaps an earlier check in and a little leaniency for those who arrive slightly early, this is a great place to stay.
Less

'Luxury on Cape Cod'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 20, 2011

The "INN" is actually a B&B which in the USA means something very different and upmarket than in the UK. The Inn is a beautiful 18th century colonial house on Route 6a, the Old Kings Highway, and is very handy for visiting all the destinations on Cape Cod.

All the furniture and fittings are of first class quality and the little extras (upscale coffee & tea machines, complimentary cookies/brownies, excellent reference library as well as the magnificent home cooked breakfast set this establishment apart.

Mike and Helen really care about their guests and you are treated as old friends from the minute you arrive until you bid a sad farewell.
Less

Cleopatra561

'I'm back at the Beverly Hills Plaza and loving it!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 19, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Here I am , back in Apartment 407 at the Beverly Hills Plaza, my home away from home. I cannot stress enough, the fact that this is a huge apartment with a full kitchen, dining room, gorgeous living room, huge bedroom, marble bath with jacuzzi bathtub, all gorgeously furnished and appointed, for less than the cost of most hotel ROOMS in the Beverly Hills area. Located on the corner of Wilshire Blvd and Comstock Avenue, the hotel is across the street from the gorgeous park in Holmby Hills where President Reagan used to come and sit every day. I still have fond memories of talking with him, while walking in this beautiful, shady park. Add that to the fact that I am less than 5 ninutes away from Rodeo Drive, 15 minutes to the beach in Santa Monica, and surrounded by rhe best restaurants in the world. Bottom line? NOTHING compares with the Beverly Hills Plaza for comfort, location, space, and especially price!! I will be back in June, and in a two bedroom, two bath apartment, so that my husband can have his own bathroom. Unfortunately, you can't have 2 baths without two bedrooms, so one bedroom goes unused, but for families, what could be be better than that.....I stay here when I am on a business trip, and I stay here for all my pleasure trips. I am here for 12 days this trip and will be here for 10 days next stay. I simply would not stay anywhere else! Love this property.....best staff in the world. Most important tip......go for the one or two bedroom luxury suites, and ask for the South side of the pool, off of Wilshire Blvd where is it quiet and serene.
Less

nick1981
poole, england
Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
10 helpful votes 10 helpful votes
'Stayed for 11 nights and had a great time'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 15, 2012

We've just got back from staying at the Beverly hills plaza for 11 nights and prior to going I had some reservations about the fact the reviews saying it was two separate hotels joined and the staff attitudes and the such like, but I can honest say that we could not fault it the whole time we were away.

Starting at the beginning when we arrived the staff were very friendly, the doorman/valet helped us unload the bags from our car and explained he would bring them up to our room if we wanted once we had checked in, we agreed to this and as I'll explain later it was worth every penny of the 3-4 dollars we paid him. Upon checking in the staff asked us if we had a car and would we be checking in we explained we would valet if we had to but if not we would park across the street (no problem as it is right opposite the hotel and there is a crossing 50m down from the hotel entrance) They had no problem with this at all.

Now the hotel I believe was two separate buildings at one time, we were staying in the building that was not situated around the swimming pool but around the Jacuzzi. There is a lift to take you to the floor where you cross over from one building to the other but when you get through there is stairs which you may have to carry your luggage up (see why $3-4 is worthwhile now!!)

The rooms are very nice (we had one with a separate lounge) and plenty of space for 2 people, there was a TV in each room and a small fridge/kitchen which came in handy for storing food /drinks. Housekeeping was very friendly and helped us out and came to see if we wanted the beds turned down every night.

Pool area was lovely with plenty of loungers (very comfortable padded sort) and there was a bar/restaurant if you wanted food/drink (it was quite pricey but you are in Beverly Hills)

If you are staying at the hotel you will need a car but then if you are staying in LA for any period of time you will need a car!!!

The only downside is the carts that housekeeping use to move their supplies/towels/etc. can make a lot of noise fairly early as it is concrete floors but there is not a lot they can do about this and I only noticed it a couple of the days we were there.

Having stayed at the Beverly Hilton and the Hyatt at century city before here I can definitely recommend this hotel as it was every bit as good, slightly more personnel and a lot more reasonable than either of the others.

    *
    *
    *
    *

Less

BerkshireMash
Berkshire
Senior Contributor
35 reviews 35 reviews
Reviews in 29 cities Reviews in 29 cities
42 helpful votes 42 helpful votes
'Great hotel, great location'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 13, 2012

We stayed here for a week in early February to celebrate my husbands birthday and had a great time. We upgraded the room to a suite which was really nice and spacious with a small kitchenette. The bed was very comfy and big and the bathroom was modern and spotless.

The suites seem to be in a wing to the side which my friend (who lives in LA) descibed as being "just like Melrose Place" which summed it up quite well! There is a side entrance straight out to Wilshire Boulevard from this wing so you dont have to traipse back through the main hotel every time. There is a hot tub (awesome), a koi pond (pretty) and lots of greenery so I really liked this wing. It felt like having your own apartment.

The location was great. LA is not a walking city but you could walk to Century City or Rodeo if you wanted, it's maybe 20 minutes. We parked our car directly opposite the hotel most nights for free (one night it was busy so we parked just around the corner, again for free) and avoiding the $28 nightly valet fee at the hotel. Everything is easy driving from this hotel - Bev Hills, West Hollywood, Santa Monica, shopping etc.

The staff were friendly and polite. We paid for one days worth of wi fi (about $15 I think) and had no problems.

I would stay here again for sure - the rooms were super clean and big, the public areas of the hotel were well kept and cared for and the location was perfect. We didn't use the pool but it looked great. The hot tub we did use and it was excellent.
Less

'We loved our stay at the Beverley Hills Plaza Hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 9, 2012

My Family of 4 stayed here in January it was our last stop after a four week stay in the cold climates of London Paris and New York, so not only were we a lot warmer but walking into our apartment was a joy, the kids who had their own apartment next to ours were ecstatic, these apartments our gorgeous and luxurious and soooo reasonably priced! I have recommended them to our friends already. The staff were nice and friendly and greeted us with a smile every day, the pool area is lovely and water is heated too, there is a small bar and restaurant but we
The pool area is lovely and water is heated too, there is a small bar and restaurant that looks cosy, but we preferred the room service so we could enjoy the apartment, the menu is the same. There is also a day spa on the premises but it seemed quite expensive and a hairdresser. The hotel is on Wiltshire Boulevard which is very long, but away from the main centre near Rodeo Drive, we travelled by taxi, it was totally fine and convenient for us.
There is bus stop out the front of the hotel as well if you don't like to travel by taxi, if you like walking there is a great shopping centre called Century City which takes about about 15 mins
by foot. We dined at a fantastic restaurant called Rock Sugar at Century City, you will also find two department stores a grocery store and lots of designer and fashion stores.
We will definitely stay here again if ever we get back to L.A!
.

Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
ProfessAW
New York City, New York
Contributor
15 reviews 15 reviews
Reviews in 12 cities Reviews in 12 cities
21 helpful votes 21 helpful votes
'Good value but you get what you pay for'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed January 25, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Stayed for business for 6 days. Checkin took forever as they were seemingly figuring out where to put me. The hotel has 2 sides - the upscale and the converted apartment building. I was put in the old side, and while it could be considered a "suite hotel", the actual size of the room is pretty standard. They are just narrow and long. The bellman showed me to my room (since there is no elevator on the old side), but did NOT take my bag, which I thought was odd. After climbing many stairs (only option), I settled in to find the only "desk" was taken by a desktop computer which cost $15/day. There wasn't even a coffee table, so if I wanted to do work, it had to be in my lap. The bathroom was also very small, with very little counter space, and the bathroom amenities are outdated. The mouthwash was nasty. The room had 2 flatscreen TVs (non-HD), but the cable was "being worked on" for a few hours so it was out. The kitchen consisted of a small sink and basic kitchen items. Cheap countertops and cabinets.

After 3 nights of poor sleep from the sun shining in (no blackout shade and the shade did not cover the whole window) and the pounding from upstairs, I switched to a top floor room. Again no help with my luggage even though the stairs were the only option. Cable went out 2 more times. It seemed like they were covering up problems/mistakes, not fixing them.

Another HUGE disappointment was the internet. For $15 for 24 hours, you get slow service on ONE device. I had 2 computers for work, so I had to pay $30 per day. And if I wanted to have my phone connect, it would have been another $15. Really? And you have to call the front desk to get a code to log in. Seems very outdated and cheap. Didn't even work properly all the time.

Housekeeping was fine, the morning newspaper was nice, but no breakfast, and staff seemed burdened when I had a question/issue.

In short, there are 2 sides to the hotel: nice and cheap. The lobby is nice, but the property is not well maintained. No desk to do work in the rooms. Card reader to get in the more convenient way did not work. Fitness center was about 20 years out of date. Staff was not so good. Walls/roof are very thin. Valet costs $28 per day when you can park across the street for free. Internet is $15/day for one device (no disconnecting/connecting to new device). Not really walking distance to anything special.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

See 2 more reviews by St.LouisEileen for Los Angeles
St.LouisEileen
St. Louis
Senior Contributor
44 reviews 44 reviews
Reviews in 24 cities Reviews in 24 cities
48 helpful votes 48 helpful votes
'Can't Get a Better Bang for your Buck'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed January 15, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Who doesn't want to say they're staying in Beverly Hills? But who can afford it, really? Well, try the Plaza. I just got back from my first visit, and I can't overemphasize how impressed I was. First of all, what it isn't. The Peninsula. Don't expect stars or ridiculously expensive furnishings or an air of pretension. Although, truth be told, there were independent film people there, and the lobby really is gorgeous. I has that old Beverly Hills look.
What the hotel is: a comfortable, clean, efficient, warm, full-service hotel for about $100/night less than the surrounding places. I know. I checked. The room decor is not outstanding, but the beds are comfortable, and every room is a suite, which I think means big room with sitting area. I got upgraded, and had a separate living room that was very comfortable and spotlessly clean. There is a lovely pool area, a spa, hair salon and full exercise room. The hotel is perfectly sited, especially if you need to be on the west side, right at Wilshire and Beverly Glen, and about a block down from the lovely little Holmby Park where all the locals hang out. (I've stayed at Trip Advisor's #4 hotel, the Brentwood Inn many times, and as much as I loved it, I'd give it to the Beverly HIlls PLaza all over the Brentwood. It's more convenient, more roomy, has more amenities, and more helpful staff)
And the best part of the Plaza? The staff. They went out of their way to help in everything big and small. They rented a Voltzwagen for me for $44/day, which was dropped off for me at the hotel and then picked up there when I was finished. I just gave my keys to the concierge. If you don't think that was worth every penny. It didn't matter what time of the day or night, somebody was available and happy to help(if you've been out all day and don't want to go out to eat, have them give you the info for First Szechuan Wok, which delivers. Really good basic Chinese). The hotel restaurant IS very small, and can easily get overcrowded at breakfast, but the food is basic and good, the bartenders happy to serve, and it's damn convenient.
My only caveats would be that because the hotel seems to be made up of more than one building, its halls wander about, and it's easy to get lost.Not only that, if you have trouble with stairs, let the staff know right away so you don't get a room in the back, because stairs are involved. But that's really my only caution. I've already told them I'll be back this summer. I can't wait--especially because I can sit out by the pool then.
Less

DetroitLouie
Chevy Chase, MD
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Nice location, good value'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed January 9, 2012

We stayed Dec. 30-31, 2011 in two rooms, one containing my wife and myself, the other our daughter, her husband and their two year old son. We took two adjoining executive rooms (bedroom and front room with kitchen essentials). It was perfect.

First, we booked the rooms only days before and were trying to save by booking one exec room and one standard. When we got to the reception desk the hotel upgraded us (about $10/night) to two executive rooms so that we could be next to each other. That was extremely helpful and considerate of them.

The staff was always very nice and accommodating, from the reception to the valet staff. The location is great, on Wilshire Blvd between Westwood and Beverly HIlls. We even found parking on the street both days and were able to avoid the $28/night parking fee. That may have been because of the holiday season, though, and if you did have to use their parking, it is valet and convenient.

In the back, near our rooms, there is some rushing water and a pond with koi. Our 2 year old grandson loved it.

The building looks like it was two older motels put together, refurbished, and a new front added. It is owned by Donald Sterling, so my guess is that when the real estate heats up again he would sell or convert this considerable footprint to a high rise condo building, like the many others on that stretch of Wilshire. But while it is there it is a little gem, well run at very reasonable price in a great location for those who want to get to central and west L.A. We were all extremely happy with the experience.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Problem with this review?
pandoras_chocolates
York
Senior Contributor
44 reviews 44 reviews
Reviews in 31 cities Reviews in 31 cities
48 helpful votes 48 helpful votes
'Enjoyable stay at a great hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 19, 2011

Coming off the back-end of two very long flights, we decided to break up our journey in Beverly Hills (for a variety of reasons, including the ever-popular "let's walk up and down Rodeo Drive experience"). A friend recommended the Plaza. It was a great choice. It's a unique hotel, situated around a courtyard with swimming pool. We asked for a quiet room away from Wilshire Blvd (which is a tad busy), and they put us in what was effectively a second wing. We had to walk past a little waterfall, the jacuzzi, loads of gorgeous green plants, and up some winding stairs until we reached our huge, well appointed room. We were away from all street noise and slept in peace and quiet. As I said, our room was huge: bedroom, kitchen/dining/living room, lots of storage space, and some comfy sofas. It was not newly decorated, but everything was extremely clean and worked.

We walked to the centre of Beverly Hills (around 20 minutes or so) for dinner and a bit of sightseeing. There's nothing much around the hotel, so you'll either have a bit of a walk or you'll need to drive. Traffic can be terrible on Wilshire -- we drove up from LAX in rush hour, and thanks to construction it took quite a while. Just be patient and be prepared for arbitrary stupidity from other drivers, and you'll be fine.

The staff at the hotel were great, from initial greetings from the parking valet, to the check-in staff, to housekeeping. Everyone was friendly and went out of their way to help.

Finally, LA is expensive, but the Plaza is very reasonably priced, and you get a lot for your money. We'd definitely stay again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'A little worn around the edges but has ageless charm'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 11, 2010

We had been travelling for nearly a month when we arrived at the Inn. We were greeted very warmly by the innkeeper Karen and instantly made to feel at home. We had a room with a king sized bed an a private bath. The floors sagged a little and creaked some but that is the charm that comes with a house the is nearing 200 years old. Karen was a wealth of knowledge on the Cape Cod area and provided excellent referrals to really good local dining. We spent two wonderful nights and left rejuvenated and ready to continue our trip. I would recommended this Inn to anybody visiting Cape Cod.

momkms
Reston, Virginia
1 review
'A mixed bag.'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed August 23, 2010

I agree with an earlier review that the Village Inn is like staying at your grandmother's house. The stairs are crooked and creaky, the furnishings are pleasant but worn, and there's a bit of a musty smell. There is a certain charm. The screen porch offers a lovely and relaxing place to read and chat with other guests.

The inn keepers provided a wealth of local knowledge and sent us to some great restaurants and beaches. They are generally friendly save for a strange incident when my husband entered the wrong bathroom and we were scolded excessively like children. That put an unpleasant vibe on the rest of our stay.

Breakfast was simple but tasty and generously supplied. The service was impeccable. The young waiter even anticipated our requests from the previous mornings.

The rooms were clean but the literally threadbare bedspreads and seriously uncomfortable beds were a deal breaker for me. If we return to the Cape, we'll be staying elsewhere.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

One Centre Street Inn

mslaughter_az
Gilbert, Arizona
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Home Away From Home'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 2, 2011

When we first heard that breakfast was served at 8:30 am, we were worried and set our alarm clocks. Silly! Around 8:00, we were woken by the most delicious smells wafting into our bedroom from the kitchen below. We followed our noses every morning we were there, and we were never disappointed. The food was excellent, but the hospitality was outstanding!

The rooms were filled with cozy furnishings, and the beds were soft and comfy! Mary and Judy were wonderful hosts! They were quick with advice as to the best restaurants, activities, and shared local history and current events with us. They even suggested good places and times to take breathtaking photographs.

Other reviews have mentioned that they are centrally located, and I've got to agree. It was never too far to go to get somewhere or to get back "home". They really made us feel like we were family while we were there, and I've no doubt we'll be seeing them again.

1 review
'Cead Mile Failte'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed October 23, 2010

We had a wonderful time. One Centre Street is a great place and provided us a warm, friendly and comfortable get-away. This well-maintained, tastefully decorated inn is located in picturesque Yarmouthport along 6-A. The innkeepers have resisted the urge to fill One Centre Street with antique bric-a-brak, letting the period charm of their home show through. We started each day with a delicious multiple course breakfast and refreshed mid-afternoon with tea and pastriesbe sure to ask for the ginger snaps. From the advice on local restaurants to help with whale-watching, Mary and Judy helped to make our week-end a truly pleasant experience. Although we have been going to the Cape for 30 years, One Centre Street has made 6-A is our new favorite locale. We came as guests and left feeling like family. The sign over their front door says it all, 'Cead Mile Failte'

'A treasure to stay in on the Cape'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 8, 2009

What an incredible treasure we found in the One Centre Street Inn in Yarmouth Port and the hosts of the Inn. From the moment we arrived to the moment we departed, we felt as though we were in our own home and truly felt welcomed. Having travelled extensively and stayed in all manner of accomodation, we can truly say that this is one of the best inns/b&bs that we have ever stayed in. The inn is well situated in a lovely small town that affords a quiter/peaceful vacation and yet given the size of the cape is in an ideal location for daily jaunts to the various parts of the cape.

We cannot say enough about the warm, knowledgeable and generous hospitality of our primary host (Mary Singleton). From the moment we arrived, we felt welcomed and at home. Not only did Mary provide us with great travel tips during our stay, but also lined us up with some fabulous dining experiences.

We stayed a total of 4 evenings - 1 in Cogswell and 3 in Doane, and loved both rooms for their tasteful presentation and very comfortable beds. Surprisingly, each of our breakfasts were different during our stay, and were not only filling, but delicious each time.

Thank you so much for an inviting and pleasurable stay during our time on the Cape. We look forward to our return and to debating which room in your lovely inn we will book. What a fabulous property!!!
K&S

'Wonderful experience in a beautiful home!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed August 13, 2009

A few friends and I traveled to New England last fall and staying One Centre Street was one of the highlights. The Inn is located on a historic, picturesque street, Olde Kings Highway, which boasts some of the most magnificent Cape homes. As echoed by every review so far, Mary, the inn keeper, couldn't have been a more warm, welcoming host. She was always available for restaurant suggestions or a cup of tea or just to offer up some good New England conversation, including bemoaning the loss of the Patriot's Tom Brady to injury.

We stayed in the Phillips room in perhaps the most comfortable bed I've ever slept in! Breakfast was wonderful and allows you some social time with other guests of the Inn. Despite two or three other couples staying there, that was the only time we ran into them so the Inn never feels crowded.

Our only complaint was the stay there was too short!

SeaCoast Inn

Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
'Great Value, Great Service'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 14, 2012 NEW

My wife and I stayed here last week for our honeymoon and we couldn't have picked a better place. It is amazing what one can do with some updating and a little old-fashioned hospitality. We arrived during a driving rain storm and the first thing Al did was offer the use of an umbrella. Then, with my wife freezing due to packing for the summer rather than the cold New England spring, Terri offered coats, gloves and scarves. Try that at your local chain hotel. They knew the perfect places to eat and to visit along the cape and where to go on the islands. All in all, they were the perfect innkeepers and made out visit one to remember. Thanks!

DavenCarol

Contributor
19 reviews 19 reviews
Reviews in 12 cities Reviews in 12 cities
10 helpful votes 10 helpful votes
'Best value in New England'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 14, 2012 NEW

We have stayed at the SeaCoast Inn 3 times in seven years. Each time has been as good as it gets. It has to be the best value in New England, if not the US.

Terri and Al make improvements every year on the property but they can't improve on the service they provide, it is the best. You can read any of the reviews and you will find the same theme throughout. They go out of there way to take care of their guests.

We had made plans for our current trip so we didn't need a ride to the ferry or help with maps or things to do. They still asked to help with everything and when we started to walk down the street to the local store Al came out to offer a ride to the ferry if that was where we were going. The first time we were here in 2005 the rental car power socket didn't work so I had no way to charge our cell phone. Not to worry, they plugged it into their car while we were at dinner. On our previous trip Terri made reservations for us on a tour of Nantucket and when the tour operator got to the pick up location she asked who were the people Terri sent to be sure we got first pick of the seats.

It is true they don't have a pool or spa or elevator but they do have the best run operation west of the Atlantic.

cygnetgirl
San Francisco, California
Contributor
18 reviews 18 reviews
Reviews in 11 cities Reviews in 11 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'It's a Bro - Tel!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

It may look like a motel, and have motel services ( no pool, no resort-like feel), but the owners make it feel like a cozy bed-and-breakfast in the best possible ways. No frilly decor, or intrusive breakfasts and awkward halllway visits, but definetly a friendly and knowledgeable couple run this and enjoy what they do. Breakfast in the sun room is good, but not fancy. Access to washers and dryers, beach chairs, towels, free books basket --and individually created rooms make you realize this isn't just some chain. They don't gouge you in the summer prices and even have a deal on boat tickets to the islands, if you ask. No tourist trap here. A big thumbs up from a frequent traveler used to business hotels and expense accounts. This one is a great one for families, tourists, etc. Room #18 was large and comfortable with a refrigerator, table, microwave and large storage closet.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask cygnetgirl about SeaCoast Inn
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

Basktpl
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'We didn't intend to stay on the Cape...but we're glad we did!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 via mobile
8
people found this review helpful

We had spent several afternoon hours on the Cape but were sure hotel prices would be over our budget that we didn't even consider staying the night...until we ran into a local gent who told us about the Seacoast Inn. He even bought us a copy of that day's edition of the Boston Globe that featured the hotel's most recent Trip Advisor award. With those kinds if recommendation, we had to stay!

I called the hotel and got reservations for $85 including breakfast for a spacious king room. Al, the owner, took my reservation but never took my name or credit card number. He said to just tell him when we arrive that I was the lady from Ohio and he'us show us to a room. And that's exactly what happened!

All the kudos expressed by others are some of the same I could repeat. These people are authentic. The stories are real.

The property has unique touches that make this place shine. My favorite is the electrical outlets and light switches built in to the headboard that was hand-built by the owner himself. Why doesn't everybody think of this? Put an outlet right behind me so I can plug in my cell phone, laptop, medical equipment or anything else I might use. And then put the light switches right beside the outlet. Oh yeah...put a shallow ledge on top (4' above floor height) so I can rest my cell phone. How convenient!

Will we be back? You betcha! After whale watching off Provincetown on an Al and Terri recommendation, we decided late in the afternoon to go back the very next night. We were so glad we were ahead of the busy season so a room was available. This time, we got a room with a brand new mattress.

It just keeps getting better.....
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Just geting to the front door to the building I got splinters on my hand, from holding onto the railing. When I entered the rm. I wanted to run, but I had paid for 2 days, and would of forfeited my money. The rug had burn marks from a droped iron. The furniture was old and the rm was dirty, I looked up and you can see the amount of dirt on the ceiling fan. The First thing I did was use my pets blankets to cover the bedspread. I used my dogs towels to cover the pillows. Dinner the waiter's shirt was filthy, the dinner was o.k. I would't let my dogs in that pool, it was green. Skipped breakfast nothing to brag about, I just wanted to go home. When I got home the first thing I did was take a shower and wash my hair. I used the steam cycle to wash my clothes, which I left my luggage open on my porch for a couple of days. My dogs went to the groomers for a thorough grooming the very next day.I will never ever go to a place relying on pictures on a web site.

Glenn G
Hamilton, Canada
1 review
'A perfect way to celebrate our wedding day'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 30, 2012

My new wife and I recently enjoyed a very simple, but perfect wedding day on beautiful Cape Cod. We got married by a Justice of the Peace at her lovely 1777 home and then came a wonderful treat given to us by my Aunt and Uncle who live on the Cape, which was dinner and an overnight at the Colonial House Inn. They had often commented to us that they would go there for special dinners and had never been disappointed.
We arrived at about 5:00pm and were greeted warmly by Mac the Innkeeper who showed us to our room which was beautiful, spacious and very comfortable. Our party of four then enjoyed an absolutely delicious dinner in the part of the dining area overlooking the garden area. The dinner was perfect and the service very good as we lingered over with our wine, dessert and coffee. After my Aunt and Uncle departed my wife and I got into our jeans and took a leisurely stroll for about an hour through the very interesting streets near the inn and enjoyed the Cape Cod homes all of which were quite unique from the one next and many of them obviously dating back into the 1800 and early 1900 time frame. It was a great way to mellow after the wonderful Cape Cod inspired seafood dinner.
The next morning we had a terrific breakfast in the dining room featuring fresh baked goods from the Inn's kitchen and we had the pleasure of some great conversation with Mac who explained to us some of the history of the Inn and the surrounding area.
Our stay at the Colonial House Inn was a perfect way to celebrate our wedding and the start of our new life together. Thank you to Mac and the staff at the Inn.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

It was just perfect. Looking forward to the next time you come to visit your parents Ernestine & Richard. My best wishes to Stay well to all in both your Families.
Mac
Innkeeper

'Pet Friendly!!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed March 5, 2012

We were looking for a pet friendly place on the Cape to escape from Boston. The Colonial House Inn was one of a very few places on the Cape that allowed us to bring our dog. The service was extremely professional. They have an indoor pool and Jacuzzi something that is rare to find for a Cape style Inn. Dinner was also included in the room reservation, so we sat down in their dining room in front of the fireplace and ordered stuffed haddock, which was amazing!!

William M
Albany, New York
2 reviews
'We had a wonderful weekend'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed January 30, 2012

My wife and I got away for a long weekend with friends and had a great time. Mac arranged to have all of our rooms in the carriage house and set the pool area up for us to have a private party. The rooms were clean and comfortable BUT they are not corporate chain hotel rooms. They each have their own individual character and charm. The rooms have WiFi and TV but, except to check the weather, I didn't use them. We had dinner and breakfast there every day. The food was excellent and the service even better. Our server was attentive and friendly while allowing us to enjoy our meals at a leisurely pace. The seafood was fresh and well prepared. Breakfast was a sampler of fruit, quiche, muffins, nut breads, OJ and coffee and tea. Mac is a fount of information on things to do and places to see on the Cape. We spent a couple of days exploring following Mac's directions.

This is a warm and friendly place to stay, unlike the cookie cutter hotels that can be found all across the country. We would gladly stay here again.
Less

Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Decent deal, especially in off season'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed January 30, 2012

We spent a January weekend there with a group of friends. The room rates include an expanded continental breakfast (the french toast was delicious) and your choice of entree for dinner (appetizers and dessert are extra). The dinners were good to very good, depending on how seasoned you like your food. My husband thought one meal lacked seasoning but the next night his meal was very good. Rooms are cozy but certainly adequate (we stayed in the carriage house). Things were clean. This is an old Cape Cod inn so it is not the Hilton - if you want that you should look for something else.
Less

'Paranormal Weekend at the Colonial House Inn'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed November 4, 2011
1
person found this review helpful

On October 28-30,2011 we spent the weekend at the Colonial House Inn in Yarmouth Port on Cape Cod Mass.
It was a Paranormal Weekend and I being a Ghost Hunter was all for that, we arrived at the Inn Friday afternoon and was greeted by Mac the owner he was so gratious and gave us a tour of the Inn and a ground level room because of my friends handicap we were pleased with the room we had in the Carriage House amd more pleased when later we were getting some activity on the clock radio and my K2 Meter going off at the same time like morse code and at 3:00AM Friday night there was a loud bang on our door!!! There was a Ghost Walk around town earlier but Mac found out for us it would be too much for us so he gave us the printed information and Saturday morning we did it our selves.Friday night Dinner on the Veranda was wonderful and there is a full stocked bar in the lounge so there are many spirits there ha ha.
Saturday after a great breakfast Mac gave us some shopping tips and directions we had a great time at the Just Picked and the Christmas Tree Shops and when we arrived back we were just in time for the First half of the Paranormal Presentation put on by the Massachusetts Paranormal Society from the area it was very informative and some of the stories from their investigations were great! We broke for Dinner and again the food was delicious after we ate we went back to the Pool area and we got to do a Investigation on the Banquet area and we did get some activity on the K2 Meters and I have a voice on my Tape recorder saying "Want it to me" and " Are we scaring you" so this place is very active.
Sunday morning brought another delicious breakfast then we had to leave but before we did we had Mac sign our Ghost books we purchased at the Inn and told Mac we were doing some more sight seeing at the Ancient Burial Ground and the Museum so there is plenty to do in the area for Haunted Activies and we are already planning a trip back in the Spring so go to their Web Site to see what they are planning.

'BEST money can buy'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

This is the first time I've stayed at a hotel in New England where I enjoyed spending time IN the room as much as I do being out and about. For Hyannis specifically, I've stayed at four different places and while this costs slightly more than the others, it's the ONLY place I would recommend and it offers MUCH more, including pool with harbor view, beautiful breakfast spread in a charming setting, wrap around balcony to watch the marina, plus great location (walkable to everything) and friendly service (my husband isn't easily impressed but he was floored that the housekeeper left wine glasses next to our unopened bottle on the desk). If possible, go after high season and get the best value around.

Aussie_Charlotte
Toronto, Canada
Senior Contributor
25 reviews 25 reviews
Reviews in 22 cities Reviews in 22 cities
44 helpful votes 44 helpful votes
'More than just a Motel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The Anchor In Motel may be called a motel but the rooms and service are of hotel quality. It was clean and the bathroom and furniture are updated. Even better, it is right on the water and has it's own pier. It's one block form the port to catch the ferry to Nantucket and given the lack of parking in the area in general, this is very handy. It's also walking distance to the main street which has cafes and restaurants. My only complaint is that the bathroom was quite small with no counter space which seems inconsistent given the size of our room and that there was a large walk-in closet next to it. We took the cheapest room (there are 4 of these rooms) which don't have balconies and are on the ground floor, but I think next time I'll pay more for the other rooms which have balconies because everyone else was sitting out on their balconies watching the boats sail by. If you take the cheap rooms, there are chairs on the grass outside your door you can sit on and look out but the views are not the same as the other rooms which are on a higher level.

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Thank you for your review. Our interactive website offers the ability to see views from several areas and from most of our one of a kind guest rooms. In essence, you have the ability to choose your guest room and your view. The Traditional guest rooms in the lower level of the Main Building have a forty-five foot deck patio in front of them with deck chairs and tables. These guest rooms were completely renovated in 2011. We look forward to your next visit and it would be our pleasure to assist you from reservation to check out. We are third generation family owned and operated. Our goal is your perfect Tripadvisor rating.

Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
'Convenient location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012

Although we arrived early and our room wasn't yet ready, we were welcomed and invited to leave our cases in reception whilst we went to explore the local harbour. Our room at this hotel was large, clean and comfortable with fabulous views of the marina. There were comfortable armchairs, a desk and separate space with a fridge and dressing room. It was a pleasure to have so many table lamps in all parts of the room. Sandy (hope I got her name right) in reception was very helpful and went out of her way to advise us on making reservations for trips, local transport etc. Breakfast was of the continental-style with a good variety of cereals, fruit, toast and fruitjuices. Coffee was available 24 hours a day and the dining room was comfortable and sunny. We had't realised that Cape Cod is very quiet until end of May and so ferry trips and public transport had a limited timetable. In spite of this, Sandy helped us get to our destinations and back again.

Katherine817
Providence, Rhode Island
Senior Contributor
22 reviews 22 reviews
Reviews in 16 cities Reviews in 16 cities
12 helpful votes 12 helpful votes
'A Gem in Hyannis!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

My friends and I decided to stay at the Anchor In as our gateway to explore Cape Cod. I had a gift certificate to use and I could choose to stay at any one of the New England Inns & Resorts and I narrowed in on the Anchor In out of several choices.

I am very happy with the decision we made and the Anchor In is a lovely place! On the outside of the building it says "Anchor In Motel", but don't let that fool you. It's more like a charming, smaller hotel and the rooms are clean and upgraded. When I checked in the agent was very friendly and gave me a small "tour" around the property showing me where brochures with area attractions are, menus for nearby restaurants are, as well as where the lounge/ breakfast area is located. The rooms are just right in size and our East Wing Deluxe View room had a gorgeous view and porch overlooking the harbor. The breakfast at the hotel was a pleasant surprise! They have delicious, giant muffins, bagels, several kinds of cereals, fresh fruit and juices. It's only open until 9:30am, so don't sleep in too late!

I went back to the front desk to ask about ferries to Martha's Vineyard and the one leaving within walking distance from the hotel in Hyannis is $71 per person roundtrip. However, if you drive about an hour west on Cape Cod to Woods Hole/ Falmouth, the Steamship Authority ferry is $16 roundtrip with $12 parking for the day, and from the parking lot it's about a 10 minute drive on the parking shuttle to get to the actual ferry terminal. I was hoping to be more central to a place to take the ferry in Martha's Vineyard without being so pricey, but the drive is not too far and at least we were able to make it to the island! I inquired about restaurants in the area that have good pasta/ seafood, and I believe it was Francis, who took the time to search through several restaurants in the area to see their availability, menu, etc. which was much appreciated.

There are a wide variety of restaurants to choose from on Main Street in Hyannis mixed with several cute shops. It's just about a 3 minute drive to Main Street and we never had issues with finding a spot to parallel park on the street.

Overall, if you're looking for a great place to stay on Cape Cod in Hyannis, definitely stay here! The location on the scenic harbor, close proximity to Main Street, quaint New England charm, and attentive and friendly staff make this place a true gem in Hyannis!

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

person found this review helpful

The Anchor In Motel may be called a motel but the rooms and service are of hotel quality. It was clean and the bathroom and furniture are updated. Even better, it is right on the water and has it's own pier. It's one block form the port to catch the ferry to Nantucket and given the lack of parking in the area in general, this is very handy. It's also walking distance to the main street which has cafes and restaurants. My only complaint is that the bathroom was quite small with no counter space which seems inconsistent given the size of our room and that there was a large walk-in closet next to it. We took the cheapest room (there are 4 of these rooms) which don't have balconies and are on the ground floor, but I think next time I'll pay more for the other rooms which have balconies because everyone else was sitting out on their balconies watching the boats sail by. If you take the cheap rooms, there are chairs on the grass outside your door you can sit on and look out but the views are not the same as the other rooms which are on a higher level.

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Aussie_Charlotte about Anchor In Hotel
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
AnchorInHyannisowner, Owner at Anchor In Hotel, responded to this review
June 12, 2012
Thank you for your review. Our interactive website offers the ability to see views from several areas and from most of our one of a kind guest rooms. In essence, you have the ability to choose your guest room and your view. The Traditional guest rooms in the lower level of the Main Building have a forty-five foot deck patio in front of them with deck chairs and tables. These guest rooms were completely renovated in 2011. We look forward to your next visit and it would be our pleasure to assist you from reservation to check out. We are third generation family owned and operated. Our goal is your perfect Tripadvisor rating.

'Convenient location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012

Although we arrived early and our room wasn't yet ready, we were welcomed and invited to leave our cases in reception whilst we went to explore the local harbour. Our room at this hotel was large, clean and comfortable with fabulous views of the marina. There were comfortable armchairs, a desk and separate space with a fridge and dressing room. It was a pleasure to have so many table lamps in all parts of the room. Sandy (hope I got her name right) in reception was very helpful and went out of her way to advise us on making reservations for trips, local transport etc. Breakfast was of the continental-style with a good variety of cereals, fruit, toast and fruitjuices. Coffee was available 24 hours a day and the dining room was comfortable and sunny. We had't realised that Cape Cod is very quiet until end of May and so ferry trips and public transport had a limited timetable. In spite of this, Sandy helped us get to our destinations and back again.

Katherine817
Providence, Rhode Island
Senior Contributor
22 reviews 22 reviews
Reviews in 16 cities Reviews in 16 cities
12 helpful votes 12 helpful votes
'A Gem in Hyannis!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

My friends and I decided to stay at the Anchor In as our gateway to explore Cape Cod. I had a gift certificate to use and I could choose to stay at any one of the New England Inns & Resorts and I narrowed in on the Anchor In out of several choices.

I am very happy with the decision we made and the Anchor In is a lovely place! On the outside of the building it says "Anchor In Motel", but don't let that fool you. It's more like a charming, smaller hotel and the rooms are clean and upgraded. When I checked in the agent was very friendly and gave me a small "tour" around the property showing me where brochures with area attractions are, menus for nearby restaurants are, as well as where the lounge/ breakfast area is located. The rooms are just right in size and our East Wing Deluxe View room had a gorgeous view and porch overlooking the harbor. The breakfast at the hotel was a pleasant surprise! They have delicious, giant muffins, bagels, several kinds of cereals, fresh fruit and juices. It's only open until 9:30am, so don't sleep in too late!

I went back to the front desk to ask about ferries to Martha's Vineyard and the one leaving within walking distance from the hotel in Hyannis is $71 per person roundtrip. However, if you drive about an hour west on Cape Cod to Woods Hole/ Falmouth, the Steamship Authority ferry is $16 roundtrip with $12 parking for the day, and from the parking lot it's about a 10 minute drive on the parking shuttle to get to the actual ferry terminal. I was hoping to be more central to a place to take the ferry in Martha's Vineyard without being so pricey, but the drive is not too far and at least we were able to make it to the island! I inquired about restaurants in the area that have good pasta/ seafood, and I believe it was Francis, who took the time to search through several restaurants in the area to see their availability, menu, etc. which was much appreciated.

There are a wide variety of restaurants to choose from on Main Street in Hyannis mixed with several cute shops. It's just about a 3 minute drive to Main Street and we never had issues with finding a spot to parallel park on the street.

Overall, if you're looking for a great place to stay on Cape Cod in Hyannis, definitely stay here! The location on the scenic harbor, close proximity to Main Street, quaint New England charm, and attentive and friendly staff make this place a true gem in Hyannis!

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Days Inn Hyannis

palmtree7270

Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Warmest, most friendly service ever'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW via mobile

Just as I'd read in other reviews before booking this hotel, the staff were extremely pleasant. The front desk staff are welcoming & offer useful information about area attractions and directions. In our room, the housekeeping staff laid out towels artfully in bow-ties on the beds. I was happy with the fridge & free wi-fi. Beds were perfectly comfortable. I did find the walls to be incredibly thin; anything said in the hallway was clearly heard inside the room with the door closed. I might suggest adding room-safes, though I never felt unsafe at any time in the hotel. The complimentary breakfast offered a decent selection & included scrambled eggs. We stayed 3 nights. I would recommend it to anyone.
