jenna914
Omaha, NE
2 reviews
'Back Bay Hotel--Very Satisfied'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

My sisters and I stayed at the Back Bay Hotel for 6 nights. We really enjoyed it. We were there very little during the day, but were usually in by 9ish at night and out the door by about 10 a.m. Housekeeping did a lovely job. We had everything that we needed. On a couple of rainy days when we were walking a lot, they gave us an extra umbrella to use. The door man was very conversational and even gave us a souvenir miniature police car, since the building used to be a police station. There was some construction across the street, but there was no disturbing noise from it. Great location for doing all the "touristy" things in Boston, and close to a couple of T stations. It was a great trip!

'A wonderful stay'

people found this review helpful

The Back Bay Hotel is a great place to stay. Each member of staff that we came into contact with were so kind & helpful. Nothing was a problem for them. The rooms are very good and the hotel itself is very interesting being the former home of The Boston Police Department. The location is perfect. Just a few minutes walk to the Public Gardens and Boston Common, Copley Square. A number of T Stops are close by, if you need to use them. Boston central is so easy to navigate by foot so you won't be needing the T too often (dependent on weather).

This is a truly great hotel and especially because of the wonderful staff.

'Great location, average round the edges'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The BBH is in a perfect location for the the centre of Boston, Fenway Park (walking distance) and the high end shops in Back Bay. There are building works still going on opposite but they didn't bother us. The room was a good size, clean, nice sized bathroom but it was a bit ragged around the edges and felt like it needed an upgrade soon. Overall the BBH is a solid, decent value 4* hotel and would have got the same rating here but.....WiFi was woefully slow, both in the room and the lobby. I see fast WiFi as standard these days - it was terrible. Either fix it, or don't pretend it works. We were here for leisure but it would be impossible for business.

Would I come to Boston again? Yes, in a heartbeat. Stay in BBH......? Probably not - bit too average.
Less

'Awesome family stay in Beantown'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

I recently stayed here with my husband and 3-month old baby. The location was absolutely perfect. We valeted our car for $40/day with unlimited access to it. The hotel is in walking distance (and stroller-friendly) to several key spots: Dunkin' Donuts (major!), Shaw's supermarket, and the Prudential Center. Bring your own goodies to the room, since it comes with a decent-sized mini-fridge (with complementary water bottles). The room was great, and the bed was one of the most comfy beds I've ever slept in. I would stay here again in a heartbeat.

'A treasure in Boston'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The Back Bay Hotel is a five star hotel at a reasonable price. While not as high profile as some of the other local hotels, this is a wonderful spot with a terrific history (used to be the police headquaqrters). The did a great job transforming the building into a hotel including some very interesting design features. The rooms are comfortable and upscale. The common areas, while not opulent like the Copley Plaza, are very nice. They even make the valet parking work when they don't have much room and no attached parking facility. And, the location is phenominal; right in middle of back bay and walking distance to most everything. I would go back in a heabeat.

Wells P
Hannibal, Missouri
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
'Location and Personal Service'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012

I rate the the hotel Very Good, adding that the location is excellent and central to lots of places to walk, eat and site see (Boyston & Newbury Streets, Boston Commons, Comm. Ave. all within walking distance).

Valet service was friendly and efficient. They seemed to like our Hertz Mustand GT!

Desk clerks Seth and John get a special mention as they both were very helpful in giving us directions and great day trip ideas. One morning I came downstairs to the lobby very early, before the coffee was out, and John gratiously went out of his way to get me a fresh cup that he made himself. Seth gave us great ideas for a trip to Cape Cod and Martha's Vineyard. These 'extras' made an already nice trip even more special.

An area of improvement is in what I call 'mechanics.' We actually stayed in two different rooms and in both cases the in room coffee maker did not work. In the second room the exhaust fan in the bathroom wasn't working and I reported this to maintenance. It was awknowledged but nothing was done and we were in the second room 3 nights, and the first for 2 nights. I rate these issues as fairly 'minor' and not enough to seriously detract from an otherwise very nice stay. But management can and should correct these items.

Rating: 4 Stars and Highly Recommended

For the record, John and Seth carried the rating to four stars by both being above and beyond the norm for service, more than offsetting the two maintenance/mechanical issues noted above.
Less

JustCurious44
Philadelphia
Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
12 helpful votes 12 helpful votes
'Quiet and perfect!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

My family of four (me, my husband and 2 teenage boys) stayed here for 3 nights when we were doing college tours in the area. Got a great room rate on the hotel's website (this hotel gives you the option of selecting a "quiet floor" when you book through their website...and, quiet it was!). No people noise, no doors slamming, no elevators cranking and beeping, no traffic noise...nothing! I slept so well on the comfortable king-sized bed.

The staff is amazing. As others have said, every employee of this hotel is friendly and helpful, yet they somehow manage to stay out of your way and and remain unobtrusive.

Shower pressure is amazing...like a massage! Rooms are configured in a way that makes them feel more spacious than a typical hotel room layout. Floor to ceiling windows make the space light and airy.

Location of the hotel couldn't be better...T station is right outside the front door. Rooftop pool is really nice, with an incredible view. There is also a Shaw's supermarket up the street, should you need anything.

We rented hubway bikes across the street from the hotel (check out this system; it's really a cool).

In short, this is a wonderful place to stay when visiting Boston. I'd stay here again and again.
Less

jellystonelover
Shoreline, Washington
2 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Wonderful stay!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

We stayed at the Colonnade May 23-27 for our daughter's graduation. After flying from the west coast on a red-eye, we asked for an early check-in and got one as soon as the housekeeping staff could clean a room for us, the hotel having been completely full the night before! We joined the IPrefer loyalty program (free!) a couple of months before our stay and got free wi-fi in our room. We were given a room facing the South End, and it was quiet enough that we could leave the windows open at night. The air conditioning was indeed noisy but kept the room nice and cool. Our room was a bit crowded for our family of 4 (Dad, Mom, adult daughter, teenage son) because we requested a roll-away in addtion to the two very comfortable double beds. The bathroom is small, but the shower has the best water pressure I've ever experienced!! We would have reused our bath towels if there had been a rack from which to hang them.

We loved the convenience of being right on the T - used it to get everywhere we didn't want to walk to. We walked to Fenway, MIT, and downtown easily from the hotel.
The staff was just wonderfully welcoming, especially Norman, the doorman, who has a gift for hospitality!

Our stay at the Colonnade was the centerpiece of a wonderful trip to Boston!
Less

11 helpful votes 11 helpful votes
'Not sure if I'll return ...'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 9, 2012 NEW

My initial stay was in 2010 and was checking reviews to see if I would like to stay again. Not sure at this point.

Previous stays in Boston have been at the Fairmonts (Copley & Wharf), The Back Bay and The Liberty. St Botolph has a totally different vibe than the aforementioned and that's why I chose to stay there initially. Location is great. Familiar with Boston so I didn't need someone available to answer questions.

Booked directly with the inn. No problem with the access code. Appreciated the privacy and the coffee offerings, etc.

Stayed in the 1 bedroom and it was comfortable and beautifully decorated ... but not maintained. It was a shame. Towel bar hanging from the wall, chipped paint and furniture was looking a bit worn. Preferred not to go barefoot.

That was two years ago. I recall wondering if the location and design would sustain The Inn at St Botolph because it didn't appear that the rooms were regularly inspected for cleanliness and maintenance issues. They could do better.

I suspect business is good enough and they'll coast along.

Anabasis
Chicago
Contributor
18 reviews 18 reviews
Reviews in 17 cities Reviews in 17 cities
104 helpful votes 104 helpful votes
'Not recommended'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

If you want to stay at a place where the furniture and fixtures are frayed and dirty, the staff surly and the access inscrutable, I highly recommend St Botolph's; if not, flee. I booked St B's because it was convenient to my meetings and had excellent ratings on TripAdvisor. When I arrived there was a locked door with an enigmatic access system that you get to figure out while you are waiting in an uncovered area (it was pouring the day we arrived.) We finally gave up and rang the door bell, only to be greeted by a surly young voice demanding our access code. He was appalled that we did not have one but reluctantly admitted us. They email it to you, unless of course you book through a third party such as as Orbitz, as we did. There is no access (or management presence on the property) after 10pm except by code, so don't be late!

We were assigned a "ground" floor room. And by ground floor, I mean 8 feet underground with a slit of light at the top. Objecting to paying $350 for such a room, we were met with disbelief and more surliness and the comment that we had only paid $250 (It was $369 to be exact.)

We got a better room, which looks nice in pictures but the way-too-cool furniture and fixtures are dented, chipped, banged up and, in one case, hanging precariously from the wall. Our shower area was dirty and the obviously short maid only cleaned the glass as high as she could reach leaving about 2 feet of dirty glass.

The building is noisy and largely uninsulated as you can hear every door open and every conversation on the street when the windows are closed.

Our clock was set 40 minutes behind the actual time, The thermostat had a low battery and didn't function properly. And of course there is no one to call at 11 pm when you discover this.

This frumpy B&B without the delightful owners to make up for its frumpiness is really unworthy of the praise it gets.

The droopy orchid that greets you as you enter (see photo) says it all. as does the notice in the room that says you will not get maid service unless you ask for it.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Anabasis about The Inn At St Botolph
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Thomas DeSisto, General Manager at The Inn At St Botolph, responded to this review
June 4, 2012
Dear Valued Guest,

First, allow me to thank you for choosing the Inn @ St. Botolph!

I apologize that you found your stay to be less than satisfactory. The staff at the Inn @ St. Botolph takes great pride in offering outstanding customer service. We realize our hotel is not typical and we work very hard to ensure that guests realize this before making a reservation. Unfortunately, when booking through third party websites our message is not always translated clearly.

The Inn at St Botolph integrated state-of-the-art technology when we first opened our doors in 2008. I can certainly sympathize with you and understand how some features of the hotel may have been different than what you were expecting. However, most of our guests choose to stay with us for those very same features. Some examples of our uniqueness are the keyless entry locks on the front door and unit doors, color video intercom system, free wireless and plug-in internet, i-home integration, unlimited telephone calls within the continental united states and Canada, 42' satellite TV complete with complimentary movie channels not to mention in-room features like a full size refrigerator with ice maker and kitchenette complete with wine and champagne glasses, luxury bedding plus so much more

The process of making a reservation with our hotel is also different. Most of our guests make an online reservation through our website. Payment is processed at the time of reservation and a confirmation is immediately returned via email. Two weeks prior to your arrival date guests receive an email providing them with a room assignment and entry code that will work to the front door and their room. This code is unique and only works from 3pm on the arrival day to 11am on the departure date. Upon arrival guests simply enter their code and voila - they have access to the hotel, their room and the gym. Our front desk is not located at the entry point but instead is situated on the ground level along with the business center, lounge and gym. Guests enjoy extreme privacy while they reside with us, but our staff is always available 24 hours a day, 365 days a year, willing to provide as much or as little support as needed.

All of the rooms at The Inn at St Botolph have a Southern exposure. The one bedroom ground suite has full size windows, is partially below grade and by nature receives the least sunlight of any of our suites. For this reason, this over-sized one bedroom is priced less than similar room types at The Inn. Let me assure you that because this room is so aggressively priced, is frequently reserved by third party sites and is the only guest room on the ground level, we are extremely careful that we clearly outline our room description. When making an online reservation we encourage guests to read the room description and visit the hotels website for specific information about the features of the establishment. Even intimate boutique hotels like ours have several different room types. Although each has a unique nature, not every room or every hotel is perfect for every guest.

Please be assured that we take positive and negative guest reviews very seriously. Based on your criticisms, we are in the process of re-evaluating the reservation process with third party vendors and are re-invigorating our team to better address details and handle stressful situations. I can assure you that your stay and experience is an anomaly for us.
We would be honored if you would allow us to host you on your next visit to Boston with our compliments. Please let me personally re-introduce you to our quaint little hotel.

My Sincerest Apologies,

Thomas DeSisto
Hotel Manager
617-236-8099
Tom@innatstbotolph.com

This response is the subjective opinion of the management representative and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

SH83
UK
Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Great concept, top location - bring earplugs!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 20, 2012

Pros
- excellent location, on the border of South End (cosy restaurants, pleasant streets) and Back Bay (shops, restaurants, bars) so its an easy walk into Down Town (but out of the tourist zone like the big hotels are in), plus it has a subway station 5 min walk away so its 45mins from picking up your bags at the airport to being in your room.
- key system, great too as you can't lose your keys, it doesn't matter when you check in and presumably you save money as less staff
- decent light breakfast
- very comfy bed
- ipod dock a great idea
- lots of space - had a bedroom, hall, living space and bathroom
- windows are pretty soundproof
- rooms 201, 101, 301 and 401 have the bay window

CONS
- don't pick a room next to the lift shaft (I think that is room 100, 202, 302) as your bedroom wall (thin partition) is adjacent to the elevator shaft and very noisy - we asked to move rooms NB staff helped us do this
- there is little soundproofing between floors so you can hear every footstep above you and I could hear our neighbor on the telephone in the bedroom next door until after midnight
- I agree some fixtures and paintwork could do with some TLC
- on arrival (after the 3pm check in time) we let ourselves into the room and found it hadn't been cleaned at all which was very annoying after travelling from the UK but the staff did sort it out fairly quickly
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Ask SH83 about The Inn At St Botolph

Thomas DeSisto, General Manager at The Inn At St Botolph, responded to this review
June 5, 2012
Dear Valued Guest,

Thank you for choosing the Inn @ St. Botolph!

We are very glad that you enjoyed your stay and appreciate you sharing your feedback! You are correct that all of the '01 rooms feature the turreted windows and look out over the corner of St. Botolph and West Newton Streets!

While we are a small 16 room boutique, we can't keep all of the rooms away from the elevator. We don't often receive complaints from the guests in the rooms that are adjacent to the elevator, but we do provide white noise machines to help alleviate any noise concerns our guests may have.

Please let us know when you are traveling to Boston again, and we will be happy to assist you with your reservation needs.

Best Regards,

'Unique Boutique Hotel, Close to the Action'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 7, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

This hotel was referred to me by a friend prior to a West Coast trip, when I had an early morning flight. Instead of taking an early morning bus from north of Boston to Logan at 3:00am, I decided to stay in the city to make sure I had a hassle-free experienceand a night out on the town. I stayed only one night, but want to move in! I had a very restful night's sleep in a VERY comfortable bed/linens.

This place is just a block away from the Prudential Center, yet I felt like it was in the heart of the South End. Also at 4am I was able to catch a cab right away on Huntington(I think the cabs line up for the Colonade Hotel... score!). Luckily I saw that the T doesnt run that early, if it was a later flight I couldve saved $20 and just paid a few bucks for the T, as there is a stop right at the Prudential.

The minimal interaction I had with the staff was warm, and I think its great that you dont have to have awkward give-and-take with a front desk person when you come and go. The office is on the lower level and next to the lounge/ breakfast room, and I had a good "shoot the breeze" chat with Tom the manager.

Overall, a great start to my trip and a great experience.
Less

Elgador
Boston, MA
Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 15 cities Reviews in 15 cities
26 helpful votes 26 helpful votes
'Uh-Maaay-Zing'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 6, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Before I start, you should know two things:

1. I live in Boston
2. I stayed here twice within a month

Okay, so now that I got this out of the way, you got a gist of what I'm going to say about this place; LOVE IT. I had the pleasure to stay at this wonderful property with my special guy for some personal time away from home. Our first stay was in a fourth floor unit that was spaciously cozy and the design was not overly stylish, but had an artful and simple charm- a dream studio apartment. It was truly a home away from home as it is nestled amongst the brownstones in the Back Bay/South End area. If I could afford to live here, this is exactly what it would feel like. The hotel staff were practically invisible (but always a phone call away- if you needed them) which made you feel like a true resident. Being centrally located between the high-end Prudential Center area and the urban-chic South End neighborhood, the options for restaurants and venues are endless. Easy for catching cabs, commuting or just strolling. There is a 7-Eleven across the street if you need to grab some snacks, beverages and ingredients, should you decide to make a meal in the privacy of the fully-loaded kitchenette in your room.

For our second stay we were given a room on the first floor, right by the front entrance, which we were not happy about at first (naturally we thought we would lose the nice view and gain the noise of traffic coming in/out the door) but when we entered the room it was as though we entered a sanctuary. The room layout was cleverly designed to accentuate the windows and we found that the views were actually better here. As for any outside noise...what noise? We didn't hear a thing! We made the most of kitchenette and stored our left over dinner in the fridge and cooked a delightful breakfast in the morning. I cannot forget to mention that the beds here are one of the most comfortable beds we've ever slept in!

Cons:
1. Parking - they don't have parking for the property and the closest one is at the Prudential Center which can be expensive. But they soften the blow a bit with a discount coupon available at the office (for $27.00 for overnight).

2. Standing Showers - I am not sure if this is true for all units, but the two we stayed in only had showers. I like the option to take a bath (especially when I am away from home and have the time to do so). But its not a major issue being that the bathrooms are nicely designed.

The Technicalities:

They have satellite cable with a lot of channels, which is great. However, you can't order any movies although the ads make it very tempting.

They have an iPod dock, which is great for providing your own music...but it only works with iPods (not iPhones).

Wi-fi was great..strong signals throughout!

If you're like me and like to experience hotels/inns as a way of feeling at home or as a local, than The Inn at St. Botolph will satisfy your needs. I would definitely stay here again...and again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

My party traveled to Boston the last week of March 2012. We rented all three rooms on the 4th floor (the 2 bedroom, the 1 bedroom and the studio), so we had the entire 4th floor. The neighborhood is the best with public transportation just around the corner. I have already recommended this place to several people who will be visiting Boston. I am from Chicago and have been in lots of places. This one ranks right up there. You will NOT be disappointed. Anyone who has a complaint about this place simply cannot be pleased anywhere. Strongly recommend the Inn at St. botolph.

'Best in Boston'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012

If you are headed to Boston for business or leisure, there really is no comparison to Mandarin. Location on Boylston street is ideal, connected to Copley center for best Boston shopping. Restaurants and bars are literally across the street, Fenway park is 10 minutes away. The rooms are the most spacious and luxurious. Over sized bathrooms, with mirrors in the shower, ideal for shaving. Hotel is most expensive in Boston, but clearly is the best in town.

'Luxury and serenity'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 2, 2012

I stayed in a deluxe king bed room on the Extra Day Away - One Free Night offer in mid- February. After a thorough search through tripadvisor, i chose the Mandarin for its luxury, comfort, and location.

Rooms are clean and comfortable and the bathrooms are marble and lovely. There is a large shower, bath tub, and separate WC area.

Room service is available 24hours and the food is delicious. Staff are very helpful (had some issues with the telephone , which were quickly resolved) and cordial.

The spa is fantastic and can cater to your needs. I asked for a leg - centere massage, which was heavenly.

The hotel's proximity to stores, parks, and the downtown area is ideal. A bit on the expensive side for Boston, but can be worth it

Courtyard by Marriott Boston Copley Square

tinapascal
New York City, New York
1 review
'GREAT HOTEL, NEAR BACK BAY, WALK TO NEWBURY ST.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

I first heard about the Courtyard Marriott from a google search. The pricing wasnt all that ridiculous compared to other hotels in the area. My daughter attends Northeastern University, and you could walk from here. I've been staying there for the last four years. The staff is fantastic, especially Justin McToal. Anytime I needed a new reservation, or needed anything special while there, he was right there to accomodate me. I have never seen such a clean place! The ladies room in the lobby was so sparkling clean that you could literally eat off the floor. Everything was shiny clean! There's not a whole lot of frills but who cares, you are literally 1 1/2 blocks to Newbury St., a few steps from Prudential Center, Boston Duck Tours, and across the street from Lord and Taylor. I highly recommend to anyone looking to stay in Back Bay.

person found this review helpful

The Courtyard Copley Square is a great central Boston hotel. As Courtyards go - it is not the typical cookie cutter style. The rooms are large and nicely appointed, some with bay windows that open to let in the fresh air. The staff is wonderful - anticipating your needs before you do. Within walking distance of great shopping and restaurants and a short 15 minute cab ride from Logan. When you're leaving, be sure to ask the staff to book you a car service. The company they use is excellent, friendly, on-time and the same price as a cab.

'Great Location!!!'

Stayed here May 11 - 13 while in Boston for two Red Sox games. I dont live far from Boston but prefer to just spend the night when going to games. Used Marriott points one night and got a great deal the second night. This hotel is a perfect location. Walked to Fenway one night in about 15 minutes. Only downside was parking...$45 a night for valet but it is Boston however even this a little high it seems. Would stay here again however would take T into Boston or find a cheaper place to park

Seaport Boston Hotel

Bucks161
Cork, Ireland
1 review
'All you could want and more'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 14, 2012 NEW

Having just returned from a three night stay at The Seaport Boston Hotel, my wife and I can't wait to go back. The hotel is located in the harbour area and we had a beautiful room on the 8th floor overlooking the harbour. The room was very spacious with some really nice touches. They have a 'Pillow Library' where you can choose from a variety of pillows. The staff couldn't have been more helpful and friendly. As I was in Boston on business I found the hotels business centre of great use. Don't be put off by the fact the hotel doesn't have it's own parking. You can still avail of the valet parking which is charged at a daily rate. All gratuities are included in your room price so the staff won't accept any further tips.
The area has many bars and restaurants from Dunkin' Donuts across the road to the Legal Seafood Harbourside Restaurant and The Whiskey Priest Bar. The hotels Tamo bar is really relaxing and we had a light snack on one evening which was delicious.
The walk from the hotel to the city center takes in some wonderful views from the busy harbour area to the impressive skyline of the city. Having stayed in the Back Bay area on our last visit, we will hopefully be returning and will definitely be recommending The Seaport Boston Hotel.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'Chitty Chitty Bang Bang'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

This is a business travelers review of this property, so take it in that context.

Let me start by saying, I love Boston. The city has tremendous charm, excellent restaurants, a multitude of cultural and social attractions and a very rich history. It also has a plethora of fine hotels. This, honestly, isn't one of them.

First, the good:

*The hotel is clean
*It is located near the financial district (approx 10 minute walk, or 2 minute cab ride)
*The service was excellent
*There are multiple on site facilities including full health club, spa, restaurant, snack shop, bar and valet.
*It is easily accessible form Logan airport via public transit.
*Non smoking and pure air facility. I stayed on a "pet-free" floor.
*Nice lobby, plenty of seating and meeting spaces.
*There is free wifi throughout the property. It was quick and had a strong signal.
*This is a "service inclusive" hotel. Staff will not accept tips. Really. I tried!


Now, the not so good:

*The room was sparsely furnished. I didn't find it comfortable or inviting.
*My room, right next to the elevator, was SO noisy. I heard the elevators whipping up and down, all night. Have they not heard of sound proofing?
*The bed, while large, was saggy.
*They charge an exorbitant amount for overnight parking $42
*Not centrally located.
*There isn't much in the immeadiate area, so be prepared to walk long ways, or cab it to different areas within the city.
* The surrounding area has a very industrial feel

The bottom line:

Given the vast choice of places to stay in Boston, I would only stay here if you are (a) travelling on a budget, (b) get an incredible rate (I paid $247 a night), (c) or are attending an event at the nearby convention center. Otherwise, I suggest you seek other accommodations.

This is a hotel that, like the little car that could, really wants to be a good hotel, and does try, but ultimately comes up short versus the competition.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask BeachBound_MM about Seaport Boston Hotel
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
IzzyEdmonton
Edmonton, Canada
Senior Contributor
43 reviews 43 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
27 helpful votes 27 helpful votes
'Your Home Away From Home!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

Having travelled all over the world and stayed at many 5 star properties, I have to say this hotel ranks amongst some of the best. What sets this hotel apart from many others is its CUSTOMER SERVICE! It is top-notch.

The hotel is located on the waterfront, across the harbour from Logan Airport. Best way to get to the hotel from the airport is by public transit - Silver Line - SL1 - picks up at every terminal at Logan and takes you to the hotel in 10-15min for $2!!! Get off at the World Trade Center station and the hotel is right across the street from the station, a short 2 min walk. Why pay $30 for a taxi and spend 30-40 min in traffic to do the same thing? Public transit in Boston is the way to get around and this hotel is located right on the Silver Line. The hotel provides a beautiful view of the harbour and has many great restaurants within walking distance. It is also a short walk across a bridge from the Boston Convention Center. Can't ask for a better location. To get to great shopping ob Newbury St, simply take the Silver Line again and with 2 transfers and 20 min later, you're there. No need to spend $30 for a taxi.

The hotel has an all inclusive pricing policy. $3 per day is added to your hotel bill for "tipping", so there is NO tipping allowed outside of that. What a great idea! No more feeling obligated to tip or fumbling for change. The staff is very friendly and extremely helpful. From the bell staff to front desk, to concierge, housekeeping, in-room dining, banquet staff etc., every single staff I encountered was friendly, helpful, efficient. I have no complaints!

Check in was quick and easy. My room was on the 11th floor and I could see the harbour from my window. Room was very large with a good sized bathroom. Well furnished and very functional. Although you could tell the furniture is getting old, it did not have a run down feeling. Everything was clean and neat. There was a mirror and small ledge in the hallway for you to put keys etc on. A built in luggage rack with drawers below provided ample storage space. Large work desk with high speed internet connection for the business traveller. Free high speed internet is available throughout the entire property - fantastic! Business centre provides computers if you didn't bring your own. What's great was that they also provide free printing service. You can print anything right from your own laptop in your room and retrieve it from their printer in the Business Center - 24/7!

In room Keurig coffee maker, mini-fridge, iron, ironing board, umbrella and even a UPS envelope! In room safe also available. Very comfortable bed with a nice duvet and a "pillow library" with 10 different kinds of pillows for you to choose from. You will get a good night sleep here! The only complaint I have with my room was that it was close to the elevator and you could hear people talk, esp. at night when everything else was quiet.

The bathroom was a good size and had Gilchrist and Soames toiletries. The hotel is very "green" - everywhere you turn, you see evidence of them trying to conserve and leave a smaller carbon footprint. Good recycling program in room and throughout hotel.

In room dining was excellent. Food was delivered on time as promised. My Cosmo and white wine were always ice cold and the food was always hot. Surprisingly reasonably priced and extremely tasty! I did not expect the food from room service to be as good as it was - very impressed.

The workout area is quite large and full of state of the art cardio equipment. My only complaint here is that it closes at 9pm on week nights and 8pm on weekends. Too early for my liking. Did not use the pool or the spa, so can't comment.

Conference facility was good, as was the catering for the meeting. Beautiful herb and flower garden outside, which you should take the time to enjoy.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

William D
Detroit, Michigan
1 review
'Impressed with service'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

Booked this hotel because it was the venue for a conference I was attending and speaking at. At every turn, we were impressed with this property and its operation. Late check-in, multiple bags brought to room with us by front desk clerk, unloaded and tip refused -- there is a no-tipping policy. We had a corner suite on the waterfront, and only the absence of a separate shower stall gave any downgrade to the room. Staff was attentive. The concierge, Betty Salemme (one of Boston's best), worked magic, made helpful suggestions for dining "with Bostonians", arranged transportation. Great meeting facilities, too. Rooms have free wireless access, and ability to print to a central color printer. A very "with it" place, comfortable and friendly. A redeveloped area, with many amenities.

3rdimension
London
Senior Contributor
48 reviews 48 reviews
Reviews in 28 cities Reviews in 28 cities
15 helpful votes 15 helpful votes
'Good though pricey'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 9, 2012 NEW

I stayed in the Seaport Boston for a local trade exhibition - had a corner room with a view back over the conference and exhibition center, no view of the harbor which would be preferable.

This is a hotel that gets many things right - clean, comfortable, quiet. The room was of a reasonable size, the desk was adequate with a good number of power sockets, there is a Keurig coffee maker, room safe, free wi-fi. Bed is comfortable. Water provided was $2 for a small bottle and $4 for a slightly larger 'branded' bottle. The air-conditioning thermostat seemed somewhat unreliable. Breakfast is adequate with a buffet or a-la-carte choices. But it is not luxury, the entrance, foyer, facilities, style, the colors, quality of furniture and fittings were all pleasant but not striking, the area is ok, overall it was good as a business hotel. So no complaints but the price seemed at the high end for what you get.

One thing that I hadn't seen before for a US hotel is the policy that tips are included, something they remind you of at check-in and every time you settle a check. It doesn't mean they are included in the prices, it means they add them to the check and there does not appear to be any discretionary aspect to this.

As for the area from what I could see there was very little in the immediate vicinity. The hotel is close to the conference and exhibition center. There is a Morton's steak house across the road and the Legal Seafood restaurant a short walk away as well as a few other bars and restaurants. Otherwise the sites and activity is a longer walk or taxi ride away.

Overall I liked staying here and it definitely met the needs of my visit which was business. If I was a tourist I would probably choose a different location.
Less

Brook Farm Inn

Carol S
Ottawa, Ontario, Canada
Senior Reviewer
10 reviews 10 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
'There IS Poetry Here!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 24, 2012

Visited here mid-May for a poetry writing retreat. The inn's motto is "There is poetry here!" and I certainly agree. This is a lovely old inn, welcoming and accommodating hosts, comfortable rooms and a great library including many poetry volumes. Each morning we were greeted by an excellent breakfast, a strata or French Toast, fresh baked muffins or banana bread, whole grain breads, cereal, granola, yogurt, fresh fruit. And excellent coffee. And every morning we were entertained by a theatre of birds outside the window. Woodpeckers, cardinals, even a flock of wild turkeys passing by. The inn is immaculate, rooms are made up promptly and well-stocked with toiletries. There were quiet places for reading, a lovely porch and grounds to enjoy. The azaleas were in bloom and delightful. There was plenty of travel info on Lenox and the Birkshires, Tanglewood, The Mount etc. Both Linda and Phil were always helpful in finding a good place for dinner or even a good mechanic (one of our group had some car problems)
This is a place where you feel very much at home, as if you were visiting old friends. I didn't even have the usual "first night in a new bed can't sleep" thing. I slept well, woke refreshed and ready to go every morning.
Wonderful!
Less

'Winter Wonderland, but Wonderful in any Season'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed March 17, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We arrived between snow storms last January for my husand to give a speech and it was magical every minute in this beautiful house. Phil and Linda are the model hosts, the ones that you imagine every time you book a B&B..... but rarely find. Breakfasts were expansive with delicious homemade specialties (ask for Phil's baked French Toast!). You might all find a surprise drop of Sherry waiting on the mantelpiece of your real, working fireplace that is set and ready to light or cookies and coffee in the afternoon with hundreds of books to choose from for a good read. The bathrooms, beds, linens, towels, etc,were luxurious and each room a gem (we peeked at all of them!). Look carefully at their excellent website because every room varies in size and configuration but all have the same quality of amenities...not a bad room in the house. I even suggest calling and talking to Linda or Phil about your needs and they can help you choose the best room for you. This extordinary fully restored mansion is run as an annex to Heaven! Pure Bliss! Last but not least, the level of cleanliness is remarkable, BRAVO! to the staff.

DaikonLettuce
Providence, Rhode Island
Contributor
11 reviews 11 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Lovely inn, excellent hospitality'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed February 20, 2012

We spent a winter weekend at the Brook Farm Inn and enjoyed it very much. Linda and Phil are great hosts. The common areas of the inn are great--the dining room and the sitting/living area which has window seats and a fireplace. Linda makes scones and they serve tea at 4 on weekends. This past weekend, she also told stories during that time (she's a professional story teller). It was very cool. The location of the in is fantastic--within walking distance to Lenox center and minutes away from Tanglewood (it's appears to be even walkable). The hosts are on the premises and extremely helpful. The rooms were nice--our room had a fireplace and clawfoot bathtub. You have to walk down the stairs to use the bathroom which at first bothered me but then I ended up kind of liking the fact that the bathroom was separate from the room itself. It also struck me initially as not as luxurious as I was expecting given the price of the room, but that feeling also went away after a few days. It is quite luxurious in its own quaint New England, old inn sort of way. Overall it was a great stay.
Less

innkeeper18, Owner at Brook Farm Inn, responded to this review
December 2, 2011
Thank you to this guest, and all the others who take the time to write kind remarks. We're always delighted and gratified that our hospitality and breakfasts are enjoyed and appreciated. Just want to take this opportunity to note that our 15 rooms vary greatly in size. There are smaller, third floor rooms, large canopy bedrooms with wood-burning fireplaces on the first and second floors, and enormous rooms in the carriage house with jacuzzi tubs and other amenities. All guests, regardless of the room they select, can enjoy the large sitting room and library, both with fireplaces, and our ample breakfast buffet.

This response is the subjective opinion of the management representative and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
rand99
Boston, Massachusetts
Contributor
19 reviews 19 reviews
Reviews in 12 cities Reviews in 12 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'Tips for Brook Farm Inn'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed November 22, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

My wife and I really enjoyed our stay but there are some things we learned that may be helpful to other travelers. First, our hosts Phil and Linda were wonderful, and would do anything for us. Secondly, the place was clean and charming. It's close to down town Lenox, and we found plenty to do in the area. What might be helpful is to know that the stairs to the third floor are exceptionally steep, which was no big deal for us but for older travelers might be tough so avoid the third floor. We stayed in the Cozy Hideaway room. It was cozy and the website pictures are accurate, but be aware that with two people in the bed, one person will have a challenge to get out of bed without climbing over the other person. Again, this was no problem for us but may be for others. The room was small, but adequate and the bathroom was roomy. The only other thing to note is that I had a different idea about what a buffet breakfast was. It was served buffet style, but there was only one hot item and I found it to be average. Overall though it was a great experience and I would come back and I would also recommend Brook Farm to friends.
Less

Ames - A Morgans Original

LGSkiing247
New York
Reviewer
5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Traveler Beware'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

The Ames is centrally located to many of Boston's attractions. The decor is contemporary and Clean. Light sleepers may have some challenges here. Planes, trains, and buses are part of the typical noise flow despite the sound insulated windows. Ear plugs are complimentary in the night stand. They hotel was careless in placing us next to a family with an infant and toddler who woke us at 6:30AM wth screaming, playing and crying, in addition to shaking the adorments on the wall. It makes a good couples location but the Glass Showers may not permit the privacy wanted for families as a retractable currtain in the bedroom is the only coverage. The restaurant leaves only room for improvement. The service was very sophomore at best. Innattentiveness and hanging around with their collegues seems to be the status quo on both of our visits their. The food was atrocious. My desert resembled more of a burnt hockey puck with a overly heavy and rich chocolate pudding. Boston offers so many more great food options and service than this establishment can offer even if convienence is a factor. The front desk failed to adequately address our grievances over the disruptions. While checking out, another patron also expressed dissatisfaction over the noise and service levels. The supervisor kindly told me that they only had ten rooms available that night. When asked as to why they would place a family next to vacationing couples, I was met with a stupor and an offer of an upgrade to suite should I gamble with their Establishment again. The issues are much less of the hotel and location, city life is what it is, as it is more about the staff and their customer service.
Less

clutchbomb
New York City, New York
Top Contributor
52 reviews 52 reviews
Reviews in 24 cities Reviews in 24 cities
31 helpful votes 31 helpful votes
'My favorite Boston hideaway and the BEST restaurant!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012

Honestly, this is a FABULOUS boutique property. Chic, modern, upscale boutique with great service and probably the best room product in the city aside from the top 5-stars.

Pros:
Rooms- get a room that faces Court Street with the curved/rounded windows. We were upgraded into a suite and the room was stunning with fabulous street views (I've also stayed in a more standard level room which is equally nice and spacious). I love the furnishing, light colored hardwood floors, great bathrooms with my favorite bath products (Malin & Goetz).

Restaurant- Woodward is incredible. Their skillet/hash breakfasts are to die for (get the Lobster one). The dinner appetizer- short rib tortellini- is hands down one of my favorite culinary creations of all time...I think we ended up having 3 orders. The vibe is fun- a little younger, with a great upstairs bar and dance section.

Cons:
Although central, it's not my favorite part of the city- it's very financial district(ish) but a great central point to start from to walk to all the main sites. It's also pretty close from the train station so a short taxi trip.
Less

yagators
Tampa, Florida
Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Great Location, Noisy'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I'll start with the good stuff: This hotel is in a perfect location. It's basically on the Freedom Trail and near several of Boston's best sites. The rooms were spacious with modern and simple furniture. The amenities in the bathrooms were very nice as well. The free breakfast, while minimal, was a plus. The staff was friendly and helpful.

The bad: I have never been in a hotel with this much street noise. I was there from a Saturday to Tuesday and every single night there were police cars and sirens going off basically once an hour if not more. There were also other loud cars and a ton of motorcycles driving by at all hours of the night. What's worse is that this hotel is located right next to the Veterans Homeless Shelter so there were men sitting outside and across the street arguing loudly at 11 p.m.. We were in a room on the 6th floor overlooking Court St. but it was certainly not high enough to shield any of the noise. I went to sleep every night with a pillow over my head. Luckily, the hotel offered sleeping pills on the mini bar and I went ahead and purchased those so I could at least get a few peaceful hours. The hotel warned us of construction noise and I found out on the last day that there were ear plugs in the drawer of the night stand. Wish I had seen those just a few days sooner.

All and all, I liked the hotel but I wish I was in a different and quieter room.
Less

Toronto
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Excellent quality!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I was lucky enough to stay at the Ames in Boston over the May 19th weekend. It is in an amazing area, minutes from many landmarks, restaurants and shops. The service was excellent, rooms spacious and they were very generous with their towels.

We had arrived pretty early in the morning and understandingly, our rooms were not ready. They stored our luggage for us, showed us the way to the nearest subway stop and off we were. We made it back at about 4pm and our rooms were ready. Luggage and bathrobes were sent up quickly.

They have a wonderful free continental breakfast for guests. Bagels and croissants, yoghurt, fruit, hard boiled eggs, coffee and juice. The staff was friendly and kept everything well stocked.

The rooms were large, the soaker tub fantastic and we got a great view of old State House. The decor is very modern and furniture in the room is sparse, making everything feel even more spacious.

I really enjoyed my stay and would recommend it highly to others.

The front desk was superb and paid attention to my room requests. The room was spacious and very clean. The bathroom was lovely with a rain shower and a heated towel bar. The mini bar, as well as the breakfast (which was complimentary), had plenty of choices! I most enjoyed the hip decor - very different and modern. My only complaint is that I am a light sleeper and the walls are fairly thin. Having said that, I was graciously placed in a corner room and felt as if I had most of the entire floor to myself.

You will not beat this front desk - and you really do get the feeling that the staff will do anything and everything to make your stay special.

I cannot wait to return!

LoveLuxuryHotels
Philadelphia
Contributor
15 reviews 15 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
16 helpful votes 16 helpful votes
'Trendy, great location..'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 16, 2012

Spent 3 nights at the Ames last weekend and was not disappointed. Let me preface my comments by saying- we did have a corner king room with 3 large windows all around, so that may have biased my views, vs. someone who had a smaller room. I am not sure how may windows the non- corner rooms have. Here are some of my observations:
Rooms: As mentioned, our room was very airy and bright, comfy bed, huge bathroom. As others have stated, the dcor is certainly modern, but very trendy and serene at the same time. The bathroom amenities were Malin+ Goetz, very in line with the whole feel of the hotel.

Service: Great service, concierge Charles was very helpful; even when we were out and about, we called him for directions or restaurant reservations, and received them promptly. Everyone we interacted with was friendly and helpful.

Amenities: Free breakfast sounded great, but never woke up in time to make itmade it down at 11.30 one day, and true to good service, the guys cleaning up after breakfast got me a whole tray of pastries/croissants and there was still coffee/tea set out. We did not eat at the restaurant, but had drinks and it was certainly a nice scene, better than any of the neighboring bars/lounges.

Location: Very convenient if you want to do the historic stuff, CVS across the street; 5-7 minute walk to Boston Commons, thru which you can cut thru and reach Newbury street shopping in another 10 mins. Centrally located to reach the North end or even Charles street and the river. Cabs were not quite abundant, so be prepared to wait for one outside the hotel, or just walk!

All in all, a fun, trendy 4 star; as long as you get a spacious room, you should be all set!
Less

Fairmont Battery Wharf

Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews

1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'I expected a little more for the price'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

Just left the Fairmont Battery Wharf; the front desk, extremely helpful, polite and professional, absolutely awesome. The room, had to run the A/C at 65 degrees just to keep the room cool, don't know why but the room always seemed warm. Very good breakfast; I bought the bed and breakfast option which says free breakfast but somewhere in the fine print it's only good up to $21.09 per breakfast, very strange. What I didn't care for at the Wharf is the bathroom, I don't understand why the bathroom doors (two sliding doors so they never completely come together) are 5 feet from the bed. Without getting too graphic or gross, what this means is whoever is in the bedroom can easily hear all the 'events' going on in the bathroom. In most hotels these doors are usually a solid wall with the bathroom entrance off the entry hallway that would at least allow for some bathroom privacy. The location is great, a 5-10 minute walk to the T and if you buy a day pass you can ride the T, train or bus all day. The water taxi over was fun and a cab ride back to the airport only cost $17.00 and you can't beat the Boston north end.

JDP112456
Massachusetts
Contributor
19 reviews 19 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
29 helpful votes 29 helpful votes
'Great location but skip the Gold rooms'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
6
people found this review helpful

We've stayed several times now at the Fairmont Battery Wharf and I want to give my overall impression.

First, the location is terrific. The views of the harbor are great, and it is across the street from the North End and only a 10 minute walk from Faneuil Hall Marketplace. Also, very close to getting onto Route 93.

The property consists of several buildings, some of which are also residential. There is the main building where you check in, and one just across from it where they have one bedroom suites. Another building, just off the water, and not as close as the other two, houses a separate Gold floor of rooms.

We've now stayed in all 3. The main building and one with the larger rooms have the best views. The rooms are nice, spacious, and modern. Bathrooms are large as well. The one bedroom suite is very large and the bathroom is enormous, with a separate tub and shower area. We loved both locations.

We recently stayed at the Gold building. First, it requires a room card key to get in, so if you are checking in there make sure someone is taking in your bags with you or you won't get in. Seperate check in here doesn't have the advantages as it does at other Fairmont properties. Now it took us about 10 minutes tocheck in once we got inside as they had us booked into another room which was already occupied. The room we did get had a nice view, but again set back a little farther from the water.

While the food, both at night and in the morning was very good, the service was poor. Finding any utensils, or a napkin, was a challenge, as well as finding a clean place to sit in the morning. Again, it wasn't like other Gold areas in other Fairmont properties.

We highly recommend staying here, and will do so in the future, but will probably stay in a standard Fairmont room where you get the best room and deal by far.

JDP
Less

'Absolutely flawless!'

I Live in Massachusetts and am embarrassed to admit I never had the opportunity to stay at a hotel in Boston- mostly because I lived so close and the expense of it all. Well, my boyfriend and I were invited to a night wedding last week and decided to stay in the city that night. WOW- a friend of his recommended this hotel and I have to say I have NEVER stayed in a hotel so nice- anywhere- Most people have hit the nail on the head in their reviews already, but I loved it so much I wanted to share-
Upon arrival we were greeted by valets who were extremely pleasant, helpful and informative. We got to the room and my gosh- they told me we didn't have a view BUT we were right on the wharf! I don't think there IS a bad view there- we looked right out onto the water....
Amenities included beautiful decor- modern and classy- expresso machine that really worked and produced expresso for real :-) Lovely leather lounger, gorgeous linens and extremely comfortable king size leather bed with huge silk headboard- stunning color coordination- 46" flat screen- huge for a hotel! Tasteful woods and lighting. The hall closet opened up from the bathroom- I LOVED this- so convenient- the bathroom had a large walk in shower with overhead rain shower , large sink area with modern fixtures-
I had a wardrobe malfunction and called the front desk- in 5 minutes a nice woman arrived at the door and proceeded to help me "fix" the situation- sweet-
I could go on and on- if you just want a treat / sneak peek just go in and look at the main lobby ladies room - (ladies! :-) )
Walked to tiny place for a quick breakfast- they held our baggage for us without a problem and suggested where to go even when they had breakfast there- high quality service-
We didn't want to leave.. we just loved it there- seriously - Didn't get to see the building that housed the spa and fitness center- it was huge- in retrospect we should have at least checked it out-
ENJOY this place is you are lucky enough to go there- I could not find a single thing wrong with it- it cannot disappoint! :-)

acaller
London, United Kingdom
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Nice hotel in good location, but...'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 9, 2012 NEW

I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights during a recent business trip to Boston. To be honest it was not my first choice and I'll not stay there again if I can help it. The room was perfectly nice and the reception and bar staff perfectly lovely -- but far from what I would have expected given the reviews and the prices.

Let's start with the room. I had a very good room by all accounts, and the bed was nice. But the room was badly laid out and the bathroom was quirky and small with just a single basin (okay for me for a few nights, but hopeless for a couple, or even a woman who would need to do makeup). The AC worked but the thermostat was unreliable so that it was almost impossible to get the temperature comfortable and keep it there. The Internet was wireless and free -- good for a business hotel -- but was slow and kept timing out. The room on the 4th floor was quiet, as requested, and helped by the ice machines being on the odd number floors only.

There is a restaurant that serves breakfast and dinner, but no lunch or room service. And there's nothing to shout about with the food which is expensive for what you get. The seating is uncomfortable and the ambiance, well, what ambiance. The bar is excellent, though, with a good selection of beverages, sensible music, knowledgeable and welcoming staff, and a great feeling. It's probably the best thing about the hotel.

There is valet parking, but it's slow. Cars are kept at a lot across the street and there are simply not enough staff to make it possible for two cars to be moving at the same time, either from or to the hotel. The morning I left I even booked the time I needed the car the previous evening, and still it was not there when I came to leave for the airport.

I would say that this all amounts to a bit of a shame. What could be superb -- nice decor in a great environment, simply fails to impress. I see that other reviewers have noticed some of the same issues I did and still gave 5/5... Perhaps those authors are less sophisticated travelers than I am and have simply not experienced what the best of the boutique hotels are like around the world.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask acaller about Copley Square Hotel
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

'Sophisticated, Elegant, Hip in prime location, convenient to everything!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

On this trip to Boston, my daughter (23 yrs.) and I went apartment hunting for her. We were extremely luck to get a fabulous rate ($170!!!) through priceline. The Copley Square knows what they are doing and how to take care of their guests. Everyone on the staff was extremely cordial, helpful, well spoken and dressed very professionally. Our first night we were in a King Deluxe room (408) with a very comfortable bed with exquisite linens and pillows. There was a settee next to the window with a decent view. All of the decor (including a casual chandelier over the bed) was very modern and comfortable. The bathroom and closet had plenty of room for 2 women and all that we travel with! Free wifi was a big bonus for us as we were apartment hunting. The 5 - 6 p.m. complimentary wine pour in the lobby was such a nice touch after long days of apartment visits. Then, the housekeeping came around with complimentary bottled water in the evening. I highly recommend this property for all of the above reasons and the fact that it is so centrally located to shopping, restaurants, public transportation, and the historic Boston city!

NOLATravelGal
New Orleans, Louisiana
1 review
'Chic boutique luxury'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012

This gem of a hotel is situated in the heart of Copley Square, within walking distance to the great shopping and dining options. I arrived very early in the morning and was welcomed with complimentary coffee and Leslie at the front desk, who graciously called me when my room was ready. I was not able to make it to Wine Down hour, but they offer a nightly wine reception for guests.

The decor is sophisticated, yet playful with neutral colors brought to life with bold patterns and pops of color. This was the first visit to the Copley Square Hotel, but hopefully not my last.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

BrendaTo
Toronto, Canada
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'Lovely hotel in good location but it's that staff that make it exceptional!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

My girlfriends and I spent our annual "girls" getaway at this lovely old hotel in historic Boston. The rooms were very nice - not overly large, but certainly sufficient, nicely appointed, with good lighting (important as we get older....) and comfortable beds. The rooms are somewhat oddly configured, but that was not totallly unexpected as it is a older building. The fan in our bathroom did not work, it wasn't a real issue for us, but the one in the other room did. The hotel itself was very quiet and is located near teh glorious Boston Public Library, Trinity Church, the Hancock Building, MANY shops and restaurants and Newberry Street. We had no view, unfortunately, but were happy with having quiet after long days of touring around (it is an older hotel so you can't always have everything!) While we all liked the hotel itself, it is the staff that made this an exceptional experience - from the very first bellman to the very last valet. Of special note is Ana, the concierge who seemed to be on the entire Memorial Day weekend. Ana made some great recommendations for restaurants in the area and helped get us in for dinner on a very busy night, on Newberry St. All the staff were friendly and helpful and very well trained - hey, Jude! - I hate to mention individuals when they were all that good. The restaurant in the hotel was opened only for breakfast and dinner. We had breakfast there several mornings - the prices were quite good for a hotel, and the quality was very good. The hotel has a daily "Wine Down" between 5-6PM which we took full advantage of, featuring Californian wines - a very nice touch, after a very busy day of touring. We were able to meet fellow travellers and exchange information about various locations/sites and finds!
One of us utilized the on-site Gym every day and said it was pretty good for a hotel. The password protected WiFi was an unexpected bonus.
I am impressed that Ryan called from the hotel a few days prior before our arrival to confirm the reservation and ask if there was anything more we required other than what we had previously requested, or if he could help to arrange any specific tours or restaurant reservations. He turned out to be one of the concierges on duty when we arrived and was as charming a young man in person as he was on the phone.
My husband and I are now planning a getaway to Boston and will certainly make this hotel our base, as well.
Less

18 reviews 18 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
10 helpful votes 10 helpful votes
'Lovely central hotel, with nice extra touches'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

I usually stay in the Back Bay area of Boston due to the central location and the numerous of nearby amenities and attractions. This was the first time I'd stayed at the Copley Square and I can't believe I didn't try it earlier. First impressions were good. Staff on check-in very friendly and efficient and my room and bathroom were definitely a decent size (although I think I was in a 'Deluxe'?). Probably the only thing that let it down was the not so great view of a road, from my window. On a sunny week in Boston though, I wasn't planning on staying in and looking out a window though... Location-wise it's perfect. Literally in the heart of Back Bay, right next to a million shops, restaurants etc, a short stroll from Boston Common and right around the corner from the nearest T stop.

The thing that absolutely impressed me most though was the nice little touches. Not only is there free wifi for example, but also an inclusive 'wine reception' every evening - very nice on return from a day at work! Then there's the card placed in your room every day that informs you of events for that day and the next (my particular favourite being 'National Chocolate Chip Day' on which an enormous and complementary chocolate chip cookies was also placed in my room)...

I would definitely stay here again, particularly considering the price I paid for a last minute trip. Very good value for money.
Less

'Great Location. Microscopic Room.'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012 via mobile

We bid $140 on Priceline for Memorial Day weekend which must be why were in a tiny room with a queen bed and a small bathroom with barely enough room to use the toilet. Speaking of the toilet, the seat was loose as was the toilet paper holder. There was free Internet but no free water. Even though we were on the 6th floor, the window was not soundproof and we could hear the bar below.

The bed was hard and there was no sheet, just a one piece comforter which is too warm unless the room was freezing. I like just a sheet which most nice hotels now have.

When we left to attend a Red Sox game, I asked for 2 extra pillows to be brought to the room. They were not there when we returned. I called and asked for 2 and they brought one.

JSorokurs
Hartford, Connecticut
1 review
'Cozy Room, Good Location, Quiet'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 22, 2012

I knew I was getting a "boutique room". That was fine; it was what I wanted in an historic hotel in Copley Square. After all, Boston is all about History - past, present and future. I liked the historic touches: the elevator, the gorgeous open staircase, the interesting shaped room, the interior doors (closet, bathroom).
My room had a chandelier and several lamps with dimmer switches so I had plenty of light to work at the desk, read in bed, do make up and hair. LOTS of light in the bathroom, which also had a magnifying mirror on an articulating arm. Very handy and nothing I've seen in other hotels.
The well carpeted hall was so quiet, I didn't realise that there were other guests near me.
The AC is central, so it's fairly quiet, unlike window units which are very noisy going on & off all night.
Saw the Gym on my way in & out. There's a bar off the lobby. Password protected Wifi on the premises.
The lobby was kinda dark but I was greeted each time I entered. The concierge was quite helpful, which is great when you're from out of town.
Location was great for me: Copley Square, near the T, the Boston Public Library, the Hynes Convention Center and all the cool shops & restaurants on Newbury St.

The only thing I didn't like was the decor in the room. It was all browns with intriguing patterns (wall paper in the bath has "The Midnight Ride of Paul Revere"!) but I would have liked something a little more in keeping with the historic nature of the building. But it's a hotel and with all the people coming & going, I understand why the furniture was black lacquer.

Should I have another opportunity, I'd be very happy to return to this hotel.
Less

melt2009

5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Would have been better with a nicer room'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012

I stayed at this hotel for 2 nights. Overall my experience was good-- the staff was friendly and helpful, the amenities in the room were nice and the room, while small, had very high ceilings which made it feel more spacious and grand. Probably the biggest perk were the sheets... so comfortable and felt like thin velvet. I slept great! On the down side, I was in a handicapped accessible room and they were unable to switch me to another so the bathroom was pretty unusual, in particular the shower which looked like it was straight out of a $80 a night hotel (thin plastic shower curtain liner with no other shower curtain, really small, mediocre shower head that wouldn't stay on straight so the water was always hitting the back wall instead of me, and peeling wall paper around the edges and near the shower stall). The shower made the whole experience in the room pretty unpleasant, especially at $350 or so a night. I did use the fitness center which was small but nice and had a drink at Bond, the restaurant/club in the lobby and that was also very fun. Overall, a good experience but bummed I didn't get a nicer room. I understand the need to have accessible rooms for those with disabilities but that doesn't give the hotel an excuse to make it really sub-par, especially at the rates the hotel charges.
Less

'Bustling hotel in a great location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

Thankfully I arrived in the mid-afternoon because the hotel was oversold and they had to turn away guests the later it got in the day. This Westin is in a great spot - next to a lot of shops, restaurants and some bars.

Check-in went smoothly. My room, on the 35th (out of 36) floor had a great view of the city. I liked the extra touch of an extension cord to accommodate the various devices one needs to charge.

I was especially delighted to have a voice mail from hotel management about joining their 'running concierge' for a run around the city and the Charles River the next morning at 6:30 a.m. Who knew such a thing existed?! In spite of a late night out, I made it down to the lobby, joined by a few other guests and we did five miles. Learned a bit more about the city and got a great work-out in! Apparently this event occurs on Tuesdays and Thursdays.

I found the staff very friendly, the Heavenly bed heavenly and the room clean. My only nits are: $47 for overnight valet parking (which persuaded me to not have a rental on this biz trip), sometimes slow elevators - considering the number of floors and the number of elevators available, you'd think you wouldn't wait too long, and one day where the internet connectivity was spotty or non-existent.
Less

FlipFlopsR4Me

160 helpful votes 160 helpful votes
'MANY THANKS to the Westin Copley Place for helping to make my daughter's 15th birthday one she'll never forget!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 8, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

We came to visit Boston for the weekend of my daughter's birthday and I have to say at first I wasn't thrilled to be spending a long weekend in Boston when we could've gone somewhere warmer, but this is where she wanted to spend it since she hopes to go to college here in 2015. We arrived at the airport at 1200 and I thought it was too early to check in so I called the Westin to see if we could at the very least check in our luggage. To my surprise I was informed our room was ready & we could check in as soon as we arrived.....Hmm, this was starting out to be a pretty good afternoon. Check-in was short & sweet, Thank you so much Kelly for helping out with EVERYTHING the Thursday we arrived, I hope my mother wasn't too overwhelming to deal with;)

Our room was on the 22nd floor & upon arrival I noticed everything was in order, the room & bathroom both very clean & well kept. When we arrived from lunch our roll away was in the room as requested upon check-in. The beds where very comfy, super clean linens & trust me when I say I am VERY thorough when checking hotels rooms out, my mother (who also accompanied us on this trip) has worked in the hotel business in NYC for over 25 years & she was with me and also praised the room on how well it was maintained.

We ate in the hotel for all 3 meals each day at either The Huntington (for breakfast) and Bar 10 ( for lunch & dinner) and all our meals were totally awesome as was the service. Marie at The Huntington was such a sweetie pie! Thank you so much for such lovely service. I felt like I was visiting family with her as our morning server. Amanda was also very friendly & attentive to us at Bar 10. My daughter loved the Red Velvet cake she gave her on her birthday, thanks again! We all loved all the shops inside the attached mall area, although a bit on the expensive side, it was still fun to walk around & browse. Loved the fact that we could buy our duck boat tour tickets in this mall then turn around and shop at Barnes & Noble and so many other great stores.

The highlight of our stay was the surprise birthday cake sent up on the morning of my daughter's birthday. She was just thrilled to see such a lovely set up for her on her special day! It was delicious & I'm sure her favorite dessert on this trip. Thank you to everyone involved in setting up & coordinating this from NYC to Boston, I appreciate it so much! In the end, I have to say we had such an excellent time in Boston and I have to thank The Westin Copley Place for doing such a great job taking care of us & totally changing my idea on how this trip was going to end up. I would HIGHLY recommend anyone interested in visiting Boston with family to stay here.

Avondaletraveler
Phoenix Arizona
Senior Contributor
46 reviews 46 reviews
Reviews in 16 cities Reviews in 16 cities
35 helpful votes 35 helpful votes
'A solid hotel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012

Great location, nice rooms, good service, I had no real complaints.
Our party arrived early to check in, about 11am, but our two rooms were still not ready till 2pm, ahead of check in, but later than we would have perferred.

Also, their breakfast buffet is not your best option. We had it on the weekend with the expanded service (and price) to include an omlette station. The price is too high for what you get ($30 each I believe) and the food is rather bland. There are so many places to eat in Boston, go elsewhere.

On the other hand, Turner Fisheries was a delight! Excellent service and ambience, the food was wonderfully presented and tasty (although portions were rather small, seafood appitizers are not meant to be shared) and the price in line with other local restaurants.

The hotel bar was also quite nice. It was very lively each night of our stay and althought we went elsewhere for our entertainment we found ourselves stopping in for a nightcap on our way back to our room due to the atmosphere.
Less
