yen77
Melbourne, Australia
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'As you would expect from a Westin hotel.'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012

Stayed here for 5 nights after a 4 night stay at the Hyatt Regency in Downtown Boston. Was in Boston attending two conferences.
The check in process here was efficient. I got the impression that it was a very busy hotel and that the room allocated to me was not ready at the time of check in. The receptionist did a bit of searching and found me a great room on a high floor - 2705.

The view is spectacular, don't get me wrong.

Upon entering the room there was an intense buzzing from the ventilator which soon disappeared with some tapping on the grille. However, the fan or whatever belt was used to power the fan sounded like a jet turbine whenever it came on, ie whenever it was working !

The floor supervisor happened to knock on my door and even open my door about 2 minutes after I entered the room - I gathered this unannounced entry was due to the fact that the front desk had randomly allocated my room and this woman did not realise it. She was very polite, a little bit flustered, but not in the least interested when I told her about the vent.

Being tired and extremely jet lagged despite staying in boston for 4 days prior, I decided to give the room a try and see how it went. The sound after all appeared to be confined in the entry hallway initially.

By the 2nd night the sound was a constant annoyance and I rang the service number who sent the engineer round during the day when I was out for the meeting. I returned to find that the sound was only slightly reduced and there were dust bunnies all over the room - a sign that the vent had been freed. I endured my last night with pillows over my head and the fan switched to a temperature that didn't come on frequently.

Another thing was the room was supposed to be newly renovated, but the entire shower apparatus on the wall kept coming off. The handle holds the tap and the chrome faceplate onto the wall and the handle itself was loose. This was rectified by the engineer though.

I had the opportunity to have breakfast in the hotel on my last morning, which was good. The maitre'd was very welcoming and efficient. All the staff were helpful overall. The gym was well equipped and extremely crowded come 6:30 in the morning.

Locationwise - I got bored from this location as the only attractions around the area are shops and the boston duck tours. I benefitted much more from the hyatt being close to all the happening places whereby food and touristy bits were much closer.

the overall feel from the hotel was that this is a nice hotel but the focus is on the numbers and they do not place enough emphasis on the upkeep and maintenance of the building. The side entryway from the lobby to the street had a revolving door which had a broken handle and was still not fixed when I left despite one day of the door being cordoned off with cautionery tape.

Only thing I have to say is I paid $100 more per night at the westin compared to the hyatt regency for a room half the size, and three times as noisy from the ventilation. Avoid room 2705 and stay here if you feel like paris hilton and are extravagant. Otherwise value for money awaits elsewhere.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

The rooms have been recently renovated which inlcuded that shower head and spiget...again a lapse by the housekeeping department in not reporting it to be fixed. I am really surprised that you got bored by the location and thought the downtown location offered mre to do...perhaps we did not do a good job on directing you to the myriad of attractions close by. It would help me tremedously if I could speak to you a bit more about your experience. Perhaps if you had a moment you could reach out to me at michael.jorgensen@westin.com

Once again my apologies and I look forward to speaking soon.

Obviously, the hotel is on the more expensive side, but, especially in big city hotels, you get what you pay for. I WOULD stay here again and WOULD recommend it for business travelers. No comment on family stays since I was not in this mindset during my trip!

Richard H
New York, New York, United States
1 review
'Absolutely loved it'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012

Start with the location: in the heart of Beacon Hill, steps from The Public Garden, near The Boston Common underground parking garage. Then the warm, welcoming staff. Then the design/graphics look of the place (very important to me): simple and clean (in all senses of the word) but warm and welcoming. Then the staff: friendly, knowledgeable, really pleasant to talk to.
The room was very nice. Small, but thoughtfully and tastefully furnished. No crappy hotel stuff. Like a nice bedroom in a nice housekinda modern, but with a traditionalist sensibility.
Loved the third floor terrace! Overlooking the street, with lots of light. Delightful. The complimentary breakfast was amazing. Not just some "continental" thing with some carbs and yogurt, this is a full menu. Order whatever you like, all complimentary (they just add a gratuiity).
The hotel was so quiet, I assumed we were maybe the only guests. Was shocked to hear that it was booked! Guess it's partly a credit to the clientele: not exactly the rowdy type.
Can't wait to return. Truly.
Less

Ask Chocolate74 about Beacon Hill Hotel and Bistro
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Chandler2004
Ottawa, Canada
1 review
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'The best Boston has to offer'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed March 19, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

The Beacon Hill Hotel and Bistro is a wonderful hotel in the historic Beacon Hill neighbourhood of Boston.

It is very well located, making it easy to walk to the Boston Common, Newbury Street, and downtown. Other parts of the city can be reached by taxi, which are not overly expensive compared to some other destinations. Beacon Hill itself is enchanting, with shops, cafes, and beautiful architecture.

Our room was on a street corner several floors up, giving us a great view of the intersection near the hotel and providing plenty of light into the room. The room itself was relatively small but very comfortable, with a great bed and modern bathroom facilities. Our room was at one extremity of the hotel, making Wifi unreliable but there is a quiet lounge area on the second floor in the hotel where the Wifi can be accessed without problem.

One of the best parts of our stay was the bistro on the main floor of the restaurant. It is decorated in a simple but classic style that fits very well into Beacon Hill's feel. The food was excellent, and the bar is a great place to relax after a day of walking around the city.

The breakfasts were incredible. They were included with the room but you are able to choose anything from the bistro's breakfast menu. This is no continental breakfast - during our stay we had everything from the standard eggs and hash-browns (with toasted warm sourdough bread) to pancakes and yogourt with granola and fresh fruit.

The hotel also has a roof-top patio with chairs and tables. A great place to sit and people watch, and the site of our engagement!

Parking is a little tricky since the hotel is located in a dense, historic neighbourhood. Parking at the nearby Boston Common was cheap enough, and since you can get around on foot or taxi it is good place to leave your car during your stay.

We strongly recommend the Beacon Hill Hotel and Bistro and look forward to our next stay - for us, the hotel itself is worth the visit to Boston.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Sherylan
Portland, Oregon
Contributor
12 reviews 12 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Perfect for a long weekend in Boston'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed November 27, 2011
3
people found this review helpful

The Beacon Hill Hotel and Bistro were everything I'd hoped for on a three-day trip to Boston...good location for lots of sight-seeing, quiet, pretty retreat every evening, personal service (not many rooms, so the staff knows who you are) but not so intensely personal as that at a bed-and-breakfast. I was able to get to many places on foot from this hotel and public transportation is a short walk across Boston Common. The staff is knowledgeable and most willing to assist you in getting to know the area. Even when they were busy with the bistro end of the business (the check-in desk performs dual functions for hotel and bistro), I was never neglected.

The room I had was small but well-appointed and perfect for a single traveler. With two windows, there was plenty of light; so I never felt confined by the space. I'd definitely choose to stay here again.

If you expect a separate check-in desk and a hotel lobby, this is not the place for you. Also, if you need elevator assistance, be sure to mention that when making your reservation. Staying in certain rooms requires climbing stairs in this charming little inn.
Less

sasli
new york
Top Contributor
110 reviews 110 reviews
Reviews in 24 cities Reviews in 24 cities
57 helpful votes 57 helpful votes
'excellent service'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

thanks to tripadvisor i found kate, who i sent an email to organize my booking here. she was extremely responsive and did a great job assisting me. i booked with a corporate rate on the phone, which saved us a good amount of money. we had a total of 4 rooms here, organized well and close to each other. the staff at check in knew who we were right away as they were expecting us. the companion goldfish made it to each room which was great and everyone was enjoying the company. we stayed for 2 nights and valet was just too much for our group so we opted to park at the governement center garage (google this!) which is literally a 2 block walk away on congress street. it is also the official parking for TD Garden. the rates are very affordable on weekends if there is no event, even if there is an event its cheaper than valet at the hotel.

the double deluxe rooms as noted by a staff are all non-street facing which meant we were away from the noise (if any) from the bars. you can request for a room on a higher floor which we did. the rooms are at 280 sq feet, which are small but in most city hotels the hotel rooms are tiny. the bathroom was bigger than usual but i love big bathrooms for my comfort. the sink was huge, which was also great, and there was a good space between the toilet the sink and the tub. the curtains on the tub expanded outward which meant it can accommodate a larger person comfortably as well. the water pressure was good too. the air condition in our room was loud enough to notice but if it wasnt pointed out on tripadvisor i wouldnt even have taken note of that. we slept well and it did not bother us. we did have room 801 as one of the rooms and the air condiitioner wasn't working well, they sent up an engineer to fix it but it was still very humid and damp/muggy in the room the rest of our stay.

the area is pretty deserted but this weekend we were there it so happened to be the final game 7 between heat and celtics so the bars brought in lots of people and there was a gay parade on saturday as well. the 7 eleven was extremely convenient for us as the drinks are super duper cheap there. the location is in good proxiimity to quincy market and faneuil hall, less than 10 minutes if you got the directions correct. also close to some good eats. if it werent for the game on saturday night i think we would have scored free parking on the street til sunday when we checked out. the T is also close by in case you want to navigate to the other tourist attractions in boston, but boston isnt exactly abundant in parking so no matter where you stay your best option would probably be to take the T anyway.

overall a good stay and great accommodations. i wished that would have been able to arrange light breakfast and croissants or something for us in the morning that we could have grabbed to go. it wouldn't cost too much extra and it would have definitely peaked the review and experience to a 5 star.
Less

We spent one night here because we were watching a game at TD Garden that night. The hotel is literally within steps of the Garden. The check-in and check-out process ran really smoothly. We were also celebrating an anniversary, so they upgraded our room to a penthouse suite (even without our request) -- that was very thoughtful and well appreciated. I'm not sure if I really like the decor of the hotel though, but that's my only complaint.

Some tips: If you are attending an event at the Garden, there is a discount via the TD garden website. Cabs take about 5-10 minutes if you want to call one -- this isn't NYC, where you can just hail one.

Eliot Hotel

Robert L
Freehold, New Jersey, USA
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Nice boutique hotel in a beautiful neighborhood'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 14, 2012 NEW

Other than the fact that the elevators smelled a little musty (which isn't really a problem because you don't spend a lot of time in the elevators), this was a very nice hotel. The room was clean and fresh, and the pillows/beds were very comfortable.

Our room had 2 double beds (a little smaller than queen beds), and the room was the size of a typical hotel room. By looking at the floorplan on the back of the door, we noticed that most of the other rooms on the floor were a lot bigger (more like suites, I suspect). However, we had plenty of space in our room.

We were in Boston on business, and typically stay in the financial district, but this time we decided to try staying in Back Bay. What a beautiful area! One block over, on Newbury Street, was block after block of trendy shopping and outdoor dining. You can easily take the subway or a taxi to the financial district, but the weather was nice so we walked. It was about a 35 minute walk, which we didn't mind since the weather was beautiful.

I would definitely stay here again!
Less

ALovelyMermaid
Penobscot, Maine
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Perfect Location for Fenway and Public Gardens'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

A very nice older style boutique hotel in a perfect location. Reminded me a little of the nice 3 star hotels in Paris but The Eliot was much larger. Beds were super comfy. We had a Suite that had 2 double beds and a large living room. The bathroom was marble tile: shower, walls and floor. Plenty of hot water. We were 2 couples and the space was more than adequate. I called the desk for extra towels and they were delivered promptly. Parking is $36. a night. I booked thru Bookit,com and got a $550. room for $335. including taxes. An easy walk to Fenway and the Public Gardens. Be sure to ride the beautiful Swan Boats; only $2.75./person. Room service coffee was $5. for a small pot but it was hot and very, very good. Three pots was plenty for 4 people. We did not have breakfast at the hotel restaurant (looked a little pricey). Went to the top of the Prudential instead and it was a special treat. Very elegant and moderately priced with a fantastic view of Boston. The best part was my boyfriend was asked to remove his baseball cap!
Less

5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Great Change'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Wanted to stay in town for the Red Sox game (they won against the Oriels in last inning with questionable hommer..but yea!!) ANd ran into 2 conventions in town so after calling 10 hotels, LUCKED into getting the last 2 rooms they had for the one night!!! I usually stay at the Boston Harbor (LOVELY) but no availabilities there. We arrived at this quaint looking brownstoneish hotel in the back bay AND now have another favorite place in Boston!!! The location is absolutely fantastic being close to Newbury street and within walking distance of Fenway which was great for us. The lobby is small BUT who cares!!! We checked in fast and went straight to rooms at the 3:00 check in time. The rooms were spacious and the bed uber comfy!!! Great suite layout! Bathrooms were a little small but totally fit with the ambiance of the hotel!!! The staff was professional and warm and had we stayed longer, I'm sure we would have had a better scope of all they could offer! The treats in the room upon arrival were SWEET!!! Best cookie and gummies EVER!!! The street was busy and a bit noisy BUT I can honestly say that with the layout of the room, my sleep was VERY PEACEFUL! It was a quick stay BUT will be going back!!! It's a great place even with the kids because it is close to many things AND they have tvs in room as well as the sitting area! One room had a HUGE computer with touchscreen (free internet...nice...not sure why our other room didn't have the computer..). It was a great surprise to find such a treasure of a hotel at the last hour...and will stay here again!! Also good for romantic weekend because it's so close to soooo many fun places....within crawling distance if you know what I mean!!! Give it a try!!!
Less

'A Decent Alternative To The Chains'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 7, 2012

Our family of four spent 3 nights at The Eliot in April 2012 and had a generally positive experience. The hotel is located close to shopping and dining on Newbury Street and within walking distance of a subway stop and Fenway. Our suite was large and comfortable, although the furniture and bathroom fixtures were beginning to show their age as were the elevator cars. The beds were of recent vintage and the hotel staff went out of their way to be helpful. The in-room computer was fine for simple tasks, but would be awful for serious work. If you want a good, quasi-European alternative to the traditional chains for vacation travel, the Eliot might be worth a look.
Less

'Niceeee but...'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I stayed here recently for two nights. The location of this place is very good. It is walking distance to Quicy and the harbor.

I stayed in room 626. Even after a quick shower, the floor outsite the shower area floods. It's a shame because the bathroom is sooooo nice. The shower system is really nice.

The bed is nice and firm. The entire place is very clean, no funky smell.

They did charge ~$10 for Internet, which I thought was a rip off. So I went across the street to Starbucks to use their Wifi while getting my coffee.

The room has a complimentry umbrella in the closet. The umbrella became useful since it rained on the day I was there.

I don't think the service is all that. When I got there, I asked the service desk person how do I get to TD Garden. The guy just handed me the local touristy map and asked me to look for it on there. I was like: Really?!

Overall, the hotel is nice. The location is good and clean. But the service and quality is bad. Would not stay here again.

jmp660
Toronto, Canada
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Amazing Location but that's about it!'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

I recently stayed at this property for (1) Saturday night. You really can not choose a better location. Seconds from Quincy Market and a 5 minute walk to the North End(Little Italy) best cannoli's around. I would describe this hotel as a boutique hotel. Entrance and lobby very modern and chic as were the rooms. The valet gentlemen were very helpful and attentive (steep overnight charge of $45). So here are my issues -
*no free wifi which is okay except for the fact that if you travel with a laptop, cell phone, ipad etc. you will be charge $9.95 per device per day to access the wifi.
*bottle of Fiji water in the room $6.50
*don't even think about touching the mini-bar as if you tap it you will be charged
*Bathroom is lovely, no bath tub just a beautiful shower - only problem is that the entire bathroom floor gets flooded when you shower. I slipped getting out of the shower because of all the water ( and yes, I had the floor towel down). I made mention of this to the front desk when I checked out but they didn't seem to care and said they would make a note of it.
*hotel does not have ice machines but you can request from room service "complimentary" which means you still have to tip the person who is bringing you the ice.

All in all, great location but for the price of this hotel, there are plenty of others that I would stay at next time in Boston. Just felt like I was getting gauged every turn I took at this hotel.
Less

'Great Location, Huge Rooms'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

This hotel is right next to Quincy Market.. Although it may not look like much on the outside, it has just gone under a massive rennovation and is now a modern looking hotel from the inside.

The hotel rooms are generous sized. there is a walkway that opens up into a big bathroom with oversized shower. Little bathroom amentites like cotton buds, cotton balls, mouthwash, shampoo, conditioner, body moiseteriser and body wash are available. So is a hairdryer.

It may get a little noisy at night, depending on the foot traffic outside, but you can't complain about that as you're in a prime location.

Walking distance to Hannover Street (little italy) which is fantastic. The best canolis I've ever had in my life can be found at Mike's Pastry.

InterContinental Boston

BDMNH9
Hampton, New Hampshire
Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 18 cities Reviews in 18 cities
11 helpful votes 11 helpful votes
'Good for Business'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

Considering this hotel is right in the Business District in Boston, I should have realized it was basically business oriented. Do not get me wrong, it is a beautiful hotel; well appointed, great staff and well situated to downtown Boston. The only thing I found lacking was, no restaurant for breakfast. From what I understand you have to order room service for breakfast which is expensive ( thus the very good rating instead of excellent). $10 for a bagel with cream cheese plus 18% gratuity and tax added on. We did not starve, the valet sent us to a great little deli
( Scali) which is frequented by the locals where a bagel with cream cheese is $2.50 and bacon and eggs special was $4.49.
The room itself was gorgeous with a spa like bathroom, quiet and huge. Standard room $470 but large enough to feel like a suite.
Location is great, incredible if you are here for business. It is only a five block walk to Quincy market and it is located at Independence wharf. The Boston Tea Party Museum can be seen from the restaurant ( which opens at 11am). The restaurant has a patio out on the wharf.
Great place for combining business and pleasure.
Less

DanJanet
Huntley, Illinois
Senior Contributor
25 reviews 25 reviews
Reviews in 16 cities Reviews in 16 cities
57 helpful votes 57 helpful votes
'Great hotel in a great city'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I stayed here Memorial Day weekend for a long weekend. The hotel is in a great location on the water right by the harbor.

We took a water taxi from the airport which was a lot of fun. The hotel has a dock right out back where you can request a water taxi to take you anywhere on the harbor.

We did not eat at any of the restaurants in the hotel but they did look rather classy, so bring something nice to wear. We walked across the bridge to the Barking Crab and had wonderful crab legs and lobster. We also had amazing cupcakes at Crumbs bakery just down the street.

The concierge was very helpful when we asked what was the best way to get to Harvard.

South Station is a 5 minute walk from the hotel which gives you access to the subway.

The nice thing about Boston is that it is small enough that you can really walk anywhere, and you want to because there is so much to see.

My only complaint about the hotel is the bed. It was horribly hard and fairly uncomfortable. For a high priced hotel like the InterContinental I expect a much better bed.

We did have a street view of the fire station but hardly ever heard the sirens, they rarely went off.
Less

The restaurant was very nice - we had an amazing breakfast service and the food was very good and not expensive. The staff was always there to assist. Great service! As I mentioned already, the key left on the windshield after my check in was just wrong. Then you have to go pick your car up in a hot garage??? I thought it was VALET... I should have used the self park next door instead. On the top of that, we were never helped with the bags upon check out. It seemed like they were there to drive cars only... Overall we enjoyed our stay but these minor details made us think that hotel is not really service oriented.

Lis L
Philadelphia, Pennsylvania
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Rooms are beautiful!!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

We stayed here May 26th, 2012 and really enjoyed our stay. We booked 2 rooms next to each other, a king standard room and a room with 2 double beds for my family. The rooms are beautifully appointed. The beds are very comfortable. I did use the extra pillow from the closet. Our bathroom had a really nice soaking tub and a nicely sized shower. The rooms were very spacious and had lots of seating which came in handy because we ordered room service at 1AM after a Red Sox game and all pigged out together. It was really fun, the food was great, service was friendly. Parking was a little expensive at $40. There were only two negatives, and they were very minor. When we got back from the baseball game, we wanted to relax at the water front bar area. When we walked out there we realized we were VERY under dressed. They told us they were closing in 45 minutes, last call was in 15 minutes and we could order from the bar, but couldn't get wait service. The staff was a little chilly towards us, but no big deal. We were all wearing Red Sox gear and felt a little silly. The other minor negative was that our hotel windows faced the Fire station. We could slightly hear the fire engines taking off. It was pretty muffled and only happened a couple times, but my husband and I are both pretty light sleepers. If you're a light sleeper, I would request a room that faces a different direction. Overall, the hotel was great and I would stay there again (and bring a dress!).
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Lis L about InterContinental Boston
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

If you don't mind stiff sleeping arrangements, I would not hesitate to stay here. Typically I find comparable hotels have much more comfy beds.

'Everything A+ except for parking fiasco.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 27, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

The hotel was top notch and beautiful. We were treated awesome. The restaurants and bars were better than normal hotel quality and we were very impressed. Everything was immaculate. Location was great.

When we went ot check out, we were told that we would have to go get our car from the garage, though we paid $49 for valet parking. You can drop it off in front, but you have to go to the back of the hotel and take an elevator down into the garage, where we had to wait and show that we had paid for parking. Minor inconvenience, but it was over 90 degrees outside and it was stifling in the garage. We waited over 20 minutes in the garage, hot, as the attendants brought us the wrong car twice. There needs to be a better system. If I were to be in town again, I would stay there only if I didn't bring my car.

1 review
'wonderful weekend in the berkshires...'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 24, 2012

After setting out to book a weekend in the Berkshires for President' Day, we stumbled upon The Kemble Inn after a friend recommended the recent NYTimes article on winter in the berkshires. Upon checking out the inn's website, we decided to give it a try over our other choices. We booked the Valentine's Day special which included one dinner plus a cheese plate and prosecco in our room upon arrival. These were all nice touches and the dinner surpassed all expectations we had of a dinner at our little inn. The breakfast included with the stay has a pretty vast menu and was perfectly cooked to order each morning. Most of the service provided over the weekend was by Paul and we could not believe how accomodating, helpful and nice he was and how much he handles around the inn! The service was amazing, the inn very quaint and pretty, and I can definitely appreciate the updates such as our room having a new bathroom. I can say I'm always hesitant to stay somewhere older for fear of it being dirty or rundown and this was not the case. In fact, we understand that there are more renovations on the way and this can only perfect this as the perfect inn for a weekend getaway. This is also a pefect location for trips to any sights and restaurants within Lenox and Stockbridge and not too far from Great Barrington. I hope to be back this Summer! Thank you!

LandB
Cote d'Azur, France
Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Great choice for first time trip to Boston'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

My husband and I stayed here for two nights on our first visit to Boston and found it to be a great place which suited our purpose exactly. Although they were doing some work in the entrance area, the staff were very pleasant and helpful (and apologetic for the work in progress) . I was worried that the noise of the work would affect our room but we were assured that it would not - and that they had given us a room on the 8th floor (top floor) anyway.

The wifi did not work at first but was swiftly repaired and followed by a call from the receptionist to make sure that all was well.

The room was pleasantly decorated and highlighted the original brick walls and merchant warehouse history of the building. The bed and pillows were comfortable, The windows actually open so that you can have fresh air and are not reliant only on the AC. The view along State Street to the State house in one direction and to the sea on the other was great.

My only minor complaints would be that the lighting in the room is very dim - would be nice to have just one more optional light overhead for dull days or evenings when you just need to see better!
It would also be nice to have the possibility of breakfast in the hotel - or at least a coffee maker in the room. However the 24 hour availability of coffee and tea in the lobby was good to have.

Next door there is a funny little breakfast/pizza place and very close by there are all sorts of other options for food throughout the day at Fanueil Marketplace. Also, Bostix kiosk is practically on the doorstep - great for half price "day of show" tickets, and the Hop on Hop off trolley tours start right across the road.

So, you can see that we thoroughly emjoyed our stay, would be happy to return, and would definately recommend this hotel to anyone!
Less

Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
13 helpful votes 13 helpful votes
'Enjoyed our stay!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I spent 2 nights at Harborside at the end of May, and we enjoyed our stay so very much. I had read reviews so knew pretty much what to expect. We had a 10-15 minute walk from Boston South Amtrak Station and the desk clerks were so helpful when we checked in early. Our room was ready for us. We had the queen atrium room which was fine with us. It was very comfortable and clean. I loved the exposed brick wall and the updated shower bathroom. Our tv worked great -- my husband loves sports. Also used the refrigerator in our room since there was a 24-hour shop on the block. The desk clerks answered our questions about the area and there was also a guest information book in our room with suggestions about breakfast cafes, diners, restaurants, etc since Harborside does not have an eating place. Location was my biggest reason to choose Harborside since it was right on the Freedom Trail and near Boston Harbor. We spent most of our time in the vicinity - walking from Boston Common to the USS Constitution and enjoying a sunset harbor cruise. Took desk clerk's recommendation the rainy morning we left and caught a taxi on Atlantic to get back to the Amtrak Station. I would recommend this hotel to all of my friends if they were going to that area of Boston.
Less

TucsonCurt
Tucson
Top Contributor
88 reviews 88 reviews
Reviews in 34 cities Reviews in 34 cities
50 helpful votes 50 helpful votes
'Good Boutique Hotel In Great Location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We stayed at the Harborside at the start and end of our Cape Cod vacation. Easy to get to on the Blue Line from Logan, the Aquarium station elevator comes up right in front of the hotel entrance. The hotel's lobby is a work in process and still being renovated. Right now, it's a relatively large space (for a smallish hotel), but not particularly inviting - yet. Most of the rooms have no views, with the window facing an inner well (not really an atrium), so you want a view of downtown or the wharf, this isn't the place. A few rooms might front State Street. But the nice thing is that there is no street noise at all; it's really quiet in the rooms at night.

Most of the rooms are on the smaller size, with a queen bed though there are a few rooms with a king bed available - get one of those if you can. They told us no rooms with two beds. What we really liked was that the rooms, and especially the baths, had been remodeled and were very nice. We loved the large, walk-in tiled shower. So much nicer than the typical tub-shower with the lousy coutain found in most hotel rooms. The towels were big and thick - very nice.

Free Wi-Fi throughout. You won't find that in the large business chains! Coffee in the lobby 24 hours.

But the real plus is the location, right next door to the Custom House, a block from the Quincy Market, two blocks to the Haymarket, and across the road from the wharf. Our favorite Irish pub, the Black Rose, is almost across the street. The teriffic Sultan's Kitchen, is just a couple blocks up State Street. You can catch the T right in front and go anywhere in town. The North End, with all the great Italian restaurants, is a ten-minute walk.

So, yeah, if you want the big hotel with all the amenities, and the big price, by all means do that. But if you'd like a nice, boutique hotel with modern rooms and a great location, give the Harbor side a look.

Tip: We booked our room a few months in advance on Hotels.com and got a great rate!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Krystal H
Raleigh, North Carolina, United States
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'A Lot of Money for a Budget motel'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I was so excited to be staying at teh Harborside Inn. The reviews had me excited to stay in Boston and so close to everything. I was very very very disappointed. We paid over $200 a night and I felt like I was in a budget hotel. The towels hanging in the bathroom were shredding and had hair all in them, the tv was very fuzzy and hard to watch anything. The floors creaked and not just cute old building creaking...creaking like the building could fall apart at any time. The bathroom was nice and upgraded and the bed was decently comfortable. There was an awful smell in the building, but that could be from the construction, kicking up all dirt and dust. The window were little peek-a-boo windows and the room was very very small. All of this would have been fine but the staff was absolutly horrible. The never greeted me or my husband when we came in or left. We needed to print off boarding passes and their computers didn't have Flash, so the guy behind the counter said he could help - he just needed our email and password. When we refused to give him that info, instead of offering the keyboard and allowing us to put in the information, he gave us tons of attitude and acted like he shouldn't be doing anything to help us. I never write reviews, but I was so disappointed in the quality of the hotel and the service I felt the need to let others know. I didn't expect a 5 star hotel, I didn't pay 500$ a night, but for almost $300 a night I felt like I should have had decent towels and quality customer service.

11 reviews 11 reviews

27 helpful votes 27 helpful votes
'GREAT place to stay. Awesome location & Value.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

A month before my convention, all of the convention hotels were sold out except for the $500+ per night rooms...which I wasn't willing to pay. I took my family along (2 adults, 2 kids ages 1 and 3). I didn't want to stay 40-minutes away so, I did what I always do....searched for a good hotel in downtown Boston using TripAdvisor. Once again, we were quite pleased. The location is ideal. Easy walk to EVERYTHING....Aquarium, Museams, Quincey Market, North End (Little Italy), Marriott Longwharf across the street (for an awesome buffet breakfast), 24-hour convenience store next door, etc. etc.. It is only 10 steps from the (wheelchair accessible) exit/entrance of Aquarium subway station which means that it's 2 subway stops from Logan Airport and further destinations (or avoiding the rain) are easy, as well. The hotel itself is unique with it's original interior brick walls exposed. Our room was very nice...decor and bathroom great. The only things that could have been a bit better for us...(1) room carpet could have been a bit cleaner, (2) they do not offer cribs/pack-and-play, so we had to bring our own and (3) we were on the 8th floor and we could still hear some late-nighters outside at street-level until 3am. Otherwise, especially for the price in downtown Boston, the Harborside is a great place to stay.
Less

Marriott Residence Inn Boston Harbor on Tudor Wharf

surfinginflorida
surfinginflorida
Top Contributor
143 reviews 143 reviews
Reviews in 53 cities Reviews in 53 cities
122 helpful votes 122 helpful votes
'Great stay, except for housekeeping.'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed at the Residence Inn for 3 weeks; my best advice is get a map from mbta.com, a 7-day link pass ($15) and explore! So many awesome things to see! I absolutely loved returning home from Boston on the ferry every night (covered by the link pass)  so relaxing sometimes I stayed on just for another round trip!

Location: I thought the location was great; right on the wharf with plenty of places to walk around. If you bring your dog (or kids) Paul Revere Park is on the other side of the bridge. The dogs ran around leash free and played, and there was a playground for the kids. If you exit the building through the back door by the gym, it is an easy and pleasant walk to North Station (subway), through the park and across the locks. Easy walk to the US Constitution, water taxi to Long Wharf and Beacon Hill monument. Taxi is $25-30 to hotel (tolls) and $15-20 return to Logan. If you aren't hauling too much luggage, you can take the subway to the North Station, or take the water taxi from Logan to Long Wharf and then the ferry from Long Wharf to Charlestown.

Sleep Quality: with the windows closed, the hotel was very quiet. The bed was comfortable, but the pillows were not (lumpy fiber fill). Great shades  kept most of the bridge light out.

Rooms: Smaller than a normal Residence Inn, and not updated with the new modern furniture. The rooms were fairly clean, but we had mold (both black and red) in the shower. I can see why; housekeeping didn't clean the tub area while we were there.

Dining: A great breakfast was offered every day, and the staff was wonderful. 'Dinner' was offered Mon  Thurs. I'm pretty picky and usually cooked in the room, so we only took advantage of salad items and cookies, although lots of residents ate there every night. There is a grocery store (Johnny's) in Charlestown  but even better  a produce/fish/cheese market Fri & Sat at Haymarket (orange or green lines), Trader Joe's at Copley (green line) and Whole Foods Bowdoin (blue line) and farmer's market in Dewey Square Park Tue & Thurs afternoons. All the restaurants around Charlestown are good (except the closest one, Max and Dylan's).

Amenities: Gym was small but nice, lobby was comfortable with leather chairs and a fireplace. Indoor pool and hot tub, but it looked like it really needed a good cleaning. Laundry was onsite and very clean.

Service: Was amazing. Front desk staff was friendly and helpful, as was valet. Restaurant staff was very professional and accommodating. The only problem we had was with housekeeping. It was kind of a joke, but after awhile it was very frustrating. We never knew when housekeeping would come, could be as early as 9:00 or as late as 4:30 which sometimes made it hard to plan my day. Also, cleaning and supplies were very inconsistent. Sometimes we would get washrags, other days not. Same thing went for dishwasher detergent, shampoo, kitchen towels, etc. We are fairly clean, so sometimes all they would do is make the bed  we ended up having to leave a mess to ensure our dishwasher would get started, or that soap dishes would be cleaned. The only thing gross (and this has been mentioned by other guests) was food that wasn't ours under the couch, the mold in the shower and the sheets for the foldout bed were put away un-cleaned and smelled strongly of men's aftershave. I left the sheets on the floor but clean ones were never put back. Housekeeping supervisor needs to do inspections.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

June 13, 2012
While we are always grateful to receive reviews, positive or otherwise, we are disappointed to learn that your experience did not meet your expectations. If we get the pleasure of welcoming you back during a future business trip, we are certain that our staff will be able to direct you to the best shortcuts to Boston's public transportation system (the T). We regret if any noise disruptions disturbed your peaceful stay with us and hope that next time you will let us know immediately of any concerns. We truly appreciate your feedback and hope you will visit with us again. Thank you for sharing.

'DEFINITELY CONSIDER STAYING HERE!!!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

An aboslute 10 on 0-10 scale!!! Great location on the water. Just a few minutes from airport. Great views as right on the water front, great staff, all trolleys pick up right next door at the Naval shipyard. AWESOME complimentary breakfast. Luggage hold. Just a walk across the bridge from Italian north end best eating in the area and out of main traffic avenues of prime Boston. In-room kitchenette, if you want to eat-in and complimentary grocery service or close by to do yourself. Great staff as well. Would DEFINITELY recommend and would stay again.

'Very nice location, housekeeping could be a bit more thorough'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Stayed here to attend a Red Sox game on a Saturday night. I liked the location of this hotel, with a short walk to North Station and also to the ferry that takes you over to the aquarium. Nice wharf to walk out on and seemed to be in a pretty safe area. The breakfast was decent, included in the price and certainly plentiful. We ate breakfast outside overlooking the harbor so that was enjoyable. The lobby is pleasant and the staff are very accomodating and friendly. On the negative side, we came back from the baseball game around midnight and I searched all over for the remote control for the tv. (which was somehow missing from the room). This included looking under the bed, in the closets, inside the pull out couch. Through this search I found a dirty sock, gum wrapper, directions to the hotel (printed out two weeks ago) and enough dust to knit another sock, If I wanted a pair. I think, had the remote not been missing from the room, I probably wouldn't have found this treasure trove of left over stuff. Recommend that the hotel perhaps pick up the housekeeping a bit and double check rooms to make sure all the amenities (like the remote control) are in the room when doing up the room.
Less

Lisa M

Senior Contributor
25 reviews 25 reviews
Reviews in 14 cities Reviews in 14 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Great location, views, and value in Boston'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Convenient to the North End (Little Italy), The Garden and the U.S.S. Constitution, this Residence Inn occupies a lovely perfect spot in Charlestown, near Paul Revere Park. We were thrilled with the waterviews from our 8th floor suite; and caught a glimpse of the steeple of the North Church from the end of the hall. The lobby was welcoming; the lounge/breakfast room, quite nice; and the suites were spacious, clean and up-to-date. All in all, a very nice facility.

If you're driving, be aware: There is no on-site (free) parking, as with most Residence Inns; but valet is available for $35 per day. Cabs are readily available; but hoofing it isn't difficult, as many venues are within easy walking distance.

If you're going, be sure to grab a pie at Pizzeria Regina -- 11-1/2 Thacher St., best pizza in the North End -- and a cannoli from Bova's Bakery -- 134 Salem St. Both are easy walking distance and will make you all the more glad that you chose this hotel. I'm glad I did!

Less

'Wonderful quiet location!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 12, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Given the incredibly high prices of decent hotels in Boston this is a lovely find. No, it isn't cheap but it delivers really high class accommodation at a price which doesn't bring the tears...and breakfast is included. On the route of the Freedom Trail in the beautiful Charlestown dock area it is a short walk from Boston Centre - or go by ferry - and only a $15 taxi ride from the airport.We had a one bedroom suite overlooking the bay and it was extremely well equipped and comfortable - dishwasher, microwave hob, tv in both loung and bedroom free wi-fi etc - honestly could not have wanted more. It is though of the Holiday Inn Express concept, ie doesn't have a restaurant etc but the breakfast was a full hot and cold buffet served in a comfortable spacious dining area. Why though do they let themselves down by using plastic plates and cutlery - so disappointing and cheap! The staff were excellent, helpfull and friendly. Would certainly recommend it.
Less

Fifi58
Northern California
Senior Contributor
26 reviews 26 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
39 helpful votes 39 helpful votes
'The good and the not so good'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 1, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

The location of the hotel is good...it is just over the Charles River and a very short walk to The Constitution, the ferry to Boston (which docks next to the Aquarium) and Bunker Hill. If you are not infirmed, you can walk over the bridge to Boston and walk the Freedom Trail in one day, very easily.

The room seemed a little small in comparison to other Residence Inn's we have stayed in. It was basically in the same configuration as the others; a kitchen and living area with a sofa bed, a separate bedroom and bathroom. The problem with the room was that we booked a Pure room which is to be allergin free and it cost quite a bit extra to book this type of room. The room seemed clean enough until I prepared for my shower the first evening. The shower curtain and the liner was covered in black mold. I decided I was not going to take a shower that evening and I'm glad that no one in my family is allergic to black mold. It was late and I didn't want to deal with housekeeping that evening so I decided to take my shower the next morning. I reported this to the front desk the next morning and they were apologetic and said that the curtain would be changed by the time we returned from our tour of The Constitution. Upon our return, the curtain appeared to have been washed, as it was wrinkled and still had black mold in the same location, but just not as much. I wonder - - for the amount we paid for that room for 4 nights, they easily could buy hundreds of new shower curtains. At least the liner had been changed out.

The bedroom had two queen sized beds, which were very comfortable. They were not hard as some hotel beds can be. But, with two beds, there really wasn't much room to walk and at one point I tripped on the bedskirt which was hanging down on the floor and found out that it was safety pinned to the bed as it previously had ripped the length of the bed. It was also filthy with random stains.

All-in-all, not what we paid for. The location was good, the breakfast was okay albiet crowded, the staff was friendly and prompt, but the Pure room was not up to standard.
Less

'Very Convenient, very clean.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 29, 2012

We just spent four nights in Boston for sightseeing AND the Boston Marathon. This hotel has recently been refinished with new carpets, etc., and we thought it was new construction, because it was so clean.

Helpful, friendly staff. Nice breakfast selections with good amount of seating. It got a bit crowded with the marathon bunch in town, but it probably has plenty of seating for a normal week.

Hotel is just a couple of blocks from the USS Constitution (at dock) and directly on the "Freedom Trail". It is a short walk to the North Stop of the subway (the home of the Celtics and Bruins just above the subway, too).

Walked each evening into the Boston North End neighborhood for great restaurants. There are 75 Italian restaurants in that neighborhood!

gsuzuki
Honolulu, Hawaii
Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 19 cities Reviews in 19 cities
20 helpful votes 20 helpful votes
'Good Hotel Outside of Downtown Boston'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

My two friends and I stayed at this hotel for a three night stay to watch a Red Sox baseball game. We chose this hotel because we wanted a larger room since there was three of us sharing one room. After reading the reviews we made the reservations and here are some additional information:

Shuttle from Airport: After collecting our bags at the airport I called the hotel for the shuttle and about 10 minutes later the shuttle arrived. For some reason, the hotel was not located on the free phone list at the airport baggage claim. Make sure you have the phone number handy.

Checking In: Checking in took about 10 minutes because there was several other guests checking in. The person checking us in did her job adequately, we had no complaints.

Room: The room is a typical Embassy Suites, there was a living room and a separate bedroom. There was also a dorm size refrigerator in the room. There was also a desk/table in the room. The room was perfect for myself and two other friends. Even though the hotel is near the airport, we did not hear any airplane noise.

Location: We did not walk around the hotel so I cannot say if there was anything (grocery store or restaurants) around the hotel. Dollar rent a car is right next door and there was also an office building but the area looked like an industrial area.
The subway (or "T" is what they call it in Boston) is about a 5-10 minute walk across this park. During the day, the walk is pleasant with people playing soccer or kids playing sports. At night, the park is lighted however it is pretty empty so some people might be spooked about this. The latest we walked across the park was about 10:30 pm and it was fine for us. If you did not want to walk across the park, I believe the hotel has a shuttle that will pick you up. The subway takes about 10-15 minutes to reach downtown Boston.

Checking Out: Checking out was quick and the shuttle back to the airport was uneventful. Just a warning, if you are flying United, make sure you know if you are flying to Newark, Houston, or Cleveland because United uses two separate terminals.

Overall we had no complaints about the hotel. Yes, there is a fee to use the internet, but oh well. We used this hotel because of the size of the room. If I was travelling with just another person, maybe we would have stayed someplace closer to downtown Boston, but then again the price might have been more than what we paid. I would recommend this hotel to anyone who is looking for a bigger size room.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

pinglosangeles

Reviews in 38 cities Reviews in 38 cities
18 helpful votes 18 helpful votes
'typical airport hotel'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 8, 2012 NEW

This was a typical Embassy Suites hotel...although somewhat impersonal since it is an airport hotel. Unfortunately they do not have a "happy hour" experience here since the city of Boston does not allow them to give away cocktails or wine. They do, though, have the usual breakfast that is always good. The good part is that there is a subway station just a 5 minute walk away that takes you directly into Boston for just $2.00. The bad part is that the hotel is quite isolated, restaurant wise. It's basically in the middle of nowhere. We ended up eating at the Embassy Suites restaurant. Just adequate...they have a captive audience. For Hertz rental car users, it is extremely convenient. Right next door to their facility. Shuttle service to the terminals was very efficient. Very expensive stay since they doubled their usual rates due to graduation week.
Less

'Good but not cheap.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

I used this hotel twice once on arrival for two nights and once flying out the next day. It is good for the airport 5 minutes away and also the subway which is a short walk across the park and a $2 ticket gets you in to Boston 2 stops away. All the major car rental firms are within walking distance which was another reason we chose it.

The rooms are excellent a bedroom big bathroom and a lounge area. there is a pool which is small and a spa. Next door is a small gym.

The breakfast is excellent with fresh omelets on request, and is normally included in your room rate. Now the down side, the room rates I paid less for two nights than I did for one night on a sunday night. $360 for one night is frankly robbery. I had three night in Cape cod for less and got change! So think on if money isn't a problem It's a good place to stay fro airport and city access.
Less

'Great airport hotel in Boston'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012

We stayed at the Embassy Suites at Logan airport for 3 nights post cruise before flying home. The hotel itself was your basic Embassy Suites with a large atrium for the bar/breakfast area. The service in the hotel was very good and we had a pleasant stay even though the weather did not cooperate. It rained heavily two out of the three days we were there. The location was very convienent for those of us having early flights. They have an airport shuttle every 10 minutes and the breakfast service starts at 5:30am which was great. It is a 5 minute or less drive to the airport from the front door of the hotel. Also all the flights are listed in their lobby so you can do a quick check to see if your flight is ontime even before you leave the hotel. There is a business area with free computers and printers. Overall a very nice stay (other than the weather)

Charlesmark Hotel

arayaBKK
Bangkok, Thailand
Senior Contributor
25 reviews 25 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'great base to explore Boston'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

The hotel : small boutique hotel, modern & tasteful decor through out the hotel.
The location : near Copley sq., Newbury st. & Prudential mall, pretty of shops & restaurants, near subway, the ride to-from the airport is around $30.
The check-in & check-out : fast, accurate.
The breakfast : free bagel & hot drinks.
The room : very small, very clean, the bed is incredibly great, the decor is modern with very clever use of materials, the air con works very well, no nice view, mine is facing the service alley with disturbing noise in the early morning.
The bathroom : very small but functional, very clean, the decor is modern with very clever use of materials, water pressure is great, good amenity, pretty of great towels.
The staffs : very capable, very friendly & very helpful.
The rate : reasonable.
The Internet : fast & free.
Overall : it's a very good choice for a city center hotel, great base to explore Boston if you don't have a car.

CONS:
- The breakfast did not have much selection, just bagels, some oatmeal, donuts....

kz2
Merrick, New York
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Boston "Pensione"'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

My husband and I stayed at the Charlesmark during the perfect storm time period for getting a hotel room in Boston....Spring and multiple college and university graduations. We were in town for one such graduation. I picked the Charlesmark for location. It is in the perfect spot... Copley Square and just steps from the "Green line T" (Boston's mass transit system) If you are taking Amtrak into Boston it is also very close to the Back-bay Train station.
If you are driving there are a number of garages around the area, and the hotel has a limited discount at one a number of blocks away. I believe Boston is not a good car city, and it is easy enough to use public transportation or walking to get most everywhere. We had to bring a car because of moving our student's belongings.
The Hotel itself reminds me of a European pensone. It is small, and has limited services, but is lovely and easy. This is not the hotel to go to for over the top luxury/services. But the rooms are clean, and comfortable. I noticed in other reviews complaints about the size of the rooms. In my opinion the room was fine. I didn't have a view of any kind, but that is to be expected in this type of hotel. The building is an a very old part of Boston and once upon a time it was a residence. It is very quintessential Boston! (I used to live in Back bay many years ago) The bathrooms were clean and modern. I did find the provided soap etc. to be extremely basic. There is a 24 hour CVS (drug store) a block away for any forgotten toiletries. We bought soap that was more to our liking there.
The front desk staff was accommodating and helpful. The complementary breakfast (continental) was easy and adequate. The bar is lovely and active, but we had no issues with noise. I thought the price was good as well. I was renting a room during a high volume/high cost time period and this hotel was reasonable for the city. If you are looking for serious bargains motel like prices, you will need to go to the suburbs. Over all I would recommend this hotel.

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Four20AllDay

Contributor
13 reviews 13 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Great Overnight Stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 24, 2012

My wife and I stayed here last summer on the tail end of a road trip from NY through ME and MA. Reception was very pleasant and quick. Upon entering out room we were greeted by the sound of classical music playing lightly in the background, the room was clean and modern. Our room was small but comfortable, the bathroom was a nice size, kind of large considering the size of the rest of the room. The stereo was hooked up to speakers in the bathroom, which was a nice touch while showering and getting ready. The bed was comfortable and clean. I usually don't sleep directly on hotel pillows. I either bring my own pillow case or use a t-shirt. There were no worries here! Our view was of an alley between buildings, not very exciting but we weren't in town for the view from our room anyway.

The continental breakfast was basic but good. We did some adventuring around Boston but we never made it to the bar downstairs to try the drinks or food.

Parking in the area can be pricey but we found a great deal right down the street. Walking out of the Charlesmark, take a left and walk about 3 blocks (1-2 min) and there's a parking lot on the left.

Overall I was thrilled at the value here. Reasonable prices, great staff, great rooms and great location.
Less

'Modern & trendy but tiny bed!'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 21, 2012

After reading the reviews for this hotel we felt sure it was a good find. It is in a great location as mentioned in other reviews. It also lived up to the modern & trendy decor and vibe but I wasn't quite prepared for how small the rooms and bed in a standard room are! I don't really mind a small room but the bed was just ridiculous!!! It is definitely not what I would call a 'standard' double bed. When we asked to upgrade we were told that the Hotel was full and we couldn't be moved. We therefore had 2 uncomfortable nights sleep, disturbing each other everytime we moved!

The breakfast is ok, but don't expect much! A variety of bagels, fruit and doughnuts are served. A toaster would be a welcome addition.

In all, everything was good except for the bed size. If you book at this hotel I would suggest you pay a bit more for the Queen bed! We also liked the music system in the room but would rather have a good nights sleep.....so perhaps spend less on the sound system and give people a better bed!

The hotel is located right next to the Copley train station, close to lots of restaurants and shops and the Hynes Convention Centre is about a 10 min walk away. Walking distance to Boston Common too.

It is also great value compared to other hotels in the area. Highly recommend staying here when visiting Boston.

The Fairmont Copley Plaza Boston

Dgfvsxz
Contributor
14 reviews 14 reviews
Reviews in 12 cities Reviews in 12 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'Thanksgiving Weekend'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 13, 2012 NEW

My mother and I stayed at this property over Thanksgiving weekend in 2011. The front desk was courteous and professional. The location is excellent, close to sights and public transport. There was a bit of scaffolding over parts of the facade but it didn't affect my stay. Given the holiday weekend, it was pretty quiet, which I didn't mind.

We had a room with 2 queen beds on a low floor. It reflected the rest of the hotel: although once grand, it was aging and showed it. That isn't to say that the beds and bathroom weren't clean - they were spotless. But the furniture, fixtures, and paint touch ups betrayed their age. It's not that I wanted modernity - the decor is befitting and I like the look of another time. It's just that when you look at things up close, a stale mustiness comes to mind. That was certainly the case of the closet. While rather large (a small walk-in) management decided not to upgrade it in terms of a paint job. The color of the interior of that closet did not match the attempt at freshness of the rest of the room and it looked a bit depressing. The view out the window wasn't much either, but I didn't mind that so much.

The bathroom amenities were good and I especially liked the rose-smelling lotion. I almost never use hotel lotion but this one was excellent. There's also a heat lamp in the ceiling so when you get out of the bath or shower, you can enjoy toasty (but noisy) warmth while drying off.

The Oak Room is gorgeous, of a different time like the rest of the hotel. The breakfasts we had were luxurious and indulgent. The potatoes that came with everything were the best breakfast potatoes I've ever had. Crispy on the outside and fluffy inside. I suspect they were parboiled and had absorbed a lot of oil in the cooking but not greasy although plenty of calories, I'm sure. The fruit platter was arranged a bit oddly  the morning cook must have been having fun or keeping from boredom by creating an odd architectural piece with cut fruit. The hot chocolate was a disappointment  while I believe it was made with steamed milk (a good thing) it was clear they'd used powder (Nestle or something like that).

We also had Thanksgiving dinner in the Oak Room. The place was lively, although the buffet area felt odd with stations so far from each other. I didn't even see the hot cider until as I was leaving. The room was dimly lit and the cider station was placed so close by the door that I completely missed it when walking in. The food was quite good. The turkey was delicious as were all the trimmings. There was a bit of confusion with the server at the start when he had to actually come find me as I was at the buffet to take our entre order, but it was smoothed out and service was fine for the rest of the evening. The wait staff, from what I saw, is mostly men whom I suspect have been doing this for a long time. I've seen better buffet spreads (Lacroix at the Rittenhouse Hotel is amazing) but this one was quite good and I was very happy with the raw bar. What was a disappointment, however, were the stale desserts. If they were made on premise, then they should find a different pastry chef. I suspect, though, that the desserts were bought elsewhere. The small raspberry cakes had horrible oily pink frosting. The sponge cake itself was dry and chewy. The mini blueberry crumble pie was stale and the filling gummy. The only good thing was the banana cream pie, however, what little I got to taste of it was scraped from the mess diners had made of it. I went back a couple of times more to see if the hotel staff had refreshed the desserts and put more of the banana cream pie out but they hadn't. I wish they'd attended that station better.

All in all, a pleasant stay. The hotel lobby is gorgeous. The Christmas tree and the other decorations that were put up while we were out were lovely and in appropriate taste to the rest of the hotel. Another great touch is having Catie, a beautiful black lab, in the lobby. Although the dog house is stationed by the door, I only got to see her once the whole weekend, probably because she was busy accompanying guests on their walks. That's such a great amenity, to be able to go for a walk or run with a beautiful dog. Despite the poor desserts, I enjoyed Thanksgiving dinner in the Oak Room and was glad for the experience.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Ask Dgfvsxz about The Fairmont Copley Plaza Boston

'They put the "Fair" in the Boston Fairmont'

I enjoy the wide and quiet hallways and the spaciousness of the rooms but some functionality was lacking (nowhere to lay out bathroom items around the sink). Too bad.

ChrisHNewYork
New York
2 reviews
'Classic spot, uneven execution'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

We just completed a stay at the Fairmont Copley Plaza. It was our first visit to the hotel, but we are frequent visitors to Boston. Sitting here now, I don't think I'd return.

Copley Square is, in my opinion, the best place to stay in the City. Central to everything. The hotel is classic, and beautiful. In spite of the renovation, the rooms still feel old, with thick old coats of paint and bad lighting. But the room we had was huge, as was the bathroom. There was virtually no furniture, though, so both seemed empty.

The main issue is housekeeping. There was an old M&M on the floor by the TV, so I have to question the vacuuming. Our ice bucket was taken and not returned. I had to ask twice over 2 days to actually get one brought to the room. And when we called to get fresh towels brought in and the wet, used one removed, the front desk obliged, and then housekeeping called to argue over whether we actually needed them.

The maitre'd at breakfast was great. Very polished, very professional. Unfortunately, he wasn't at his station when we arrived, and we were sent to a table with a curt finger-point. And that's emblematic of this hotel. Sometimes sublime, too-often careless and off-hand and dismissive.

For the price we paid, we hoped to be pampered a little. We didn't expect to have to plead a case for towels. This hotel needs to decide what it wants to be.
Less

AKLVancouver_Canada_
Vancouver (Canada)
Contributor
20 reviews 20 reviews
Reviews in 18 cities Reviews in 18 cities
14 helpful votes 14 helpful votes
'Not my first choice'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

I have not been back since 10 years ago. Came back again for business and was booked at this hotel again by my company. The room has been beautifully appointed, even though it's on the small size, but adequate. However, as I mentioned in my last review on this hotel, the wall is still thin and voice travels from hallway and next door (my room, 532, was right next to the service elevator, so I could hear the bell ringing every time it stopped on my floor). And the water pressure is still weak (my colleague describes it as "old-man peeing"). This is all due to the age of the building, so I don't think it will be changed. And that's the reason I would not pick this hotel if I have a choice.

One big plus is their newly added fitness centre. Not the biggest, but has every equipment needed, in a very open, bright space.

Service-wise, I find it hit-and-miss. Some I find are truly friendly and willing to go above and beyond. Some are just going through the motion, saying all the right things, but action and attitude do not match.

Less

Steve Z
Northport, New York
1 review
'A wonderful gem in Back Bay!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

We have stayed in the Copley Plaza many times, even before it was a fairmont. But clearly the best stays at the Copley Plaza have been during the Fairmont years. The lobby is lush with its hih ceilings the grand entrance hall from st james ave. and the decor on the gold floor is warm and luxurious, but not in your face as the lobby may seem to a first time Copley guest. The room has a beautiful chandelier and comfy beds, not to mention the great all marble bathroom. The room has a huge window overlooking the square with a large sit-in window sill. The Oak Room downstairs has delicious steak and a classical ambiance. The service of the whole hotel is unparalleled. They even set up my son's stuffed animals on the bed. The private gold floor check in was speedy and our bags arrived within five minutes. The maid even left us a Christmas card on the nigh of Christmas Eve (turndown is also complimentary :)). The Copley Plaza is a must stay in Boston.

ILove2Travel95
Michigan
Contributor
16 reviews 16 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
15 helpful votes 15 helpful votes
'Pleasant, charming and comfortable stay, great location in Boston.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

I recently stayed at The Fairmont Copley Plaza for a conference and while I initially heard the hotel was undergoing some renovations, it looks as if they are in the very final stages. The hotel is charming, something that you don't always get today with many of the cookie-cutter chain hotels. This is a historic building, originally opened in 1912. However, the recent renovations have restored the building and brought the interior to more modern standards. The room was luxurious with a very comfortable bed, new furnishings, fixtures, carpeting and a large flat screen and a solid, functional work desk. The bathroom is beautifully done in marble with a wonderful rainfall shower head (amazing, going to buy one for home!) The high end soaps and shampoo provided were such a surprise. They smelled amazing. I wish the hotel shop sold these or that they could be obtainable from the retailer, but it looks like they're specifically made for the hotel only. The restaurant and room service both delivered excellent quality and well prepared food. Room service was served punctually and temperature appropriate. Nothing left to desire as far as food in my opinion, but food is very different for everyone, of course. The renovation has definitely transformed this hotel although I did notice some areas like doors and door frames, for example, that were a little rough around the edges. It looked like the work was done, but some of the finishes just looked a little odd, as if they were not a part of the renovation plan or just done with poor craftsmanship or as a result of cost cutting. I found it odd that not everything would be completely finished after a renovation of this scale. Also, speaking of doors, they are loud, and noise from hallway traffic and conversations and door slamming at night was a little annoying while trying to relax. This certainly isn't an issue unique to this hotel but maybe the doors could have been constructed differently so they do not have to be slammed. Nonetheless, this is an excellent grand hotel with friendly and attentive staff and I would not hesitate to return if in Boston for business or pleasure. Oh, and be sure to spend a little time with Catie Copley. I've never stayed in a hotel with a resident canine, so this was unique and special!

Less

LuxFirstTravel
California
Top Contributor
74 reviews 74 reviews
Reviews in 25 cities Reviews in 25 cities
31 helpful votes 31 helpful votes
'Much Needed Renovation'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Stayed at the Fairmont Copley for a conference in 2008 and was disappointed in the shabby condition of the rooms. This and the odd bites on my feet and ankles had me convinced that I would never return. Glad to say, the latest renovation has breathed new life into the historic hotel. The drab, dirty and dreary carpet and furnishings now sparkle with a nouveau Cape Cod style with soft tones of silver and gray. A vast improvement.

It is important to note that the Oak Bar is still under renovation and the temporary bar in the St. James restaurant is fairly inadequate. The Gold floor lounge is nice, but isn't always well-stocked for breakfast or evening hors d'ouevres. The service there was outstanding, however, thanks to Aja, one of the supervisors at the desk. She helped make this stay a memorable one. In terms of Catie Copley, the canine ambassador, it may be time for her to retire. At 10 years old, she looks a bit too weary and deserves time off.

All in all, a repeat visit is warranted. Copley Plaza is a great location with easy access to all the major sights. The hop-on, hop-off trolley with the harbor cruise is a great way to see Boston whether it's your first time there or not. And nearby is Legal Seafood, a place where the fresh seafood and sangria are simply sublime.
Less

Hotel Manager, Manager at Omni Parker House, responded to this review
June 13, 2012
We find this assessment of our hotel somewhat odd considering that our guestrooms were recently renovated and feature new HD televisions, Wifi service and more. It's true that we are an historic property with some smaller rooms, but many guests report finding these qualities add to our charm. We do apologize for not delivering the Select Guest benefits appropriately and acknowledge that this unfortunate circumstance undoubtedly clouded this guest's experience of their most recent stay with us.

This response is the subjective opinion of the management representative and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
DolphinaSheffield
Sheffield
Contributor
19 reviews 19 reviews
Reviews in 14 cities Reviews in 14 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Fantastic Hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

We were very fortunate to stay at the Omni Park House hotel for two nights as part of an organised tour. We were fascinated to learn about this historic hotel which is centrally located to amenities and attractions. It is a short walk to Beacon Hill, Boston Common and is located on the Freedom Trail and close to the T-line subway system. The lobby, restaurant and bar areas are all decorated in dark wood panelling and there are wonderful themed flower arrangements which are changed every two days. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful and are only too happy to help and answer questions. Our room was very spacious as was the bathroom, however, our fellow travellers seem to say their bathrooms were quite small. The service in the dining room is excellent and we ate very well at breakfast. The chef in there cooks a brilliant omelette! We fell in love with Boston and want to return in the near future to spend more time there and will have no hesitation in staying at the Omni Parker House again. We can highly recommend.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask DolphinaSheffield about Omni Parker House
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
WorldWondererNYC

16 reviews 16 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Omni Parker House: Old and tired, but that may be its charm'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 9, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

It's like a visit to my long deceased grandparents' home (I have mixed memories about the time I had to spend at my grandparents' home...).
North America's oldest hotel is certainly that: old. The furniture is old and stuffy, the toiletries very "traditional", the window treatments somewhat smudgy - all in all it's ,more like the housing facility of a fancy gentlemen's club than in a commercial hotel. I was reminded of an anecdote about the Claridge in London - upon complaints by a Texan billionaire that the furniture was all worn out in his suite, a staff member replied to him: "yes, but they were worn out BY ROYALTY."
The only real complaints: The shoe shining service did not work, and there was only one light plug in the living room of the 2 room suite I stayed in, forcing me to use my cell phone light to search for the light switch when I got up in the middle of the night.
The staff was nice and helpful, cannot comment on housekeeping as i spent only one night.
Not my first choice, but quite all right, and in all its stuffiness quite charming.
Less
