Martin B
West Chester, Pennsylvania
Contributor
14 reviews 14 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Perfect central hotel  with winds of colonial style and stars from stage and screen'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

The family spent Memorial weekend (May 25th- May 28th, 2012) in Boston for the first time and we stayed at Omni Parker House in central Boston which was great.
The feeling inside is of an old British colonial style hotel with dark wooden panels on the walls and I love it, and we will definitely come back next time we visit Boston, maybe together with our little puppy since pets under 25lbs. are allowed.
PS. See also my note at the end.DS.

Staff is very attentive, friendly and provides excellent service. Both check-in and check-out went quick and the bill was correct with breakfast and bar tabs that we've put on our room. On the 3rd floor we had a quiet deluxe room and slept like queens in it. It was also with a sofa group so we could all (family of four) gather around it for different evening activities like playing a game of 'Clue'. It was actually like a small living room. Included was also a $15 Food and Beverage credit per stay, which we used. If we would have joined their Guest Loyalty program before we got there we could have had complementary wireless internet.

The hotel is located in the heart of Boston close to the theater district, shopping area (Quincy Market, and Faneuil Hall marketplace), The New England Aquarium, restaurants (don't miss a lobster for dinner!), rapid transit station, the start of the Freedom Trail (we walked half of it and ended up in the Italian District for a fabulous dinner) and it has been the place for stars of stage and screen since the 19th Century, who also could enjoy the hotel's famous Boston cream pie, which is extra ordinary to-die-for delicacy!

We had a Park n Stay Package which made it easy to leave our car at the valet parking, since we walked to all of the spots we wanted to see and if it was a little too long to walk we took the underground trolley transit which was very easy and convenient. We used it to get to The Fenway Park (USA's oldest baseball arena) and Museum of Fine Arts. No need for the car during our stay even if our package included unlimited in/out privileges. There was also a complimentary extended checkout for the vehicle that are past 1 pm, which we didn't needed to use.

NOTE! NOTE! The hotel is located on 60 School Street, but be aware that there are 7 different 'School Streets' in Boston so pick the correct one! Our GPS took us to one of the wrong ones and we had to ask our way to find the correct address and that added and extra hour in driving time to the already 6 hours from Philadelphia.

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

dnadad
Lafayette, CA
Senior Contributor
25 reviews 25 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Small but comfortable rooms'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 13, 2012 NEW

It's a reasonably priced boutique hotel in a quiet residential neighborhood. If you don't want to spend the bucks necessary for a chain hotel in pricy Boston, this is a nice alternative. It's within 2 easy blocks of the Back Bay T station on the orange line, so all of Boston is easily accessible. The 2 twin beds were comfortable, and the small bathroom was chic and functional. Water pressure in the shower was good. We stayed in early June and the individual AC unit in the room did a fine job. There's good free coffee from the Flavia machine in the lobby 24/7, so no in-room coffee/tea was not a problem. The staff was super friendly and pointed us to the diner and upscale coffee shop around the corner. The only issue might have been the bar in the lobby that was very loud until late at night on our first night, a Sunday. It was quiet on a Monday night. If that's a concern, ask for an upper floor room in this 8 floor converted apartment building.
Less

Tony P
Providence, Rhode Island
1 review
'Chandler Inn - You Might Want to Avoid It'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

Disappointing hotel. Rooms are tiny, and bath room is even smaller. Only had enough floor space to open one suitcase, had to clear off a night table to open a second suitcase. Parking (self parking only) is a few city blocks away in a public garage. We were notified during our stay (and was well posted throughout the building and elevators) that power would be shut off from 10:00 AM to 12:00 AM during our stay. Since checkout time is 11:00 AM, there was no info on whether we had to checkout before, or if it would be extended. So we planned on checking out before. At 8:30 AM we received a call from the front desk advising that there was a change, and power would go out at 9:00 AM. So we rushed to packed our bags and get out. We got to the elevator at 8:53 AM, and found the power to them was already shut off. Inconceivable. So our luggage (two suitcases and two overnight bags) had to be carried down from the 5th floor to the lobby via the stairs. This was a planned extension to our trip to Boston as part of my daughters wedding. It was a disappointing end to what was a great week otherwise.
Less

301Lake
Los Angeles, California
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Good value, great location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012

Stayed 4 nights with family and friends during Harvard commencement week, when prices around town were sky high. We weren't looking for hotel amenities, just affordable rates, clean rooms, a convenient location. The Chandler Inn met our needs. Rooms and bathrooms are small, but functional; think modern European boutique with Ikea-type furniture. No closet for clothes; instead you get a stylish stainless steel rack on one of the walls. The bedstands have drawers and some rooms have a desk with additional storage space. Air conditioning is remote controlled and, once turned on, removes what another reviewer called a "musty smell" from the room. Ample good quality soaps, shampoo, conditioner, lotion that are replenished daily. Friendly reception staff. Free wifi.

For breakfast you're likely to be referred to Billy's around the corner on Berkeley Street; it's a local hangout that serves huge American-diner meals. If you want more 'refined' food, the Berkeley Street Cafe next door has excellent pastries, coffees and teas. A slightly longer walk west on Tremont Street offers a multitude of cafes, bars, restaurants, for all tastes and in all price ranges. The area is gentrified, trendy, with a Whole Foods/farmers' market ambiance. Farther down on Washington and Shawmut Streets is a Latin-American/Caribbean enclave, with ethnic offerings. Actually, Noche, a really good Latin-themed restaurant/bar, is just a block away from the hotel on Appleton Street.

One caution: the bar next door to the Inn's entrance - it shares the restrooms - is a fairly genteel
gay watering hole, but we did see two men openly making out at 6pm on the street corner, which
was a bit upsetting to my elderly parent. Please note that the men's conduct would have been inappropriate for the location even if they had been a heterosexual couple.

The Inn is going to be opening another hotel across the street, with suites and larger rooms. I would stay there, if the prices are in the same range as rhey are now, although the Inn itself is entirely acceptable, given its modest ambitions.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask 301Lake about Chandler Inn
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

But the sheets............and that is something they could have done something about for very little money.

'Clean, good location and price, but I won't stay here again.'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012

So I stayed at the Chandler Inn over Memorial weekend after reading reviews on trip advisor and finding a decent deal online. I was concerned about some of the reviews I read but decided to book it because of the price and location, and that's about what I got. The room was clean and the front desk was very friendly and did a great job of providing customer service.

Although I was not expecting a 5 star hotel, I was very dissapointed to find that the room I got (806) had a musky/humid smell and the mattress was in pretty bad shape. The smell would go away while the AC was on, but it would be back the next day after being out of the room during the day. The mattress wasn't damaged or dirty, it just felt old and out of shape. It was not very comfortable. I wouldn't stay here again mostly because of the mattress. I was in pain after the second night.

To be fair, I didn't complain or ask the front desk to change it, mostly because I spent very little time in the room. However, this is a deal breaker for me and I will stay elsewhere next time.

The Back Bay T station is 2 blocks away, and lots of restaurants and shopping areas are within 5 minute walk, so the location is excellent.

We stayed in Boston with the kids after a college reunion and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. The hotel location is superb; it is not on a very busy street, but very convenient to numerous sites and shopping. A friend of mine mapped out a walk down Mass Ave to the Esplanade along the Charles, to Charles Street down to the Public Garden, then back down Commonwealth Avenue. Beautiful. We walked 10 minutes to a Redsox game, whereas the rest of the population is taking multiple forms of transportion and spending hours to get there. Newberry Street, with all of its shops and restaurants is a few blocks away. We would definitely stay again. Our room was large enough to accommodate an additional rollaway bed. I thought the room size was perfectly adequate, especially compared to a typical Manhattan hotel. The T stops are convenient as well for trips to the North End, Cambridge, etc. Excellent!

As we were smiling away she didn't shoot a smile but was like "I was suppose to go but here I am at work" so we responded with "ya it must be hard working on holidays its memorial day and all official kick off to summer!" and what came out of her mouth was just shocking and we couldn't stop talking about it she said "I hate America i'm not from here I don't care about this country or their holidays, its like christmas I don't celebrate it who cares and we are a hotel open 365 days a year 24 hours a day" me and my friend were like UMM OKAY? We are both Canadians and were still irked by this. She just handed us our keys still no smile and that was that. The elevators were quick our room was easy to find it was spacious and clean the beds were very comfy as always at the Hilton. The view was nice it was of the city we were on the 15th floor. Location was PERFECT!!!!! About 3 blocks away from Newberry Street and 4 blocks from Fenway park very convenient and cabs are always lined up outside which was nice. Parking is 41$ per night extra so keep that in mind. There is a Starbucks which was great for a morning coffee and bite to eat it's located right beside the complimentary business center. Overall I would stay here again cause of the location and the rooms and hopefully next time I won't get such a odd check in experience.

'Really cool hotel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

I liked this hotel alot. It was really cool how it was once a jail, now it is an upscale, modern hotel. The lobby is amazing with it's high ceilings and great woodwork. Our room was a good size room up on the 12th floor, although the only view we had was off Boston MGH Ear and Eye Infirmary. The beds were clean and comfortable and the bathroom was really nice. It had a separate shower and bath, along with a large sink and several mirrors. This hotel was steps away from the red line T stop which was convenient. It was also within walking distance of the Charles River, Beacon Hill neighborhood and the Boston Common. There were a few nice looking restaurants and bars in the hotel, but we did not try them. Overall, this was a great stay and I would definitely come back.
Less

TANYAMEMME
Los Angeles, California
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
11 helpful votes 11 helpful votes
'Exciting and Fun if you're up for a party!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW
3
people found this review helpful

While traveling with Sell This House Extreme, in Boston, we stayed at the Liberty Hotel in Downtown. It might not be my first choice to stay with family and kids, but I sure am having a good time! The restaurants on the bottom floor and on the top floor have great food, good service, and the entire front lobby turns into a multi-level night club, or trendy scene with a cool vibe, good looking people ready to have a great time. The rooms are fairly quiet, with the exception of late night stragglers not yet ready to end their night. Once an infamous prison, remnants are apparent in the design with the exposed brick and iron bars. You can clearly see the layout of the cells, and can't help but imagine what it was like years ago when the prison was in full function. Kind of erie, if you think about it, but they've done a great job of turning it into a cool hip place to stay!

Things I like most:
* I love the free coffee station they have every morning at the bottom of the elevators
* The cool hip vibe of the front lobby
* The bouncers at the front door are really great and have fun personalities
* The service at the valet is great
* The front desk staff is great!
* Love the beds in the room
* Lots of counter space in the bathroom
* Bath tubs are new, deep, and clean
* Beautiful glass shower - sexy design

Things I disliked:
* The bar menu in the bottom left restaurant should have have a few more healthy choices
* They have a program where if you choose NOT to have your room cleaned, you get a 5$ coupon for the hotel. I have been here for two weeks, had my room cleaned twice and was only given ONE coupon. No big deal to me, but if you're offering the program, it should be done right.
* As with many hotels, there should be easier outlets in the room to access to charge phones etc....
*Noise can be an issue in the hallways outside the rooms on some nights so if you need rest .....


*
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Club Quarters Boston

jahansen
Western New York
Contributor
15 reviews 15 reviews
Reviews in 11 cities Reviews in 11 cities
79 helpful votes 79 helpful votes
'Not Your Typical Hotel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW
2
people found this review helpful

My wife and I stayed at the Club Quarters for a couple of nights while attending our son's college graduation. While I booked months in advance, this was the only hotel in the downtown Boston area where I could get a room for under $300 that weekend... in fact, it was under $200.

This is a really nice place, but you must accept the fact that it is not a typical hotel. When they say "Club" Quarters, they aren't getting. Companies can join and get special rates, and if your company is a member, you can get even better rates on weekends. They also have branches in NYC, Washington, London, and elsewhere. If you are a business traveler staying by yourself, this would be a fabulous place to stay even if your company isn't a member But, the rooms are small... everything is reduced in size; the room, the bed, the bathroom, etc. The bed, for example, is a full size bed... not even a queen. If you're traveling by yourself this would not be an issue, but traveling as a couple, the whole room got a bit tight. But everything was clean and completely up to date.... even a flat screen television, though, like everything else, it was small.

I loved the way they set up the amenities. Need an extra pillow... or an ironing board... or whatever? No need to call housekeeping... there's a closet on each floor that has this stuff and you just help yourself. Want some fresh drinking water? There's a water dispenser in the hall with bottles available... so you can make your own bottled water for free. Downstairs, the lobby is also tiny, but there is a "club room." TV, reading materials, coffee all the time... it's a really nice place. The coffeemaker is one of those Keurig machines so it only makes 1-2 cups at a time... no problem with it sitting around getting burned all day. Other amenities are available too... they even have iPad's available for loan, for example. There are computers downstairs in case you need them and one is reserved solely for printing boarding passes during certain periods.

There is a bar/restaurant connected to the lobby on the first floor. It's a nice place, but stay away from it on Saturday nights unless you like loud Karaoke.... I mean really loud. No noise filtered up to our room, but if you are looking for someplace to have a quiet nightcap, this is not it.... at least not on Saturdays. By Sunday this had all cleared out and it was pretty pleasant, but still not as quiet as the lobby bar at a top hotel.

The staff was extremely friendly and helpful... couldn't have been nicer... and that's a little strange for a downtown Boston hotel. The hotel is a bit of a hike to the nearest subway station....may be a 5 to 10 minute walk, but you can reasonably walk to the blue, green, red and orange lines. The nearest is the blue line so getting to/from the airport is a snap. BTW, if its a nice day and you are up for a little adventure in going to the airport, you can walk down to the waterfront and take a water taxi over for $10/person. Reservations suggested.

The hotel is in the financial district and there is not much open on weekends in the immediate vicinity... especially on Sunday. But it's a reasonable walk (again, about 10 minutes) to the waterfront (where there is a Panera"s) or to Faneuil Hall.

If the rooms hadn't been so small I would have given it 5 stars. You need to know that going in, but this is the reason the prices are so reasonable (at least by downtown Boston standards). It's a reasonable tradeoff, and a fabulous deal especially if you are traveling alone.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask jahansen about Club Quarters Boston

'Club Quarters Standard: Great Location, Great Hotel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

The Club Quarters Boston is exactly what you'd expect a Club Quarters to be: small, well-appointed rooms, great staff, and an excellent location. I had a hard time locating the hotel and hotel parking but had a positive experience once I managed to get there and check-in; I would not expect anything else from Club Quarters. The only small issue that I had was one of room location: they were unable to locate a standard room on an upper floor on the first night of my stay and placed me on the first floor, just a few feet up from the street, on an alley, above dumpsters. As a solo traveler, I was uncomfortable with this room location and paid to upgrade my room to a suite on an upper floor. The hotel staff was very understanding of this preference and even offered to move my things to an open standard room on a higher floor for the remainder of my stay. Overall, this hotel provided the same positive experience that I've come to expect from Club Quarters.

'Nice place for a short trip - fire alarm in action'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

The room is small but good for a small trip. Very good location, close to South Station, can be done by walk, in case of very small luggage and no rain. Close to Faneuil Hall. The only comment is that the fire alarm snoozed on our first night, and we were forced to go to the street from the 5th floor, in a rainy night. After the fire squad inspection, it was said that it was a false alarm. Two conclusions: a) the fire alarm connection to the fire squad is working fine b) the fire alarm must be revised for a proper work. In the reception there are 2 self attended machines that speed the process for closing the room charges. There is one living room very nice, for the hotel users, with 2 internet connected machines, as well as a fire place and a desk with free coffe and tea. The hotel rent Ipads.

IzZzalot
Binghamton, NY
Senior Contributor
36 reviews 36 reviews
Reviews in 30 cities Reviews in 30 cities
56 helpful votes 56 helpful votes
'Great Location!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We were looking for a hotel in downtown Boston for Memorial Day weekend and were having trouble finding anything "decent" for under $200. Found Club Quarters on Expedia for $140/night, which, for its location, was better than anywhere else nearby. Plus, parking on weekends is only $16/night (self parking), which was a steal compared to some other places. So we booked the Club Quarters after receiving a recommendation from a friend and were not disappointed! As other reviews have stated, it's not the easiest place to find. There is a small sign next to the door, and a flag above the door, but otherwise you wouldn't know it was there (and wouldn't necessarily know it was even a hotel). Check-in was painless and they were able to provide us with the mini-fridge that we had requested. We were on the 11th floor right off the elevator. Hallway noise was not a big issue and we couldn't hear anything in any of the other rooms. The room was small, but not as small as I expected. We had our son with us and his pack-and-play and we were able to find a spot to set that up and still have some room to walk around. The room was fairly simple with a desk, bed, TV on the wall, chair (with a work table), and a small bathroom with a shower. I knew to go check the "supply closest" early for extra pillows, which I did and they were there. Going back for something later though, the closet was pretty empty, so if you need something extra, get it early. The TV selection in the room was fine, the bed comfortable, air conditioning worked well. The "Club Room" had a nice supply of free K-Cups for coffee and was a nice inviting room. The bottled water dispenser on each floor was also nice, especially to have some water to take with you while sightseeing. Check-out was painless. A lot of good restaurants in the vicinity, and the location, only three blocks from Quincy Market and the Freedom Trail, and only a block from a T station, could not have been any better. I will definitely look at staying at Club Quarters in the future.
Less

Jen_and_Chloe
Washington DC, District of Columbia
1 review
'Seven Hills Inn in Lenox, MA is a perfect place for a weekend wedding!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 26, 2012

We got married at Seven Hills in September 2011. When we were looking for a wedding venue, we wanted a place where we could bring together all our family and friends for a weekend to relax, play, celebrate, have a great time AND have a beautiful wedding. Seven Hills Inn is that place and uniquely so  we did not find anything else like it and haven't since. We were able to take over the entire Inn for the long weekend (in our case, it was Labor Day weekend, so we had three days) and the beauty of the estate, in the midst of the gorgeous Berkshires, allowed us and our guests to feel transported and away from the rest of the world, but also to feel comfortable and relaxed like it was our home, without any stuffiness. For example, we had 20 kids running around all weekend!

The weekend was full of games, music, food, and hanging out at the pool, on the lawn, and throughout the Inn's many rooms and spaces. A favorite moment was sharing breakfast with everyone we love each morning, getting to see family members reunite and people we know from all the parts of our lives get to spend time together. The estate offers a perfect space for everything you would want in a wedding venue: The back lawn is a spectacular spot for a wedding ceremony  we were surrounded by hydrangeas and had the stunning woods behind us, which was also where we took portraits after the ceremony. We also took advantage of the back lawn and patio for our 'rehearsal' dinner, where we opted for a lobster 'bake' picnic table extravaganza, complete with an ice cream Sundae bar and lots of kids running around with glow sticks! The banquet room was perfect for the wedding dinner (as well as breakfast for all the guests) and the music room  with its art deco style floor and bar  made a fun and classy space for dancing the night away. In between, the main living room was a perfect lounge area and the 'heart' of the Inn all weekend where family caught up with one another, people could sit and read, and guests could peruse old family photos. Our friends camped out in the library for a marathon poker game and that is also where we set up a photo booth during our reception. In other words, you can do lots of amazing things at this place!

What makes Seven Hills this special is not just its physical beauty (the Inn is kept up to the highest standards), it is the owners, Robin and Dennis Wong, and the wonderful staff they have put together. From the first moment we met with Robin, we felt well taken care of and this lasts throughout your entire experience, from pre-wedding planning through to very last moment. Robin's background in theater, combined with her enthusiasm for weddings and events, means that you essentially get a wedding planner extraordinaire! She has tons of great ideas, and experience, but is also totally open to customizing and changing things up, to make it the wedding you want it to be. Between Robin, her husband Dennis, who rounds out the dynamic duo, and their amazing staff, we were in very capable hands and they took care of EVERYTHING during the wedding weekend itself. Every single one of our guests was blown away by the venue and the presence and awesomeness of Robin and Dennis!

We could not recommend Seven Hills Inn highly enough! And it is definitely going to be a vacation destination.

Jen & Chloe
Less

ethantw
NYC
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Special wedding venue; even more special hosts'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 21, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

You seriously couldn't choose a better place for a wedding. We got married at Seven Hills in September of 2010 in the back lawn surrounded by pine and hydrangea. All day, our friends and family had been hanging around the lawn, throwing frisbees, playing wiffleball, and catching up with all those people you only ever see at weddings. Robin managed the ceremony with the precision you'd expect of someone with her theatrical background. Everything went off without a hitch, and many guests wrote US thank you notes for inviting them to one of the best weddings they'd ever attended.

Two things make Seven Hills special for a wedding: the space, and the innkeepers. The space is why we chose Seven Hills. One of those 19th century mansions that dot the Berkshires, Seven Hills has been significantly updated and upgraded by Robin and Denis without sacrificing any of its charm. The guests wander between a music room (with the bar), a parlor dotted with numerous conversation nooks, the ballroom where the tables are set out, and the patio, which is accessible from the other three rooms. What this set-up creates is the perfect alternative to the "everything in one room" weddings you get at most hotels: an organic flow of people from room to room, changing temperatures, lighting, and activities as their tastes dictate. Our guests grabbed a drink, danced, and then when tired retired to one of those Queen Anne sofas to chat with friends or out onto the patio if they'd been particularly energetic. It's totally unlike any wedding venue I've been to before or since--and that's a good thing.

But the innkeepers, Robin and Dennis, went above and beyond, contributing to our night on a personal level. They were friendly and gracious to us throughout the process, of course, but they also stayed up until the last guests had gone to bed, close to 2 a.m. When they discovered that my wife and I had somehow missed out on our own wedding cake, they defrosted the slice they had placed in the freezer and sat with us while we ate it in the formal dining room. They even got us glasses of milk! What is clear is that Robin and Dennis are in the business of weddings for the joy they get from the occasions, not for the money. Eating cake and drinking milk with them after all our guests had gone to bed is one of my wife's and my enduring memories from the night. You couldn't find two better people to put in charge of your special day.
Less

My husband and I were married at this lovely spot in the Berkshires in the summer of 2010. We had been debating between getting married in Boston or out in the Berkshires. The convenience of this Inn left no questions for us. We had a lot of out-of-towners for the wedding, so having on-site accommodations was very agreeable. They also had breakfasts in the morning, which was a nice touch. The Inn itself is very quaint and has a romantic feel to it. There were great locations for Wedding photographs. Our wedding was a more traditional Jewish one, and the Innkeepers were very accomodating for us. We were able to work with them to make this work for us. We ended up with about 130 guests, and the Inn size was just perfect for that. Another nice thing is that for your wedding, you can book the Inn for the entire weekend, just for you and your guests. Robin was very helpful in arranging and organizing the day of events for the wedding. You can tell that she thoroughly enjoys this aspect of her work. And even since our wedding, Robin has kept in touch and we still go to events at the Inn at different times of the year! Of course, I should also add how much more affordable this site is than some others near by in the area. Budget is an important factor in planning a wedding, and they are definitely aware of that. Overall, very good experience here, and I hope we can celebrate other events at this site in the future!

514Paul
Marlborough, Massachusetts
1 review
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'People, Place, Experiences,'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed December 6, 2011
1
person found this review helpful

People-
At the Seven Hills Inn you will be treated like family, friends or allowed your own space. Dennis and Robin Wong, owner proprietors, have a sixth sense in the ability to recognize exactly how their individual clients wish to be treated. I have been witness to their incredible generosity of spirit along with the ability to remain out of the picture, yet insure your every need is met.
Place-
The Seven Hills Inn has unique spirit both inside the structures and outside. The spirit indoors seems to provide a peace within itself that pemeates all who enter. The more your senses become aware the more you notice the richness of the decor which stirs the imagination in many directions. Outside, depending upon the time of year, stirs the inner spirit into a feeling which enhances whatever mood you are feeling. Whether you are inside or outside, as you appreciate your surroundings you will feel the aliveness of all that surrounds you.
Experiences-
Whatever you desire to experience is provided by a unique environement throughout the Lenox and surrounding area. Whether you seek the beauty of the Berkshires, the backroads and mainstreets all is within your reach. Depending upon the time of year entertainment varies in all directions.
Less

noagenda_7
jersey shore
1 review
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'great wedding'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed October 25, 2011
2
people found this review helpful

A little dated which i think most of the places in the area are. We stayed in the terrace motel and found the room clean and nice for our needs. It was a bit musty but it had windows that could be opened for fresh air. Breakfast was served at 8:30 and although not five star we had no complaints. One thing that would have made the stay a little more enjoyable would be wi-fi in the rooms. This is not a place for early risers such as myself as there is no coffee before 8:30 and no newspapers. A bit frustrating in the absence of wi-fi. Most places I've been to have coffee ready at 7am and newspapers available. My only other problem with the Seven Hills inn is it's location. Pretty but far from any store (for coffee or food). With that said we had a great time and they did a wonderful job with the wedding. I've never been to the Berkshires before and i'm strugling to find the attraction. NY state was much prettier and less expensive.If I did go back I would probably stay at the Red Lion in Stockbridge about 15 min. away. A little more pricey but lively with its very old bar and fireplaces.Plenty of nice shops and pub like eateries. Walk to everything! If you perfer solitude The Seven Hills Inn is very nice
Less

AJ5331
London, United Kingdom
1 review
'Another wonderful wedding weekend at Seven Hills Inn'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed September 30, 2011

We recently celebrated our wedding at the Seven Hills Inn. From start to finish, Robin and Dennis Wong and their staff did an exceptional job. The space was beautiful, and they were wonderfully professional. Robin personally contacted each of our vendors to make sure they would be there on time and that they had everything they needed, and we didn't have a thing to worry about during our rehearsal dinner (which we held onsite) or during the wedding itself. Although the weather was beautiful, the ground was wet from all the recent storms, and Dennis spent part of his Saturday locating tarps so that the guests would not be in the mud during the outdoor ceremony. And, when we inadvertently forgot the ringbearer's pillow, Robin was there with a substitute in 5 minutes. Our family stayed in the Manor House, and everyone was delighted with the beauty of their rooms and the included breakfasts. It was such a treat to have the Inn to ourselves for the weekend. I would highly recommend the Seven Hills Inn as either a hotel or an event venue.
Less

Ritz-Carlton Boston Common

BillySOS

Top Contributor
74 reviews 74 reviews
Reviews in 20 cities Reviews in 20 cities
31 helpful votes 31 helpful votes
'Not bad, Good Location, Good Service'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 13, 2012 NEW via mobile

The location of the hotel is very good. I found the staff to be very friendly and very helpful. The hotel itself and rooms were not what you think of when you go to a Ritz Carlton. When I checked in the friendly staff said, "We have your Marriott Rewards as opposed to your Ritz-Carlton Rewards number on file" and I think that best summed up the stay, a Marriott with a Ritz-Carlton logo. The service was Ritz-Carlton, the hotel and rooms were not. While I was here on business our entire group's room keys simply did not work which was terrible, but Ritz-Carlton staff were on all of the floors to help us get into our rooms, so they did a great job of diffusing the disaster. I give a reasonable rating because of the location and staff, but it would not be my first choice when traveling to Boston again for sure.
Less

Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'One service problem after another on a short stay'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

On a brief stay for a business trip, I found that Ritz-Carlton Boston had one service problem after another. The check-in desk was completely understaffed at 9pm, and no bellman was promptly available to bring luggage up. There was a burned out lightbulb on the desk lamp, and no knob at all on the floor lamp. Setting the (very complicated) alarm clock required a visit from an engineer who needed 5 minutes to figure it out himself. A room service order was delivered incomplete, and shoes to be shined and returned at 7am were returned closer to 7:20 --- and then only after a phone call. Given the high rate charged, this stay was not a good value at all.

The Four Seasons is a much better hotel in Boston, although it has the big disadvantage of not having stall showers (which the Ritz does).
Less

travelnuts88
Houston, Texas
Senior Contributor
26 reviews 26 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Last Ritz'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed here to celebrate my birthday in early May and this was our first and last Ritz stay. I chose this hotel with high expectations that were sadly completely missed.

It was truly an overall disappointment with the room, level of service, security, amenities, price, parking.

The room was overlooking the unfinished courtyard with the workers lounging around. Obviously they saw us and other guests. Our view was pretty much the courtyard and surrounded with buildings. Could not see anything beyond the other buildings.

The staff though professional, they were not knowledgeable of the area. Concierges gave conflicting directions to gas stations. Any Courtyard I've stayed at would be better than this Ritz. The lobby was dark, empty, and did not give a welcoming and safe ambiance. The music in the bar was loud with a handful guests (or were there the staff).

The hotel did not provide a safe and secured feeling. Anyone can walk up to the lifts and go to any floor without secured room keys.

The best thing about the hotel stay was "Kenny" the doorman. He's the only one who's knowledgeable and greeted us with smile.

Very, very, disappointing stay. I'd recommend the Westin Copley, Marriott Copley or if you don't mind staying slightly outside Boston, I'd highly recommend Boston Quincy. Very convenient access in / out of freeways, to the city (with the T). Look for my review of this hotel.
Less

TravelAllDay2011
Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
15 helpful votes 15 helpful votes
'Great location, sub-par Ritz'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 5, 2012 via mobile
1
person found this review helpful

My wife and I booked 3 nights at the Ritz Boston but decided to leave after 2 due to the unsatisfactory experience.

THE GOOD

Location is great. The hotel is right downtown next to the Boston Commons, subway station and the theatre district. Great for both tourists and business travellers alight.

The gym is Huge and fully equipped. It even has a basketball court.


THE SO-SO

The rooms as okay. Ok size and finish. Nothing bad but nothing distinctive either. Not a Ritz standard though.


THE BAD

The service. Staff are not rude, but you can always sense their condescending attitude. They always do just enough to get by but never there to please.

The parking. If you drive, forget about this hotel. It's $44 on-site, 30 off-site self park a day. This is against advertised rate of 40 and 24 respectively, which they didn't honour. The conceirge were helpful in pointing out cheaper alternatives either (which we found on our own).

Basic amenities are missing. No coffee or tea making facilities in the room. No earphones provided a the gym (they sell them though).

Security is an issue. We were asked for our IDs when we checked in so anyone can pretend to be us. There is also no card limited access through the lifts so again anyone can gain access to the doors. Sure there are police all around the front entrance but they can't tell who are guest who are not.

THE DOWNRIGHT UGLY

Completely uncceptable fire alarm procedures. We were rudely awaken at three am by fire alarm, asked to go down a floor. So we made our way to the floor below only to be told but a staff coming out of the lift that it was a false alarm. There were no staff on our floor directing guests, there were no PA announcements made to stop guests from having to leave the room. Only thing the staff told us was "oops false alarm, sorry". A night's sleep ruin.

***

Stay at the Four Seasons. It's 2 min walk away. Same price, way better.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask TravelAllDay2011 about Ritz-Carlton Boston Common
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

'Great Location, wonderful staff'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 14, 2012 NEW

We stayed here for 4 nights and were very happy with the overall experience. Check-in was a breeze. Room was big (handicap room - so no tub). The only thing negative I can say about this hotel is the beds are small. We were 4 people and got a room with 2 beds and they are doubles not queens. So if you don't have little kids, it will be tight. Still it was very nice. Nice gym, indoor pool overlooking harbor. 5 minute walk to Quincy Market (for food), near freedom trail and the T station is right there. Also there is a bike rental kiosk right outside hotel. I must say it was a little pricey but that is Boston.

Reviews in 39 cities Reviews in 39 cities
36 helpful votes 36 helpful votes
'My favorite hotel in Boston'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 14, 2012 NEW

This is a great hotel for business or pleasure. The rooms are a decent size and up-to-date and the location can't be beat. It is right across the street from Fanueil Hall and within walking distance of the financial district, North End, and Boston Common. There is a blue line subway station literally right outside the front doors, which I believe is the same line that goes to the airport. Parking is $46/day (valet only) or there is a deck on the other side of the aquarium for about $35/day - but I wouldn't bother with a car at this hotel. Fitness center is one of the best that I have seen. There is also an indoor pool and a sun deck.
Less

Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'Great service at the Marriott Long Wharf in Boston!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 8, 2012

Just returned from a GREAT 2 night trip to the Marriott Long Wharf, Boston, MA. Immediately upon arrival, Mike (one of the most accomodating door men) welcomed us and assisted us with our check in. From this first greeting, everyone we came in contact with, was exceptionally helpful and interested in our having a wonderful stay. We had cool weather, with scattered showers one day and were delighted to find complimentary umbrellas waiting for us as we exited the hotel, to sight see. The hotel was impeccably clean. All our special requests were handled immediately, with a cheerful attitude. Extra coffee and a whopping amount of extra half n half creamers were provided. One night my daughter left her IPad in the car, which was already valet parked, and Bob, (another of the door men) gladly, searched the vehicle and brought the ipad to us on the 6th floor. What a wonderful, very well run, hotel. In addition, the hotel is perfectly located across from the aquarium, Quincy Market and Fenuil Hall. Great food and shopping! On our last day, upon check out, we learned that our car could stay complimentary at the hotel till 6pm. What a great perk! The (terrific) valet guys brought us the car and re-parked it 3 times that day, for our convenience. Overall, our introduction to Boston was delightful, and left us wanting to go back!!
Less

drdw
NNJ
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Perfect location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

This is one of the better Marriott hotels we have stayed: perfect location, modern dcor, and friendly and professional staff. The room we had, however, was a little small, particularly the bathroom, for the price we paid (since last month was Boston's graduation month; the rate was double than normal rate). The towels were not as thick or soft as one would find in other hotels in the same price range. Insulation of the room was very good, except a few boat whistles in the morning (before 7AM), which could be charming if one was awake. We didn't have any meals there (we usually do not eat in a hotel restaurant). The wifi speed was very good. There are a few computers in the lobby with free printing, which is nice (most hotels, including many Marriott's charge fees for non boarding pass printing). Valet parking (no self parking) was efficient with a little premium. Overall, it was a pleasant stay. If the rate is right, we will certainly go back again.
Less

KillingtonVT
Killington
Reviewer
5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
15 helpful votes 15 helpful votes
'GREAT RENOVATION, FINALLY!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012

Visited May 30th and was pleased to finally see some renovations! Escaltor still takes you up to reception/check in so bell-hop for large/several bags is a must.
Once at Check-in a new second floor lounge, sitting area has been added. Comfy club chairs with several seating areas, large flat screen TV, library feel with bookcase lined walls and reading material. Also the dark access to the bar/restaurant has been taken down so you can SEE it from check-in. Very light and bright now. Also added a computer work station /business area and separate, lovely, reading, relaxing room with large chaise lounge chairs and a great view of the park across the street. Starbucks still downstairs along with 2 water-view restaurant bars! Water taxi to/from the airport is literally right out the door for $10.00 each way. Rooms still clean and fresh, large bathrooms, good housekeeping. It seems they wanted to apeal to a broader crowd than just families. The indoor pool is key to family fun and is ALWAYS crowded. But on weekdays you can have it all to yourself along with a lovely, large wrap around, outdoor pool deck to sit and enjoy the harpor, sunset or a cocktail. (BYOB, no drink/food service out there). GREAT area for food, across from Legal Seafoods, 2 blocks from Quincy Market/Fanuiel Hall and Boston North End for Italian.
Still a keeper!
Less

JAdvisor
Los Angeles, California
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Excellent location, Easy walk to all nearby attractions'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

It was our first trip to Boston as a family and we needed a place to be close to all areas.
We stayed 3 nights and had two kids around 9 &11. Our friend recommended this hotel as she was a Boston resident for many years.
This is not a super luxury hotel, but we did not need that for a short visit which we were out of the room most of the day. The room size was fair for what we paid. We asked for the extra bed and it was there when we arrived. The room had 2 queen beds as well. The room was clean, the beds comfortable. We had a good view of the Marina.
The location was superb. Easy walk to all nearby areas including the Quincy Market, harbor, the Freedom Trail, Paul Revere's house, USS Constitution (a little further away) ...
Walking distance to the metro and plenty of taxi available. We also took the metro to see the Harvard / Cambridge (very nice), MIT, ......and took a cab to come back.
The hotel is walking distance away from a lot of nice Restaurants with seafood, Italian, ...
The Hotel lobby is modern looking and they have good friendly staff there all the time.
The internet was free at the lobby only.
The ride to the airport was about 15-20 minutes.
We made the reservation with breakfast and it had a good selection for us and the kids.

Overall we enjoyed the visit to Boston and this hotel's location and staff made it much better.
Less

Chloe267036
Cedar Rapids, Iowa, United States

14 reviews 14 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Very Convenient'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

The Hilton hotel is very convenient for people flying into Boston. They have a free shuttle that will come pick you up from the airport. However, when we got here, we waited for the shuttle for almost half an hour, it only runs every 15 minutes. It's not quite a luxury hotel, but it's very nicely decorated, and they have good service. The view of the Boston Bay area is beautiful from the rooms. In the morning, the shuttle will take you to the metro or the airport or anywhere else you need. It's clean, and quiet and good for relaxing after a long (or short) flight. There were plenty of elevators that were fast. The restaurant at the hotel is very expensive, so I would have to suggest eating somewhere else. Otherwise, the hotel was very nice and near the airport, it was very convenient.
Less

Poopycat

Contributor
19 reviews 19 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
11 helpful votes 11 helpful votes
'The best of the airport hotels'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

I have stayed in quite a few hotels that are attached to airports, and most are overly expensive or extremely noisy due to air traffic. I am happy to say that rooms at the Boston Logan Airport Hilton are very quiet, and also very reasonably priced for the location.

I have absolutely no complaints about my experience here. The signs to the hotel are very easy to spot in the terminal, check-in was prompt and courteous, and I received free internet service as a Hilton Honors member. I had one of the best room service meals I have ever had - maybe it was just because I was returning from overseas and was desperate for a steak, but everything I had was delicious and generously portioned. Room was very quiet and well appointed.

Do yourself a favor if you find yourself having to stay in Boston overnight in order to catch a flight, and stay at the Airport Hilton. It is convenient and a good value given the amenities and location.

John W
Atlanta, GA
Senior Contributor
23 reviews 23 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Outstanding place to stay while in Boston!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

Do yourself a favor and choose this location when traveling to Boston for business. Oh, and pay the extra few dollars to get a room on the executive level with access to the Executive Lounge.

Although located at the airport, it's a quick 20-min ($20) cab ride to downtown. Or, the courtesy van will drop you off at the public transit, where it will cost you all of $2 to go pretty much anywhere in Boston.

I "discovered" this hotel during the first of my four week-long recent business trips to Boston and rebooked each time after. I originally selected it for price reasons ($150+/night less than similar downtown hotels). I returned because of the experience. Modern facility convenient to airport (5 min by courtesy van or 10 min walk via connected sky bridge. Very nicely appointed, spacious rooms. Excellent, attentive staff. All the amenities one would expect from a hotel at this price point.

If there's any negative comment I would have about the hotel, it would be that it's restaurants serve rather ordinary food at relatively high prices (I found $16 for a run-of the mill hamburger to be disappointing and the filet to be overpriced). However, that was offset by the choice of complimentary breakfast items and hoer d oeuvres available daily at the Executive Lounge.

All-in-all, the hotel is superior accommodations and service at a great value for the business traveler seeking high quality accommodations.
Less

'Good choice'

Abazaba
Los Angeles
Senior Contributor
47 reviews 47 reviews
Reviews in 30 cities Reviews in 30 cities
65 helpful votes 65 helpful votes
'Conveniently close to Logan Airport'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

If you're vacationing in Boston, this is probably not the best place to stay due to its location. However, if you are traveling to Boston on business, as I was, It's ideal if your meeting/conference is nearby (i.e., World Trade Center).

The Renaissance is comparable to a Category 4/5 Marriott property. Rooms have the Marriott updated furniture, TV, etc., Beds are comfortable and that's one of the reasons I like Marriott.

Despite having a conference complimentary WIFI code, I was unable to connect the second day. Calling the 800 number to resolve the issue was an unexpected surprise. The person was extremely competent and I had no issues after that time.

The area has been built up quite a bit. In fact, the nightlife is quite active as many people were milling about the bars and various eateries. Of course, there is a Legal Seafood within walking distance and an interesting place called Legal Test Kitchen.

I opted for the Lobster Yankee Fish Market which appeared to be a casual place for the locals. This restaurant is only 2 blocks from the hotel and you can arrive casually dressed. It was the perfect place for me to enjoy a lobster roll.

I later found out that the T Silver Line (bus) is immediately west of the hotel. From there, you can catch a ride to the airport for only $2.00. You can also ride in-bound to the city and hook-up with the network of trains. On my last day, I traveled in-bound and went to Quincy Market. It took a couple of transfers, but I managed to get there.
Less

CardCarrier
Royal Oak, Michigan
Senior Reviewer
10 reviews 10 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'A satisfying stay, better location than we expected'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

My partner and I stayed here for a commencement ceremony that was taking place at the nearby Bank of America Pavilion. We wanted someplace within walking distance of the Pavilion, and fully expected to be inconvenienced a bit by the hotel's South Boston location in regard to other sightseeing we might want to do. But we were pleasantly surprised to discover that the Silver Line was just outside our door, and offered easy, inexpensive transportation. A few quick connections on the T and you could basically get anywhere, including any attractions and the airport. In the meantime, we also had the chance to explore the South Boston area, and we began to really like it --- it has a different, waterfront-resort type of vibe than the downtown area and yet that difference was very welcome after a day of busy, urban touring. The restaurants were good, the convenience stores were plentiful, and the Institute of Contemporary Art (ICA) was about a 7-minute-walk away and was an impressive experience if you have a spare hour or two. The hotel itself was clean and comfortable, but i have to admit that the price was too high for what you get with respect to the style of the room (another reviewer was right to question the beach-inspired decor), the lack of a good soaking tub (shower stall only), and no complimentary Interact access. I suppose this is to be expected for a great Boston trip, however, but it does turn my five stars into four when I think about the other high-end hotels I have experienced.
Less

'Great Hotel!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 9, 2012 NEW

Stayed here for 6 nights before moving onto NY. The hotel was great, very modern, clean, fresh and very friendly staff. Had a great view from the Hotel room and were very close to local transport links! The Breakfast in the hotel restaurant was nice however I would avoid the maple sausages and bacon, pretty disgusting although seemed popular with others! However we had breakfast in the Hotel's Starbucks which worked out much better on a morning. The TV's in the room were a very good size, the bathroom was spacious and clean, the beds were very comfy and I had no problem sleeping in it and it was all very clean. The pool Jacuzzi and sauna are great and the gym is a good size with a good range of equipment. All in all I would recommend this hotel to anyone going to Boston, good restaurants nearby, in particular the legal test kitchen next door and the Ben and Jerry's stand over the road is great too, great facilities in the hotel, good transport nearby, and very friendly staff!

'Brilliant Stay at Renaissance Boston Waterfront Hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 7, 2012

What a gorgeous hotel and a wonderful overnight experience! The hotel is beautifully designed and is in imaculate shape thanks to a dedicated staff who clearly love what they do and take great pride in their hotel.

Our room was modern, spacious, and had every amenity you could want including a great bathroom and the most comfortable bed I may have ever slept in. Not to mention the view! Downtown Boston and the water - gorgeous!

The hotel's pool and hot tub provided the perfect relaxation before dinner, and although I didn't use it, the fitness room was first-rate with free weights, treadmills and plasma TVs on the wall.

Dinner and breakfast the following morning were great experiences as well at the hotel's elegant 606 Congress restaurant. In particular, our server, Jessica, was very friendly, knowledgable and took excellent care of my wife and I. The food was delicious (I recommend the seasoned french fries, no matter what entree you get!), and the atmosphere was perfect for a romantic dinner.

This was really an awesome experience and I strongly recommend this hotel if you are visiting the Boston area, or are an area resident looking for a perfect getaway for a night.

biun
Caracas
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Great Stay, Great Hotel.Perfect if you are attending an event nearby .'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012

I stayed at this hotel because I was attending a graduation at the Bank of America Pavilion, which is less than a block away. It's a great hotel if you are attending an event nearby or if you are traveling on business and all your meetings or conferences are around that area. If you want to explore Boston or you are traveling for leisure I would recommend staying somewhere closer to Downtown or nearer to public transportation.
That being said, the rooms are big,comfortable and clean. And I can't say enough about the beds and the pillows. It was one of the best sleeps I have ever had. Great Views as well.
They have a Starbucks in the lobby if you get and hankering for coffee (I can't say anything about the food in the hotel, since I never ate at the restaurant) and if you want one of the Best Lobster rolls ever, there is a Restaurant called "Yankee Lobster" also less than a block away, and it worth the walk. Amazing!
Because we drove from New York we had a car. Do not leave your car at the Valet. Like all hotels they charge WAY TOO MUCH. Just park your car in one of the various parking lots around the area. Great staff, pleasant and friendly.
It's expensive, but you can see where your money goes. I do wish however that Boston had a better hotel offer with better prices, but hey, that's not the hotels problem.
Less

Belasaria
Fairfield, Ohio
Top Contributor
90 reviews 90 reviews
Reviews in 37 cities Reviews in 37 cities
210 helpful votes 210 helpful votes
'Perfect place for attending a BCEC conference, except for the internet service & restaurant'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012

I stayed at the Westin for a week for a conference held at the BCEC. Overall, I was impressed by this Westin except for two near-fatal flaws.

First, the good stuff -- Upon check in, I was greeted pleasantly by the staff. I had to drop off several items for my group to pick up when they checked in, and the staff was very helpful with this.

I booked a small suite since I knew my group would be having several closed-door meetings. What was nice about this was that the parlor was completely separate from the bedroom, so there could be meetings in the parlor while I could do work in my room without being disturbed.

The view from the room wasn't particularly pleasant--parking lots and the side of the convention center--but for the type of room it was and the price paid, it was nice.

Housekeeping did a nice job at keeping the parlor area tidy after each meeting. I would call down once the meeting was finished and they would be up within 10 minutes to service the room. I tipped them for each trip, because they were efficient in turning the room around. It wasn't that my group was sloppy (the room seated six max), it was the coffee cups, bathroom, and room service dishes that needed to be taken care of.

Room service was exceptionally fast--I never had to wait longer than 20 minutes for my meal, although I ordered very simple items. The Irish Pub had decent food and shared the menu with the City Bar. Both had good service and good food.

The Birch Bar was either closed for renovations or cordoned off for a private event. Keep in mind when there is a large convention in town, the City Bar and Birch Bar can be bought out by groups and will not be able to serve the general customers. This is in the Seaport/Waterfront District, so there's really not much within close walking distance. Restaurants like LTK, Morton's, Salvatore's and Legal Seafood are a good 15 minute walk from the hotel.

Now, the bad news.
I had lunch and breakfast at Sauciety, which is the main hotel restaurant. Wow. What a disappointment. They turn the restaurant over at 11:30 AM from breakfast to lunch. There was a group of six people patiently waiting at 11:30 AM to be seated. The hostess blatantly ignored them, ignored me when I tried to flag her down, and ignored two other guests. I know the restaurant is busy changing linens over or whatever, but all the hostess had to do was ACKNOWLEDGE us and we would have been happy. She went out of her way to ignore us. When we tried to flag down the rest of the staff--they refused to make eye contact and scurried away. Insulting, to say the least. When they finally had the restaurant set (which was at 11:45 AM), the hostess and staff deigned to speak to us. Several of us were concerned that the restaurant was fully booked for lunch (they accept reservations, it was the peak convention day, and there were several tables already marked reserved), which was why we were trying to get their attention. I mentioned it to the person who dropped me off at the bar and she refused to respond.

Why I went back here for breakfast is beyond me, except that I was hungry and I had a long flight ahead of me. The buffet is expensive and the waitress was clearly unhappy that I didn't want the buffet. I placed my order, asking for the breakfast potatoes to be cooked without the bell pepper. She said it couldn't be done.

As a veteran of full-service hotel restaurants, I know this isn't true. The potatoes were deep fried and the peppers were added at the end; they weren't cooked together like a hash. She still claimed the restaurant couldn't make it without the peppers. Disappointed, I ordered the small salad and got grief for daring to ask to have the cucumber held. While her service was slow (getting refills on my tea was painful), she was super-quick with the bill. Upon departing, I addressed the hostess about the whole potato thing and she just blew me off.

Finally -- the internet issues. The hotel's servers were down repeatedly throughout my stay, which made working a huge challenge. After speaking with the front desk on the phone, followed by their off-site help desk (which makes no sense having someone offsite to service internet on property, but I digress), they finally said it was an issue with the hotel. Knowing I was being charged $13/day for it, I went down to the desk, asked to have the internet refunded, and asked when they thought the 'net should be back up. No one knew.

What was worse was that the Westin sent automated calls about their Westin Workout, but failed to do so when their internet went down. C'mon, people. All you needed to do was leave a message that the 'net was down, how long you estimated it to be down, and viola! I would have been much happier if I didn't have to keep calling people to get my 'net to work.

Will I stay here again? If I have an event at the BCEC, you can't beat the Westin for convenience. However, I think overall the Renaissance and Seaport hotels are better deals and have more restaurants in the immediate vicinity than the Westin.

See all photos
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

617-532-4863, I would appreciate it. I would like to get a better understanding of what happened so that we can improve our services where necessary. I look forward to hearing from you and I hope you will consider staying with us in the future so that we can provide a more enjoyable experience for your next visit.

'Top notch service!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012

I decided to take an overnight road trip to Boston. Since I had never been, I let Hotels.com choose the place and I'm glad I did! The convention center was very busy but the valet noticed me immediately and had me at check in within a minute. I checked in early and no one sighed and rolled their eyes like I've experienced at other hotels. Instead they graciously upgraded me to a harbor view and got me enrolled in the SGP rewards program. Room service was less than a 15 minute wait and I appreciate when I don't have to stop by the front desk to check out. The rooms were clean, the shower was great... I'll be booking with Westin for my upcoming stay in Hawaii because of the great service in Boston.

gmac66
Aransas Pass, Texas
Contributor
17 reviews 17 reviews
Reviews in 11 cities Reviews in 11 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'This is "ALMOST" and Exellent Hotel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 10, 2012 NEW

We stayed here for two nights at the end off our holiday in New York and MA. We were in City View rooms and the view was indeed fantastic. The rooms were spacious and there was little to no 'airport noise'. Other reviewers complained about the absurd parking charges but that is the norm for city hotels and one reason we choose this one....you can return the rental car and use public transport, water taxi or subway to get into the city - it's very convenient. We didn't eat in the restaurant; I avoid hotel restaurants if at all possible. They are either mediocre or over priced. Besides, if you are on holiday why would you eat at a hotel instead of something local? The staff was friendly and helpful. There are two reasons I can't rate the hotel as excellent. We were gone from our room from around 9AM until 8:30PM and the room was not cleaned. Granted, when we called the front desk they did send someone up but there should be controls in place. The one thing that really annoys me is the 12.95 charge for internet. If you stay in low to mid-range motels, the internet if free. If you stay in a higher-end hotel you are charged. It's kind of like all of the airline fees...you feel a if you are being "gouged". In addition, once I paid the fee, the connection was so slow I might as well have been on dial-up. At least if you are going to charged for it have a decent transfer rate.
Less

We're from Palm Beach, Florida. My wife and I stayed here over the Memorial Day weekend. The hotel's on the smaller, but yet intimate size for a Hyatt Regency, but the staff more than made up for this. These guys were absolutely great. The person who made our stay the most memorable was Jamie Merlino, the restaurant manager. We ate at the hotel everyday. Ms. Merlino personally addressed each guest during breakfast. I've never seen this - - anywhere. Trust me. We are experienced travelers. Over the past year we've stayed in at least 15 Hyatts (regency & grand) including the flagships in Kauai, Hi, & Dubai, UAE. One evening we returned to our room and found a cheese and strawberry plate awaiting us courtesy of the restaurant. In addition, our last meal was succulent: lobster pasta and a snapper dish that would make your toes curl.

The concierge was also knowledgeable and provided accurate information regarding events and restaurants in the greater Boston area. This was an extremely busy Boston weekend, too: 4 weddings, a celtic home playoff game crowd and 2 proms. The car was also delivered on time with my wife's door opened first! This is a big deal for me. These guys never missed a beat.

Finally, the front desk was also excellent. From the harbor view upgrade to the 4:00 p.m., late check out, to accomodate our evening flight, they were very attentive. The hotel personnel made this stay great. I would return solely because of these employees.

Frank D
Miami, Florida
Senior Contributor
30 reviews 30 reviews
Reviews in 10 cities Reviews in 10 cities
20 helpful votes 20 helpful votes
'Excellent location, and I never heared any airport noise from my bedroom'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 23, 2012

I stayed here on May 2012, and I loved it. If its your first time in Boston, I highly recommend it, simply because its a great location. First of all, you can take the free shuttle to the hotel, right from Boston Logan Airport (save over $20 in taxi fare, roundtrip), It's only minutes away from the airport, so you can sleep in a little more before waking up to take that early flight home, and you never have to deal with traffic. Second, the views. Wow. if you like the Boston city skyline, you're going to love this place. Sit back and have a drink as you watch the sun set over Boston Harbor. Third, I took the Water Taxi nearby, which was $34 for a round trip from the hotel to downtown (its cheaper than taking a taxi over there). It will leave you in a perfect place for taking Old town trolley tour bus, and Ghost tour venues nearby. You can also eat some good seafood in the variety of local eateries on the bay, and walk off the calories by taking a nice stroll around the historic places of interest.

Less

CharlotteBeebo

Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Luxurious, Family-Friendly Stay in a Fantastic Location'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

We stayed at the Taj Boston in March for 3 nights. It was our first time visiting Boston.

I booked the Taj through an online booking site and was not disappointed- it is a very luxurious and usually way out of my league place to stay. It is in an outstanding location, overlooking the Public Gardens and Boston Common and when you step out of the hotel, you step onto Newbury Street and your wallet practically jumps out of your pants. Newbury Street hosts a lot of high-end stores and high-end shoppers.

Practicality and family-friendliness have become very important to us in travelling with a little kid (he was just 1 at the time) and Taj didn't let us down there, either. When you're travelling with a little one, they bring you a stocked crib and the cutest gift bag filled with baby toiletries (shampoo, baby powder, etc.) and a little stuffed bear. How cute is that?

Taj Boston's staff were really fantastic- always friendly, knowledgeable about the surrounding area and generally warm and kind.

On-site there was a gym and two restaurants/lounges...and....get this....a Chanel store. I didn't go, but I really, really wanted to. Believe me!

Just down the street there are more affordable food options- chain restaurants, a Dunkin' Donuts (which I understand America apparently runs on) and lots of other stuff.

Like I said, the location was so central to everything, we walked every where and used the subway to visit Harvard Square.

Really great stay, totally impressed!
Less

'Classy Hotel'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 12, 2012 NEW

On entering the hotel we immediately felt we were out of place, it seems the very rich were the favoured customer. The rooms were plush and traditional, the bed was the best I have ever slept in with feather topped mattress and gorgeous plump feather pillows. The restaurants will not allow anyone in with casual clothes such as T shirts, shorts or trainers?? We thought the meals were overpriced anyway so found our way to a variety of choices for breakfast etc in nearby locations.
Boston Public Park and Boston Common are opposite which we found was a wonderful place to relax, see the real Bostonians and take in the sun. All in all a lovely hotel but too stuffy in many ways. Depends what you are looking for and how much you are willing to spend.

Robert C
Mumbai, India
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Great hotel, not great value'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 11, 2012 NEW

I stayed two nights during June 2012.

The good: Outstanding location (overlooking the park in the center of Boston). Courteous and knowledgeable staff (as you would expect from a Taj property). Wonderfully comfortable beds and pillows (as Goldilocks would say, "Just right!"). Tastefully furnished. Superb food -- the breakfasts were among the best I've had at any hotel. The fitness room is well-equipped (happy to find free weights).

The not-so-good: Breakfast is NOT complimentary with the room (the only Taj property I've stayed at that did not include breakfast). While the food was excellent, breakfast averages about $45-50 per person! No complimentary internet, either (also a departure from other Taj properties). Considering the extremely high room rates, this Taj seems downright chintzy in not offering complimentary breakfast and internet. The rooms are also not well-insulated from noise -- I could hear everything from the room next to mine. And the telephone in my room was broken.

So overall I would say this is a really comfortable hotel, but not a very good value for the price.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

On your next visit to Boston, I encourage you to try our Express Continental Breakfast in the Bar, which offers hot and cold beverages, fresh fruit, an assortment of breads and pastries, and more for a great value of $19++ per person. Also, we urge you to take advantage of our Breakfast Inclusive Package as you book your next visit to Boston, which is a great value and includes breakfast in the Caf.


Thank you again for staying at Taj Boston, and we do hope you choose to stay with us again on your next visit to Boston.

Joseph L
Posted by an Easytobook.com traveler
Boston
1 review
'First time visitor. Will there be a second?'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 24, 2012

Having grown up in the Boston area, the Ritz Carlton was the place to see and be seen. But, I never set foot inside until I moved 1250 miles away and returned for my daughter's grad school graduation. This was now the Taj and I was skeptical about the change. I was right to be guarded.
Upon arrival (Sat.), it was chaos. The elevators were not working but the management decided not to tell anyone. Weddings were going on; people in for various graduations all over town; and the staff acted indifferent. No one to offer to take our bags up to the room or store until elevators repaired.
After checking in, we went to the room overlooking the Commons. The room was delightful. A trip to the bar before heading out to dinner was exceptional - top service but this is not a place to go into and drink heavily - at least without bringing some gold coins. Pricey. Returned to the bar later for its cupcake dessert bar - trendy and good.
Next morning took six people to the brunch on the roof. Very nice buffet, but not the best i've been to by any stretch. Waiter said he could not take a group picture of us. WTF? Claimed he would be fired. Management should fire anyone who refuses such a request, IMO.
Used the workout area. Adequate machines with top service. How many times have you been offered a towel while on a treadmill?
Finally, had an opportunity to also have breakfast at the Cafe. Good selection and variety. Bring some coin. You are paying for convenience and comfort - any doubt, go have the same meal at the Paramount. Cheaper, but at least you avoid the prison mess hall experience offered at that Beacon Hill eatery.
I wish they offered a choice of newspapers delivered to your door in the AM. I would have preferred the Globe to the WSJ or NYT. Give the people an option.
Seemed understaffed at times in terms of bellmen. As opposed to four people hovering over the person at the concierge asking about the swan boats.
in the end, I did like the hotel better than some of the bigger chains in town or even the smaller older ones. But for the price, I think I will try somewhere new next time.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
