Lclyatt
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
'The service was unbelievable'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012 NEW

The hotel has a great location that is near the start of two cable car lines and great shopping and dining. The staff could not have been nicer and everywhere we went it seemed like they were doing something extra to make us feel special. One example was that my son wanted plain M&Ms from the honor bar but they only had peanut. We called the front desk and within a few minutes we had 5 bowls of sorted by color M&Ms plus two glasses of milk, all for no charge. When you also add in things like the daily wine reception along with the personal service it is easy to see why Kimpton is my favorite hotel chain.
Less

Pollysej
Cardiff, United Kingdom
Senior Reviewer
9 reviews 9 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
14 helpful votes 14 helpful votes
'Central Location & Helpful Staff...'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We stayed here for 2 nights recently, the hotel was in an excellent location. Just around the corner was a large Westfield shopping centre with Bloomingdales and all the big names.

We look the Bart underground from SFO airport to Powell Street station. It costs $8.10 per person for one way. The hotel is just a 2 minute walk as you exit the station.

The room was nice although a little small. Free WiFi was a plus, sign up for Kimpton rewards before you go, only takes a few minutes. We were located on the 5th floor, this is where the restaurant, gym etc was located.

I found that when I got home the hotel had charged my credit card for the room although it was already pre-paid. I contacted them and they apologised for the mistake and refunded me. The staff were very friendly, nothing was too much trouble.

I would defiantly recommend this hotel and would be happy to stay here again.

    *
    *

Less

See 2 more reviews by gorettigirl for San Francisco
gorettigirl
California
Reviewer
5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Great Place for a Celebration'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

From the moment I booked our reservation at Hotel Palomar, I felt like a welcomed guest. Rachel Wang, the guest service representative, contacted me by e-mail to acknowledge my room requests and to answer some questions about transportation. She was so engaging and knowledgeable I was quite enthusiastic about our stay.
Our arrival at the hotel was made simple via BART from the airport with a direct stop to the hotel. For those who are not accustomed to an urban environment you may be a bit nervous about the kinds of people who are wandering around the hotel area. While it may be off putting it is really the state of the environment throughout San Francisco - this situation is not peculiar to this hotel. The front desk staff welcomed us with a salute to our anniversary and with a professional air that was down to earth and inviting. The staff was fully knowledgeable of the hotel amenities and gave us specific information about our stay. They were also always at our disposal to offer directions to and from our restaurant choices and AT&T stadium.
The bar and lounge area in the hotel is vibrant and welcoming as well. Our bartenders Brian and Sarah were professional, but also friendly without being intrusive. Brian had expert knowledge of his bar and introduced us to several wines and cocktails that we will definitely try again. The free happy hour of wine and appetizers is a nice perk offered at all Kimpton Hotels and we did enjoy the one at the Palomar as much as the others we experienced in Chicago, San Diego and DC.
We will return to the Palomar for all these reason - great staff, great service, great atmosphere, great location to public transportation. We will be back to celebrate other occasions!
Less

TravelingFoodie319
Contributor
11 reviews 11 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
13 helpful votes 13 helpful votes
'Friendly service, nice suite'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 25, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

This hotel is centrally located and only a quick walk to the Convention Center. If you can afford a suite, they offer lots of room and huge bathrooms. Although the hotel is at a busy intersection the soundproofing is excellent (I was on the 9th floor and barely heard traffic noise). The staff front-desk staff are uniformly helpful and friendly; one exception was a doorman who tried to convince me to take a town car to the airport when I asked him repeatedly for a taxi. I always prefer having a coffee maker in the room for first thing in the morning. Although there is coffee service in the 5th floor lounge, it would have been nice to have a Keurig in the room. This hotel is a wonderful alternative to the huge, sterile, and anonymous Marriott just across the street.
Less

Problem with this review?
jul222
Edinburgh
Senior Contributor
27 reviews 27 reviews
Reviews in 21 cities Reviews in 21 cities
37 helpful votes 37 helpful votes
'Loved this hotel.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 25, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We stayed here for 4 nights at the start of our holiday and could not have asked for anything more.
From the welcome email prior to arrival through to check-out, the staff were friendly, helpful and professional. We were given a lovely room on the 5th floor which was quiet and well positioned. There was a coffee maker, animal print robes and a well stocked mini-bar in the room. The bed was very comfortable with quality linens.
I joined Kimpton club prior to arrival, so internet access was free and there was a wine gathering each evening - a lovely touch.
Breakfast was decent if a little slow. We didn't eat dinner in the hotel but were told by others that the food was excellent.
There was even a lovely dog in reception for me to pet in the morning before walking the short distance to the sights, the hotel is in an excellent position close to cable cars, shops, public transport and sights.
I've stayed in more luxurious hotels but overall, this is a great hotel, excellent value for money in a prime location with the best front desk staff I've encountered.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Drivin_and_Cryin

Senior Contributor
28 reviews 28 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Right in the middle of the action.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 23, 2012 via mobile

I was in SF on business and going to the Moscone Convention Center. This is very close and much nicer than the other giant chain hotels nearby.
Easy to get to on the BART from the airport ($8.10 and 1 block walk from Powell station)
Room adequate size, modern, clean, flat screen TV. Excellent wireless Internet that is free if you join their frequent guest program. Other benefit of the program is free NY Times in the AM, and $10 credit for the minibar (2 Clif bars for me!)
Best was the friendly front desk staff including Maverick, an elderly gentle chocolate Lab (see photo)

We stayed one night whilst my Husband was working in Framingham and had a welcome break
from dump that is the Sheraton In Framingham.
As it was our anniversary the hotel thoughtfully left wine and chocolates in our room, a nice touch.
The room we were in had a outstanding view of the harbour and was well appointed.
Toiletries were of a high standard and the bed extemely comfortable.
The bar tender was knowledable and attentive, nothing was too much trouble.
Parking was convenient and reasonable .
Will come back for longer next time.
Thank you from the UK.
Less

MrGroove
Long Beach, California
1 review
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'The Hotel Highlight of our New England Trip!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012 NEW
3
people found this review helpful

Just got back from our week stay in the New England and could not wait to review this place.

The only sad thing about this place was that it was our first hotel stay of the trip and set the bar way too high for any other New England hotel to match. We took the red eye flight in from Los Angeles so when we landed at Logan at 5am we were zombies. It's really easy to get here from Logan via the "T". All you have to do is take the Silver Line to the South Station and it's a short walk up Atlantic (We wish we knew this when we first got there).

Knowing that our hotel check in wasn't until 4pm we wondered over to the hotel to simply check our bags and wonder around town. The front desk was extremely gracious by seeing if there was something they could do to help us out and gave us our 4pm check in at 7am!

Once we got to our room we were quite impressed with the size of it. It was very spacious and very comfortable. I've read some of the reviews about the style being old fashioned or outdated in this hotel but after checking it out it wasn't old fashion. It was a bit more turn of the century and Art-Deco in it's design. Sure it wasn't one of the modern design places like the Intercontinental a few places over but I come from LA where every hotel looks like that. The Boston Harbor Hotel gave me a little more of a New England Feel and for that I am very grateful.

When we finally crashed on the bed we laid down of one of the softest most comfortable mattresses we've ever slept on in our lives. It was like sleeping on a cloud.

I took advantage of the Fitness Center and was very impressed with it. I loved the salt water pool and was impressed with the locker room which had a sauna and amenities for me to shower, shave and start my day.

The hotel also sits on the harbor with a beautiful boardwalk at it's back door.

This hotel was truly the hotel highlight of our trip and cannot express how pleased we were with our experience. No other hotel was able to live up to this hotels experience. If you have the dough to shell out for a little luxury, make the Boston Harbor Hotel your choice. We're so glad we did!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

cmd108
New York City, New York
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
'Extremely Noisy'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

I stayed at the Boston Harbor a few weeks ago, as a colleague booked it first and I choose to stay near him rather than book at a separate hotel. My first room was so loud that it seemed like the elevator control room was in my hotel room. There were constant sounds of people talking in the corridors, and even a dog barking away around 1 or 2am. I got about 3 hours of sleep that night. I got moved to the 'quieter' tower. I was taking a conference call from the room around 3pm and could literally hear the jangling keys and rustling of a garbage bag by one of the housekeepers walking by. I then checked out and moved next door to the Intercontinental. I would never re-book at this hotel until they figure out some sound attenuation. It's sad, because it is classic Boston with beautiful views and good restaurants, and a stellar location. I have stayed at the Liberty, Intercontinental, Ritz, Beacon XV and W and have not had any sound issues to this extent, and I have spent roughly 25 nights in hotel rooms in Boston over the last 8 months.
Less

DebbiesOnTheRoad
Moorpark, California
Senior Contributor
39 reviews 39 reviews
Reviews in 33 cities Reviews in 33 cities
15 helpful votes 15 helpful votes
'A pleasure; decide what's important to you'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 24, 2012

The hotel is in a wonderful location on the harbor. It's convenient for both Freedom Trail tourists and financial center business travelers, and easily reached by public transportation (from Logan, take the Blue Line to the Aquarium stop.)

I had a junior king suite with a very nice city view. It had a separate living area with a work desk, television, sofa and chair, the very comfortable king-sized bed with another television, and a bathroom area. The bathroom amenities are higher end and even include liquid laundry soap. There is a minibar with some directions on how to use the refrigerator for your own items.

There is both wired and wireless Internet. I wasn't able to get the wireless to work, but the wired was fine. Both are complimentary. A business center off the gift shop has computers, printers and copiers. You have your choice of newspapers, rather than only the customary USA Today.

The health club is excellent with a variety of cardio machines, weights, a pool, and even personal trainers (for a fee.) A number of spa treatments are also available.

The staff is uniformly friendly and helpful. Your wake-up call comes from a live person, not a recording. There is an evening turndown service (but no chocolate on the pillow!)

As a road warrior, I'm not looking for a great hotel experience. If I get one that's a bonus, but I'm more interested in small things that make the time away from home less painful. Two things missing here:
1. Convenient check-out. There's no statement under your door; you'll have to go down to the desk to check out. That was fine for me this trip, but if there were a line, I'd have been running late to my meeting.
2. No in-room coffee. I'm not sure why upscale hotels find coffeemakers beneath them, but many do and this is no exception. I use the coffeemaker for morning coffee, instant oatmeal for breakfast, maybe a cup of tea in the evening, and not having one makes a difference. On this alone, given the choice, I wouldn't stay here again. There are plenty of other options.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

With so many aspects of your stay having been seemingly enjoyable, we do hope that you will give us another try in the future.

62 helpful votes 62 helpful votes
'Good stay, Dissapointed in club level.'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012 NEW

We planned this vacation, pretty much based on a review of the Ritz San Francisco Club level being one of the top of the country.
The hotel is beautiful, no pool, old classy feel to it.
The rooms are spacious and well appointed.
Check in was appropriate , I had called for an early check in since I was driving from Napa and had early reservations to see Alcatraz. They did have a nice room ready for us. I am a platinum Marriott member, no upgrade was offered or was available, but this was ok since I had the room early.
The club level staff never really acknowledge us much. The presentations at the club were nice and varied but repetitive. I have stayed in many Ritz club levels before, this was not the best. I did like that they had their own bar but most times was not staffed.
I did not feel staff was very accommodating, I hear people asking for mimosas in the am and being declined.
Location was just ok.
We ate at their restaurant parallel which was good.
Overall, a good hotel, most definitely not best club level.
Less

If you bring a car, parking is around 72 including tax. Not great for a Ritz, better stay close to Union Square and where it is flat.

See 5 more reviews by LeanCEO for San Francisco
LeanCEO
Morro Bay, CA
Senior Contributor
48 reviews 48 reviews
Reviews in 27 cities Reviews in 27 cities
28 helpful votes 28 helpful votes
'Disappointing but still nice'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My wife and I get up to San Francisco a few times a year for some R&R. Generally we are Four Seasons junkies and stay there or the Grand Hyatt, but this time we got a deal at the Ritz and decided to stay there for four nights. We knew that the experience would be different - we expected that the Ritz would be more old world charm and elegant compared to the trendy modern style of the Four Seasons.

First I do want to acknowledge some good aspects of the Ritz: the hotel was spotless and in perfect condition. No chipped tiles, missing grout, dinged floorboards that you see at even some other five star hotels. The hostess/waitresses at The Lounge and the bar at Parallel 37 on Friday and Saturday nights were fantastic - perfect discrete yet attentive service. Every concierge that we talked to during our stay was knowledgeable and helpful. The car valets were very professional and helpful.

But we had some issues. First off, the service in the restaurant side of Parallel 37 (their main restaurant) was very spotty. Some, like Reinaldo, were perfect. Others not so much. In fact at one breakfast we finally gave up after waiting 10 minutes for the bill and simply got up and left. Really! I can't remember the last time I've done that at even a Burger King, let alone a Ritz. The restaurant itself, as well as The Lounge, is a bit of a conundrum. The hotel is old world style, yet the restaurant and lounge have been renovated to a modern style - coincidentally very similar to what I'd expect in a Four Seasons with the sleek lines and chillaxing music. Somehow it just didn't fit. One minute you're in an ornate marble lobby, the next you're surrounded by sleek wood and metal. Huh?

Another issue was with housekeeping. We tried and tried, but somehow our schedule must have perfectly conflicted with room cleaning and the evening turn down. Even though each day we were out of the room from 8-10 and 11-4, then 6-8pm. Finally we called and asked for at least a special turn down so we'd have some clean towels. At other five star hotels they uncannily know when you're gone - presumably some spies in the lobby or something - and the room mysteriously gets cleaned each day regardless of schedule.

The hotel itself is at the top of a steep hill. Only a couple blocks from the Union Square shopping area, but those two blocks are MUCH more difficult than the two blocks from the Four Seasons to the same Union Square, let alone the Grand Hyatt right off the square. One odd thing, that perhaps just brings out the hotel snob in me, is that at no time was there a doorman to open the doors for us. Of course we can do that ourselves, but I guess I've come to expect it.

The rooms are nice - perhaps a bit small but that's ok. No separate shower, which I like. The courtyard view rooms are very quiet - almost too quiet! Some noise in the hallways in the mornings, but nothing significant.

Don't get me wrong - it's a very very nice hotel. Just not what I expected from a Ritz, with the level of perfectly attentive yet discrete service I've come to expect at any and every Four Seasons. Which is where we'll stay, again, next time.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 5 more reviews by LeanCEO for San Francisco
Ask LeanCEO about The Ritz-Carlton
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

'In need of training'

'In need of training'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

Spent 3 nights at the Ritz in San Francisco. The room were lovely, surprised we did not have some of the bathroom ammenities upon arrival but were placed the next day.
Front Desk were friendly and polite. The front door valets were the best....
Resturant service was fairly poor in both occassions. With the restaurant semi empty (only 5 tables were occupied) we waited over 25 minutes for two bowls of fresh fruit. Whas fumming when waiter instead of moving to my right side to place my spoon on the table, he just came fron the left side - across my face to place it on the table. Folks I understand training is time consuming and perhaps expensive but this is the Ritz-Carlton.
Next day we had a similar situation in the same restaurant, when I asked for a latte it was served on a tall glass mug but the spoon was too short to stir the sugar. When I asked the waiter for a taller spoon, he just gave me a nasty look and response " we do not have any".

My family and I have spent a week in San Francisco and booked A ONE Bedroom suite for our last night in San Fran because we knew we would get a great nights sleep in preparation for our long flight home. When I booked the room I explained what we needed a suite with a door separating the bedroom. My family and I went up at 900 for the late night desserts and found most things gone and as we sat there a young lady took away the containers of cookies. Also not a soul even asked what we might need on the club level. I sometimes think that people who complain on here simply cannot be pleased however now I understand that sometimes the service you expect someplaces is simply not delivered. My family actually ate dinner at the HYatt down the street when the Suggestion by the Ritz had a long wait for dinner. I should have thought to call but I am not the Bellman at the Ritz Carlton I am just a paying customer that will know cancel my future reservations at other Ritz properties i have made for the fourth. Metcalf-3
Sydney, Australia
Senior Contributor
40 reviews 40 reviews
Reviews in 24 cities Reviews in 24 cities
35 helpful votes 35 helpful votes
'A heritage apartment building perfect for a longer stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 5, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed here as a family of 3 for 4nights, and found it to be ideal and well worth the money. We had a superior studio, meaning separate bathroom, kitchen and living/sleeping area. The living/sleeping area was creatively arranged, with a Queen murphy bed which we put up during the day, to allow sufficient space to have a little living area with sofa to watch tv or relax without feeling like we were in a bedroom. The mattress on the Murphy bed was very comfortable and felt like a good firm quality mattress. With a 21month old, it also helped to have that 'extra' space for him to play when we weren't out. The kitchen was modern enough and clean, with full size refrigerator, 4burner stove and oven, dishwasher, coffee maker, toasting oven, cutlery, crockery etc and breakfast table with 2 bar stools. Bathroom was clean, although a little older, and perfectly fine for taking a bath. There is a small wardrobe/cupboard area in the short hall between the living room and bathroom, which we actually used to put our toddler's crib (taking off the front sliding doors) - this effectively put him in 'another' room, which enabled us to watch tv and have conversations at night once he had gone to bed. We were in room 509 which faces to the back of the building and into the central part of the building. It was quiet and we didn't really hear much noise at all outside our apartment, except the neighbours coming home late at night, as their door way was right next to ours....but no real noise between apartments. In fact, we hardly saw anyone else except in the lobby during our stay.

The other guests we did see, tended to be either permanent residents, or longer term stays such as business travellers, with an occasional short stay like us.

As per other reviews, this is not a traditional hotel, with concierge, restaurants, room service, and other hotel amenities you might expect, but reception was there during the day and into the early night, and were especially helpful and friendly - more so than that i have experienced in many other hotels. Nichole at the front desk was always smiling, and offering to help us. The entrance lobby is secured from the street front, with code access, and inside is a lovely classic clean heritage feel throughout. They even have the original elevator with latch gate door inside, which was pretty cool. The building is heritage listed, with excellent maintenance evident throughout. There is also a laundry in the basement, with washer and dryer for easy self service.

The location is Nob Hill, as defined by Wikipedia and other San Fran maps, and we found it safe enough to walk through. It is about 3 blocks north of the Tenderloin area, which reception kindly marked on a map for us, and suggested not to walk in that direction. There was nothing else that way anyway, so it wasn't a problem at all. We could walk to Union Square, to the West, East, and North, to Fisherman's Wharf, Chinatown etc....without worrying. There are occasional homeless people around the streets nearby, but we found that throughout the city area anyway, regardless of the neighbourhood. We took the bus about 3 blocks away, walked down to the cable car at Powell St about 4 blocks away, and were able to get everywhere in the city in one easy mode of transport or on foot.

Regarding price, we booked directly on the hotel's own website, which seemed to be about the same rate as that we found anywhere else on aggregator/discount sites.

Overall, we had an excellent stay here at the Steinhart Hotel, and would highly recommend it for a family or anyone who wants the convenience of feeling at home, in a good central location - but without needing the luxury pampering of a hotel.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Brian Thomas
Plainfield, New Jersey
Top Contributor
78 reviews 78 reviews
Reviews in 48 cities Reviews in 48 cities
118 helpful votes 118 helpful votes
'Quiet, Classy, Close to Everything'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed February 5, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

One of the best all around lodging experiences I have ever had. We stayed here for five nights and we could easily have stayed a month. The Steinhart balances apartment-style living with hotel convenience at a very affordable rate. Our suite of rooms at the back of this venerable building on the 4th floor was quiet, stylish, and spotlessly clean. We had four large rooms, including full kitchen, dining room, living room and bath. This all for about $200. per night. Although the hotel does not have a cafe, room service or other conventional amenities, the immediate neighborhood offers these services in abundance. Turn right and there's a well stocked market; turn left and find Cup a Joe, a wonderful urban coffee shop/cafe. The location boasts easy access to tourist enclaves like Union Square and authentic residential settings like Pacific Heights, or you can trek through the panhandlers of the Tenderloin to SOMA. Rent a car around the corner at Hertz for $40.00 per day, all in.

The kitchen had everything we needed although we mercifully ate most meals out. Wireless was free and though the two large flat screens are not high def, they have tons of offerings. The wire cage elevator is fun and there are two set of stairs that anchor the wide, pleasant central hallway.

Maid service is once a week, but the suite was well stocked and we'd rather have the privacy.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
Elliot W
Melbourne, Australia
1 review
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'My stay at the Steinhart helped make my trip to SF unforgettable'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed January 11, 2012
7
people found this review helpful

I recently booked a studio apartment at the Steinhart for a week in December, based on solid reviews on this site. Not only was I not disappointed in my choice, but my expectation were exceeded far greater than I could have even asked for.

If you read some of the other reviews here you will notice the resident manager Dimitar's name all over the place. The reason for this is the guy is exceptional. Upon arrival there weren't any studio rooms available, so he instantly upgraded me without flinching. He was full of information about San Francisco and was not only pleasant to deal with, but gave all the time needed. Nothing was a stress for this guy and there were no pressures at all in my stay.

Obviously the room is one of the most important things, and the room I stayed in was a one bedroom apartment. The room was clean and spacious, with a large comfortable bed. There was a small TV in the bedroom and a large flatscreen in the lounge. The room had a full kitchen, complete with stove, oven, microwave and fridge. The bathroom was spacious also, with plenty of full length mirrors. Upon arriving in my room I unpacked all of my clothes into the closet and drawers, as this place really felt like a small apartment one might live in. I really felt at home here and it was such a shame to leave.

One thing that people need to realise before they decide on making their booking is what type of building they want to stay at. If you are after a hotel with doormen, room service and the like this place is not for you. The Steinhart is a gorgeous apartment complex that provides a stay in a great part of San Francisco in a contemporary apartment. The elevator is classic old school and the lobby is beautiful. There are laundry facilities downstairs should you wish to use them. This place is the perfect place to stay if you're looking to go about your business at your own convenience and don't require all of the minor things that hotels do. I noticed that on my trip I stayed at hotels, but lived at the Steinhart. This was such a big difference.

The location is another thing that this place has going for them. They're located in a quiet street, only 8 minutes walk from Union Square. One can easily walk to Union Square and bypass the Tenderloin completely (which is 2-3 blocks away). SF has a big homeless problem, but thankfully there weren't any homeless people around where I was staying. The Steinhart still has double security doors with keycodes (which they give you upon arrival) to add that extra layer of security. Across the street is a great coffee shop if you want to grab a morning coffee and bagel. Three doors down is a grocery store, which is perfect to stock up the full kitchen. Next door to the grocery store is Aces bar, which is open until late 7 days and plays all major sporting games.

My stay in San Francisco was one of the greatest experiences of my life because of the comfort, location and friendly staff at the Steinhart. I'm already clamoring to head back to SF and there is no doubt in my mind I will stay there again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

See 3 more reviews by HotelBloke for San Francisco
HotelBloke
London, United Kingdom
Top Contributor
92 reviews 92 reviews
Reviews in 24 cities Reviews in 24 cities
35 helpful votes 35 helpful votes
'Exceptional service, Fantastic Views, Great Restaurant'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012 NEW

This was the first hotel stop fro 3 nights on our Californian holiday driving down the Pacific Coast Highway from San Francisco to Los Angeles. What a great choice! The ground floor of the hotel was being refurbished and there were many areas of the hotel unavailable. The staff were exceptional, we received an excellent welcome from the moment we stepped out of the taxi. Our cases were whipped away somewhere and we walked into the makeshift reception cleverly hiding all the building work behind them by curtains. The hotel is perched on top of a tall building in the city and starts at the 38th floor. Our room was on the 44th floor, a huge corner room with the most magnificent bathroom. There was a huge window over the bath tub from where we had a great view of the bay, coit tower, Fishermans wharf and Alcatraz Island. If you stretch you could also see the Golden Gate Bridge. The rest of the room had windows all the way round with additional views and to our surprise all the windows opened! We were able to have real fresh air in the room and a great view all round Excellent! The room had a very comfortable large king size bed with quality bed linen and excellent pillows, a large sitting area, large desk, power sockets everywhere, three telephones, a safe, free water, fully stocked mini bar. The bathroom had a separate shower cubicle with an excellent shower, one large basin, a small bath tub with hand shower, quality fluffy towels and Molten Brown toiletries. Our cases arrived seconds after we entered the room and the bellman showed us around our room.

There was only one restaurant available on the 2nd floor of the hotel and this was the bar, main restaurant and breakfast area while the refurbishment was taking place. I am sure by the time you go to this hotel it will be fully functioning. The food in the restaurant was excellent. Breakfast was cooked to order and very good indeed. The waiting staff exceptional.

The concierge were also exceptionally helpful and particularly professional. They had booked our Alcatraz trip before arrival and it all worked perfectly. We asked for a restaurant booking on the second evening and left it totally to them. On our return to the hotel after a day out in the city a note was left in our room that the restaurant was booked and the complimentary hotel car was at our disposal to take us to the restaurant and collect us at the end of the evening. We are particularly enterprising and love making our own way around cities by public transport where possible but to have this offered to us was a pleasant surprise - Exceptional service!

There were no leisure facilities available but the hotel had arranged the use of a nearby gym and pool, we did not have time to use them at this hotel.

The hotel is situated seconds walk from Market Street from where you can walk to all the shopping areas, Union Square, Westfield etc. It is so easy to get around San Francisco, the buses are easy to navigate and of course you MUST travel a cable car. Take it UP the hill and walk down (if you can!) They run up Powell Street.

This is the first time we have stayed at a Mandarin Oriental hotel and if this first experience is typical of the service we will certainly be back.

A GREAT first hotel stop on our huge trip.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

'Spectacular view!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

I stayed at the Mandarin Oriental, San Francisco in a 2012-year renovated room. The view of the city from your hotel room is beyond compare, I can only imagine what a view of the water would have been like; however, I will note that from my vantage point, I could see a little bit of the water from my room as well. This hotel has spectacular views! Walk through the hallways of your room/suite floor and you will see views of both sides of San Francisco (city and water). Location wise, the hotel is situated where you could take a brisk walk to Chinatown, Union Square (shopping), and the Ferry Building. The area is pretty quiet after dark since the hotel is in the Financial District (I think).

While you check-in on the first floor, the rooms/suites start on Floor 38. The lobby was still being renovated at the time of check-in. I did not particularly care for the set up of the Front Desk and Concierge in such close quarters to each other (they share the same curved row together). While checking-in was easy, as a first time guest, nothing was shared with me about any hotel amenities or package benefits that came with my booking. Ask if you have any questions.

During my stay (while renovations are still in progress), there was a business center available to guests and complimentary access to an offsite, very nearby, gym.

Room: What I immediately noticed about my room was that the three windows actually opened. Yes! The hotel has a very robust A/C and heater, which is always appreciated as well. I stayed in a room with two double beds; therefore, there was no sofa/table. The room featured an in-room safe, closet, dresser, working desk with two chairs, three telephones and a full master bathroom with separate shower and tub. There was no in-room coffee-making machine; although complimentary coffee is served in the morning in the lobby. The bathroom was great, especially the shower. Bathroom amenities are from Molton Brown. Lighting controls in the bathroom are one setting  either all on or off  but there is plenty of light. On a nice day, when it's sunny, open the window blinds and there is plenty of natural light. You can also draw the sheer blinds to filter the sun. Note: If you open the windows on a windy day, the blinds will go all over the place. From my vantage point, you can easily see your neighbors in the other wing of the hotel, so use the blackout shades accordingly for privacy. Light in the room is sourced from a floor lamp, two sconces by your bed, a table lamp and a few recessed lights in the hallway and over the work desk. All in all, lighting was sufficient but lighting controls from your bed are not intuitive  you have to walk to your front door to turn off the hallway lights. I really like the neutral colors in the room, it has a very contemporary feel.

Room service: I ordered twice from in-room dining. Dinner: (2) entrees, (1) appetizer, and (1) side  with all taxes, service charges, delivery fees, came up to almost $80  pretty standard for a hotel of this caliber. Breakfast was close to $70 dollars for two, again pretty standard. Food fare was okay  but the service was excellent. The food was brought always brought up within the quotes times (usually 25-30 minutes). I wanted to order wonton noodle soup, which was on the menu but was informed that it was no longer being served.

Service: The hotel graciously brought up a birthday cake for me  which is always a nice gesture from a hotel when you're celebrating a special occasion. You could cut four generous slices from that one cake alone. While staff was generally pleasant throughout the property  from the doormen to housekeeping, I experienced some service issues with the Front Desk. What matters is that everything was resolved by the time I checked-out. And, to be fair to the hotel, what I considered 'issues' is subjective. To preface this statement, I vary my expectations based on the circumstances  i.e. leisure or business travel (who is paying), the brand (MO is comparable to Four Seasons, Ritz Carlton, and the St. Regis, all which have a presence in San Francisco), and price (entry level rooms during my stay started at a little shy of $400). In this case, I had high expectations of the hotel.

Lastly, I noticed some, or maybe all, of the Concierge staff had the iconic golden keys on their uniform  so they are part of Le Clefs d'Or, a prestigious Concierge association. I did not request any services but I trust that any and all requests would be taken care of.

    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *

'A VERY happy anniversary!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 5, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We wanted a special celebration for our 25th wedding anniversary in San Francisco. I was drawn to the property because of their reputation for customer service, but mostly because of their incredible views! However, I was slightly reticent to book there due to their renovation in progress. I did call and speak to their staff who reassured me that the only difference that we would notice was their temporary lobby and that everything else should be as though no renovation was going on. Wow, was she correct! From the moment we walked up to the hotel to the moment we left we were pampered and treated to a wonderful experience. Every single staff person was not only very efficient and professional, but they were all incredibly warm and hospitable as well. It is my impression that it is a happy staff and they all seemed very proud of their hotel. We had a beautiful, newly renovated room on the 45th floor overlooking the Bay. The gorgeous room combined with the incredible view was breathtaking. The welcome tea was just lovely. We had a fantastic celebration dinner in Silks, with an equally high quality staff and delicious food and wine. Breakfast in Silks was also top rate with incredible attention to every detail. We thank everyone there for their kindness and hospitality. I would highly recommend the Mandarin Oriental San Francisco to anyone who values excellence in customer service combined with beauty, calmness and serenity. By the way, just prior to our check-out, they closed the temporary lobby and opened their newly renovated lobby, which is gorgeous. We are looking forward to eating in the new restaurant as soon as it opens!
Less

Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities

'Soon to be back together'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed April 23, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

First into a Bridge-to-Bridge room after renovation/refurbishment demonstrated a few problems with the room that indicated the staff just hadn't checked things well enough before letting the room. In the bath, new wallpaper was only partially adhered to the wall and sloppy grouting between tiles was messy and obvious. A floor lamp wasn't properly assembled and it leaned in a corner between windows that bracketed spectacular views. The gym was not reopened yet, but that was not indicated on the hotel website. The property location is excellent for city business, but a few blocks away from popular shopping/strolling. Staff courtesy/knowledge, room service and room amenities were excellent. Given the price is at the top, until the kinks are worked through there are better values at other of the luxury properties in the city. Suspect these problems are likely to be resolved soon.
Less

'Wonder hotel experience - highly recommended!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

I stayed at this hotel for the first time over Memorial Day weekend. I wanted to write this review because I had a an exceptionally good expereince. The location is terrific, and the room was modern, spacious and comfortable. No doubt NYC hotel prices are high - put this hotel delivers your money's worth. The staff was incredibly attentive. The concierge desk is right by the elevator, and they greet you as you go by and ask if they can assist. Join Omni's select guest program for free, and you get free room wi-fi and morning beverage on the spot.
I go to NYC often, and I have found the place where I plan to stay in the future.
Less

farawaymum

Senior Contributor

Reviews in 22 cities Reviews in 22 cities

'Nicely renovated, but not spectacular- avoid suites ending in 19'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW

We booked a berkshire suite which was spacious but dark and unwelcoming due to its rear facing location looking onto adjoining buildings.Lights are required day and night. No amount of style makeover can disguise this.Our room was also located adjacent to a maid's service room that was the centre of constant noisy activity day and night. Overseas guests are often on different body time clocks so this was less than ideal.

Omni have the makings of a good loyalty program and they have joined a global alliance, but their recognition of various membership levels , personal preferences and the consistency of the benefits is patchy.Issues once raised were addressed by management efficiently.

The location is good, easy walk to the subway.
Less

ENBB
Sparta, New Jersey
Top Contributor
50 reviews 50 reviews
Reviews in 26 cities Reviews in 26 cities
79 helpful votes 79 helpful votes
'Omni Does It Again'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

I guess I must be upfront about this: we love staying at Omni Hotels.This was our 25th stay at an Omni, (according to their records). We stayed at this Omni for our 33rd anniversary 'celebration' trip to New York City. My wife and I have stayed in just one other hotel in NYC, the Times Square Hilton (back on New Year's Day in 2010). For this anniversary weekend visit, we decided to stay at the Omni Berkshire Place, since we've tried the Omni Hotels in Boston, New Haven and Washington DC (and loved them). The rate was fairly expensive - it is New York, after all - but we were upgraded to a junior suite that overlooked Madison Avenue (you really couldn't see the street from our windows, but we knew it was down there, as we heard them re-paving the road at night - and yet, with the drapes closed, the sound was such that it did not impact our getting a good night's sleep).

Everything at the hotel was what I expected from an Omni: check in staff was efficient, helpful and friendly. Room service was great. the fitness/exercise room (with a view of St. Patrick's, no less) was adequately equipped.

Long story short, we had a wonderful stay at the Omni Berkshire Place and would recommend it highly if you are interested in staying in this part of Manhattan.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
David D
Washington DC, District of Columbia
Senior Reviewer
6 reviews 6 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'A nice hotel, but doesn't quite live up to its rating'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

While the Omni was a nice hotel, it is only slightly nicer than your average Holiday Inn, and using the "star rating" system, it is certainly not a 4 star hotel -- maybe 3 1/2 stars?

The rooms were clean, but fairly stark (and not in that new stylish, minimalist sort of way). The beds were nice, but not spectacular. The bathroom was adequate -- yes, the floor was marble, but it was small and didn't make good use of space. We stayed in a room which was a "Premier Room", one up from the lowest "Deluxe Guest Room". I would expect a bit more for a higher priced room, but I guess it was the few extra square feet of space. The built-in wall unit barely provided enough closet space. The lobby was small and nothing special. The hallways were bland and dimly lit.

The staff: Always courteous, but certainly I would not classify them as "friendly" or "helpful" -- and it's not like they were that busy. The cleaning staff, valet staff, and luggage staff were the most kind and helpful. The front desk crew was...well...just there.

Location: Good if you're interested in shopping on 5th Avenue or Madison. A block from Saint Patrick's Cathedral. The Omni is walkable to Central Park, Times Square, and the Theater District IF you have a good pair of shoes and don't mind a bit of a hike.

Overall, it's a nice hotel, but I question its high rating. If you can get a room for the mid $100's, then it's a bargain. Anything over $200 for the first two levels of rooms and you may be disappointed. Why? Because for the same price in NYC, you can get many nicer hotels in better locations.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask David D about Omni Berkshire Place
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

GObata
Las Vegas, Nevada
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Absolutely the BEST hotel in NYC - no kidding!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

During our recent vacation, my husband and I spent a few days in Boston first then went to New York for a few more days to revisit our favorite places. We'd never stayed at the Omni so I was really unsure of what to expect. We love old (but nicely renovated) NY hotels and have previously stayed at a number of other properties in Manhattan -uptown, midtown and downtown. NONE have compared to the Omni Berkshire Place. We were so pleasantly surprised by this hotel! From the outside, it really doesn't look like much -standard facade, no porte cachere, nothing really remarkable to make it stand out. But inside....what a treat! After checking in with the terrific front desk staff, we were thrilled with our room. We stayed on the 14th floor and for the first time ever in NY, we never heard a peep from outside -and there was even the Turkish Day parade going on! Our room was beautiful, big (especially by NY standards) and the bathroom even has a wall-mounted, lighted/magnified make-up mirror -what a great amenity! The concierge staff was fabulous -gave us directions, advice and generally were super helpful. And Lenny the doorman, best in the city! He always made sure we were headed in the right direction and smiled and greeted us every chance he could. In the future, we will never stay anywhere but the Omni They did what most hotels fail to do -they made us feel so welcome and at home.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 2 more reviews by GObata for New York City

8 reviews 8 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
'Nice Remodel and Friendly Staff'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW

I first stayed here when it was the Hotel Montecello and couldn't come back on my next trip until the remodel was done. The rooms were updated but still maintained the historical hotel charm. Bathrooms were nice and big and the staff were very friendly. The best part of this hotel is its location - only 1/2 blocks to the cable car station on Powell and downtown by a lot of the stores. I would have given this 5 stars except the amount of noise at night comes through the windows for the rooms facing the street. I suggest they update the windows on that side. The staff did warn me though prior to check-in and I appreciated that but I ended up with the last room. :)

The wifi was fast and that is helpful as a business traveler.
Less

Heather V
Hattiesburg, Mississippi
Senior Reviewer
10 reviews 10 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
'Fabulous Boutique Hotel, Even Better Staff!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

My husband and I booked this hotel through Hotels Tonight for one night while we were in San Francisco. We arrived well before check-in time but the staff still allowed us to go ahead and get settled into our room. When we booked the room, there was no guarantee what kind of room/bed we would receive. Still, we got a lovely room with a king-sized bed. We immediately decided that we wanted to stay another night and the staff was so helpful in arranging that. Never, have I ever had such WONDERFUL customer service. I travel often and stay in many different hotels but nowhere have I ever been treated with this level of care. From hailing a cab, to greeting us by name, the staff catered to our every whim like we were the only guests staying there (although I know we weren't from seeing people come and go). The rooms were freshly remodeled, the beds were very comfortable, and the heat/AC worked well. The location was also great being very close to the cable car/bus stops and lots of shopping. I only wish every hotel we stayed at was this nice.
Less

'Remodeled updated European style smaller rooms and lobby with modern amenities and service at the root of cable car and humming '
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012

Clean and recently remodeled small European hotel with efficient service people 1/2 block from start of cable car on Powell, avant garde decor well appointed. See 3 more reviews by AnnieLovesFrance for San Francisco
AnnieLovesFrance
Southern Maine
Senior Contributor
31 reviews 31 reviews
Reviews in 20 cities Reviews in 20 cities
13 helpful votes 13 helpful votes
'An absolute gem!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 5, 2012 NEW

You TA folks lead me to this one, and I thank you. Hotel Rex is located very close to the Powell Street BART station, certainly within walking distance with two rolling suitcases and a couple smaller bags. (I recommend taking BART from the SF airport; 45 mins, $8.00 each, easy-peasy to get to within the airport).
And once you arrive at the hotel, you will likely be greeted as nicely as we were. Great staff, engaged and friendly.
Our room was a corner queen, with plenty of room for two people and a nice, clean if smallish bathroom. Water pressure was good, no complaints. Amenities were class-act as was the Joie de Vivre welcome card and sparking water "gift" left for us after we arrived. This was a true surprise since I'd just joined the Joie de Vivre club prior to making this res. Bed was very comfy, with a duvet.
Other sincere pros: def enjoyed the evening glass of wine at the bar; in fact we enjoyed that bar a LOT, even after the free glass of wine was gone. It is a cozy, slightly dark library with books everywhere, as well as great art on the walls. The bar menu was good; recommend the asparagus soup and grilled cheese. I flipped through a New Yorker cartoons anthology for an hour one night just hanging out. Very serene spot.
There was also a delicious breakfast buffet--$14.00 each but that included everything: juice, coffee, pastries such as croissant, very fresh sliced fruit, waffles, toast, eggs, bacon--good quality, home fries (California-style with red peppers), much, much more. The day before we'd eaten at a former fave, the Cafe Mason just around the corner, which wasn't a good as remembered, and cost more than the hotel's delicious breakfast the next day.
We missed meeting Maximillian, the pug, because he had "gone off shift" and wasn't working during our stay. However, we did get to see the Golden Gate Bridge's 75th birthday fireworks!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 3 more reviews by AnnieLovesFrance for San Francisco

istanbul_lover123
Boston, Massachusetts
Senior Reviewer
8 reviews 8 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
'Great location and ambiance'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

I try to stay at Rex Hotel whenever I am in San Francisco for business, which is every few months. The hotel definitely has character.
The location is hard to beat as well. Since San Francisco is not densely populated, I recommend staying in Union Square area since it is always lively even late in the evening. On the other hand hotels towards Tenderloin area would not be a good choice if you like to take a walk around. Rex Hotel is on Sutter Street which is close enough to Union Square but far enough from Tenderloin.
I like to order breakfast in my room. It also serves as a wake up call.
Wireless internet in the room works decent enough. Did not slow down during the evening where many people connect to it.
I only stayed as single person in their room. For a couple maybe ask for a large room as their rooms are not very big.
Less

See 2 more reviews by tgsapo for San Francisco
tgsapo
Anchorage, Alaska
Senior Contributor
25 reviews 25 reviews
Reviews in 18 cities Reviews in 18 cities
41 helpful votes 41 helpful votes
'Good Value'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

I stayed at the Hotel Rex last week in an Executive King room. My previous experience with the chain was the White Swan Inn, which was fabulous, so I had high expectations. There was a large convention in town and my choice of lodging was very limited.

While the ambiance was very different from the WSI, I appreciated the cleanliness and simplicity of the furnishings. The decor was very masculine, with dark woods, colors, and classic finishes. The bed was SUPER comfortable (one of the reasons I like this particular hotel chain). The bathroom was a little dated, but not unreasonably. Everything seemed clean and in good order. My room looked out onto a lovely courtyard. I skipped housekeeping for a couple of days, which landed me a $5 Library Bar gift card each day. The service was adequate, but not as warm and friendly as I had hoped. I got the whole "I'm from San Francisco and, thus, better than you" vibe... Hence, the reason for docking one star: the evening wine "hour."

At most other hotels I've stayed at, including the WSI, an evening wine reception allowed you to sample a variety of local vintages. The first evening I tried the wine reception, the bartender was particularly unfriendly--again, giving me the "why are you wasting my time?" attitude. He asked what I wanted, I told him, he poured me a glass, and I sat down. I also ordered a cheese plate ($11) using my $5 gift card. After I finished my (unsubstantial and boring) cheese plate, I went to ask for another glass of wine. The bartender says "only the first one is free." I was taken aback, as I've never heard of a "wine reception" with a one-glass maximum. I thought the guy was joking, but he gave me a small "splash" and was done. I was staying on a greatly reduced rate; had I paid full price, I would have definitely complained to the manager. Note that this hotel also does not offer a continental breakfast, but does have a breakfast buffet option at $14 (a little spendy for breakfast by my standards).

While the location (near Union Square) and room were very good, I would recommend this place only if the White Swan Inn were totally booked.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Tina S
Redlands, CA
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
'move out weekend'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012

Couldn't get a room at Hotel Del Sol (another joie de vivre location) as this was a busy weekend in San Francisco. Luckily they suggested the Hotel Rex which was actually much closer to my daughter's college dorm. Moved her out of the dorm and stayed at the Rex two nights. We were treated very professionally by a kind and friendly staff. They took care of our car with all her stuff in it. They asked her how she liked the school and the city. I thought that was pretty cool. We had a quiet little room on the top floor facing away from street. It was tiny but who hangs out in the hotel room when in San Fran? Comfortable bed, cute bathroom (love the shower head), crazy small elevator but fits the charm of the building. We hopped on a bus on Market and went to the places we chose for our short time left in the city. Max is so cute!

'Great location, great atmostphere'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 9, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

This is a fantastic traditional townhouse hotel - dark wood, paintings, books and and palms - two minutes from Union Square. The staff were very friendly and helpful. There's a lovely library bar downstairs where residents are offered a free glass of wine in the evening, which means people congregate there and there's a really good atmostphere, that you don't often get in town hotels. The room was spacious and comfortable, and well decorated. I'll definitely stay there again when I visit San Francisco.
Less

ladyweston

Senior Contributor
21 reviews 21 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
8 helpful votes 8 helpful votes
'Reluctant to share this review because we are afraid we will not be able to get a reservation for the next time we visit'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 27, 2012

We found this place on Trip Advisor and could not have been more pleasantly surprised with this inn and its sister property, The White Swan. First of all, the location was perfect. Situated just outside of Union Square, the hotel is in a great spot for walking to many restaurants, bars, and shops. As well, the cable car is a short block away. Reception was friendly with home baked cookies and a bowl of fruit in the lobby. Complimentary water and soft drinks were also readily available. We arrived in time for the afternoon wine and hors d'oeuvre which were lovely. Our first room was acceptable, although tiny. We stayed the first night, but because we were carrying extra luggage to attend a wedding, we did not have enough space and requested a room change.
We were moved to the White Swan, their sister property and treated with the same warmth and amenities. Our room there, was fantastic! A gas fireplace, dressing room and wet bar for a small upcharge. This was clearly our fault for reserving badly. We could have spent a month in the second room which was great.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'Great location, friendly and comfortable!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 23, 2012

My fiance and I got married in San Francisco's City Hall and stayed in Petite Auberge for our wedding weekend. We also booked rooms here for both of our parents. Everyone had an amazing time. The staff was so friendly, the location was fantastic, and so many pleasant details were included with our stay. A different delicious breakfast was served every morning, the hotel had complimentary cookies each afternoon and a free wine hour each day! Most of all, staying here felt like staying in the guest house of a friend who happens to be a wonderful host. I highly recommend it!

solender
Toronto
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
18 helpful votes 18 helpful votes
'Quaint alternative to big chain hotels'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 21, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Quaint alternative to a large hotel chain. I enjoyed my stay here and despite a few quirks, everything was lovely. Petit Auberge has many upsides: the staff is very friendly and genuinely seems to want you to enjoy your stay. The breakfast buffet is quite good, with alot of nice options. I especially enjoyed the San Fran sourdough bread and the fact that they had actul plain (no sugar or chemicals) yogurt each morning. Every afternoon there were house-baked cookies, which was a nice touch. The breakfast area is adjoined to a lovely sitting room and to a patio, which looks lovely for the warmer months.
Some of the quirks: each room has a gas fireplace, which is the only source of heating in the room. So, if you want to be warm, it has to be on, but then it's very bright in the room. Not too much of a problem, since I always travel with any eye mask. The staff didn't really understand my request to NOT change my linens every day, despite me leaving them a hand written note. Not very Eco-minded of them, even though there is a placard in the room asking guests to re-use! I resorted to leaving my "privacy please" door hanger on for the rest of the trip. 
The hotel is small (only 28 rooms) and has a quirky, verging on shabby-chic decor. I personally liked this, but fussy folks may not. The building is quite old, and you can hear some of your neighbors at times. Overall, my room was rather quiet though. 
I enjoyed my stay overall and would stay again. 
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

lees42
Melbourne, Australia
Contributor
13 reviews 13 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'A great stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 14, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

Following good reviews on TA we chose this hotel and were very pleased. We had requested a back room and were given this on the top, 5th floor. Being in the city it was noisy on Saturday night but that was to be expected. The room was very comfortable, except the pillows but that was a problem everywhere we stayed - much too soft. The rooms were clean and serviced daily. The fireplace lent charm and coziness. The old fashioned charm of the hotel was great, including the lift. Breakfast was varied and the 5 pm wine reception amazing. Food was really good and much more than just cheese and biscuits. The opportunity to mix with fellow guests made our stay very interesting. The provision of endless tea, coffee, water & soft drinks as well as cookies was much appreciated. It was in a convenient location just a short walk to the cable cars. The staff were helpful and I would certainly recommend this hotel.

    *
    *

Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Great stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 9, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

We spent 3 nights here with my daughter and her fiance. This is a charming old hotel in a great neighborhood. It's an old building and you will hear the floors creak as people walk around so if you're a light sleeper you'll probably want ear plugs. We slept with the windows open and the city wakes up around 4:30 a.m. We were in room 25 and had a nice view of the adjacent buildings garden. My daughter was in room 24 and their view was a brick wall. I had a view and they had privacy. Her in-laws were on the third level that also looked onto the garden. Breakfast was delicious, eggs, sausages, fresh fruit, yogurt, cereals, and fresh bread to toast. The 5:00 wine reception offered and red and white wine with some other snack.

Pippsan
London
Contributor
11 reviews 11 reviews
Reviews in 9 cities Reviews in 9 cities
7 helpful votes 7 helpful votes
'A gem!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 1, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My first impressions of the hotel were not great. The location is great, just a short stroll to the Union Square and Chinatown, however, when getting there the area seemed a bit grubby. We had to check in in the White Swan next door and it seemed complicated after 11 hr flight. The following day the area no longer was grubby :) The room is on the smaller side, however, we were lucky have a splendid view over the garden.

Everything works. The bed is small but comfy. The fireplace is a lovely extra. What makes this hotel a real gem to me (and at this point I hesitate to share this with you as I hope the hotel will remain the same forever) is the staff and the homely little touches. You can get coffee, tea, water and soft drinks any time from downstairs drinks/fridge area. The breakfast is plentiful (cereal, fruit, eggs, toast, pastries, sausages, croissants and more - there also is some variation each day). There is a pot of (very yummy) cookies for anytime munchies and wine (!!) and some appetizers in the afternoon. The staff are more than happy to help with any questions you might have. There even are some games and a small library.

When checking out I felt like this will be the place I would love to stay again and would definitely recommend this to you, too.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
Hoooskow
Rochester
1 review
'Not worth the $$$.00'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed April 29, 2012

My stay was 3/19/12-3/22/12. I could not wait to LEAVE. I felt the bed linens were dirty, so I slept with the spread off and the extra blanket covering me. There was little privacy. The building across the way is about 30 meters. So I could practically sit in the resident's apartment and watch his TV. Beware, Wednesday morning at 5AM is garbage day. If your windows are open, because it's so damn hot in the room you will start your San Francisco travel day very, very early.
There was no one at the desk on the nights 3/20, 3/21. This I felt was unsafe. If we had questions, we were to go next door to the nicer (Cove) Hotel. The breakfast was ok. I am not trying to be an elitist, but I have been to those little type Parisian hotels, where there are beautiful antiques in each room, croissants, homemade jam and cappuccino for breakfast. This is NOT THAT HOTEL! As Tony Soprano would say,"for get abou dit."
Less

See 2 more reviews by NapaLex for San Francisco
NapaLex
Napa
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'It's perfect, except...'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed April 25, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

The staff is very accommodating as well as helpful - the service was excellent. Breakfast foods and drinks were plentiful and a step above what one usually is offered for complimentary breakfast. Close to Union square, Nob Hill and Chinatown. A good value if you are not looking for a high end cookie cutter hotel experience.

Our fifth floor room (#54) was very nice but unfortunately the hotel has no air conditioning. I realize that San Francisco weather is cooler than most places but being from around here, I also know that the financial district often has sunny weather and a climate controlled room is a must. We had to leave our windows wide open at night so the room wouldn't be uncomfortably stuffy and the outside noise on Friday night was unbearable. Four miserable hours of sleep was all we could get as drunken revelers were at it long after 2am just outside the hotel. This can't be an isolated occurence in this area, so close to the tenderloin. If we would have had A/C, we would not have had to open the windows and the A/C white noise would have minimized the outside noise. This is the one thing that holds me back from recommending the hotel to others and I myself will pay more for a different hotel next time unless A/C is made available in this hotel (how much can a window unit cost?). If it had A/C, I honestly can say that I would have rated cute little hotel 5 stars.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

LionInFLL
Fort Lauderdale, FL
Senior Contributor
22 reviews 22 reviews
Reviews in 11 cities Reviews in 11 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'A best kept secret in San Francisco'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

What you are reading here on TripAdvisor about Coventry is very true. Our room was spotless, the bed was comfortable, the decor of the room is tasteful, and the hotel is convenient to the Marina District. All of this at one-third of the cost that other hotels of comparable quality were charging for the same weekend. What a find!

The only negative of our stay was that the elevator was broken and we had to use the street access and stairway to get to our room, as did everyone else. Since our room was stationed right by the stairwell door, we were subjected to a very late night and early morning of hearing the door open and slam shut as patrons entered and exited.

All in all, though, it was a great find, and we would stay here again.
Less

Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
DenverGriz
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'San Francisco find !'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 24, 2012 via mobile
3
people found this review helpful

Great deal and good location in San Francisco for $100. We had a choice of two queen beds or one king bed at that price. We chose the former and received a spacious, spotless room with a loveseat, table with chairs and floor-to-ceiling bay with window. Other amenities included marble tub surround (ceiling height), large marble vanity, updated bath fixtures, 42" flat-screen TV, refrigerator, coffee maker, hair dryer, iron and ironing board.

The building and rooms are older and the staff is small; but everything is very clean and Tony could not have been more accommodating. There is no restaurant or spa; but free underground parking is included. The security system is very good. The location is covenient (just a few blocks west of Van Ness) to Ghiardelli Square, Fisherman's Wharf and the Marina area.

Only couple of minor gripes: Lombard Street is also U S highway 101; so truck traffic--and, therefore, traffic noise-- is noticeable. Also, there were no doors on the closet; but that was a small, purely aesthetic issue.

The. Coventry Motor Inn is great value. We're anxious to return.


Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask DenverGriz about Coventry Motor Inn
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

Real nice hotel, rooms appear to be recently remodeled, with new carpets and flat screen TVs. The hotel is not fancy at all, but it is clean, rooms are nice, and the price is affordable. Again don't expect anything fancy because it is not. The staff are friendly, beds are comfortable, and depending on the location of the room you either get a little bit of street noise OR no noise and no view :)
Less

Overall, the stay was OK - for the price and star rating I just expected much more than I got...

coastaleddie
Encinitas, CA
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'An excellent visit to the Huntington'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW

We had a first visit to the Huntington this past weekend; and were fortunate to be upgraded to a suite - room 1001 on the tenth floor. Sweeping views over Fisherman's Wharf to Alcatraz and beyond on one side, and out towards the Bay Bridge on the other. Room was so enjoyable, we wanted to hang out in it, and a great place to recover after a day of site seeing.
A quick few blocks downhill to Union Square (or tough climb up) the location worked for us. The California line for the cable cars goes right by the front door, the Fairmont and its Tonga Room just across the square, and the Cathedral and park right in front of us. Chinatown just a short walk away, and North Beach a little further.
Only spent a brief time in the spa - no services, but jumped in the pool and jacuzzi; very relaxing. The staff and service seemed great; we were very well taken care of.
Perhaps not the place for everyone, but our experience was excellent.
Thank you Huntington!

    *
    *

Less

'The worst hotel I've ever been in....and I've been in hotels all over the world.'
1 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
4
people found this review helpful

For $400 a night I was expecting more than what we got. The bed was terrible. We found it hard to sleep as we both got sore backs from the bed. There is no coffee machine in the room and I need my coffee to get going in the morning. The nearest place to get coffee was a 20 minute round trip. There are no ice machines. Instead there is "ice service" @ $3 & tip ! There is no mini bar... just an old fridge in the room which was not working. Yet on the web site it still says that every room has a mini bar, When I asked I was told "oh we no longer do mini bar service". The food in the restaurant was expensive and of poor quality. The staff were very unfriendly and rather snobbish. Ironic considering we were paying guest and they were working there. Never again!

Problem with this review?
See 10 more reviews by labonvoyer for San Francisco
labonvoyer
Central Coast California
Senior Contributor
33 reviews 33 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
75 helpful votes 75 helpful votes
'Large Rooms-Great Service!'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 14, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Finally was able to take advantage of a deal offered at a Nob Hill Hotel! The Huntington was a former residential apartment hotel when originally opened, When it changed to a regular hotel they did not subdivide the rooms. Because of this, the rooms are much larger than typical SF hotel rooms. Our 8th floor room had a sitting area complete with sofa, coffee table and large writing desk. Some of the furniture was a little worn but it still allowed you to imagine what it might have been like living in a 1st class residential hotel in the 1920's atop of Nob Hill. The room faced Taylor St. and had a partial view of Grace Cathedral. (As we were leaving, the maid had a door open to a room that faced California St. As I peeked in, I realized the room was smaller but the view was fantastic). One problem that I had with our larger room was the TV was on the far wall. It made it perfect if you were sitting in the living room area but was a little too far to enjoy from the bed.

Our package included breakfast. The 1st morning we did venture down to the Big 4 Restaurant. The service was fantastic. Our waiter, gave us many tourist tips. The regular coffee was great. (The restaurant opens at 0700 but the lobby has the same great coffee available before that time. The last morning I decided to get up early. It was nice to be able to get a coffee to go while I took an early morning walk thru the lovely area. I do this every time I go to SF usually stopping at a Starbucks-there are no SBs on the hill, so this is a nice touch to have good coffee available. The rest of the mornings we used our breakfast voucher and splurged on room service-relaxing relaxing relaxing-to start our day that way, All of the entrees we ordered were delicious. Again service impeccable.

Also loved that there is a doorman and only one way into lobby. Not several entrances where people are coming and going. Concierge available and helpful.

Initially was told free Wifi only available in lobby. I brought my tablet down there as I wanted to look something up but couldn't get on. Concierge came over and helped me figure it out. Apparently the Wifi was available and free in the room as I was not charged when I later when I used it in my room.

I had a massage in the spa- a little pricey at $130 for 50 minutes but the spa area is very nice. I loved it because no children under 16 years old are not allowed the in pool or jacuzzi. (for those with children: Handerly, Palace, Sheraton at the wharf, Marriott on Market all allow children at their pools), This made the Spa experience very relaxing. Use of pool, jacuzzi and sun deck free with hotel stay.

The California Cable Car stops right in front of hotel. You can buy an all day pass for the Cable Cars and buses for $14 directly from the Cable Car attendant. You cannot buy these from the busdrivers. Each Cable Car ride is $6 and bus is $2. So if you plan to travel throughout the city, this may be a good option to invest in. No bus lines to my knowledge run in front of the hotel so you have to use the Cable Car (which is fun anyway) or walked to another street to access the busline. (The hotel also says they have a limo that goes to Union Square) The other thing about the California Cable car is that it is not as crowded as the other 2 lines and so I find it more enjoyable to ride. We rode the other line in the evening down to the Wharf area. It was so crowded that you really couldn't see anything if you were inside.

While I love the hustle and bustle of Union Square, it is nice to be in an area that is peaceful. Across the street is Grace Cathedral-looking somewhat like Notre Dame. It has a replica of the Ghilberti Doors. Across the street is Huntington Park. It has a replica of the Tortoise Fountain from Rome.

So to wrap it up, Great Service, great hotel and spa, and great area.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

'Great Destressing in SF'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 14, 2012

We just love the Huntington and look forward to staying there whenever in SF. It is a small but elegant old hotel with a great spa/pool area that is so inviting we use it often to just destress. Also, it is so annoying to have to pay extra for the wi-fi. But the restaurant, the piano cocktail area and the ambiance more than make up for the inconveniences. Unfortrunately the rooms the sound carries very easily between rooms.

MrsDeaver
San Diego, California
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'Fantastic stay in top notch location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 11, 2012

My husband & I stayed here for 3 nights and enjoyed our stay. Our room had a fabulous view of the city, which we could enjoy from our "sitting room" section or the comfortable bed. (great linens & pillows) Older hotel with European charm; renovated room with modern amenities. The location can not be beat; across from Huntington Park and Grace Cathedral. We walked in every direction to sight seeing and restaurants.

The bellman and cleaning staff were among some of the most considerate and professional I've encountered. Front desk staff was 50/50; some fantastic but others a little haughy at times; one early morning my husband went to the lobby and asked for a business document to be faxed and the front desk man asked him "if he was even staying here"....needless to say that frosted my husband a bit.

The spa is the added bliss moment of our stay. Guests have free access to the spa facilities which are fantastic. Great steam rooms, saunas, small but refreshing pool, jacuzzi and deck with loung chairs. I hear the spa services are great as well....maybe next time!

    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *

This is at the top end of a 3 star rated hotel - it could easily be a higher rating if the old boys club (the Elks) that take up the lower floors shared their toys (spa, handball court etc.) As a solo woman traveler, the location couldn't be better. A stone throw from Union Square and 4 short blocks... More
