gojph
Cumbria, England
Top Contributor
56 reviews 56 reviews
Reviews in 39 cities Reviews in 39 cities
42 helpful votes 42 helpful votes
'Excellent hotel, fantastic location'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 2, 2012 NEW via mobile

We chose the Bryant Park because of the location, which we'd liked on a previous visit to New York. It's a fantastic looking building, overlooking the small but charming green space of Bryant Park, right by the Central Library, on the edge of the garment district, a few blocks from Times Square and Broadway. It's not particularly quiet though with the busy 6th Avenue nearby.

Friendly staff greeted us in the lobby and were helpful throughout our 2 night stay. We checked in early after a midday arrival at JFK and were found a nice corner room, with an excellent view of Bryant Park and 6th, that was an upgrade from the "Superior" room we'd booked. The dim lighting and red-leather padded cell effect in the lift was a little weird!

Excellent bar downstairs, particularly between 5pm and 6pm when drinks are complementary for guests! The staff were pleasant and helpful if a tad underdressed (I think I'm getting old!). We went to Koi restaurant, entrance in the lobby, one night and thoroughly enjoyed our meal and the atmosphere.

Not a huge room, but a good size for NY with an excellent bathroom with both shower and bath. Plenty of fluffy towels, face cloths, excellent toiletries, bathrobes and slippers. The bed was very comfortable with superb down pillows (you can ask for foam if preferred). Excellent large screen TV, Bose radio and CD, and dock for MP3 players (not an iPod dock though).

To me, a light sleeper who doesn't like background noise, the only downside was the constant drone of the aircon, even when the fan was turned off. The odd noise making machine next to bed supposed to provide soothing backround noises didn't help. The earplugs provided did, a little. Because of that and the traffic noise, I probably wouldn't come back, which is a shame as otherwise I really liked this hotel.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 2 more reviews by gojph for New York City

'The only place I'd ever stay again in NYC.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012 NEW

Just returned from a 3 day girls' weekend to NYC. The hotel was wonderful! It is a beautiful old building in the perfect spot in the city. Just off Times Square but away from all the noise and chaos. We had coffee and breakfast in beautiful Bryant Park every morning and in the evenings, just sat and enjoyed looking at the beautifully lit city surrounding us. The room was fabulous... at least 6 windows made it bright and airy, the beds were heavenly, and the bathroom was wonderful. The staff was always helpful and on Mon-Fri afternoons, there is free open bar in the hotel's Cellar Bar for hotel guests. We both agreed this is where we would be staying on our next visit. I can't recommend it enough!
Less

Problem with this review?
MsNatGlobetrotter
Stockholm, Sweden
1 review
'Excellent in all ways!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

I go to NYC regularly - both for business and for romantic getaways with my boyfriend - and I always stay at the Bryant Park. I have never been disappointed. The hotel is excellent in all ways!
The location cannot be better: not too far up north nor south, a few blocks only to the 5th avenue shopping, a few blocks only from Times Square, easy to get in and out from Manhattan to Newark, the area around Bryant Park is wonderful and quiet (!), AND you almost don't hear the traffic (very unusual to escape that sound or the sounds in sirens in NYC...but at the Bryant Park you do!)
The rooms are great: clean, spacious and bright with views of the park (I always stay in a Deluxe room, or a Bryant Park suite). I love that the floors are wooden (I hate carpets in hotel rooms!), love the large bathroom with its Molton Brown ameneties, and the huge tub! Wi-fi usage is complementary and it is super easy to get connected (you don't need to fill in names, passwords etc).
Service is excellent! All staff is very friendly and helpful, and I appreciate that they don't "hang over your shoulder" all the time, or trying to convince you to take the luggage to your room when you arrive (as they do at the Ritzes of the world). As a guest you always feel that you have your privacy, but if you need the staff they are always there to assist you.
I'm a frequent traveler and normally stay at luxury 5-star hotels from Leading Hotels, since I'm very picky when it comes to hotel rooms....But in NYC I would never think about staying somewhere else than at the Bryant Park!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask MsNatGlobetrotter about The Bryant Park Hotel

rgreenie27
Barnsley, United Kingdom
Senior Reviewer
8 reviews 8 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
14 helpful votes 14 helpful votes
'Brilliant Hotel in an Excellent Location'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

My now fiance and I (we got engaged on the Monday while we were there)stayed in this delightful hotel at the beginning of May. We have to say this is one of the best hotels we have ever stayed in and would not think twice about staying anywhere else if we returned to NYC. The Hotel itself has an old world look to the exterior but very modern and almost Boutique look to the interior especially the lobby and main reception, we loved every part of the dcor.

The Staff were always very polite and attentive also they were extremely knowledgeable and it seemed as no request could be impossible to service. The Cleaner (maid) was brilliant, full clean up in the morning and even a turn down on an evening whilst we were visiting the many restaurants and bars around the hotel.

I understand that the hotel rate per night is not the cheapest in New York. However, there aren't many that can top this hotel for location. Nestled to the rear of the Library Building adjacent Bryant Park on a quiet street between 5th and 6th Ave (as quiet as you're going to get for Midtown New York). So if you take into consideration staying here you can walk to 90% of touristy places (Times Square, Empire State, Rockefeller Centre, Maceys all within 10mins walk) therefore you don't need taxis or the subway the cost doesn't seem that bad. Also, when you factor in the Complimentary Bar Service in the Cellar Bar between 5-6pm for residents is a brilliant idea, and one I'm sure would be a great plus point for much of the Brits staying here, the Rate becomes almost reasonable ;-)

The other plus points about this hotel was the large bathroom with great shower and MASSIVE Bath, just what you need when you've been peddling round Central Park all day. The only Negative I could say is that we had a room round the back of the hotel on not a very high floor, there wasn't any issue with noise from the streets below. However, the view could have been a little better than brick walls. However, you could argue that you aren't in the room for that long anyway and if you are really bothered about a better view then you would pay for a better room.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

FamilyTies_11
Metung, Australia
Senior Reviewer
10 reviews 10 reviews
Reviews in 8 cities Reviews in 8 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Great New York Location'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Stayed at the Bryant Park Hotel for 4 nights from May 6. Had a junior suite on the 19th floor with a terrace. Nice views out over Bryant Park across the road. Room was nice and spotless. Bed was very comfortable. Very large bathroom with separate bath and shower with Molton Brown products. Only single glazed windows, so a little noisy from traffic, but it is New York. Ipod dock of sorts in room. Only had the stereo plug, not proper docking connection, so bring your charger. No tea and coffee facilities in the room. Drinks were complimentary downstairs in cellar bar for hotel guests from 5.00 to 6.00pm Monday to Friday. Very trendy bar and a lovely touch. Service at the hotel was prompt. Location was good. Only ten minutes walk downtown to Macy's shopping area and about the same over to Time Square and the theatre district. Subway station out on the corner. If you are seeing Sister Act, it's up on 57th street. Catch the subway two stops and it takes you door to door. Overall would rate the hotel 4.5 out of 5. Quality of sleep let it down a bit, but other than that very good, clean and recommended.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

'Perfect Location & Excellent Customer Service!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 15, 2012

person found this review helpful

My husband and I recently stayed at this hotel on May 9-13th and we absolutely would recommend it to NYC travelers! The location is wonderful, short walk from Times Square and right in the middle of the city, overlooking Bryant Park. I think Bryant Park was one of my favorite parks, so pretty and well taken care of! The hotel staff are so accomodating and friendly, the front office manager, Robert Falco, was so very helpful and even said to get ahold of him for our next visit for a room that overlooked the city, now that's customer service!! The restaurant in the hotel, Koi, was yummy and even did last min reservations for us on a Sat. night! We never tried out the cellar bar, but it had a line to get in on a Sat night, so it must have been a good time! The hotel is not very noisy, even though one of the things they have in the bathroom was earplugs, which I had never seen before! My husband and I will def stay here again, we loved it and it made our trip that much more fantastic!!!

Problem with this review?
Andrew C
New York, New York United States
2 reviews
'Dreary, Dirty, Deplorable Service, Much better off at the New York Palace'
1 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012 NEW

The Waldorf Towers; The pinnacle of luxury in old world Manhattan.... not. The service was horrible along with the building.
It's a dump!! The molding by the tired in-room bar was ready to fall off. It was discreetly wedged in rather than fixed. The amount of deferred maintenance is astronomical.

The service we received for the tariff we paid to stay in this dump was just a ugly as the condition of the building. Upon arrival, no one showed us to our room or even the elevator. It was as though we were to fend for ourselves for a rate $500 a night. When we would walk in and out of the hotel not one staff member ever even greeted us or acknowledge our mere existence! Not a even a smile. It was an extraordinarily impersonal hotel experience, no one knew our names or made us feel welcomed. When I called for a tooth brush it took four calls and 45 minutes. This is unacceptable at a holiday inn for god sake! Their explanation was rude and a women stated that, "We have 1700 rooms and we dont have enough time to get there that quick". Meanwhile, the description of the Waldorf Towers leads customers to believe that they are paying to be in an exclusive, 188 room alcove of the Astoria where the service and attention to guests is impeccable. To say that the staff in the Waldorf Towers is attentive is the anthesis of the truth. It is a scam!

The maid service and women who worked at breakfast seemed unenthusiastic and sent the message that you were always inconveniencing them. They never smiled. The women cleaning one of the tables at breakfast even said to a colleague, "If these people want to make such a mess and eat so much, just go to the Palace". I fortuitously heard the conversation from a few tables away. I was shocked to say the least.
I go to New York about 5 or 6 times a year and have stayed at over 10 hotels, some better than others.
This one happened to worse than all of them.
The Setai and The Palace are the best. They deserve your business.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

Problem with this review?
Amonfrank
1 review
'Wonderful, relaxing, substantial and real.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW via mobile

The combination of best-in-class service with the authenticity of this 1920s designed grand hotel made it perfect choice for our long weekend of broadway shows and art museums! With all of the fantastic things to do in the city, i have a hard time pacing myself and taking time to recharge my batteries. We booked a regular room in the towers and got upgraded to a 2 room suite with perfect view of Chrysler building. If I had a rich aunt with an apartment in the city, this is what it would be like. Style and service is definately of another era. And l don't feel like I'm missing out on doing stuff in the city by just relaxing in my room. Rather than being "on the go" from morning to night, I've a few hours in morning and afternoon just hanging out in the suite or quietly wandering around the halls, lobbies and ballrooms of the hotel. I hope to come back here again in the fall.

    *

Less

See 13 more reviews by stacey049 for New York City
stacey049
London, United Kingdom
Senior Contributor
24 reviews 24 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Good central location, old fashioned charm'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012

The Towers has its own entrance, its own concierge and check in desk and breakfast restaurant, thank god because just walking through the Waldorf Astoria will have you running for a quieter, less frenzied hotel. The Towers is old fashioned, sophisticated charm and service. The rooms are comfortable full of elegant antique style furniture and large bathrooms with separate showers. We both agreed though that the room needed a fresh coat of paint and a general update. When we phoned down for slippers, towels etc they came up within minutes, nothing was a problem. Breakfast for the Towers is served in its own little restaurant, a choice of fruits, meat, cereals etc, but nothing hot or to order. You can also have afternoon tea here, which is included in the room price. It was great to have a separate concierge desk too, because we saw long queues in the main lobby. It's a very comfortable hotel, but it's not young and funky and neither are the clientele, but if you want a good location and elegant, old fashioned surroundings then this is the hotel for you.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'Great location and grande common areas. Room was a bit underwhelming'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 27, 2012 via mobile
2
people found this review helpful

The hotel is very beautiful and luxurious and the front desk staff are very attentive and friendly. The beds are up to the Hilton standard of amazing so a goods night rest will be sure to be had. The room decor and furnishings are in need of Reno and appear old, worn and neglected.

'Perfect room and great service'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I have to say that this was one of the best hotels that I have ever been to. The room was extremely comfortable, spacious and very well decorated. I used the room service a couple of times and the response was always polite, prompt and effective. The concierge (Michael) arranged a reservations for 2 very good restaurants (Co op and Standard Grill) for the next days, which was really great. In terms of localization the hotel is also good, as it is in walking distance from Madison Ave., Central Park and other nice places. I would definitely stay here again and recommend.
Less

Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'If you haven't tried this side of the Waldorf, you don't know what you're missing'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 10, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

I have stayed in most of the nice hotels in NYC except, until this week, The Waldorf Towers. The Towers has a well-known illustrious history, from Presidents to Kings to Mrs Douglas MacArthur. One's perception of the Towers may be that of a past its prime, dowager of a hotel. Well you would definitely be wrong. The hotel and rooms, while very last century in style (I don't mean that negatively, but rather as in very elegant) are in excellent condition and spacious. The high ceilings and uncrowded common areas give you the sense of being cosseted in a private cove in a very busy city. It feels very much like you are in the comfortable quiet confines of a pre-war Park Avenue apartment (which you are). The separate entrance sets the tone, and it doesn't stop. The exclusiveness of the Towers and the relationship with the employees feels more like a co-op residence rather than a hotel guest experience.
Now, while there are a few hotels that offer this level of luxury - the Carlyle, the Pierre, the St. Regis, etc. what I like about the Towers is that you also have all the features and services of a large hotel just a few yards away in the main hotel. Also, the location - just a couple blocks north of Grand Central - is really ideal.
I will definitely make the Towers my first choice of NYC hotel going forward
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 3 more reviews by Nempuku for New York City

'Elegant Luxury'

Stayed here as a family for a week a Easter to celebrate a special anniversary and were very kindly upgraded by the lovely Abir for our stay. anned123456
co meath ireland
Reviewer
5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 5 cities Reviews in 5 cities
6 helpful votes 6 helpful votes
'Elegant Luxury'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 9, 2012

Stayed here as a family for a week a Easter to celebrate a special anniversary and were very kindly upgraded by the lovely Abir for our stay. Huge two bed suite it felt like our very own apartment on Park Avenue. Very luxurious rooms with amazing linen/towels etc. Great breakfast room (and compliments to the girls working there) it is a small room however we were never waiting more than 5 minutes. Lovely selection of breakfast in particular the cinnamon granola.
Beautiful lobby, bars and great concierge service in the Towers. Recommended some good restaurants and some casual ones when travelling with teenagers. Don't bother with the Starbucks in the hotel its madly expensive. There is a great one opposite the main door of the Waldorf. This was our first trip to New York as a family and we will certainly never forget our stay at the Waldorf!!
If you are travelling with teenagers I highly recommend the Pizza Tour of Brooklyn (book in advance) it takes you to Coney Island too and it was one of the highlights of our trip.
If u get tired of 5th Avenue (because at weekends it does get hectic) shop in Soho or Seaport.
Less hassle and if the weather is nice you can take a walk/bike ride across Brooklyn Bridge (at Seaport) or sit outside and sip a white wine while the teenagers shop!!
We will be back to the Waldorf. Some day!
ps. lots of SUV's outside the hotel offering great rates back to the Airport. 90 dollars all in for 4 of us and 8 pieces of luggage
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

'A real Grand Hotel from last century, in excellent condition!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 8, 2012

Obviously this hotel is not newly built. Obviously one can see it. But everything is in an excellent condition of repair. This old hotel has style and class. Probably the best choice in NYC. We were pleased from the moment of our arrvial until departure. The tower breakfast was a great and a pleasant way to start our days (weekdays from 6.30 a.m.).

We will be back on our next trip to New York.
Less

'Super NYC Experience'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 25, 2012

The Waldorf is a special hotel and the towers are just so comfortable. I stayed one night in the middle of a whirlwind trip and it just refreshed us. Anyone who's looking for a short term apartment, look no further. Don't expect anything modern, but it's lux and comfortable and the service is top notch.
Was this review helpful? Yes

Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Best Place I've stayed in NYC'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012 via mobile
1
person found this review helpful

I've been to NYC almost 10 times and the last 3 times, I've stayed at The Beacon. I don't know if I'd ever want to stay anywhere else. The location is perfect. It's right by the subway. There's a market right across the street and a trader joes right down the road. Of course, there's a Starbucks right downstairs. The neighborhood is so lovely and makes you feel more like a local than a tourist. It's not so loud and busy like the hotels in the touristy parts of NYC. The upper west side is just a fabulous place to stay!

Also, the rooms are amazing. They're not your typical shoe box sized hotel room in the city. There's a living room along with the bedrooms and a little kitchen and great sized bathroom. It's like a little apartment. It's great for larger groups!

The staff is all very helpful and so nice! They seem to genuinely enjoy their jobs and are always ready to help.

I love The Beacon!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 2 more reviews by Madison M for New York City

'Great place to stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

As all others have said the standard suites in this hotel are spacious and well equipped with full facilities for in-house self catering. It has an excellent food shop opposite and a wine shop within yards so you can make New York a good value place to stay. The bedroom was very comfortable and the air conditioning worked well. The... 'Great place to stay'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012

As all others have said the standard suites in this hotel are spacious and well equipped with full facilities for in-house self catering. It has an excellent food shop opposite and a wine shop within yards so you can make New York a good value place to stay. The bedroom was very comfortable and the air conditioning worked well. The room was well maintained throughout our 5 night stay. I would return without hesitation.
Less

It's a great place. I'll always check to see if there is room at the Beacon when I come to NY. Perfect location and near the subway for easy access all over town.

CAisMyTrueHome
New York
Senior Contributor
26 reviews 26 reviews
Reviews in 21 cities Reviews in 21 cities
13 helpful votes 13 helpful votes
'Great Place to stay on the UWS'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 25, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed in a double room and was pleasantly surprised. The room looked exactly like the hotel photos -- was clean, beautiful, and very functional.

The room is good size for NYC (small by other cities' standards), and had a small kitchenette with toaster, coffee, microwave, stove, etc. Quite handy. So often in NYC the rooms are so small there's no room for additional seating, but this had a really comfortable chair for reading, and a small table with 2 chairs for eating.

I love staying on the UWS instead of in Times Square. Hotel Beacon is very close to the 72nd street subway--which has an Express 2/3 train to Times Square for touristy stuff. There's lots to do right in the UWS; a short walk will take you to the Lincoln Center (Ballet, Philharmonic, Opera, Musicals), the New York Historical Society (well worth a visit if an American history buff), and the Natural History museum/ Planetarium.

Definitely recommend.

Our room faced the back, but we still have a view over the rooftops. It was very quiet at night.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 4 more reviews by CAisMyTrueHome for New York City

samantha t
Drouin, Australia
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'"Home away from home - 10 out of 10!"'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

My family and I (from Australia) stayed at the Magic Castle from May 19 - May 24, 2012 on the last leg of our trip in the USA and I have to say, out of all the hotels we stayed in, it was the best! From the moment you check in it truly feels like home away from home. Our one bedroom suite was a great size after staying in small hotel rooms. The location of the hotel is fantastic, so close to everything.

The wonderful staff could not do enough for you and always showed interest in what we were doing. The room was always nice and clean and lovely to come back to at the end of our long days sightseeing in Hollywood. The complimentary continental breakfast consisting of cereals, toast, pastries, fruit, yoghurt, juices, tea and coffee was always appreciated.

The complimentary snacks and also the icy poles by the pool (which I have never encountered before in any hotel) were very much enjoyed. The pool was lovely and the hotel also supplied balls, etc for the kids to play with in the pool.

We had a wonderful time in Hollywood which was just made even better by this hotel. Thank you so much to all the staff for giving us a memorable stay, we will recommend your hotel to everyone and hope one day we get to come back and stay again!!!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'Brilliant, friendly hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 29, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Had a great four night stay at Magic Castle last week. Magic Castle staff were amazing, helpful and considerate. How they keep track of all the guests names and faces still amazes me!

I had a basic room (no kitchen), but it was plenty big enough for me. Comfortable bed and not very noisy (considering its location).

The location was fantastic, just a block from Hollywood Blvd and Grauman's Chinese Theatre. Staff were really helpful at suggesting local restaurants in a range of price ranges.

All in all, a great stay.

CarmenWBendigo
Bendigo, Australia
Senior Reviewer
8 reviews 8 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Awesome base while in LA'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

I have been meaning to write this review for ages but am only just finding the time now (8 months after our stay!) I can't say enough about the Magic Castle. From the moment you walk in the door to the time you leave, you are made to feel so welcome. We stayed twice on an extended trip to the US (start and end) and both times were very happy.

The rooms are clean and well set out (it's not the Ritz so don't go in expecting marble bathrooms!) and the access to a kitchen is invaluable for those on a budget. We also loved the snacks and DVD's that were available for a night where we were too exhausted to venture out! We also spent a bit of time in the lovely pool.

As others have stated, the service is really what sets this place apart. On our last stay, we asked if we could store some luggage at the hotel so we only needed to take carry-on luggage for a Hawaiian jaunt. They couldn't have been more accommodating to our email request and Nick ensured our two large cases were kept safe and sound for the week we were in Hawaii.

Position to Hollywood Blvd a plus if you wish to spend time in that area. We had a car and parking was reasonably priced at $11 per day (from memory) and it was very easy to find our way to pretty much anywhere from the hotel.

All in all, a fantastic stay and I have been recommending this place to EVERYONE I know when they say they are heading to LA! Can't wait to come back ourselves!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
MaCA40
Perth, Australia
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
Reviews in 6 cities Reviews in 6 cities
9 helpful votes 9 helpful votes
'Wonderful'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 27, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We stayed at the Magic Castle from 30 April 2012 - 4 May 2012. The room is clean and has all you need including an ipod docking alarm clock, flat screen television and DVD player.

The breakfast is more than adequate and included tea, coffee, juices, cereals, pastries, toast and yoghurt.

The staff are an absolute credit to this hotel. Each staff member that we encountered were friendly and very helpful. They have ready printed instructions on how to get to Universal Studios which are very handy and easy to follow.

Great location - short walk to the Walk of Fame, Madam Tussauds, Kodak Theatre etc. Maybe 5 minute walk to the train station.

The hotel offered free DVDs, chocolate bars, potato chips and soft drinks. It also has an onsite laundry, but bring your own laundry powder!

All in all a fabulous little hotel and I would definately recommend staying here.
Less

AnneD
Columbus, Ohio
Contributor
14 reviews 14 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
34 helpful votes 34 helpful votes
'Excellent Stay in Sherman Oaks'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

My family stayed at this hotel between Christmas and New Year's, and I found the stay to be completely satisfactory.

My brother and I arrived about 2 a.m. after long flights from the midwest and a long ride in a thunderstorm from the Ontario CA airport. We were exhausted, and very chagrined to find that our sister had reserved only one room for four of us, expecting my brother and me to share a room with two other siblings, two to each bed. We went back to the desk, booked another room, and bought some food. We were stupid with fatigue and a little grumpy, but the staff made everything better, going out of their way to get us a room and meal as quickly as possible. They were utterly kind and gracious.

The room was nicely decorated, quite spacious, clean and comfortable. Good furnishings. The lobby was not huge but I enjoyed the contemporary decor very much -- very well done. The room rate was quite low due to a "lull" between December 25 and 30, so it was an excellent value.

We picked the hotel based on its location near Encino, where we were visiting family. The hotel is on Ventura Blvd, close to freeway exits/entrances (405 and 101), which made it easy to travel around. I would definitely stay here again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

See 11 more reviews by KahunaHawaii for Los Angeles
KahunaHawaii
Hawaii
Top Contributor
76 reviews 76 reviews
Reviews in 16 cities Reviews in 16 cities
49 helpful votes 49 helpful votes
'Only Hotel in Sherman Oaks or on Ventura Blvd'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed April 29, 2012

Best 3.5 star hotel on Ventura Blvd in Sherman Oaks/Encino. Located off the 405 fwy at the Ventura Fwy this hotel offers a very comfortable stay for the business or casual traveler or someone wanting to stay on Ventura Blvd in "the Valley". The rooms are clean and the well appointed. Big screen TV but it needs TIVO, coffee maker that should have instant coffee VIA instant instead of cheap coffee drip maker and paper cups. The rooms are not energy efficient.. they should make it so that you have to use your room card to activate lights and have to take the card out when you leave room.. which then turns off the lights....the fridge overheats under the counter so make sure you crank it to high if you want your beer cold.

The gym is nice with a large TV and also individual TV on all machines. There is a large sun splashed deck and pool with a view south of Encino hills and the 405 Fwy. There is secure parking in the building and in/out access. The house staff is very nice,multi-lingual and the great service has the Marriott courtyard touch. The lobby is elegant and attractive, with a business center. The restaurant serves a nice breakfast for about $15. There is a lobby bar with big screen for sports but no happy hour and I would strongly recommend nice jazz music and even dancing in the lounge, because there is no nightlife or fun bars in the area. I saw Jim Simpson the famous sports announcer and his ABC crew. There in internet access. The paintings on the wll have nothing to do with LA life. The higher floors are accessed only with room card. The valley view rooms have a scenic view of the 405 Fwy interchange and in the morning before the smog you can see the entire valley to the mountain ranges.

There is really nothing for entertainment in the Encino wastelands.. it is Ventura Blvd urban sprawl if you know what I mean. There is a Whole Foods nearby and you can easily walk 2 blocks under the fwy to the Sherman Oaks Galleria for movies at the Arclight and great happy hour dining @ Cheesecake Factory (4-6), El Torito Grill (4-8) or PF Changs (3-6). I would say walk because you get charged $10 for each hour you go over your 3 hour movie validation..

East toward Sherman Oaks has many nice restaurants. Marmalade and Mel's diner are great for BK, Fatburger is the best burger in LA, there is an In-N-Out, Izakaya on Ventura Blvd for Sushi is A+. Blue Dog is an excellent sports bar and burger grill... on the side street behind the Whole Foods parking lot.

West on Ventura Blvd. is a Ralphs, high end Farfalla Italian restaurant and the only Starbucks in Encino. I did not like the homeless parking their shopping carts and smoking on the patio.. it messed up the aroma of my Kona Clover. If you have the guts and love seafood buffet.. Highly recommend Hokkaido seafood buffet...that is best buffet I have ever eaten at... just yummmy.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 11 more reviews by KahunaHawaii for Los Angeles
Ask KahunaHawaii about Courtyard Los Angeles Sherman Oaks
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

Problem with this review?
psage728
San Francisco, California
1 review
'really nice hotel, great service, good ADA facilties'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed March 14, 2012

I visited family in Sherman Oaks and researched the area for a hotel with an ADA accessible room with roll in shower (wheel-chair) for other family members coming from NY. The hotel staff and concierge -Donald- were very patient with all my phone calls and questions. The ADA room has 2 queens and big bathroom with bars and the roll-in shower with fold down seat. My daughter and i has a 2 room suite, king bed with sofa bed. The king is very comfortable, sofa bed good enough for one adult or 2 kids. The suite has a seating area perfect for 6 adults and 2 babies visiting all day. Restaurant is decent but a bit limited. We requested --and got--a microwave. Coffeemaker in the room is like the Hamilton Beach personal pod brewer, i brought Senseo pods from home and they worked fine. Rooms have a balcony with interesting views of the mountains and freeways, doors are sealed for safety and noise reduction. Nice pool/spa area with fire pit and tables. On Ventura Blvd,.lots of stores and restaurants within walking distance, also a bus route. Parking is $15 day for guests, reasonable for this area.

We really liked this hotel--comfortable, clean, attractive, quiet. I would stay there again for sure.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask psage728 about Courtyard Los Angeles Sherman Oaks
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

mvdljca
So-So Cal
Contributor
20 reviews 20 reviews
Reviews in 17 cities Reviews in 17 cities
17 helpful votes 17 helpful votes
'Comfortable, convenient, good value'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed February 27, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

Stayed overnight at the Courtyard at Sherman Oaks on Oscar weekend, when everything in Hollywood and the Westside seemed to be booked. The rooms are a little small but very clean and well appointed, with comfortable beds. Double glass doors kept out 95% of the racket from the Ventura Freeway screaming along eight stories below. The location is convenient to the Studio City-Universal Studios area, and the Westside is just a short hop back down the San Diego Freeway. There are plenty of eateries a 2-block walk away at the Galleria. Compared to similar properties in the general area, it's convenient and a good value.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

ptbooth
San Francisco, California
Top Contributor
64 reviews 64 reviews
Reviews in 34 cities Reviews in 34 cities
58 helpful votes 58 helpful votes
'OMG my favorite luxury boutique hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012 NEW

Got a reasonable deal for this relatively new 5-star hotel just next to Times Square (on 44th, same block as the ABC studio). Were upgraded to a junior suite, perhaps because we were celebrating our honeymoon. The service was incredible. Friendly desk attendant, an actual hotel butler, art deco style out the wazoo.
Then the rooms. Wow. Somehow mixing ultra-modern features with luxury art deco style (high tech room controls on the phone), bathroom in sparkly maroon/brown granite and mirrors, TV in the wall, and the toilet from space with a warm seat and water jets (!!!). The upgraded room had a small "walk in" closet with safe and mini bar area, seating area, and desk that opened up to reveal a light and work area.

The location can't be beat for Times Square activity, without being right on the square (just half a block off).

Maybe the only downsides were that the room control touch screen on the phone did not respond well to touch, so it was often hard to change the lighting and drapery settings; also that the desk lamp that lights up when the lid is hinged open basically shined directly at eye level while working, so I had to drape a hand towel to serve as a visor when working on my laptop.

But overall, this was an amazing luxury boutique hotel, at a great location, with incredible service. I will return.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 7 more reviews by ptbooth for New York City

'This hotel is the greatest'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012 NEW

We stayed here for one week and it could not have been better. The location is perfect for a trip to NYC, half a block from Times Square, the subway, theatre and plenty of great restaurants. Our room was fantastic (we are Platinum Starwood members and were upgraded to a suite) Tasteful furnishings and the bathrooms are not to be believed... every imaginable amenity and convenience including a tv built into the mirror of each bathroom. The front manager Brad, was incredibly helpful and accommodating in all areas. The staff in general made you feel like you were part of the family, and that they really wanted you to have whatever you needed. Had a fantastic facial in the spa and wonderful drinks at the bar. Cannot wait to come back

1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'New York break'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012 NEW

We were on a round the world trip from Australia and as an SPG member I usually stay at member hotels. The chatwal is a beautiful newly restored art deco hotel just off times square. It's location is fantastic ands is on a quite side street so is perfectly quiet.

The staff were faultless and their customer service spot on. We had a suite and it was lovely. The barthroom was the highlight, beautiful black marble and large rain shower. The bed was fantastically comfortable and we loved the ability to control the lights, temperature and curtains from the touchpad buy the bed.

I would definitely recommend this hotel to people wanting to have a quiet retreat in the heart of it all.

Dr Helen willcock
Less

NashvilleWslaughter
Tennessee
Contributor
11 reviews 11 reviews
Reviews in 11 cities Reviews in 11 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'First Class Experience'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

There is little, if anything, not to like about this hotel. Cordial and hepful staff, outstanding room decor and comfort, quiet location just steps from Times Square. High-tech touches abound in this art deco masterpiece. Lobby bar plus a 2nd Floor lounge that overlooks 44th Street. Bathrooms are to be experienced, not visited. The Lamb's Club restaurant is excellent, and a small, well equipped fitness room, spa, indoor pool and hot tub round out your on-site options. Wi-Fi is on the house as it should be.

I prefer The Chatwal to the Four Seasons and the New York Palace, both top properties but each lacking the "boutique" charm and warmth that you find here. If you like high-class, high-tech, high-touch without the attitude, The Chatwal is a smart choice.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
See 4 more reviews by Arlo3k for New York City
Ask Arlo3k about The Chatwal
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Lance Miller, Front Office Supervisor at The Chatwal, responded to this review
May 26, 2012
Dear Arlo3k,
Thank you for your feedback regarding your recent stay at The Chatwal.

It is most disappointing to hear we did not exceed your expectations as we take great pride in the level of service we provide our guests. We are known for providing the type of service that prompted your review on TripAdvisor in December 2011.

I would like to apologize for the inconveniences the occured with the televisions in your room. The moment you had brought the issues to our attention, our engineer was promptly dispatched to attend to the matter.

We sincerely regret that your stay was less than perfect, especially since you have left a lovely review here on TripAdvisor about your first experience at The Chatwal Hotel.

I would welcome the opportunity to further discuss these issues in greater detail. I can be reached via email at lmiller@thechatwalny.com. You may also contact the hotel directly at 212.764.6200 and ask to speak with Lance.

I do hope we have the great pleasure in welcoming you back for another return visit. I will look forward to hearing from you.

Cordially,
Lance Miller

GerdGruber
Heidelberg, Germany
1 review
'Probably one of the best hotels in NY'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW

We (a family with 2 children) spent 5 days at The Mark. It was phantastic. The building offers you all the electronic equipment that you want. B&O TV, very nice furniture. The hotel stuff makes you feel all the time like a real guest, they are always very friendly and are organizing everything you want to (cards for museum, Taxi, Restaurants ...). The Restaurant in the hotel is very good!
What else: gym in hotel is very good.
The location of The mark is very good, in a quiet little street between the Central Park and Madison Avenue, within walking distance to the hot-spots of the city (for example 20 min. to the Apple Cube) and only 2 minutes to Central Park!
I can recommend The Mark, on our next trip to NY we will stay again in this hotel.

Problem with this review?
Samantha K
New York City, New York
1 review
'A Fantastic Weekend At The Mark'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 31, 2012 NEW

We recently had a wonderful stay at The Mark. Aesthetically, the hotel is extremely elegant and sophisticated. The service was also fabulous. The staff was friendly and professional. They personalized our experience upon check in by making us smile in the elevator and while giving us the detailed tour of our room. The next morning, we ordered room service from The Mark Restaurant. Everything was perfect and it was delivered on time. The table that was brought in was set up right by one of our windows. We enjoyed the view while eating our delicious breakfast.
The Mark is a perfect alternative to any of the busier hotels in midtown. It's quiet and spacious, whereas many other New York City hotels fail to give guests that much needed break from the "hustle and bustle" The Mark did just that. Since our first trip, we've recommended the hotel to our close friends and they had a very similar pleasant experience. We can't wait to stay at The Mark Hotel again.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012

I've stayed here several times for business. The upper East Side location was a little inconvenient for a rash of mid-town and downtown meetings, but the trade-off was having a different kind of experience. There's a more personal and relaxed feel here that is missing in the typical high-end business-oriented properties. Staff is friendly. Rooms have tons of great amenities, including extra walk-in closets off the bathroom and vanishing TVs in the over-sink mirrors... great for bath time! Glass ceiling in the restaurant makes breakfast very pleasant. Smallish in feel, in the New York way.
Less

'Wonderful Stay at The Mark'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 16, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

We recently had a fabulous stay at The Mark hotel. Everything from the service to the rooms to the aesthetics of the hotel was perfect. Aesthetically, the hotel is beautiful, elegant, and sophisticated. Located on a beautiful and quiet tree-lined street on the Upper East Sid, it is removed from the hustle and bustle of the city and within walking distance to some of the best shops and museums in NYC. The staff was very professional, friendly, and provided great hospitality. The room was clean, spacious, and the bathroom was large and included some great amenities. As an individual, who has stayed in many hotels all over the world, I would highly recommend The Mark to anyone visiting NYC!
Less

30 helpful votes 30 helpful votes
'The Mark was awesome!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 6, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My husband and I stayed at The Mark Hotel April 4th & 5th, 2012. It is located in the tony upper east side. Great designer shops in the area, good restaurants & delis. Our room was lovely & very roomy, and completely equipped with a great mini bar, in- room ice maker, cocktail glasses, drinking glasses, complimentaryl bottled water each evening. Turn- down service, complimentary robes & slippers, ample closet space, and a large bathroom with both tub & shower. Free WiFi, with a desk and a couple of comfy chairs in the room.

Situated in a quiet neighborhood ( Murray Hill), so sleep was peaceful, with no traffic or night noise. That, coupled with very a comfortable King bed, contributed greatly to our comfort and good night's sleep each night.

The hotel is relatively small and intimate. Their bar seemed to be very popular, but we did not go inside, as we aren't much for drinking. The concierge was very helpful and helped us to get the complimentary tickets to visit the World Trade Center Memorial. There is no cost, but you must have reservations, and you cannot get tickets on the site.

We really enjoyed our stay, and breakfast was included, so that represented a great value, and you could order odd a menu, so lots of selection, which we enjoyed. The service was top notch, and we would definitely say there again.

This is notmthemplace to,stay if you want to be within walking distance to Times Square,or mid-town, but we walked only 2 blocks to catch the subway, which was only 2 stops from 42nd street, and it was very cheap and easy.

The Mark has a couple of complimentary limos available to guests on a first-close basis, from 3PM leo 10:00PM, butmwemwere never able to,get one. The door man was very adept at getting us a taxi when we needed it, and all the employees were very friendly and helpful.

All in all, we really enjoyedmourmstay at The Mark, and would definitely go back!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Poulain2012
Sydney, Australia
2 reviews
5 helpful votes 5 helpful votes
'What a let down... Such a shame.'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed May 2, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

I recently booked 3 nights accommodation at The Mark. I have been to NYC many, many times, normally staying downtown at the likes of: The Bowery; Soho Grand; Mercer etc. On this trip I decided it might be nice to do something totally different for the first few nights of my 12 day stay and book a good hotel uptown or on the Upper East side. After a fair amount of research on the similar hotels in this area, which hold a 5 star rating akin to The Mark, I decided to go ahead and book a Madison King Room. I have pretty high standards when it comes to hotels, travel a decent amount and I work in an artistic field so therefore apart from basic requirements deemed necessary in a hotel such as; good service, quiet rooms, bed quality, cleanliness etc., I am personally always very drawn to the small design details and dcor of a hotel, therefore based on what I saw from The Mark website and its status as one of NYC's nicest and most luxurious hotels, it looked beautiful to me and I very much looked forward to staying.

My husband and I flew in from the West Coast after flying from Sydney (20+ hours of travel) and arrived at The Mark at around 8.30pm on a very rainy Sunday night. The desk staff were nice enough, no major faults there, although honestly there is a somewhat snotty, pretentious feel about the place. It's fine if you like that sort of atmosphere (which I realise is all part of that 'UES NY' atmosphere and was half expecting it) but we found it a tad cold and insipid, it lacks warmth. You can still do 'refined UES' but be less wooden and stiff about it if that's the main agenda at your establishment due to the neighbourhood you are located in.. It all just comes across painfully stereotypical and rather boring.

We checked into our room and waited for about 20 minutes for our bags to be brought up. I was very impressed with the cleanliness of the room, the design was lovely, very stylish and it was spotless, as was the bathroom. Literally gleaming and it had a very cosy, glamorous and comfortable feel. The mini bar was good and wonderfully there was a large freezer section full of ice  so during your stay you have ice 'on-tap' so-to-speak ~ one feature I loved. We headed downstairs to meet a colleague for a drinks in the hotel bar then retired to the room and booked some room service food.

This is where it all when majorly downhill. Whilst I was waiting for the food I decided to take a deep bath, I was shattered after all the travel, the bath was great, great that is until I went to unplug it. After several attempts on both my husband's part and mine, we surmised it was totally broken and we'd have to call reception for them to organise a plumber. (BTW the plug in the sink was totally blocked too). A plumber was sent up at around 11.30pm who set about trying to fix the bath. At 12.45am he was still there and unable to fix the plug, so was shovelling bucket loads of my bath water into the shower, the room was a mess. Following this we got 40 minutes of incessant loud banging as he went at the plug with a crowbar (or what sounded like something similar). It was 15 mins into this stage that my husband went to the front desk to say we would need to be moved to another room as we were unable to get to bed for the previous almost 2 hours due to said hammering in bathroom at almost 2am.

Whilst my husband was at the front desk he received a very flippant and disinterested attitude from the receptionist. He asked that we were moved as it was getting onto 2am and we needed to get some sleep. He was told there were no rooms available other than one smaller than the one we had paid for and if we moved that's where we would be for our 3 days stay. They also told him the hotel was otherwise fully booked for the Monday and Tuesday  call me a cynic, but on a Monday and Tuesday night in early April in this area, I am instinctually feeling this was a lie. Also when I checked online in the room from my laptop, every form of room from a Madison King to their Penthouse was available to book (Why on earth don't hotels cop on to that fact guests can tell when they are lying about room availability by simply checking online ?!!). During my husband's time downstairs the plumber (a really nice guy BTW) came into my room, dripping in sweat from all his efforts saying it was totally unfixable and he wasn't sure how he could fix it the next day either.

I was pretty disgusted at this attitude from the front desk. Fair enough if we were in a 1 or 2 star hotel, but their entire attitude was snotty and cold and totally unacceptable for the level of hotel they claim to be. Had she said; "I am so sorry we are full tonight, would you mind staying in the room or the smaller one and out of courtesy we will move you to a better or same level room tomorrow?" that would have been utterly fine, also, we were very unimpressed that she never checked with the plumber after 15 or 20 mins to see how things were going as she would have been aware we were hanging around waiting for him to fix it.

We decided to stay the night and check out the following day as I'm not interested in forking out money to hotels who blatantly show they don't give a fiddlers about you unless you are paying for their Presidential suite. When my husband ventured down again to tell reception we would be leaving the following morning he was met with a stunned 'rabbit caught in headlights' stare from both female and male receptionists, who suddenly started pleading was there "Anything at all they could possibly do?", "Could we upgrade you to a better room tomorrow sir??!" What a joke, 30 minutes previous we were told there were "no other rooms available" other than a pokey lower level one. The following morning upon checking out we were asked how we enjoyed our stay? When we replied 'Very disappointed" yet again, another 'rabbit caught in headlights stare' from the morning staff who then mentioned "was there some issue with your bath plug, I see a brief note here, I am so sorry, next time please come and stay with us and I will ensure you are upgraded" The whole way they handled themselves was almost embarrassing esp. when they claim to be 5 star.

When we decided on the Sunday night at 2am to leave, I booked a room immediately at The Greenwich Hotel in TriBeCa and we moved there first thing Monday morning. Which, within second of walking into, was warm, inviting, friendly, cosy, incredibly decorated and totally welcoming, they have service and details down-pat. In hindsight I was actually totally delighted The Mark treated us the way they did as if not, I wouldn't have moved hotels and had a wonderful 2 night stay there will 100% return to The Greenwich on my next NYC trip. It is without a doubt the best hotel I have ever stayed at in New York.

On an end note, if you do decided to stay at The Mark a tip, book a room away from Madison Ave, during our one and only night stay, I must add the room was crazy noisy, at around 5.30 or 6am we were awoken by the irritating, high-pitched, repetitive beeping noise of a truck reversing, or maybe it was a bus as it happened about 6 or 7 times between this time and 8am aka zero sleep from 6am onwards. Fantastic when we only got to bed 4 hours earlier. In addition this was only made my annoying in addition to the loud humming all night long of the air conditioning unit which were found utterly impossible to turn off.

Really disappointing overall and a really awful way to start a long anticipated break away in NYC.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask Poulain2012 about The Mark
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Olivier Lordonnois, General Manager at The Mark, responded to this review
May 9, 2012
Thank you very much for sharing your well-considered and extremely thorough assessment of your recent stay with us at The Mark. On behalf of my entire team, allow me to personally extend my deepest apologies for the perceptions you have acquired about our property  first resulting from the plumbing malfunctions you experienced and then from the subsequent correspondences you received. It is unfortunate enough to hear that your bathtub was equipped with a faulty drainage system, and is even more distressing to hear that our follow-up communications with your husband only compounded your disappointment.

As humbling as it is to receive this criticism, your candid critique will serve our property team well, as we truly do continually look to find opportunities to improve our levels of service and attention to detail. I would also like to reassure you that, while your stay certainly did not met the highest level of service that I know our team is capable of, your experience is a rare one  one that I hope you will allow us to rectify and improve upon, provided you choose to give us another chance in the near future. If you have any additional comments or follow-up questions whatsoever, please absolutely do not hesitate to reach out to me personally via e-mail (Olivier.Lordonnois@themarkhotel.com) or by phone (212 744 4300). Once again, my sincerest apologies for the unfortunate series of events that occurred during your stay.

'Perfect New York City Hotel'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 25, 2012

We stayed at the Mark Hotel with our children to celebrate mom's fiftieth birthday. We booked two Madison King suites and could't have been more delighted. They are joined by a separate foyer which can be used privately when both rooms are used by the same guests. We loved the new bathrooms, the Sub Zero mini-bar systems, the technology "tablet" that operates just about everything (including the curtains) and the spaciousness of the rooms. The Mark has a long history of guests from "old wealth," but knows instinctively how to meet the needs of a cliental that includes a great deal of recent diversity. The wonderful bar and the Jean Georges restaurant add to a gracious and luxurious stay.
Less

winecat
Napa, CA
Reviewer
4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 4 cities Reviews in 4 cities
3 helpful votes 3 helpful votes
'Best hotel in NYC, or anywhere!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 18, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

I travel to NYC for business and pleasure at least once or twice a year.
I have stayed in many different hotels in various locations throughout the city, mostly near mid-town where my business takes me. I can honestly say I have never felt more comfortable or more at home. Because it is a residence building and not an over-sized, transient hotel, it is quiet and comfortable and the location can't be beat. I agree with a previous reviewer, I did not want to leave and joked with the front desk I would call a real estate agent! Well, the Sherry does indeed have one, and her name is Theresa Nocerino. If you are in the market for a pied a terre, be sure to give her a call. Everyone at the hotel and in Cipriani's just raved about her. She made sure my every need was attended to, and the entire staff could not be more friendly. The elevator operators evoke an era gone by of service and style. If you want to feel refreshed and rested after a busy day in Manhattan, the Sherry is the place to stay. The only caveat is you may not want to leave your room, so don't overschedule yourself with appointments while visiting New York! 5 star, triple A+!!!
Less

meagan1223
Boston, Massachusetts
Contributor
11 reviews 11 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
10 helpful votes 10 helpful votes
'My go to hotel in NYC'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed April 30, 2012
3
people found this review helpful

I go to NYC very often for shopping, to get my hair done, go to some dr. appts, these trips are usually solo. I also go with my husband and children during Christmas, and occasionally throughout the year. This is my favorite hotel on the East side, and I have stayed in many. The first time I stayed here I joked with Russell, the man at the front desk that they would probably have to remove me with police force because I loved it so much. One of the things that I find so amazing about the Sherry is that I find myself never asking for anything, because they have already thought of everything. The rooms are enormous, comfortable, the staff is attentive and lovely, I love the fact that beverages and wifi are included. The soaking tub and bathrooms are awesome. There is absolutely no street noise, which is kind of amazing given the location. The location could not be better, you are on the edge of central park, you can walk to any store you could ever want, as well as so many delicious restaurants nearby. There have been a few occasions where they have been booked up, but otherwise, I don't stay anywhere else, I simply don't want to.
Less

Everyone was friendly and the rooms were large. Staying in such a wonderful and friendly place made our trip even that much better. My husband is a runner so being across from Central Park was an added bonus. Already planning another trip there in the fall.

4 reviews 4 reviews
Reviews in 3 cities Reviews in 3 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Perfect stay on the UES'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012 NEW

My friends and I just spent an amazing weekend in NYC, based out of the Surrey. We all loved every aspect of the hotel - the decor was gorgeous without feeling stuffy, the service was genuinely incredible (loved our rooftop bartender and Peter especially!), and the location was perfect. Our room was very generously sized. It lacked a view, but we were forewarned by the front desk and chose it because it had 2 beds. The weekend was in celebration of our birthdays, and the hotel sent us a wonderful bottle of champagne - I cannot express how top-notch the service was! We especially loved the private rooftop terrace. It feels like the garden of a grand mansion, plus there are magnificent city views. Another plus was the location: easy to access UES shopping, Central Park and the 4, 5, 6 trains. I am already trying to plan a return visit ASAP!
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

Problem with this review?
Jeff G
Washington DC, District of Columbia
1 review
4 helpful votes 4 helpful votes
'Almost Perfect'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
4
people found this review helpful

Just checked out of the hotel this morning and back in DC. First of all let me start off by saying that this is a Great Place and would I stay hear again...you bet. The hotel staff was very friendly from the moment we walked in from the time we exited the taxi and checked out and back into the taxi. The Concierge (Andrew I think his name was) was extremely helpful and provided great input that helped our visit. The location was great just down the street from central park with a great price (comparatively speaking to other higher class hotels in the area that is). The room was very nice and roomy much bigger and nicer than I expected and the shower was awesome. The only reason this hotel didn't get a 5 was the poor extremely poor service at the bar. The bartender was not very friendly which was okay everybody has their bad days. However, the waitress was absolutely horrible when we sat at one of the bar tables. Not only was she not friendly not once did she come over to see if we needed anything. In fact, we had to pull other employees over to order our appetizers and our drinks throughout the night (not once did she help us literally). Considering their were only two of us and our bill was just shy of 200 bills this is unacceptable (especially considering we only ordered appetizers and martinis). We did go up to the roof top bar and met the waitress working up there and she was absolutely awesome (I don't remember her name but she lives in Brooklyn). As I stated before everything else was fantastic and we will stay their again and soon. However, if this happens again we will not stay there again because there are too many other higher end places that don't miss a beat in any area.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?

'A Great Upper East Sider'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 28, 2012
5
people found this review helpful

I have both lived and travelled to NY for many years and never stayed at a better hotel than the Surrey. It is a European style boutique hotel with lovely large rooms and simply fabulous European oriented service. There is nothing that is too much for the staff. From the concierge to the bellman they are incredibly alert and well trained. The restaurant is first class as well. It is certainly not inexpensive but it is a real value. The location on the upper east side is great for shopping and the museums and a walk in Central Park.
Less

Senior Contributor
45 reviews 45 reviews
Reviews in 32 cities Reviews in 32 cities
132 helpful votes 132 helpful votes
'Fantastic Long Weekend'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 24, 2012
1
person found this review helpful

My wife and I really enjoyed our stay at The Surrey. We arrived to find that we were given a nice room but it was rather noisy. After speaking to the front desk it was handled very efficiently. We were placed in an even better room that was so comfortable. Thanks Clifford! The hotel is very classy and all the staff are friendly and courteous. The location in the upper East Side between Madison and 5th Avenue is pleasant especially after spending time in more hectic neighbourhoods. It is literally located next to Central Park near a convenient entrance that leads through the park to Strawberry Fields. Our room was very spacious and luxurious in every way from the high quality bed linens to the marble bathroom. The hotel has a very pleasant rooftop patio. The hotel was very busy but never felt overwhelming. Overall, a great find and we would definitely stay here again.
Less

DDatYVR
Vancouver, Canada
Senior Contributor
30 reviews 30 reviews
Reviews in 13 cities Reviews in 13 cities
29 helpful votes 29 helpful votes
'Love The Surrey'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed May 22, 2012
2
people found this review helpful

The hotel has the perfect location on the Upper East Side for museum lovers like me. Within blocks of The Met and The Frick, the hotel is also just a block away from one of the entrances to Central Park, and walking distance to the Guggenheim and the Whitney.

Service is impeccable, with the concierge, front desk and bell staff always polite and responsive. I never had to follow-up or try to chase down a response to my request. Housekeeping came twice a day and did a wonderful job. Turn-down service was greatly appreciated with bottles of water and choclate-dipped madelines.

Stayed in a Grand Deluxe Room and loved it. It was a nice-sized corner room with beautiful furnishings, marble bathroom, and plenty of closet space. The very comfortable bed and awesome shower pressure are enough to make me return.

Please make sure you stay at The Surrey when visiting New York City.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes

'A Gem'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012 NEW

We have been visiting NYC for over 30 years and this was our first stay at The Iroquois. To say that we were thrilled with the experience would be an understatement. Our request for an early check-in was cheerfully accommodated. Every staff member we encountered was friendly, cheerful and courteous. The room was absolutely perfect. It was spotless, the furnishings were lovely and the bed and linens were so comfortable. The street view was an added bonus. The bathroom was also spotless and supplied with enough towels to last for days. The hotel is a quiet retreat from nearby Times Square and Grand Central. This will certainly be our hotel of choice for future visits.

map46
Greensboro, North Carolina
Reviewer
3 reviews 3 reviews
'Perfect Stay'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 4, 2012 NEW

We stayed 3 nights in early June 2012 and everything about the hotel and staff was excellent. The room was quiet, exceptionally clean, bed was very comfortable and room was large enough for NYC with a great bathroom and shower area. The bath amenities were top of the line. We were on the seventh floor with a room that faced the back so no view, but no street noise, so it made for great sleeping. The maintaince of the property is excellent. No visible wear and tear on carpeting, furniture etc, throughout the property.
The entire staff, from front desk to bell staff (Rocky), to the maid service, to the concierge (Vanessa, who personally arranged a shipment of goods back to our home) were polite, friendly, professional and cared that or experinece was top rate. We had lunch at the restaraunt on the property and it was excellent as was the service.
Finally, the location is terrific. Easy walks to major attractions, shopping and to subways. Cabs plentiful and easy to get.
Less

Gary T
Glasgow, Scotland, United Kingdom
Senior Reviewer
7 reviews 7 reviews
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'Fantastic Hotel.'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 1, 2012 NEW

Myself and Fiance are just back from a five night stay at The Iroquois and we really loved everything this hotel had to offer.

Check in was quick and easy and all the Receptionist staff were very friendly. We were offered an upgrade to our room which we delinced as it was an extra $30 per night (we wanted to keep our money to spend) but it was nice to be offered.

After reading a lot of the reviews on here i was worried about the size of the room as people mentioned the rooms were very small. We didnt find this the case, the room was a good size. it fitted us and our suitcases with room to move about. The next time we stay at this hotel i'd like to see what a bigger room has to offer but in our opinion the room was a good size. We stayed in room 805 (superior queen) the only thing i could fault with this room was the view from the window which was just a brick wall. It meant we didnt get much day light coming in and werent to sure what kind of weather it was outside but you dont go to New York to stay in your hotel room so it really didnt matter to us that much. The bathroom was lovely and the molton brown toiletries a really nice touch. The room has a safe which is a must for us and a large closet with iron and ironing board it also has a Dvd player and the hotel offers complementary dvds.

We didnt get a chance to speak to the Concierge much as he was always busy with other guests but we did ask what bar would be best to go watch the Scotland vs Usa football match and he directed us to a great bar. All of the staff in the iroquois were so friendly and helpful and coming in to a nightly turn down service after a long day sightseeing was so nice.

We will without doubt be staying at The Iroquois again!!!

p.s the libary has free internet :)

    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *
    *

See all photos
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
See 6 more reviews by Gary T for New York City
Ask Gary T about The Iroquois
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.
Iroquois Hotel, Manager at The Iroquois, responded to this review
June 6, 2012
I'm so pleased to hear that you and your fianc enjoyed our accommodations while you were in New York. We would be more than happy to show you our other room options on a future stay as we do have larger room types that are situated on different sides of the building such as 44th Street or facing the Chrysler Building. We hope to see you again soon!

Warm Regards,

Kelli Phillips
Assistant Front Office Manager

Gayenell
Washington DC
2 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
1 helpful vote 1 helpful vote
'nice, small, expensive bar'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 30, 2012

My room was very comfortable. The room was clean. It was not large, but had everything I needed. Only one elevator was working so it was nice being on the 2nd floor - although there was no view. The fire alarm in the room kept going off. First in the AM - then again in the PM. Hotel mgt was nice and left chocolate covered strawberries in the room as an apology. One other downside - I charged drinks to the room - they were $20/each. They were basic martini's - fair warning. I had a lemon drop martini. I forget what the other person had. I believe this is overpriced - even for NYC. The location was terrific - close to Times Square, 6th Avenue and most of the mid town tourist sites. It was safe and comfortable - the people at the desk were very nice - so overall - nice.
Less

'Nice hotel and good location'

This is a very nice smaller hotel and is within walking distance to Times Square, Rockefeller Center and theatres etc. Our room was small but adequate. We would definately stay here again.

'Nice hotel in Manhattan'
4 of 5 stars Reviewed May 26, 2012

This is a nice boutique hotel in Manhattan within easy walk of most Midtown destinations such as 42nd Street, Grand Central and Times Square.
The hotel room was surprisingly spacious, clean and confortable. Check in / check out was efficient and hastle free, plus they have free Wifi. Complimentary coffee served in the lobby during the mornings, and the neighbouring bar was smart and comfortable. Breakfast is pricey but a short walk out of the hotel to the right, there is a convenient diner offering an array of breakfast favourites at reasonable prices.

Carlitoways

Reviewer
5 reviews 5 reviews
Reviews in 2 cities Reviews in 2 cities
2 helpful votes 2 helpful votes
'Location Is The Connection'
3 of 5 stars Reviewed May 25, 2012

The location is good and central to various New York hot spots (Time Square, Central Park &Radio City). Ideal hotel for walking to all the mentioned locations with no need to a Taxi (burn those calories). We reserved a suite which was ideal for the four of us. The hotel has only one elevator in operation because the other is under refurbishment and during the morning you may have to take the stairs. we were located on the fifth floor and the A/C in the room is not best in class, That is to say, if you like sleeping in a cold room 70 degree or below after a hot not - do not count on it. The A/c in the room may not have the power to do so, Overall good location and the room was nice but nothing to write back home about,
Less

My friends and I stayed in 2 connecting rooms at the New York Palace in May, 2012. I was worried about bedbugs before choosing a hotel in NYC since I know they are a problem in the city. Before booking I called the hotel and asked to speak to a manager. I asked if they have had any bed bug... More
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
SGGill
Chatham, New York
1 review
'Nice hotel but we had Bedbugs!'
2 of 5 stars Reviewed June 6, 2012 NEW
1
person found this review helpful

My friends and I stayed in 2 connecting rooms at the New York Palace in May, 2012. I was worried about bedbugs before choosing a hotel in NYC since I know they are a problem in the city. Before booking I called the hotel and asked to speak to a manager. I asked if they have had any bed bug issues in their hotel. I was told they did not have any "confirmed cases". The hotel is in a great location so my friends and I decided to stay there, even though I was still wary of the bedbug issue. On the evening of our second night there, we saw a bug crawling on the wall. We happened to have a baggie so we put the bug in the baggie, and looked up a photo of bedbugs on our IPAD. It looked exactly like the photos of a bedbug. We called downstairs and someone came up and took the bug to be sent away for "confirmation". When I asked what else it could be they said a few other bug names, which I then looked up and they were all species of bedbugs. My friend and I were moved into another room in the Towers for the night. My other 2 friends in the adjoining room stayed since they had an early departure. My friends left early the next morning but discovered later in the day several bites which they believe to be bedbug bites. One of them tends to hug a pillow when sleeping and she got bites on her chest. I was moved to a very nice room in the Towers and we didn't have any other problems there.
The hotel is in a great location and has some nice features like an outdoor bar area ( crazy expensive but wonderful on a sunny evening). The rooms were nice. We did not see any bedbugs in the Towers, which is where I would suggest anyone stay who would like to stay at the New York Palace. The hotel never did "confirm" our room had bedbugs, even though we had the actual bedbug to prove it.
Less
Was this review helpful? Yes
Problem with this review?
Ask SGGill about The New York Palace Hotel
This review is the subjective opinion of a TripAdvisor member and not of TripAdvisor LLC.

j_rich2011
Exeter, United Kingdom
Senior Reviewer
8 reviews 8 reviews
Reviews in 7 cities Reviews in 7 cities
26 helpful votes 26 helpful votes
'Great location and the club level experience was AWESOME!'
5 of 5 stars Reviewed June 3, 2012 NEW

We got a free upgrade to a corner one bedroom suite. The room was a huge size and well equipped with an incredible bathroom. Loved the big dining table and the wifi was fast and efficient. However, there was building work going on nearby so it was very NOISY and we were woken up. Fortunately, the hotel gave us an extended late check-out as compensation for the disturbance.

Check-in was flawless. The lounge has iMacs to use which is great for airline check-in and printing boarding passes. The food in the lounge was amazing - wonderful breakfast and great afternoon snacks. Highly recommended. Great views over the Cathedral and towards Central Park. Loved the exclusivity of the Tower Club with its key entry system and separate elevators.

Location is ideal for Fifth Avenue and the main attractions. Bell services were extremely nice and helpful. Recommend this hotel!
Less
